Researchers conducted a study to investigate how genetic variations in the 3' end of genes, specifically polyadenylation, impact gene expression in human lymphoblast cells from distinct individuals. They found that transcript positions do not randomly fall in untranslated regions, but rather preferentially flank 3' regulatory elements, including microRNA sites. The usage of transcript forms and motifs varied across individuals, and polymorphisms in polyaden signals and 3 motifs were significant predictors of gene expression levels. Single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyaden variants on steady-state expression and validated regulatory function of 3 cis elements. The study focused on immune regulator IRF, establishing the effect of natural variation in RNA 3- processing on response to antigen stimulation. The results highlight the importance of mechanisms in genetics of 3- variation: usage of distinct 3- signals and effects of 3 elements determining transcript fate. The study suggests integrating 3 positions with 3 motifs will be a tool in interpreting human variation. The relationship between sequence and expression did not manifest for microRNA sites. The findings emphasize relevance of 3 motifs as predictors of variation when integrated with transcript forms.
Researchers studied the CD8 T cell response in animals vaccinated with the live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) vaccine SIVne, which is highly effective against wild-type lentiviral challenge. They used deep sequencing and CD8 cell epitope mapping to identify regions of immune pressure and viral escape, and the effect of escape on the CD8 cell response. The initial CD8 response in the acute phase of SIVne infection targeted variable epitopes, followed by widespread viral escape and evolution. However, escape expanded the CD8 repertoire to target conserved epitopes, defined anropic specificity, and generated new responses to escaped variants during vaccination. These results correlated with SIVne-induced protection and increased anropic specificity and response depth. The study found rapid escape of variable epitopes and maintenance of CD8 responses to conserved epitopes in SIVne infection, as well as new CD8 responses to escaped variants during chronic infection. Escaped CD8 responses were maintained as central memory CD8 cells, contributing to increased breadth of the CD response at 20 weeks post-vaccination. Epitope escape and new CD responses to variants deepened the CD repertoire. High-throughput sequencing quantified SIVne variants and CD8 responses in vaccinated animals, including those with undetectable viral loads. Fine-mapped CD8 responses at the epitope level at 5 and 20 weeks postacc. Longitudinal study of vaccinated animals showed concurrent evolution of virus and CD8 specificity, resulting in increased anropic CD repertoire, breadth, rearranged immunodinance, and depth.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-1 (IL-1) in the immune response to Candida albicans infections in the oral mucosa. They used a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) and found that IL-1 receptor (IL-R) signaling is critical for controlling the onset of infection through its impact on neutrophils. IL-1 regulates the recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and mobilization of newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow. IL-1 deficient mice displayed impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in circulation in response to C. albicans. Endothelial cells were identified as the primary source of G-CS during OPC, responding to IL-α released from keratinocytes in infected tissue. A link between IL-1 and granulopoies was established in vitro using a murine-derived kerocyte line and endothelial cell line. Two mechanisms coordinating neutil response in oral mucosa were identified, preventing fungal growth and dissemination, protecting the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filari (GPE) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 570 million individuals via mass administration of anti-filar drugs (albendazole, iverectin, diethylbamazine) in at-risk areas for 4-6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were calculated by quantifying the number of clinical manifestations averted and associated with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and healthcare for affected individuals. Reviewing multiple sources, including the World Health Organization, International Fund, and Labour, an estimated $21.8 billion in economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GPE. This includes $2.3 billion from protection of nearly 3 million and individuals from acquiring lymphatic filari as a result of being born in areas of transmission. Additionally, 28 million infected benefit from GLF halting disease progression, resulting in $19.5 billion economic benefit. Health systems in endemic countries save $2.2 billion from reduced services associated with LF morbidity. The Programme offers significant economic benefits, with favorable implementation largely due to donated drugs from the pharmaceutical industry, showing a high return on investment.
Researchers created a mouse model of Gaucher disease, a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene, to study how these mutations lead to Parkinson's disease (PD). The mice, called GBA-/-medaka, lacked the enzyme glucerebrosidase (GCase) activity, but surprisingly survived for months, allowing researchers to study the progression of the disease. The mice displayed symptoms similar to human Gaucher disease, including Gaucher cell infiltration in the brain, neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Detailed analysis revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-s) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disrupting α-syn did not improve lifespan, axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in G-aka. The study provides a new model for neuronopathic Gaucher disease and reveals mechanisms of α-s accumulation caused by G deficiency and minimal contribution of αyn to pathogenesis. Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal disease, caused by homozygous mutations in GBA, leading to decreased enzymatic activity and accumulation of glucerebrosides and glucosylphosphingos. The disease is divided into three subtypes: non-neuronopathic, acute, and subacute. Long-term survival of the mice allowed observation of pathological progression, revealing G deficiency causes lysosomal dysfunction and α-s accumulation in axonal swellings. Axonal transport of αyn may play a role in G mutations leading to PD and be a therapeutic target. Patients with type 1 Gaucher have increased risk of PD, carrying G mutations show intraneural accumulation α-s, Lewy bodies and Lew neurites, hallmarks of sporadic PD. Studies indicate association between G mutations and α-s accumulation. The phenotypes in G-aka brains were caused by G mutation. α-s overexpression causes neurotoxicity, neuroflamm observed in PD brains, promoting progression.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Listeria monocytogen interacts with the immune system, specifically how it evades the phagosome and enters the cell cytos to induce a strong CD8 T cell-mediated immunity. They found that the immune response to phag-confined L monocogen is not due to inefficient antigen presentation, but direct suppression of the adaptive response. This suppression affects not only phag-confined but also cytosolic L monocogen, and co-infection with both strains prevents acquired immunity and T cell expansion. Bacteria confined in phag suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines and led to MyD-dependent IL-10 production. Blocking IL-10 or MyD restored immunity. The study shows microbes in phag can impact innate and adaptive response by antagonizing inflammation and CD8 cell generation. 

The bacterium alters the inflammatory landscape and T cell potency, with IL-10 acting as a negative regulator in CD8 cells and positive in other cells. The results are significant for microbial pathogenesis and vaccinology, understanding how microbes interact with innate and adaptive systems is key to controlling pathogenic effects. The presence of Lm in phag impacts CD4 and CD8 responses to cytos Act-L and immunity. The innate response shapes the adaptive response, and ph-confined Lm alters cytokine response to cytos Act-L. Mice were infected with two L monocogen strains, Act-L escapes cytos and elicits long-lived CD8 immunity. In the absence MyD, ph-confined Lm limits cytos response. Results show the immune discriminates pathogens in subcell locations via MyD and IL-10, impacting adaptive response potency.
Researchers have identified six genetic variants in the SIX gene associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), a leading cause of blindness worldwide. A previous genome-wide study found a significant link between POAG and the SIX locus (rs10427, odds ratio=1.32, p=3.87×10-11). The SIX gene plays a role in eye development and has been linked to optic nerve morphology. The researchers sequenced the SIX coding and regulatory regions in 262 PO cases and 256 controls, finding six nonsynonymous variants, five rare and one common, AsnHis (rs12345), associated with PO (OR=1.27, p=4.2×10-10) in the NEIGH/GLUG datasets. These variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complement assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye and optic structure. Five variants, primarily in PO cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth, only in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX enhancer increased SIX expression and disrupted its regulation. The study found a feature in PO patients dependent on SIX genotype: those homozygous for the SIX risk allele (His) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than homozygous for the non-risk (As) allele. The results, combined with previous SIX work, suggest SIX variants disrupt retina development, reducing retinal ganglion cells, increasing glcoma vision loss.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch that controls the production of flagella and toxins in the human pathogen Clostridium difficile. This switch, called the "flagellar switch", is a 154 base pair sequence that can be flipped between two orientations. When in one orientation, the bacteria produce flagella and secrete toxins, while in the other orientation they do not. The orientation of the switch is reversible and occurs during growth in vitro. The researchers found that the flag switch affects the production of glucyl toxins, which are essential for diarrheal disease, and flagellar motility. They also found that the switch occurs post-transcription and requires a C difficile-specific factor to degrade early flagellar mRNA when in the OFF orientation. The tyrosine recomase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at cV, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions. Flagellar ON bacteria are motile and produce toxins, while OFF are aflagate and attenuated for toxin production. RecV mutants with the flag switch in ON are also motile and produce toxins, while those with the switch in OFF are aflag and attenuated. The flag switch affects transcription of toxin genes by σ, impacting glucyl toxins and cytotoxicity of C difficile. The researchers also found that RecV, which controls variation of cell wall protein cV, is responsible for inversion at flagellar in both directions.
Researchers studied the process of spore formation in the bacterium Clostridium difficile, an intestinal pathogen that forms spores as part of its life cycle. This process, called sporulation, involves the development of a highly resistant spore that allows the bacterium to survive harsh conditions. In the model bacterium Bacillus subtilis, two types of RNA polymerase sigma factors, σF and σE, control spore development in the forespore and mother cell, respectively. These factors are replaced by σ and σ at later stages. The researchers found that in Clostrid difficile, the main periods of activity of these factors are conserved, but activity of σ is independent of σ, σ is not dependent on σ, and σ does not require σ. They also found that σ is not necessary for spore formation. The results indicate reduced segregation between early and late sigma factors and reduced requirement for cell signaling pathways. The study supports the view that the spore network is conserved in evolution, with sigma factors regulating the pathway established 2.5 billion years ago in the Firmicutes phylum.
Researchers have developed a new framework to model the behavior of allosteric multisite proteins, which are proteins with multiple sites that can be phosphorylated or dephosphorylated, using a single variable. This simplification accurately replicates the steady-state behavior of more complex systems, such as the Monod-Wy-Change alloster model. The framework is useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems where multiple proteins interact simultaneously. It was applied to a newly discovered signaling pathway in yeast that monitors cell growth by measuring signals at the plasma membrane. The pathway's components form a hysteretic switch, with a signal proportional to growth size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-no response when the signal reaches a threshold indicating sufficient growth. 

The framework approximates the dynamics of multisite phosphorylation, which can be complex due to multiple sites' effects, using a single variable. It becomes more precise with more sites, with good estimates for four or more. The mechanism is a one-variable, quasi-stead state reduction of the Mon-WChange alloster system. Multisite phosphorylation is not fully understood, but can give ultrasensitive responses not possible in single-site systems. The framework can be extended to other types of multis modification, such as ligand binding, transcription regulation, methylation, acetylation, or ubiquination.
Researchers have used a "bottom-up" approach to study the quorum sensing (QS) system in E. coli, a mechanism that enables bacterial populations to communicate and gain a selective advantage. They focused on the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) QS system, examining the interplay between its components and regulation. By separating the network into sub-networks, they discovered a new negative feedback mechanism and revealed the importance of the Lsr regulator, previously masked by regulatory loops. A simple model was built to understand the interplay among substructures and their contributions to the overall network. This approach will help unravel complex QS architectures and direct emergent behaviors.

The AI-2 QS system consists of an auto-regulatory network with a double negative motif, providing a population response. The researchers studied network connectivity and signal propagation of AI-2, constructing mutant strains to represent the system as a complete network. Further analysis will shed light on regulatory pathways in bacterial metabolic networks and guide new phenotypes. A model was built incorporating the new element, capturing predictions and simulating the intact and sub-systems using the proposed architecture. The mechanistic basis for Lsr-mediated "switch" of E. coli QS was revealed, buried in the native system but effective.

The AI-2 mechanism was taken apart, analyzing sub-systems in isolation, leading to speculation of new interactions within the network. A "bottom-up" approach isolating regulatory elements is effective for analyzing biological networks with positive and negative regulations. Studying modules allows constructing a hypothetical system and predicting new mechanisms.
A study was conducted in rural Gabon to investigate the effect of schistosomiasis, a soil-transmitted helminth (STH), on Plasmod falciparum infection in school-age children. The study found that schosias increased the risk of Plmod infection, especially when combined with Trichuris trichi or hookworm infection. The incidence of malaria was higher in schos-infected children compared to non-infected, with a significant delay in time to first malaria event in children aged 6-10 years. The study suggests that STH enhances risk for P falcum in schos-positive children and increases susceptibility to malaria in young children, but not older children. This is consistent with previous findings that schos increases malaria prevalence in infected children. However, conflicting results exist in literature on schos-malaria co-infection due to potential confounding factors. In areas where schos is endemic, its effect on malaria outcome is a concern. The study area is endemic for both infections, with up to 30% of children co-infected with P falcum and S haob parasites. The results suggest that schos and STH co-infections cumulatively impact malaria outcome in school children, and should be considered in malaria control programs.
Researchers investigated the role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during Leishmaniasis infection. IRF-5 is a transcription factor that induces pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF. The study found that IRF-5-mediated inflammation limits CD8 T cell expansion and induces HIF-1 in dendritic cells, impairing their function. HIF-1 induction in dendritic cells resulted in a higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8 T cells, reduced CD8 T expansion, and increased IL-12 expression by splenic dendritic cells. Mice with depleted of HIF-1 in dendritic cells had a lower parasite burden, suggesting H-1 induction is an immune evasive mechanism by Leish to establish infection. IR-5 is involved in transcription of Type I IF genes and pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-12, TN, IL-23, and IL-6. IR-/- mice showed IR5 is essential for protective Th1 responses. CD8 depletion caused mild increase in parasite burden in Cre mice, while CD8 cells controlled growth in H-1 knockout mice, indicating H-1 induction limits protective CD8 responses. H-1 induction in dendritic represents an immune mechanism by Leish to establish chronic infection.
Researchers conducted a systematic review to identify factors associated with poor outcomes in patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Latin America. They analyzed 14 studies and found that jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 and over 40 years, neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections, and edema, and low hemoglobin concentration were linked to unfavorable outcomes. The strongest predictors were jaundice, thromocytopenia, and HIV coinfection. The review highlights the need for externally validated prognostic models to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes. VL is a neglected disease with scarce effective treatments and high mortality rates. The Brazilian Ministry of Health recommends platelet transfusion for patients with low platelet counts. Leishmania-HIV coinfection increased risk of poor prognosis in all studies. Only 14 of 294 studies met inclusion criteria, all from Brazil, with 10 focusing on death and 3 on clinical evolution. Undernutrition is not a risk factor for severity, but rather a consequence of VL syndrome.
In Algeria, the treatment of visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis (VL and CL) has been based on antimonial drugs for a long time. It is suspected that high selective pressure from these drugs may favor the emergence of resistant parasites. Although treatment failure is reported during antimonial therapy for both VL and CL, resistance has never been investigated in Algeria. To determine the level of antimonial susceptibility of Leishmania in Algeria is important for public health development. Within 30 years of epidemiology of VL and CL knowledge, Leish isolates were sampled to determine susceptibility to antimonial. A total of 106 isolates, including 88 from 1976-2013 in humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines, and 18 from dogs in France, were analyzed. All Algerian isolates were from endemic areas. IC50 of antimonial tartrate (Sbivalent) and stibogluconate (pentavalent) were determined in promastigotes and amastigotes, respectively. Epidemiological cutoff allowed differentiation between Leish species causing VL or CL susceptible (S) or insusceptible (S) to trivalent antimony. IC50 values were 23.83μg/mL and 15.91μg for VL and CL, respectively. A trend of increasing susceptibility in VL isolates during 30 years was reported. In contrast, an increase in S-phenotypes in CL isolates was observed during same period. Emergence of S-phenotypes correlates with L.lick (L.tropica) isolates causing CL that emerged in Algeria last decade. Results provide insight into spatiotemporal Leish antimony in Algeria, highlighting need for effective methodology to detect emergence and prevent dissemination of resistant strains.
Researchers have investigated the link between acute gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition of unknown etiology. They found that exposure to foodborne pathogens causing gastroenteritis increases the risk of CD in the post-infect period, but the underlying mechanism is unclear. Two models were developed to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimium or Citrobacterium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia (AIE), a pathion linked to CD. Results show that disease in the post-infect period after gastroenter is driven by the tissue expansion of the AIE pathion, with increased immunology defects, barrier, and delays in mucosal restitution following path clearance. These features require AIE resistance to host peptides and amin inflammatory response to enteric path. Individuals colonized by AIE at the time of infectious gastroenter may be at risk for CD onset. AIE is identified as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of interventions following infectious gastroitis in at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two gametic cells, the egg and central cell, surrounded by five accessory cells, all of which are vital for fertilization. However, the mechanisms controlling the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate are unknown. Researchers isolated the lach (lis) mutant, which forms supernumerary egg cells, indicating LIS is involved in a mechanism preventing accessory cells from adopting gametic fate. LIS is expressed in gametic cells and is homologous to yeast splicing factor PR4, suggesting components of the splice apparatus participate in cell decisions. The lis mutant reveals two levels of cell regulation: between gametic and accessory cells, and between egg and central cells. The initiation of cell-specific genes indicates Arabid distinct fates are manifested after cellularization. 

The female gamophyte of Arabidopsis originates from a haploid spore through three nuclear divisions, resulting in a syncytium of eight nuclei that cellularizes into four cell types. In lis-1 mutant synergids differentiate egg attributes at expense of syner cell, with syner marker ectopically expressed. This shows not all aspects of accessory and gametic fate are exclusive. In lis-1 mutant, accessory cells become gametic over time, with morphological features distinguishing lis-1 from wild-type becoming more pronounced. LIS is mapped to At2g00, a protein with WD repeats.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in a rural Ethiopian highland community to understand the barriers to wearing shoes, which is crucial for preventing Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs). They used the PRECE-PRO model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, and educational factors influencing shoe-wearing. The study gathered information from 242 respondents through focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and case studies. Results showed that shoe-wearing norms are changing, with going barefoot seen as shameful, and shoes confer dignity and protection against injury and cold. However, practical and social barriers prevented the desire to wear from being translated into practice. Limited resources meant people could not purchase more than one pair of shoes, ensuring longevity or afford quality shoes. As a result, shoes were preserved for special occasions and not provided for children until a certain age. Some barriers, such as fit and fear of labeling, may be specific to certain diseases, but underlying poverty-related barriers, like price, unsuitability, and low perception, are relevant to multiple NTDs. Established health behavior models identified barriers to shoe-wearing amenable to intervention, benefiting NTD prevention through shoe distribution.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of infected sympathetic neurons. Without Us, mutants are defective in anterograde transmission in vivo. Researchers investigated how Us promotes axonal sorting of many viral proteins. They found that glyroteins B, C, D, and E are associated with lipid microdomains on infected cells and directed into ax in Us-dependent manner. This study determined Us is associated with lipid rafts, critical for Us-mediated sorting viral proteins. Non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells were used, a rathepromocytoma line acquiring sympathetic characteristics in presence nerve growth factor (NG). Us is highly in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing Us affinity for rafts inhibited antograde transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. Association Us with rafts is key for targeting proteins axons, consequence spread PR from pre-synaptic to postynaptic neurons mammalian nervous system.
Researchers studied the phenomenon of genetic heterogeneity in yeast cells, where genetically identical cells exhibit different growth rates and stress tolerance under constant conditions. They found that the cyclic AMP (cAMP) regulated transcription factors Msn and M4 are responsible for this heterogeneity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a type of yeast. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, and a reporter of the pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. The paralogs M2 and M4 have different roles in heterogeneity, with M2 required for growth and M4 for expression of T1, a subunit of trehalose synth that contributes to stress tolerance. Perturbing the pathway or culturing cells with cAMP analog or PK inhibitor impacts survival under heat stress. Increasing cAMP reduces slower subpopulation and increases susceptibility, while PK inhibition slows growth and decreases susceptibility. Loss of M2 reduces but not eliminates correlation between growth and stress, suggesting M2's role in heterogeneity but residual benefit of slow growth. The study sheds light on genetic control of heterogeneity and suggests a means to defeat pathogens or tumor cells by making them susceptible to treatment.
Researchers studied the genetic diversity of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) during its rapid spread from Asia to the Americas in 2013. They analyzed viral samples from infected individuals in Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands in the center of the outbreak, using deep-sequencing and bioinformatics. They found changes in the consensus sequence and minority variants at different levels in the population. The diversity was reduced after single passages in cell lines. An infectious clone was constructed from the outbreak and a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was identified, not found in nature, leading to increased replication in insect cells. An intrahostasis analysis was performed on the new CHV outbreak in the Caribbean, identifying variants in individuals and a new 3'UTR, suggesting CHV evolved quickly in the new population. The study highlights the need for continued viral surveillance as the epidemic evolves to understand CHV's potential.
Researchers have identified a previously unannotated gene called UOR that plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and tumor formation through the mTOR signaling pathway. They found that reducing UOR function in cultured neurons and cancer cells promotes neurite growth and cell growth, while overexpressing UOR suppresses colony formation in cancer cells. Mechanistic studies revealed that UOR stabilizes a component of the mTOR complex, DEOR, to inhibit m signaling. In zebraf models, disrupting UOR gene increased mTOR activity and worsened HRAS-induced tumor formation. UOR depletion also promoted tumor growth and m signaling in xenograft mice. The study shows UOR regulates cell growth and tumor via m signaling. UOR is a vertebrate-specific gene with no known function, despite extensive sequence searches. Reducing UOR levels in neurons and cancer cells promotes growth, while overexpressing U suppresses colony formation. UOR interacts with DEOR and m complexes to inhibit m signaling. Disrupting U gene in zraf increased m activity and worsened HRAS-induced tumor. U depletion promoted growth and m signaling in xenograft mice. These findings demonstrate UOR regulates growth and tumor via m signaling.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein interactions in the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypanosomiasis, a fatal disease in humans and nagana in cattle. The parasite's biology and pathogenesis are not well understood due to the unknown functions of most of its proteins. By analyzing protein interactions, they identified 128 high-confidence complexes involving 716 proteins, including 635 with no known functions. The map correlates with known pathways and proteins across the parasite's life cycle and provides potential functions for many uncharacterized proteins. They validated several novel proteins involved in RNA editing, including a candidate in post-transcriptional regulation. The study provides an unprecedented view of the parasite's protein complex and serves as a resource for further characterization of tryosid proteins. This is the largest proteomics interaction map of tryosid parasites to date, useful for formulating new hypotheses and experimental leads.
Researchers studied lymph nodes (LNs) in macaques infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) to understand how the bacteria persist in these organs. LNs are common sites of extrapulmonary tb infection and thoracic LNs are frequently infected in humans, but the dynamics of tb infection in LNs and their function are not well understood. The study analyzed thoracic LNs from tb-infected cynolgus andhes macques using PET scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. They found that LNs have different trajectories of increasing or decreasing activity over time, even in the same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to tb than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. tb grows to same level in cynolg and rhes mac LNs, but cynolg macques control tb later post-infection while rhes do not. LNs are poor at killing tb, even with treatment, due to lack of cell-rich structures, disrupting LN structure, introducing macrophages that serve as niches for tb, and destroying vasculature. The study shows L are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation but also persistence of significant numbers of tbilli.
Researchers have identified 47 new species of microsporidia, a type of fungus that infects animals, and studied their interactions with the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans and other related nematodes. Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites, meaning they live inside their hosts, and are poorly understood. Caenorhabdis elegans has been used as a model to study microspor, with the identification of its natural pathogen Noc paris. However, it was unclear how widespread and diverse microspor infections are in Caenorhabdis and other nematodes in the wild. The study found Noc paris to be the most common microspor infecting Caenor in the wild, and described six new species in the Noc genus. Phylogenetic analysis identified two subclades distinct from Noc, named Entersect and Ptospora. Unlike Noc, these belong to the clade of microidia that includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and infect intestinal cells, except Ptos that replicates in the epidermis of Caenorhost. At the cellular level, infected spores of Entersect show apical distribution and exit via budding, unlike Noc that exit via exocytosis. Host specificity is broad for some microidia, narrow for others, with some infecting Osche but not its sister Os, and vice versa. Nauseli fails to induce Caenor transcription of genes induced by Noc species, suggesting mechanisms to prevent host response.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of protein-coupled receptors, play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer and HIV infection. Studies have shown that homo and heterodimers of chemokine receptors CXCR, CCR, and C2 modulate receptor function, and cholesterol affects chemine activity. However, structural information on homo and heterodimers of chemine receptors and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study reports homo and heterod configurations of chemine receptors CXCR, C, and C at atomic detail from molecular simulations. Homodimer patterns were similar for closely related chemine receptors, but differed between CXCR. Cholesterol modulated homod interfaces in subtype-specific manner. Chemine heterod display distinct dimer patterns CX4/5 and CX/2. Associations between CX and C reveal increased cholesterol sensitivity compared CX/ heterodimer patterns. This work provides a comprehensive overview of interaction between chemine receptors and how heterodization and interaction with environment diversifies function of related GPC.
Systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, has been known to present with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting. However, a subclinical form has been identified with one or two of these symptoms missing, replaced by lymphadenopathy and anemia. A new form, referred to as "atypical", has been discovered in patients with suspected immune deficiency. These patients were referred to a specialized laboratory for immune function tests, including microscopic examinations and biopsies. 19.4% of 160 patients had normal profiles but dysfunctional macrophages with Leish parasites. This revealed the presence of atypical systemic lemanias, presenting as a masquerading condition with non-functional immune system, predisposing to recurrent infections and various symptoms. This indicates systemic leishias has a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected and is more common than diagnosed. Among 31 patients, adults were found, showing systemic leishias is not limited to the pediatric group. The authors recommend considering atypical systemic leishias in patients with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Researchers have analyzed millions of genetic mutations and variations in the human genome to identify potential causes of diseases, reactions to drugs, and predispositions to infections and age-related conditions such as brain and cardiovascular impairments. However, predicting the consequences of a genetic variant is a complex task. A study found that conserved amino acids are useful for identifying likely variants with consequences. This study explored the potential of variants at homologous positions in paralog proteins to identify polymorphisms with consequences. A dataset of disease-causing variants from OMIM and HGMD was used to identify and characterize pairs of variants at homolog positions. Results show locations of variants are correlated in paralog proteins. If one member of a variant pair is disease-causing, the other is likely to be disease-causing. This information can be used to identify disease variants, extend procedures, and provide candidates for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

A dataset identified pairs of variations at homolog positions in human genes. Variants co-occur at amino pairs more frequently than expected, suggesting similar constraints result in coordinated distributions of disease and non-disease variants. Data suggest paralog genes and variantairs for hypothesis and clinical research. Extending to paral genes not associated with disease can identify new candidates and uncharacterized variants. A collection of disease-causing from OMIM and HG was mapped to genes and sequences. This suggests algorithms miss instances based on sequence conservation. Paralog human might provide in silico characterization complementary to SIFT and PolyPhen.

Variants in paralog proteins tend to pair. Alignments provide a resource for genomics.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of the malaria parasite Plasium falciparum in people with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua New Guinea. They found that parasites causing severe malaria had changes in their gene expression, including a decrease in the production of proteins on their surface that are targeted by the immune system. These proteins, called PfEMP, are important for the parasite's survival. The study used RNA sequencing to analyze 44 parasite samples and found that those causing severe malaria had reduced glycolysis, a process that provides energy, and altered gene regulation through histone methylation. They also had lower expression of PfEMP and multiple chaperone proteins. The study confirmed previous findings that certain PfEMP sequences are associated with severe disease and identified new associations between PfEMP domains and disease severity. These findings can help develop vaccines for severe malaria and understand how the parasite adapts to the host environment in severe malaria. 

The study differed from previous research that found increased expression of genes for PfEMP in severe malaria. Instead, 17 genes were downregulated, including skeleton protein 1, which is involved in PfEMP expression. Patients with severe malaria had lower levels of antibodies to PfEMP and recognized fewer Pf than those with uncomplicated malaria. Parasites causing severe malaria also downregulated genes involved in PfEMP expression. Antigens encountered early in life are recognized by immune children's sera more than those causing uncomplicated disease. Expression of conserved PfEMP by severe parasites explains why immunity to severe is acquired faster than uncomplicated. Some PfEMP domains bind host receptors and are expressed in severe have been identified.
Researchers used an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) to rhesus monkeys to prevent HIV-1 infection. The goal was to achieve long-term delivery of potent-neutralizing antibodies. High levels of the delivered mAb were achieved, up to 270 micrograms per milliliter. However, host responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration that could be achieved. This resulted in a wide range of delivered mAb concentrations, from 1-270 micrograms per millil. Despite the absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the virus, six monkeys in the AAV-delivered IgG1Ab group showed protective effects against SIV239 challenge. These effects included lowering viral load peak, lowering viral set point, and delay in time to peak load from exposure. All were statistically significant. The monkey with highest delivered m completely resisted six SIV239 challenges, including a final dose of 10 infectious units. The study demonstrates the potential of this approach for HIV-1 prevention. However, antibody responses need to be understood to realize the promise.
Researchers have challenged the long-held assumption that protein molecules respond linearly to thermal or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment. They studied two motor proteins, myosin and kinesin K1A, using a coarse-grained elastic network approximation, and found that linearity is deficient for lig-induced conformation motions and even thermal fluctuations. The nonlinearity is particularly pronounced in K1, where normal mode description fails to describe mechanochemical motions. This indicates that assumptions in protein dynamics theory may need reconsideration. Conformation relaxation processes associated with ligand binding and hydrolysis in myos and K1 were analyzed, revealing nonlinearity in both molecules. While myos conformation relaxation can be characterized by normal modes, K1 description breaks down. However, ordered and robust mechchemical motions are present in both proteins, but cannot be described by linear response. Large conformation changes due to lig binding are often considered in linear theory and normal approximation, despite magnitude. Strong overlaps between lig-induced conformation and atomic displacements in slow modes were found in myos, but absent in K1. Numerical investigations of elastic motions in my and K1 revealed nonlinearity in both. In K1, nonlinear effects dominate mechchemical motions, differing from normal predictions. Despite nonline, well-defined conformation paths against perturbations were found in both proteins.
Researchers have investigated the interaction between different endocytic pathways, specifically clathrin-independent endocytosis, and the role of caveolins and caveolins in regulating this process. They found that specific caveolar proteins, cavin-1 and cavin-3, but not cavin-2 or cavin-4, act as negative regulators of the clath-independent/GPIAP enriched endosomal (CL/GEE) endytic pathway, independent of cave formation. Caveolin-1 and cavin also inhibit the CL/GC pathway upon over-expression. Expression of caveolar leads to a reduction in formation of early CL/GEE carriers, detected by electron microscopy. The CL/GC pathway is upregulated in cells lacking cavin-1/cavin or reduced cavin-3. Inhibition by caveol can be mimicked by isolated caveolin scaffolding and associated with perturbed lipid diffusion, revealed by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. In absence of cavin and caveol, cavin is endocyted through the CLC pathway, but loses polarization and sorting with consequences for membrane dynamics and endytic in migrating cells and muscle tissue. Non-cave cavin-1 acts as modulator of key regulator CL/GC, C42. This study provides new insights into regulation of non-cave clath-independent endocyt by caveolar proteins, illustrating multiple levels of crosstalk between pathways.
Researchers have identified a subset of Receiver (REC) domains in bacteria and archaea that lack the conserved aspartate (Asp) residue, which is typically phosphorylated by a histidine kinase to propagate a signaling response. This subset, called Aspart-Less Receiver (AL) domains, is surprisingly common, making up about 4% of all REC domains, and is often associated with rare effector outputs. Analysis of AL structures and biochemical data suggests AL domains have reorganized their active sites to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate signals other than phosphorylation, while retaining post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimer interface. This defines AL as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into activation mechanisms between AL and REC domains. The most common AL substitutions at the conserved phospho-As site are Ser, Thr, and Tyr, which are known to be phosphorylated by bacterial kinases. Some AL domains have diversified to bind small molecules, such as antibiotics, and Ser phosphorylation through eukary-like kinases and PP phosphatases, regulating cell envelope functions and virulence in microbes. A dataset of 74,816 REC-containing proteins, 2,976 lacked or had substitutions at the conserved position, indicating up to 4% of domains do not have this residue. The AL sequences comprise about 4% of all domains in bacteria, making them the Aspart-L Receiver (AL) domain subclass of atypical RECs.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes virus (OV) that targets cancer cells with a specific receptor called HER2, which is overexpressed in many cancers. This virus, called R115, is fully virulent, meaning it can replicate in cancer cells but not in healthy cells, and is armed with IL-12, a protein that stimulates the immune system. The study tested R115 in immunocompet mice with HER2-expressing tumors and found it inhibited tumor growth, with some mice surviving long-term and protected from a second tumor. Analysis showed R115 unleashed an immunosuppressive tumor environment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines and increasing certain immune cells. The response was durable, breaking tolerance to HER and tumor cells, indicating a systemic immunotherapeutic effect.
Researchers investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. They found that CD4 cells induced by the Adenovirus 5 (Ad) vector were highly susceptible to HIV, while those induced by the ALVAC (canarypox) vector were less susceptible. This difference was associated with reduced expression of HIV entry receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on ALV-specific CD4 cells. Phenotypic analysis showed ALV-specific CD4 cells had a Th1 phenotype, producing high levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (M-β) but little IL-17. In contrast, ALAC and Ad vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 and CD4 T-cell proliferative responses, with ALAC preferentially inducing CD8-cell proliferation. Depletion of ALAC CD8 cells led to increased HIV infection of AL-specific CD4 cells, suggesting a protective role of ALAC CD8 cells. The study highlights the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination.
Researchers studied the evolution of X chromosome inactivation, a process where one X chromosome is silenced in female somatic cells, in mammals. They found that the choice of which X to silence varies among species, ranging from paternal X-inherited inactivation (PX), where females are haploid for maternal alleles, to random X-inactivation (RX), where maternal and paternal alleles are equally expressed. The study analyzed how dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence X inactivation evolution. Results show that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential can select a broad range of inactivation strategies, including unequal rates between maternal and paternal X chromosomes. RX is favored over PX when alleles are recessive to female fitness, and criteria for RX evolution is restrictive when variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolution from PX to RX increases female fitness at the expense of male fitness. The study provides a framework for predicting chromosome expression of X-linked genes and leads to predictions for future studies of allele variation.

 Species properties and genetic variation predict patterns of selection for X inactivation. Sexual and sex-based mutation rates vary, influencing transmission of deleterious alleles between maternal and paternal X. Selection favors inactivation of the chromosome with more deleterious alleles. An analysis tested evolutionary stability of X strategies. Sex-differential selection, where fitness differs between males and females, influences large fractions of genomes, affecting X diversification. Stronger selection against males decreases paternal X deleterious alleles. Sex-differential might favor biased inactivation, predicting magnitude to evolve. Results suggest conditions for biased patterns are permissive.
Researchers investigated the antiviral potential of the host protein ZAP against three flaviviruses: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIK). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, but not DENV or ZIK, and depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3-5' exosome-mediated degradation. The zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and antiv activity against JEV. The 3'-UTR, especially the region with dumbbell structures and high content of dinucleotide, was mapped to bind Z and confer sensitivity to Z. The study identified JEV as the first Z-sensitive flavivirus, suggesting Z may act as an intrinsic antiv factor through RNA binding against J infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a significant pathogen that causes severe disease in humans and animals, particularly in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Researchers studied the immune response to wild-type and vaccine strains of RVV in mice to understand its pathogenesis. Mice infected with a live-attenuated vaccine strain survived with minimal disease and cytokine response, while wild-type infection was lethal, causing lymphocyte and platelet depletion and strong cytokine response. The virus was found to be hepatotropic, with liver damage and histological data supporting this. However, a pro-inflammatory response was not seen in the liver, but rather a chemokine response indicating neutrophil infiltration. In the brain, a chemok and cytokine response was evident with little pathology. The study suggests RVV pathogenesis in mice is liver failure due to necrosis and hepatitis, with long-term disease being neurologic, supported by human and BAL/c mouse observations.
Chemotherapy resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a significant challenge for improving patient survival. Researchers investigated the mechanisms of taxane resistance in TNBC and found that C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20) is elevated during tax-containing chemotherapy in patients with no pathological complete response. C20 promotes self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCS) through protein kinase Cζ (PKζ) or 38 mitogen-activated protein (MAP) mediated p65 nuclear factor B (NF-κ) pathway, increasing taxane resistance of SCS. C20 also promotes NFκ activation ATP-binding subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug 1 (DR) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxane. Results suggest chemotherapy-induced C20 mediated resistance via upregulation of AB1. NF-κ activation C20, forming positive feedback loop between NFκ and C20, providing impetus for resistance in cancer cells. C20 can be a predictive marker for taxane response, and blocking C or its pathway may reverse tax resistance in breast cancer. Studies showed tax-induced C20 promoted self-renew of S through activation pNF, mediated by PKζ and MAP activity. A novel strategy to reverse tax resistance in breast cancer is combining tax treatment with adjuvant pharmacological inhibition AB1, improving chemotherapeutic efficacy. Results demonstrated C20 promoted resistance S through positive loop mediated PK/38NF. Tax-induced C20 activated NF through PKζ or38 and promoted expression of AB, leading to resistance breast cancer cells. Increased C20 by tax depended on NF activity, suggesting activated NF regulates C level in feedback to enhance effect on resistance.
Toxoplas gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, infects virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Its ability to infect and manipulate host cells depends on transporting "GRA" proteins from secretory organelles called dense granules into host cells, where they reside. GRA proteins have diverse roles in Toxopla's lifecycle, including hijacking host cell functions like cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRA, like GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into parasitoph vacuole (PV) where Toop replicates and transported across PV membrane (PVM) into host, but translocation process and machinery are unclear. A previous study showed TMY1, cleaved by TASP into fragments, localizes PVM and is essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional proteins for effector transport, Toopla mutants defective in cyc-regulation were screened for ability export GRA and GRA to host nucleus. A novel MY2 and MY3 play crucial role in translocation subset GRAs into host. MY2 and MY3 are secreted PV and co-localize with PVM and MY1. Consistent with transmembrane domains, all are membrane-associated, MY3 but MY stably with MY1, N-terminal and C-terminal disulf-linked. Further, intrinsically disordered effectors to structured DH domain blocks transport, consistent translo model effector.
Researchers studied how the papillomavirus (PV) replicates its DNA in host cells. PV has a mini-chromosome-like genome and initiates replication by binding the E2 protein to the origin recognition complex (ORC) and recruiting the E1 helicase. The study found that PV and bovine PV-1 E proteins bind to OR2, but OR2 is not present at the viral origin. Depleting OR2 increased PV replication in a transient model and maintained viral episomes, but not in cells with integrated genomes. E and E increased at the origin after OR2 silencing. This suggests OR2 suppresses E2 function, not activates it. Over-expressing E2 decreased OR2 at mammalian origins, implying E restricts pre-OR assembly that competes with host replication complexes for viral amplification. OR2 with E restricts replication in the maintenance phase and elevated E levels subvert OR loading and synthesis at cellular origins.
A study was conducted in the urban and peri-urban area of Dush, Tajikistan to investigate the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk. Bruc DNA was detected in 10.3% of 564 milk samples by IS-based real-time PCR, which is concerning due to common consumption of unpasteurified dairy products in the region. Bruc DNA was found in all seropositive cows, but 8.3% of seronegative cows also showed presence of Bruc DNA. Sequence analysis of the rB gene suggests one cow was infected with B. abortus and another was likely infected with B. melensis. Discrepancies between serology and real PCR results highlight the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect seroneg individuals in Bruc surveillance and eradication programs. Vaccination of cattle with S19 and small ruminants Rev1 may be needed to control Bruc infections, but further research on Brella isolation is required to understand Brella spp in the region.
Researchers studied the role of histone H3 lysine methylation in maintaining chromosome stability in the fungus Zoseptoria trici, which has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during meiosis and mitosis. They deleted genes responsible for methylation of H3 lysine 9 and 27, Kmt1 and K6, respectively, and analyzed the impact on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq showed changes in genome and chromatin structure and gene expression between mutant and wild-type strains. H3me3-deficient strains had dramatic chromatin reorganization, with H3me mostly localized in regions with H9 in wild-type. Many rearrangements and new chromosomes formed without H9, accompanied by transposable element activation. Loss of Hme increased stability of accessory chromosomes under normal conditions, without large gene changes. H9 is crucial for maintaining stability by preventing Hme in constitutive heterochromatin. Hme reduces overall stability, creating an unstable state for quasi-essential genome regions.
Researchers evaluated the cost-effectiveness of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies vaccination in low-income countries, where life-saving vaccines are often inaccessible and unaffordable to those most at risk. They found PEP to be an extremely cost-effective intervention, with a cost of less than $60 per death averted. Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) administration resulted in significant savings, mitigating vaccine shortages and reducing costs. To make P more accessible, financing mechanisms were proposed to subsidize costs for those in need and support existing rabies prevention programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility, leading to reduced rabies deaths and cost-effectiveness for healthcare providers.

The study examined costs of IM versus ID administration in different settings, demonstrating ID to be more cost-effective in averting rab cases and lives. Clinic capacity affects vial sharing and cost-effectiveness relative to IM. Rabies post-exposure vaccination is essential but out of reach for many, with shortages in developing countries and victims incurring costs and delays, leading to avoidable deaths. Changes in P costs could improve affordability, providing incentives without compromising budgets. Issues should be considered in P policy design to reduce rabies burden by increasing availability for the poor who bear the brunt in developing countries.

Incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICER) were calculated in terms of dollars per death averted: PEP/EffectivenessPE-EffectNoPEP, from the health provider's perspective, including direct costs.
Toxoplas, an obligate intracellular parasite, replicates within mammalian cells in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One mechanism for nutrient acquisition is attracting host organelles to the PV. This study examines the exploitation of lipid droplets (LD), fat storage organelles, by Toxoplas. Toxoplas replication is reduced in cells depleted of LD or impaired lipolysis or fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, host LD number and expression of LD-associated genes (ADRP, DG2) increase until parasite replication onset. PV are surrounded by host LD. Toxoplas accesses lipids in LD and incorporates them into its membranes and LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis in the cell, resulting in accumulation of neutral lipids in large LD inside parasite. Tooplas intercepts and internalizes LD within PV, some associated with Rab7, wrapped by intravacolar network (IV) membranes. Mutant parasites impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD in PV, suggesting IV's major contribution to LD processing and lipid release.
Researchers have identified a new compounds called chalcones that can inhibit the growth of Fasciola hepatica, a liver fluke parasite that causes disease in cattle and sheep. This parasite is considered an emerging zoonotic disease, meaning it can be transmitted from animals to humans. Current treatment is chemotherapy with the drug tricendazole, but resistance has been reported in several countries, making it urgent to find new treatments. The study searched a library of 40 flavonoids and found chalcones with phenyl and napht groups to be good inhibitors of Fasciola cystine proteases. One compound, C34, was found to bind to the enzyme FCL with an IC50 of 5.6 μM and is a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with key residues in the enzyme. In vitro, C34 reduced the parasite's ability to migrate through the gut and caused death within a week, but was not toxic to bovine cells. This is the first report of non-peptide inhibitors of Fasciola catheps and opens avenues for developing new treatments for fluke infections and other helminthic diseases.
Researchers investigated how the visual system transmits information about fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. They used in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells transmit signals to the retina and found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filtering. Individual cells transmit through terminals of varying size, but smaller terminals generate faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Smaller terminals transmit higher frequencies more effectively. Modeling calcium dynamics of ves release indicated that variations in presynaptic compartments contribute directly to these differences in response.

Measurements showed that presynaptic calcium is a strongly rectifying function of light intensity, increasing with graded contrast. Voltage-dependent calcium channels in terminals are responsible for non-linear transformation of the signal. Variations in presaptic signal impact output, with smaller terminals responding to step light with higher release rates, but resolution too low to detect modulations at frequencies >1 Hz. The next compartment in the pathway, synaptic terminals of bipolar cells, showed rectification in output due to increase in stimulus variance.

To quantify changes in synaptic gain, an "Adaptation Index" was used, calculated as ratio of initial to steady-state response. Assuming constant vesicles in terminals of different volume, the model predicted rate of release would depress more in smaller terminals. Whole-cell recordings from goldfish retina showed presaptic signals in large and small compartments while controlling the terminal.
Researchers have developed a new method to detect and analyze individual synapses in the brain using fluorescence microscopy images. Synapses are the tiny connections between brain cells that allow them to communicate with each other. Current methods to study synapses have limitations: fluorescence microscopy is fast and cheap but hard to distinguish between synapses and non-synaptic signals, while electron microscopy is accurate but slow and expensive. The new method uses a combination of fluorescence and electron microscopy to create detailed images of individual synapses. It uses a probabilistic algorithm to identify synapses in fluorescence images and was tested against electron microscopy images as a reference. The algorithm was successful in detecting synapses and reproducing known features of syn distributions in the brain. This method can help discover new types of synapses and their density. It can also be applied to other types of microscopy images where electron validation is not possible.
Researchers have investigated the mechanism of action of ZnT, a protein responsible for zinc accumulation and secretion into breast milk during lactation. They found that Zn2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter, meaning it uses a proton gradient to transport zinc into vesicles. This was demonstrated through experiments using Bafilomycin A, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar protonase, which alkalizes vesicles, and abolished Zn2-dependent zinc transport. Additionally, using Lyso Red and Ly-pfluorin, they showed that upon Zn2 overexpression in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc, vesicles underwent alkalization due to proton-zinc antiport, which was reversed in the presence of TP, a zinc chelator. Computational calculations suggest Zn2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2+/Zn+ ion. This means Zn2 is a motive-driven, electrutral ves zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to cytoplasm.
Researchers have discovered that 14-3 proteins play a crucial role in maintaining genome stability by regulating the processing of stalled replication forks, which is essential for accurate DNA replication. They found that 14-3 proteins interact with Exonuclease 1 (Exo), an enzyme responsible for processing stalled forks, in yeast and mammalian cells. Without 14-3 proteins, cells accumulate gaps in DNA at stalled forks, leading to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. Using DNA electrophoresis, they showed that 14-3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide conditions. The study proposes that 14-3 assist in controlling Exo phosphorylation and other targets, promoting fork stability and restart in response to DNA stress. 

In yeast, 14-3 deficient cells fail to induce Exo hyperphosphorylation and accumulate Ex1-dependent ssDNA gaps at forks, as revealed by electron microscopy. This leads to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. The researchers also found that 14-3 proteins control fork progression and stability under nucleotide limiting conditions. Phosphorylation restrains Ex1 activity, suggesting 14-3 regulate Exo activity upon DNA stress. The study sheds light on processes at stalled forks, proposing 14-3 as central regulators of fork stability and processing.
Researchers studied the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They found that HIV-1 infection leads to persistent infection and immunopathogenesis, including type I interferon (IFN) induction, immune activation, and depletion of human leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. A monoclonal antibody was developed to deplete human DC in lymphoid organs in humanized mice. When DC were depleted prior to HIV infection, induction of IF and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) were abolished during acute HIV infection with a highly pathogenic CCR/CX4-tropic HIV or standard C5ropic HIV isolate. Consistent with antiviral role of IF, HIV replication was upregulated in DC-depleted mice. Interestingly, cell death by highly pathogenic HIV isolate was reduced in DC-depleted mice. During chronic HIV infection, depletion DC also reduced induction of IF and IS, associated with elevated HIV replication. Surprisingly, HIV induced human cell death in lymphoid organs, not blood, was reduced despite increased replication. Increased cell in lymphoid was associated with reduced HIV-induced death human leukocytes CD T cells. DC play opposing roles in suppressing HIV replication and promoting HIV-induced immunogenesis. Findings suggest DCpletion and IF blockade provide novel strategies for treating HIV non-responsive patients with immune activation despite antiretrov treatment.
Researchers investigated the effect of sulforaphane (SF), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, on HIV infection in macrophages. They found that SF blocks HIV infection in primary macrophages, but not in primary T cells. SF also blocks infection in differentiated monocytic cell lines, but not in other cell types. The study suggests that SF's anti-viral activity is mediated through nuclear erythroid-related factor 2 (Nrf2), which is mobilized by SF. Depletion of Nrf with siRNA increased HIV infectivity in macrophages and reduced the anti-v effects of SF treatment. SF treatment blocks infection after reverse transcription, but before 2-L circle formation, similar to type I interferon-induced proteins SAM1 and MX. However, SAM and MX were not upregulated. The study shows that Nrf can block HIV infection and highlights a new way to trigger inhibition.
A cross-sectional study in rural Kenya found that 76.2% of pregnant women were infected with at least one geohelth, with 52.3% with Ascaris lumicoid, 39.5 with hookworm, and 29.0 with Trichuris trichi. Infection with at least geelth was associated with use of unprotected water source (OR 1.8, 95% CI 1.1-3) and lack of water treatment (OR 1.8, 95 CI 1.1-3). Geelth infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or body mass index. Hookworm infection was associated with lower upper arm circumference (mean -0.7 cm, 95 CI 0.3-1). Hookworm with egg count ≥100/gram was associated lower hemoglobin (mean -1.5 g/dl, 95 0.3-2.7). Among gravid 2 and 3 women, Ascaris lumicoid was less likely to have malaria (OR 0.4, 95 0.2-0.8) compared to without Ascaris lumic. Geelth infections are common in this population, but few detrimental effects were observed. Routine antelmin treatment during antenatal visit is recommended, but evaluation of impact on pregnancy, malaria, and outcome is useful.
Researchers investigated the effects of mycolone, a compound produced by the pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, on the nervous system's inflammatory responses. They found that mycolone suppresses the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells, including sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, without affecting their viability. This suggests that mycol's analgesic properties may be partially due to its anti-inflammatory effects. In vitro, mycolone induced cell death in these cells at concentrations above 10ng/ml after 48 hours, but suppressed pro-inflammatory mediator production at nanomolar concentrations within 24 hours. It also prevented microglia polarization, which contributes to neuroinflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain, mycolone injected in the spinal canal decreased inflammatory cytokine production without cytotoxicity. This study provides evidence that mycol suppresses inflammatory responses in sensory neurons, Schw cells, and microia, supporting previous findings in peripheral leukocytes.
Researchers investigated the relationship between genetic variations in human genes and the outcome of African trypanosomiasis, a disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambense, in West Africa. They collected blood samples from 425 individuals in Guinea, including 232 with the disease, 79 with a history of exposure but no symptoms, and 114 without the disease. The team analyzed 28 genetic variations in 8 genes and found that some were associated with the disease outcome. The IL6 rs1819 allele was linked to a lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease, while MIF36071 was associated with increased risk but not significant after correction. MIF12459 was linked to latent infection. The AP1G2 allele was associated with higher risk and AP1 with lower risk of developing the disease. No associations were found with other genes. The study shows that genes influence Tryosoma bruce gambense infection in individuals from Guinea and may lead to new control tools.
Researchers conducted a study on the genetic diversity of South Asians by whole-genome sequencing 38 individuals from Singapore, descendants of immigrants from Dravid-language-speaking states in south India, as part of the Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP). The genetic diversity of these samples was compared to those from the Sequencing Malay Project and Phase 1 of the 1,000 Genomes Project. Results showed that SSIP samples had greater intra-population genetic diversity and higher heterozygous-homozygous ratio than other Asian populations. When compared to a panel of well-defined Indians, the genetic makeup of SSIP was closely related to South Indians but distinct from Europeans in autosomal SNPs. However, samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly present in Europeans and had higher European admixture than others. Analysis of relatedness to archaic humans (Denisovan, Neanderthal) showed higher ancient admixture in East populations than SSIP. The study provides a valuable resource for South Asian samples in Phase 3 of 1,000 Genomes.
Researchers investigated the molecular basis of aminoglycoside susceptibility in Burkholderia pseudalle isolates from Thailand. They found that most isolates are intrinsically resistant to aminlycosides and macrolides due to the AmABpr efflux pump. However, three isolates 708, 218, and 9 showed aoglycos susceptibility. RT-PCR revealed the absence of amr transcripts in 708 and reduced levels in 218 and 9. Serial passage on gentamicin concentrations yielded 218 and 9 mutants that became resistant to other aminlycos and macides, but not 708. Transcript analysis showed resistance in 218 and 9 was due to upregulation of ampr expression by unknown mechanisms. PCR revealed the ampr operon was missing in 708, associated with a 70kb deletion. Rescue of the ampr region from a fosmid and sequencing showed a 131 and 141 kb deletions compared to K43 and 10. This deletion removed the operon and genes for malleactin and cobal synthesis, anaerobic arginine deiminase, type 1 fimbria, and secreted chitin. Whole genome and PCR confirmed absence from 708. Despite missing virulence genes, 708 was virulent in a murine model.
Researchers studied how CD4 T helper cells differentiate into Th1 or Th2 cells, a process mediated by cytokines and transcription factors. Contrary to expectations, they found co-expression of antagonistic transcription factors Tbet and Gata in individual cells at high levels, distinct from basal levels during priming. Cytokines were expressed in a small subpopulation, independent of transcription factors in single cells. Cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during early differentiation was larger than in the fully differentiated state. Inhibiting cytok signaling led to mutual exclusion of antagonistic factors, revealing an intracellular network overruled by extracellular signals. Results suggest CD4 cells acquire a mixed Th1/2 state early, instructed by extracellular cytokines. The interplay between extracellular and intracellular components in Th2 differentiation may be a strategy to buffer noisy cytokine expression.
In the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, the protein PAQR-2 plays a crucial role in adapting to low temperatures by regulating fatty acid desaturation. PA-2 is similar to insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors in mammals and is essential for growth at 15°C, a temperature that is usually not suitable for the organism. Researchers screened for PA-2 suppressors and found mutations in genes involved in phosphatidcholine synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. They found that PA-2, phosphidcholines, and Δ-9 desaturases form a pathway that increases unsaturated fatty acids to maintain membrane fluidity at low temperatures. This is supported by observations that PA-2 suppressors normalize saturated fatty acid levels and low detergent concentrations that increase fluidity can rescue PA-2 mutants. The study establishes a regulatory pathway connecting PA-2, phosphcholine, and Δ-9 desatases to increase unsaturated fatty acids during cold adaptation. PA-2 increases unsaturation is essential for adaptation to 15°C in C. elegans.
Researchers have used electron microscopy to study the structure of the Herpes Simplex Type-1 (HSV-1) virus, a common human pathogen that causes diseases such as cold sores and blindness. They found a previously unknown feature at the virus's vertex, a connection between the capsid and the membrane, which may play a role in releasing the virus's genetic material into the host cell's nucleus and maintaining the virus's structure. This feature is similar to a structure found in bacteriophages, viruses that infect bacteria, suggesting a shared evolutionary link between the two. 

HSV-1 has a complex structure consisting of a DNA, a protein layer called the tegument, and a lipid envelope. The lack of a tail-like structure in HSV-1 was thought to be due to the virus's ability to infect eukaryotic cells. However, the process of delivering DNA into host cells is similar to that of bacterophages, which have a tail. The HSV-1 capsid has a constant diameter of 125 Å and varies in size from 155 to 240 Å. The structure consists of pentons, hexons, and triplexes.
Researchers studied how the Schistosoma mansoni parasite's soluble egg antigen (SEA) affects HIV-1 infection in the body. They found that SEA can bind to a protein on dendritic cells (DCs) called DC-SIGN, blocking HIV-1 from entering these cells. When DCs exposed to SEA matured under Th2 conditions, they induced T-cells that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection, but not X4 infection. This was not seen when DCs matured under Th1 or Th1/2 conditions. T-cells induced by SEA-exposed DCs produced less IFN-γ and MIP-1. The study also showed that recombinant omega-1 (r-1) protein, similar to SEA, induced T-cells that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection, but not X. This was associated with reduced IF-γ and M-1 expression and CCR5 surface expression. The study suggests that SEA and r-1 can modulate HIV-1 infection, potentially influencing disease course in co-infected individuals.
Researchers investigated the phenomenon of neural activity-induced shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and astrocytes in grey and white matter. They found that neuronal stimulation causes a 30% shrinkage of the ECS, which has implications for understanding potassium clearance and astrocyte function. A model was developed to account for experimental data in wild-type and gene knockout individuals. The model suggests that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride, and passive channels of the Na/K pump, and osmotically transport of water through the astrocyte membrane are sufficient for ECS shrinkage. However, considering ECS and astrote ion concentrations with neuronal stimulation, the actions of the Na+/Cl (NK1) and NaHCO (NBC) cotransporters are critical for achieving observed levels of shrink. The model is detailed and constrained to guide future experiments and pave the way for comprehensive astroglia-neuron models in normal and pathophys situations.
In Arabidopsis thalian, transposons and repetitive DNA elements can be detrimental to the organism if expressed. These elements are suppressed by the establishment of repressive chromatin modifications through the siRNA-mediated transcription silencing pathway, where non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) produced by RNA Polymerase V (Pol) guide ARGONA4 (AGO) to chromatin and enzymes that establish repressive chrom modifications. However, it is unknown how chrom modifying enzymes are recruited to chromatin. This study shows that SPTLTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of SPT elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcription silencing. SPTLTF binding occurs downstream of Polymer V but independently of the presence of 24-nt siRNA. Additionally, SPTLTF and AGO are recruited to chrom in parallel and independently of each other. Using methylation restriction enzymes, binding of AGO and SPTLTF is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at several loci. The study proposes that coordinate binding of S and AGO creates a platform for direct or indirect recruitment of chrom modifying enzymes.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Rpo regulon in the tick phase of the Borrelia burgdorferi life cycle, a bacterium that causes Lyme disease. They found that Rpo-dependent gene expression is necessary for the transmission of spirochetes by feeding nymphs. Without Rpo, the spchet are confined to the midgut and transform into unusual round bodies during the later stages of the blood meal. This transformation is reversible and appears to be caused by reduced levels of Coenzyme disulf reductase, which provides NAD for glycolysis. The study shows that spiroes default to an Rpo-independent program for round formation when energy for transmission is unfavorable. The results highlight the importance of the R regul during the tick phase of the cycle and suggest a new role for RSB in physiological adaptations for tick-to-mamm transmission.
Researchers investigated the relationship between gibberin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) hormones in controlling stamen development in Arabidopsis. They found that GA promotes the expression of MYB21, MY24, and MY57 genes, which are involved in stamen elongation. Loss-of-function of DELLA proteins, which are inhibited by GA, restored the expression of these MY genes and restored stamen growth in GA-deficient plants. A triple mutant of MY21, MY24, and MY57 resulted in a short stamen and male sterility. Genetic and molecular studies showed that GA suppresses DELs to mobilize the JA biosynthesis gene DAD, leading to lower JA content in GA-deficient flowers. The study established a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA, where GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control the expression of MY21, MY24, and MY57, a prerequisite for normal st development in Arabidopsis.
Researchers investigated the role of hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in lifespan extension caused by dietary restriction (DR) in Caenorhabditis elegans.
