Deep learning can distinguish informative from uninformative statistics and accommodate complex models. It provides a complimentary approach to existing likelihood-free inference in genetics. Other methods, such as ABC and SVM, can also be used. It is unclear which would produce most accurate results. Deep can be used to classify regions as neutral or selected for demographic inference.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) oncogenes disrupt the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway by impairing localization and deubiquination of FANCD2. Persistent expression of high-risk HPV oncogenes is necessary for the development of anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers. Research shows that E6/E7-expressing cells are hypersensitive to DNA-damaging agent cisplatin and have defects in repairing interstrand crosslinks (ICL). The study elucidates how E/E7 attenuates the FA DNA repair pathway. E7 activates the pathway by increasing FAN2 monoubiquination and foci formation, but inhibits completion of repair by multiple mechanisms. E7 impairs FAN localization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering downstream protein Rad51 recruitment to DS in E cells. Further, E expression delays FAN deubiquination, a process for effective ICL repair. Delayed FAN deubination is associated with chromatin retention ofAN, hindering US1 deubiquinating activity and persistently activated ATR/CHK-1/p565AN signaling. E-mediated p53 degradation does not hamper cell cycle processAN modifications but abrogates repair by disruptingAN deubination. E reduces and foci formation of Pal2, a repair protein downstreamAN.
In the Southern Chiapas region of Mexico, a major onchocerciasis focus in Latin America, 559 communities have undergone semi-annual ivermect treatment since 1998. In 50 communities, iverectin frequency shifted to twice a year in 2003, and an additional 113 communities were added to the quarterly regimen in 2009 to achieve rapid suppression. Epidemiological and entomological assessments were conducted in 6 sentinel communities with 2 rounds of iverectin per year and 3 extra-sent with 4 rounds per year. No Simulium ochum l collected in 201 were found to contain parasite DNA by PCR-ELISA, with an upper 95% confidence interval of 0.06/2,000 examined. Serological testing on 4,230 children under 5 revealed 2/4,230 exposed (0.05%). These findings meet the criteria for transmission interruption developed by the international community. The Onchercias Elimination Program aims to eliminate ocular morbidity and transmission in 13 foci in Latin America. The Southern Chiapas population (114,024) is 21% of the Americas at-risk population. Since 1990, onchercias control relied on iverect distribution to at-risk communities. Annual mass iverect began 1994, modified to 6 months in 1998. In Chiapas, iverect started 199, initially for cases, then all eligible in hyperemic and hypoemic 1994, 25% hypoemic 1995-7. 22 rounds >85% eligible have been provided over 11 years, coverage >85 every year 199-201.
Listeria monocytogen is a Gram-positive facultative intracellular pathogen that invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate within the host cytos. A transcription activator PrA regulates gene products for intracellular growth and bacterial spread. However, the signal that activates PrA has not been defined. Researchers found that L monocytogen secretes a small peptide pherone, pA, which enhances escape from host vacoles and may facilitate PrA activation. pA is generated via proteolytic processing of P lipoprotein signal. P lipop is dispensable for pathogenesis, but bacteria lacking pA are attenuated for virulence in mice and have reduced escape efficiency from vacoles of nonphagocytic cells. Mutating PrA restores virulence and eliminates need for pA signaling. Experimental evidence suggests pA may signal monocogen presence within vacole, stimulating expression of products contributing to escape and PrA activation for growth.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Vibrio cholera, which causes cholera, adapts to the hostile environment of the human intestines during infection. They used a technique called whole-genome transposon sequencing (T-seq) to compare the genes required for colonization in mice with and without antioxidant treatment, N-acetyl cystine. The results showed that mutants of the methyl-directed repair system, such as MutS, had a significant advantage in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in N-treated mice. Further analysis suggested that accumulation of catalase-producing and rugose variants in N- mice was the cause of Mut mutant enrichment by oxidative stress during infection. Rugose variants could revert to smooth colonies in aerobic in vitro. The mutation rate of wildtype colonized in N- mice was higher than in N+ mice. These findings support a paradigm that Vibrio employs a temporal strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes.
Researchers studied the role of the Mlh3 protein in baker's yeast in meiotic recombination and mismatch repair (MMR). They analyzed 60 new Mlh alleles, five of which disrupted MMR and one that specifically disrupted meiotic crossing over. The researchers purified and characterized two representatives of each class, Mlh-32 (MR+, crossover-) and Mlh-45 (MR-, crossover+). Both displayed wild-type endonuc activities in vitro. The M2sh complex, which acts with Mlh in MMR, stimulated the endon activity of Mlh-32 but not Mlh-45, suggesting M-45 is defective in M interactions. Whole-genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type, M+ crossover, M- crossover, endonuc defective and Mlh mutants in S288/Y789 background. Compared to wild-type, all Mlh mutants showed increases in non-crossover events, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative pathways. This study provides a structure-function map for Mlh and highlights the importance of protein-protein interactions regulating Mlh's enzymatic activity. It also shows how meiotic components can alter the fate of meiotic recombination intermediates, providing insights into how meiotic pathways are regulated.
Researchers have found that the structure of a host population plays a significant role in the reversal of resistance to antibiotics after treatment is stopped. When antibiotics are used to treat diseases like tuberculosis, malaria, Staphylococcus aureus, or gonorrhea, resistance levels increase, leading to a switch to new drugs and discontinuation of older ones. However, resistance often persists or declines slowly. This is often attributed to the low fitness cost of resistance in the absence of the drug. The study shows that host heterogeneity in the number of contacts also affects reversion dynamics. During treatment, host structure leads to non-random distribution of resistant strains among the population, and after drug discontinuation, it affects competition, resulting in mitigation of fitness advantages. As a result, reversion rate and probability are lower on the population level after treatment is stopped. Simulations show the impact of heterogeneity is largest in biologically plausible range when fitness costs are small. 

The study confirms contact heterogeneity lowers reversion probability even when a substantial pathogen population is sensitive when treatment is stopped. Large differences between sensitive and resistant strains result in non-trivial distribution of infections over the network, influencing reversion once treatment is stopped. Costs of resistance are generally small for many path-drug combinations, making the biologically relevant range where effects of heterogeneity are largest. The range of fitness values affecting reversion probability shifts closer to 1 with system size. During treatment, resistant infections increase while sensitive decline. Once resistant has risen to a level, treatment is stopped, and dynamics are governed by wild-type and resistant competition in absence. Modulating host structure on reversion is strongest in biologically when differences are small. This framework allows studying disease emergence during treatment and competition between strains after is discontinued.
Researchers studied how genetic variations in the human genome, known as copy number variants (CNVs), contribute to autism spectrum disorders (ASD). They used fruit flies (Drosophila) as a model to examine interactions between genes affected by CNVs in individuals with autism. The study found that pairs of genes affected by the same CNV showed synergistic effects, meaning their combined effect was greater than the sum of individual effects. This was observed in three out of four CNVs with complete ortholog relationships. Changes in Doph genes resulted in similar neurological defects to those previously reported in Doph models of ASD variants. The study suggests that combined effects of multiple genes contribute to autism, rather than a single gene. This is supported by the fact that individuals with autism often have multiple CNVs affecting different genes. The researchers used Doph as an in vivo system to examine interactions between genes implicated in autism, as it is a tractable and high-throughput model. They modeled effects of gene changes on Doph neurological readouts using sets of genes from multigen de CNVs identified in patients with autism. The study focused on Doph orthologs of genes affected by CN whose products participate in ASD networks and neural functioning. Many CNs affect genes in the same pathway, and 33% affect multiple genes interacting within that pathway, suggesting combined copy change contributes to autistic phenotypes. The study illustrates how synergistic effects from structural variation contribute to disease.
Research has shown that CD8 T cells play a key role in the development of experimental cerebral malaria (ECM) during Plasmodium berghei AN infection in C57/6 mice. However, the mechanisms through which they mediate their pathogenic activity during infection are not well understood. This study used intravital two-photon microscopy and flow cytometry to examine brain-infiltrating T cells in mice infected with ECM-inducing (P berg AN) and non-inducing ( berg NK) infections. Results showed that T cells accumulated in the perascular spaces of the brain during both infections, but displayed arrested behavior specifically during berg AN infection. T cells formed long-term interactions with CXCR-bearing antigen-presenting cells in the brain during AN infection, but depletion of these cells did not prevent ECM development. Pathogenic T cells localized with apoptotic cells expressing CD31, a marker of endothelial cells, but apoptosis was rare and did not result in loss of vasculature or disruption. The study found that arrest of T in perascular compartments is a signature of ECM-inducing infection and suggests an important role in ECM development.
A study was conducted in Vih County, Kenya to determine the burden of Tungis, a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tungaans, also known as jigger. The study was a cross-sectional and involved 437 participants aged 5 and above from 21 villages in 3 sublocations. The overall prevalence of Tungis was 21.5% (95% CI 17.7-25.3%). The disease was more common in areas with low economic status, indicated by a monthly income of Ksh 100 or less, earthen floor, lack of toilet facilities, age 14 or less, no use of closed footwear, and resting inside the house. Tungis is a significant problem in V County due to the economic status of the affected. Factors contributing to the disease include poverty. The study suggests the need for cost-effective and accessible strategies to control Tungis. Tung is endemic in tropical and subtropical countries, with unknown global burden. In Kenya, studies have reported prevalence between 19-40%. Children and the elderly bear the brunt of infection. Tung is a neglected disease, not recognized by WHO, affecting communities in poverty, poor housing, sanitation, and contact with domestic animals. Mapping of neglected diseases has improved, but more is needed for Tungis to understand affected communities and magnitude. The study found no spatial autocorrelation, indicating Tis prevalence may be random.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the interaction between auxin and cytokinin hormones in Arabidopsis root patterning. The model considers the regulation of auxin transporters by aux and cytokinin in a spatial context, taking into account cell shape and polarity and cell walls. Analysis shows that a cytokinin pattern generated by diffusion is unlikely and not required for auxin patterning. Instead, aux-dependent modifications of cytokinin response allow necessary feedback, amplifying and stabilizing aux maximum. The model highlights the importance of auxin efflux regulation for robustness and predicts a role of AUX and LAX2 aux influx transporters in vascular patterning. Local PIN polarisation generates an aux flux stabilizing accumulation in the xylem axis and provides a mechanism for aux to accumulate in xylem-pericycle cells, an early step in lateral root initiation. Pericycle cells opposite xyle poles compete for aux accumulation, consistent with lateral roots not initiated opposite each other.

The model extends a previous longitudinal aux transport model, considering regulation of transport under aux and cytokinin control. It identifies a novel role for aux influx and a connection between subcell polarity and tissue robustness. Insights into transverse aux transport will aid three-dimensional models of root growth in Arabidopsis. Cytokinin distribution is sufficient to activate PIN, resulting in aux transport to the xyle axis and patterning; a gradient around cytok biosynthesis sites is not required and unlikely. Simulations show the mutually inhibitory aux-cytokin loop maintains aux in the xyle axis. However, aux becomes confined to protoxyle, while simulations show sustained aux throughout the xyle axis. PIN localisation is a factor in aux distribution and flux.
Researchers have identified a key player in the process by which migratory locusts change their behavior in response to their environment. A protein called CRE-B acts as a mediator in a signaling pathway involving a neuropeptide (NPF) and nitric oxide (NO) that regulates locomotor activity between solitary and gregarious phases. CRE-B directly activates the expression of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) by interacting with its promoter region. Phosphorylation of serine 110 on CRE-B changes in response to population density and is controlled by N2. The involvement of CRE-B in N2-regulated locomotor plasticity is confirmed by RNA interference and behavioral assay. Protein kinase A transmits the effects of N2 on CRE-B phosphorylation and OS transcription. The study reveals a precise cascade underlying environment-induced behavioral plasticity.
Researchers studied the role of the zinc-finger protein Zelda (Z) in the early development of Drosophila melanogaster embryos. Zelda plays a key role in the transcriptional activation of genes involved in sex determination, patterning, and other early developmental processes. To understand its mechanisms and targets, the researchers used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing (IP-Seq) to map regions bound by Zelda before, during, and after the maternal-to-zyotic transition (MT). They found thousands of regions bound by Zelda in cycle 8 embryos, most of which remain through cycle 14. Expectedly, early Zelda-bound regions include promoters and enhancers of genes transcribed at this stage. However, they also observed Zelda bound to promoters of genes whose transcription does not occur until MT, and thousands of enhancers bound by transcription factors that regulate gene activation during MT. The association between Zelda binding and MT is strong that Zelda can identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with specificity. This suggests Zelda not only regulates earliest transcription but also plays a role in activating genome at MT.
Researchers have investigated the timing of protein-protein interactions (PPI) in the context of the circadian clock, a fundamental cellular mechanism regulating physiological processes with a 24-hour cycle. They identified 109 novel PIs among circadian proteins using a yeast-two-hybrid approach, including the interaction of phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL, which resulted in BM1 destabilization. A dynamic circadian P network was constructed predicting P timing using circadian data, and systematic circadian phenotyping (RNAi and overexpression) suggested crucial roles for involved components in interactions. Analysis of a global network in liver revealed interacting proteins expressed at similar times, likely restricting interactions to specific phases. Circadian PIs were found to connect many cellular processes, such as signal transduction and cell cycle, contributing to temporal organization in an unprecedented manner.

A comprehensive view of circadian P dynamics was provided, distinct from previous studies focusing on specific processes or phases. Novel PIs included modulators of CLOCK/BMAL function, indicating phosphatase 1's role in regulating BM1 abundance. The network was extended with validated interactions from literature, some essential for normal circadian dynamics. Timing of gene expression, protein interactions, and post-translational modifications are essential for sustaining circadian rhythms. The study highlights the importance of precisely timed PIs for the circadian clock, but emphasizes the need for a comprehensive view of PIs among circadian proteins and their dynamics. The extent of regulation of circadian processes via time-dependent PIs is largely unknown.
Researchers have solved the three-dimensional structure of ABA-1, a repeating unit of the nematode protein allergen (NPA) from Ascaris su, using nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The protein has a novel seven-helical fold with a central helix and two four-hel bundles on either side. Two discrete hydrophobic ligand-binding pockets are found in the N-terminal and C-terminal bundles, and amino acid chains affected by ligand (fatty acid) binding were identified. Recombinant A-1 contains tightly-bound ligand of bacterial origin in one of its binding sites. This is the first post-translationally processed unit of a tandemly repetitive polyprotein to be structurally characterized from any source and belongs to a new class. Nematodes have no counterparts in vertebrates, making them potential targets for drug or immunological intervention. Ascar and filarial nemat parasites have a simplified array of N units with predominantly identical or similar amino sequences, unlike other nematodes and free-living species. NAs are immunodominant and allergenic in nemode infections, with no consensus features making a protein more or less likely to be allergenic. Several disease-causing nemodes express NAs associated with strong immune responses and hypersensitivities. The structure of ABA-1 may contribute to elucidation of a consensus for infection-associated allergens. NAs have affinity for pharmacologically lipids or precursors, suggesting sequestration or delivery may be a mechanism to subvert host response, making them relevant to parasitology and protein science.
Between 1998 and 2008, there were 39,677 reported cases of ciguatera poisoning in 17 Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PITCs), with a mean annual incidence of 194 cases per 100,000 people. This is a 60% increase from the 104 cases per 100,000 reported between 1973 and 1983. Accounting for underreporting, an estimated 500,000 Pacific islanders may have suffered from cigater in the last 35 years. Ciguater is a tropical disease caused by consuming coral fish contaminated with cigatoxin, a toxin produced by dinoflagates and cyanobacteria. Symptoms include acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac issues, and in some cases, chronic neuro symptoms lasting weeks to months. The disease is often underdiagnosed and underreported, with only 2-10% of cases reported to health authorities. Cigu is a major public health concern, expected to increase with environmental changes.
Researchers studied the impact of benznazole treatment on CD4CD+8 T cells in chronic Chagas disease patients. Chagas disease is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi, a parasite that persists in the body and impairs the immune system. CD4CD8 T cells are a type of immune cell that expands in chronic Chagas patients, but their role is not well understood. The study included 38 patients with chronic Chagas, 20 asymptomatic and 18 symptomatic, and 12 healthy donors. Blood cells were stimulated with T cruzi antigens to analyze cytokine and cytotoxic molecule production by CD4CD T before and after benidazole treatment. Expression and co-expression of inhibitory receptors in patients after treatment were studied using flow cytometry. CD4CD T frequency was higher in Chagas patients than healthy donors, with higher CD4CDlowCDhigh ratio. CD T from patients expressed co-expressed inhibitory receptors in proportion to disease severity. Benidazole reduced CD frequency and CD ratio, decreased inhibitory co-expression, and enhanced multifunctional capacity of CD T. After treatment, T antigen-specific CD T expressing IL-2 and TN-α increased. CD T could control T infection, producing effector molecules. Benidazole partially reversed exhaustion caused by T in these cells, improving T antigen CD T response.
Researchers have identified Arabidopsis thaliana phosphoinide-specific phospholipase 2 (AtPLC2) as the primary enzyme responsible for phosphoinide metabolism and its role in seedling growth and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress responses. Lipid profiling of multiple PLC mutants showed increased levels of phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate, indicating impaired phosphide metabolic pathway. PLC2 displayed distinct tissue expression and localization at the plasma membrane in different cell types where phosphide signaling occurs. Seedlings of PLC-1 mutant showed growth defects complemented by heterologous expression of PLC, suggesting phosphide-specific phospholase activity by PLC is required for seed growth. The PLC-1 mutant also showed hypersensitive response to ER stress with changes in phenotypes and gene profiles. The study revealed primary enzyme in phosphide metabolism, its involvement in seedling and emerging link between phosphide and ER response. 

The endoplasmic reticulum is a major site of phosphid biosynthesis, and phosphid signaling may be associated with ER function. Involvement of lipid in stress response is emerging in plants. The study isolated and analyzed mutants of multiple PLC forms in Arabid. Lipid profiling phosphides in mutants showed PLC is primary PI-PL in phosphide metabolism. Plants may have unique mechanism cross-talk between ER and plasma to cope with stress. Conclusion, PLC is major PIPL in phosphide and seedling in Arab, important for ER tolerance, suggesting link phosphide signaling and ER response.
Researchers challenge the assumption that causation in the physical world occurs at the micro level, excluding emergence at the macro level. They use a measure called intrinsic-effect power-integrated (Φ) to show that a macro level can "beat" the micro. Systems were evaluated across different spatial and temporal scales by considering all possible black boxes, which are elements of one or more micro elements over one or more updates. Cause power was based on inputs and outputs of the boxes, ignoring internal elements that support their input-output function. Results show black elements can have more inputs and outputs than micro elements, revealing emergence of high-order mechanisms and constraints not apparent at micro. A macro system can have higher Φ than its constituents with more mechanisms that are interconnected. For a system, local maxima of Φ can be identified across spatiotemporal scales. The framework is demonstrated on a biological system, the Boolean model of fission-yeast cell, which identifies local max during its biological function. These max correspond to levels of organization where emergent cause properties come into focus, providing a point for scientific inquiries.

Intrinsic power is used to quantify causal power and examples of black macro systems with higher power than micro are shown. This refutes the assumption that power resides exclusively at micro. Evaluating power across spatiemp scales shows local max of power, which integrated decreases to zero. Max capture emergent roles of macro elements, corresponding to system descriptions as NOR, OR, AND, or MAJ elements. Reduction assumes power resides with micro, but power is evaluated explicitly as intrinsic and spatiemp levels where properties emerge. A framework to evaluate power and properties of a black system is proposed. Emergent properties include increase power and relationships between elements that become apparent at macro. Intrinsic and counterfactual framework is used to quantify power and mechanisms at micro and black levels.
Researchers have investigated the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, which play a crucial role in cell adaptation to the environment but can also cause damage under conditions of hypoxia/reoxygenation leading to various diseases. To understand this, they extended a model of complex III to account for electron transport, proton translocation, transmembrane electrochemical potential, TCA reactions, and substrate transport. Measurements of electron flux in rat mitochondria fueled by succinate, pyruvate, and malate, and dynamics of NAD reduction by reverse transport from succinate through complex I were analyzed. The model fitting provided insight into the formation of free radicals that transfer unpaired electrons to oxygen, producing superoxide and initiating ROS. Analysis revealed association of ROS with specific electron transporters and their combinations in complexes I and III. The phenomenon of bistability in complex III was found to be valid for the whole chain. Conditions for switching to a state with high free radicals in III were predicted and confirmed. These findings provide new insight into ROS production mechanisms in the chain.
Researchers have studied how motor proteins transport cargo within cells, which is essential for various cellular functions. Motor proteins convert chemical energy into kinetic energy, enabling unidirectional and bidirectional transport of cargo over long distances. Disruptions in this process, caused by mutations altering motor characteristics, lead to neurodegenerative diseases. For example, phosphorylation of the kines motor domain at serine residue is linked to Huntington's disease. A study on phosphorylated phosphim ser residues showed lowered motor stalling forces. This article investigates the effects of similar mutations on transport properties of cargo carried by wild-type and mutant motors. Results show mutants with altered stalling forces determine average velocity and run-length, even outnumbered by wild-type motors. Mutants gain advantage and increase run-length when load is near mutant stalling or multiple of stalling force. A semi-analytical method was developed to analyze transport by multiple motors of types, determining transition rates between configurations and computing biologically relevant quantities like velocity and run-length without Monte Carlo simulations. This method can model single parameter alterations and deduce effects on transport by multiple motors.
Researchers investigated the role of the CAC1 gene in operant learning, a type of learning that involves selecting and adapting behavioral strategies to achieve a goal. They studied mice with a genetic modification that impairs learning, a knockout of the CnaC1 gene, which codes for a subunit of high-voltage calcium channels. These channels are crucial for synaptic plasticity and have been linked to learning and psychiatric disorders. The study used a detailed analysis of individual learning strategies and computational models to show that Cna1 knockout does not impair learning in general, but affects how mice adapt to reward. Most knockout mice increased reward by adapting to outcome, while controls followed the intended cue-association rule. This suggests a specific role of the gene in learning and highlights the importance of examining behavioral strategies. The results may have implications for treating psychiatric disorders.
Researchers studied how Wolbachia infections in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes respond to cyclical heat stress. Aedes aegpt mosquitoes infected with Wolbach are being released to suppress arboviruses worldwide, but their ability to invade and persist depends on environmental conditions. The study reared Ae aegypt larvae with different types of Wolbach (Mel, wMelB, and wMel-CLA) under diurnal temperatures. Results showed that rearing Mel and Mel-CLA-infected larvae at 26-37°C reduced cytoplasmic incompatibility, a reproductive manipulation by Wolbach, and decreased Wolbach density in adults. Mel and Mel-CLA infections were not transmitted to the next generation when exposed to 26-37°C across life stages. In contrast, wB infection maintained high density, exhibited cytoplasm incompat, and transmitted to offspring with high fidelity under this temperature. These findings have implications for Wolbach interventions across environments and highlight temperature control in rearing.
Researchers studied the presence of adenoviruses in the gastrointestinal tracts of non-human primates, including great apes and macaques. They found that these animals shed substantial quantities of infectious adeniruses in their stools, with frequencies comparable to those reported in humans. The team purified and sequenced 30 adeniruses from apes and 3 adenir from macques, and analyzed them with 22 adenirus genomes from GenBank. The results showed that ape adeniruses belonged to human adenirus species B, C, and E, with evidence of intraspecies recombination and high phylogenetic relatedness across primate hosts. This suggests cross-species transmission has occurred in the history of B and E viruses. The high asymptomatic shedding of adenirus in non-human primates and zoonotic transmissions warrant caution for primate handling and housing. The presence of persistent latent adenirus in the gut should be considered in human and non-primate studies with adenirus vectors.
Researchers have investigated the process of unwrapping the outer helical turn of nucleosomal DNA, a fundamental to various cellular processes. Nucleosomes are protein-DNA complexes where 146-147 base pairs of DNA wrap 1.75 times around a histone core. To function, nucleosomal DNA must be unwrapped, but the details of this process at an atomic level were not well understood. Using molecular simulation with enhanced sampling, the researchers calculated the free profiles for unwrapping the outerhelical turn of nucleosomal DNA, finding a free energy change of 11.5 kcal/mol, consistent with single molecule experiments. The simulation revealed various conformation states, indicating multiple paths to unwrapping but a dominant asymmetric one. Unwrapping started at one end with 5 base pairs, then 5 at the same end with increased energy, then at the other end with 10 pairs unwrapped. Further unwrapping 15 pairs, unwrapped at one end then the other to complete unwr the turn. This provides insight into nucleosome construction, disruption, and repositioning, ongoing cellular processes.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism by which the protein Apolipoprotein D (ApoD) protects cells from damage caused by oxidative stress. Oxidative stress can damage cell membranes, and lysosomes are particularly vulnerable because they require a stable acidic environment to function. Apo, an extracellular protein with antioxidant properties, is secreted by cells in the nervous system, such as astrocytes, to help neurons cope with stress. The role of Apo is known at the cellular and organism level, but its mechanism was unknown. The study analyzed Apo's intracellular traffic and role in lysosomal homeostasis under oxidative stress. Apo is endocytosed and targeted to vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner, and is functionally stable in acidic environment. Its presence is necessary and sufficient for lysosomes to recover from oxidation-induced alkalinization in astrocytes and neurons, by preventing membrane permeabilization. Two lysosomal processes, myelin phagocytosis by astrocytes and neurodegeneration-triggered autagy in Drosila model, require Apo-related lipocalins. Results uncover a new function of Apo, a member of conserved gene family, and set lipoprotein regulation of lysosomal integrity as a mechanism critical for neurodegenerative diseases.
Researchers studied the biology and susceptibility of Phlebotus orientalis sandflies to Leishmania donovani, the parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis in East Africa. Two colonies of P. orientalis from different locations in Ethiopia were examined: a non-endemic site in the lowlands of Melka Wer and an endemic area in the highlands of Addis Zemen. Significant differences in life cycle parameters were found between the two colonies, including requirements for larval food and humidity during pupation. However, genetic analysis using Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA (RAP) and DNA sequencing of cytB and COI genes showed no genetic differences between the two colonies. Hybrid offspring had higher fecundity than the parental colonies. Susceptibility of P. orient to L. donani was studied through experimental infections. Even the lowest infective dose (2,103 per ml) was sufficient for successful establishment of L. donani infections in 50% of P. orient females. Using higher infective doses, infection rates were 90% for both colonies. Leish development in P. orient was fast, with metacyclic promastigotes in the thoracic midgut and colonization of the stomal valve by haptads recorded in P. orient females by five days post-feeding. Both MW and AZ colonies of P. orient were highly susceptible to Ethiopian L. donani strains. The average blood-meals taken by P orient females were about 0.7 µl, the infective at lowest dose was one or two L. donastigotes per sand-meal. Development of L donani was similar in P orient colonies, hence the absence of visceral leishiasis in non-endemic Mel Wer cannot be attributed to susceptibility local P orient populations to donani.
A study was conducted to quantify the quality of life and disability of patients with advanced schistosomiasis japonica in a schistosoma japon-haemic county in the People's Republic of China. A total of 506 candidates were screened, and 215 cases were confirmed with advanced schosmias japonica. Most patients reported impairments in at least one health dimension, such as pain or discomfort (90.7%), usual activities (87.9%), and anxiety or depression (80.9%). The disability weight (DW) was 0.447, and age-specific DW ranged from 0.378 among individuals aged 30-44 to 0.510 among the elderly ≥60. DW was associated with loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and albumin were protective for quality of life. These patient-preference estimates provide data for revision of the Global Burden of Disease (GBD) study and evidence-based decision-making in China's schosmiasis control program.
African Trypanosomias, also known as sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in animals, are prevalent parasitic diseases in sub-Saharan Africa. They are caused by the bite of tset flies infected with Trypanosoma brucei protozoa, specifically T. b. gambense in West and Central Africa and T. rhodesense in East and Southern Africa. A retrospective study used national census data from 1999 to estimate population vulnerability and disability in Kenya's tse belts, where tse flies are vectors for T. rhense and other trypan agents. The study found that tse belts were associated with increased disability, both directly through bites causing human infection and indirectly by reducing agricultural production due to diseased livestock, leading to nutritional deficiencies and poverty. Incorporating census data is a promising tool for future surveillance in sub-Saharan Africa. The combined burdens of human and animal trypanosomias and agricultural losses contribute to disability in tse-infested areas.
Hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) is a compound that induces cell differentiation and HIV production in chronically infected cells, but its mechanism of action was not well understood. Researchers found that HM activates the PI3/Akt pathway, leading to the phosphorylation of HEXIM protein, which releases active transcription elongation factor (PTEF) from its inactive complex with 7 small nuclear RNA (snRNA). As a result, PF is recruited to the HIV promoter to stimulate transcription and production. Despite HM presence, released PF rapidly reassembles with 7snRNA and HEXIM. A mutant HEX protein that cannot be phosphorylated and released via PI/Akt pathway antagonizes HM-induced viral production. Studies reveal how HM targets cellular factor PF for HIV reactivation and suggest modifications in equilibrium between active and inactive PF contribute to cell differentiation.
Researchers have identified a link between the Leishmania virus (LRV) and aggressive forms of cutaneous leishiasis (CL), which can lead to mucosal (ML) or disseminated cutaneous leishias (DCL). These complications occur when the infection spreads from a primary skin lesion caused by a Leish-infected sand fly to secondary sites, causing significant morbidity and inflammation. LRV is found in Leish strains L. guyensis, causing elevated parasitemia, hyperinflammation, and disease exacerbation. To study this relationship and LRV distribution in other Leish strains, improved detection and quantitation methods are needed, independent of viral sequence knowledge. This study presents techniques, including an anti-dRNA monoclonal antibody J, for specific and quantitative recognition of dsRNA in sequence-independent fashion. Applications include immunofluorescence, ELISA, and dot blot, complementing nucleic acid purification and real-time PCR. Methods were evaluated and demonstrated LRV detection by J in several strains, patient sample, and infected mice biopsies. LRV is recognized by host Toll-like receptor TLR, exacerbating disease in murine models. Leish has a life cycle, promastigote in sand fly midgut, amastote in mammalian macrophage. LRV was tested on isolated Leish from L brazensis patient, later typed as L. brazensis. The approach was applied on catalogued isolates, fresh L braz sample, and murine biops, showing ease of use for field application. The technique has potential for predicting LRV-related leish dissemination risk.
Enteropathogenic and enterohemorrhagic Escheria coli (EPEC and EHE) are closely related pathogens that attach to intestinal epithelial cells, efface microvilli, and promote cytoskeletal rearrangements into protrusions called actin pedestals. PEC employs the tyrosine phosphorylated transmembrane receptor Tir, while EHE relies on the multivalent scaffolding protein EspF. The ability to generate these structures correlates with colonization in animal models, but the function of pedest in infection is unclear. Researchers characterized colonization of PEC and ECE during polarized epithelial cells, finding both formed bacterial communities or "macroies" that encompassed multiple cells. Tir and Esp, as well as the Arp2/3 complex, were critical for expansion of macroies over time. Unexpectedly, EspF accelerated formation of larger macroies compared to PEC, as Esp-mediated actin assembly drove bacterial motility to junctions, where bacteria formed a pedestal on a neighboring cell and divided, allowing one daughter to disengage and infect the second. These data reveal Esp enhances epithelial colonization by actin-based motility and efficient cell-to-cell transmission.
Researchers compared two methods for isolating extracellular vesicles (EVs) from the excretory-secretory products of the parasitic worm Fasciola hepatica: differential centrifugation (DC) and size exclusion chromatography (SEC). DC is the most commonly used method for isolating EVs from pathogens, but SEC has been used for isolating EV from other pathogens. The study found that EVs isolated by SEC were smaller and less diverse than those isolated by DC. SEC also resulted in a higher purity of EV to excretory-secretory protein (ESP) ratio, with reduced contamination from soluble cathepsin proteases. Proteomic analysis showed DC EVs contained more ESP and tegument proteins than SEC EVs. This suggests DC and SEC do not isolate equivalent EV populations, and caution should be taken when choosing purification methods. The study proposes using SEC for isolating EV before downstream studies.
Researchers used a reverse-engineering approach to study post-transcriptional regulation in the fruit fly Drosila melanogaster, focusing on the gap genes Krpp, kni, and gt. They analyzed detailed, quantitative datasets of mRNA and protein expression to fit a model of post-transcription regulation and determine its structural and practical identifiability. The results showed that post-transcription regulation is not required for patterning in this system but is necessary for proper control of protein levels. The study demonstrates the uniqueness and specificity of a fitted model can be rigorously determined in the context of spatio-temporal formation, increasing the potential of reverse engineering for study of development and other complex biological processes.

The researchers used a reverse-engineering approach to gain quantitative insights into postcription regulation by fitting the model to data in a rigorous and reproducible manner. They first determined if the model was formulated to have a unique solution, then fitted it to protein data using mRNA as inputs or boundary conditions. If the models reproduced protein patterns, they concluded postcription was not required for expression. If they failed, they identified features relying on postcription processes.

The approach was applied to the complex problem of spatio-temporal formation in the fly embryo, testing the importance of postcription in development. A high-resolution dataset of mRNA expression for Kr, kn, and gt was created covering the blastoderm stage.
Researchers investigated how age affects susceptibility to rotavirus infection, a major cause of diarrhea worldwide, in a mouse model. They found that infants and newborn mice are highly susceptible, while adults remain asymptomatic and shed low viral particles. The team discovered that Toll-like receptor 3 (TLR3) expression in the intestinal epithelial cells is low in newborns but increases during the postnatal period, inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, shedding, and histological damage. Adult mice lacking TLR3 or its adaptor molecule Trif showed higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial pro-inflammatory and antiviral gene expression compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice lacking TLR or Trif did not display impaired stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, a significant contribution of non-hematopoietic cells in Tr-mediated antiral response was detected in adults. A significant age-dependent increase in TLR expression was also found in human intestinal biops. Upregulation of epithelial TLR during infancy might contribute to age-dependent rotavirus susceptibility.
Researchers analyzed whole-exome sequencing data from 1,039 individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and 870 controls from the National Human Genome Repository to determine the distribution of rare genetic variations. Two sequencing centers used different methods to produce and identify variants, and the goal was to ensure the distribution was similar. Variants were filtered based on missing data, read depth, and balance of alternative reads. Seven samples were sequenced at both centers, and results were evaluated. The study addressed how to combine data and results from centers. Gene-based analysis was a choice, but should statistics be combined across centers (meta-analysis) or data combined and analyzed (mega). Due to the nature of gene-based tests, mega-analysis had better power than meta-analysis. Before analysis, the impact of population structure on rare variants was explored. Like other studies, population structure confounded case-control studies by clustering variants in ancestry, but principal-based analyses controlled for ancestry and produced appropriate distributions. Using gene tests and mega-analysis, no new genes were found for ASD. Results suggest gene-based tests require larger samples for discovery, even for a disorder like ASD.
A study investigated the association between genetic polymorphisms in the chitin-degrading enzymes chitriosase and AMCase and the incidence of mycetoma caused by Madlla myetatis in a Sudanese population. Chitin is a component of the fungal cell wall of M. myetatis, which can trigger the human immune system. Polymorphisms in the genes for chitrios and AM were studied in 112 myetoma patients and 103 controls. A 24-b insertion in the chitrios gene (rs1317) resulted in impaired chitin activity, while a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the AM gene (617) resulted in decreased AM activity. Additionally, a SNP (41292) and 10-b insertion in the 5'UTR of the AM gene (143) were studied, resulting in increased AM activity. DNA was isolated from blood and genotypes were determined using PCR-RP. Histological staining confirmed the presence of chitin in the fungal grain. The polymorphism resulting in decreased chitrios activity was associated with increased odds of myoma (OR 2.9, p=0.004). No association was found for polymorphisms in the genes for AM (p>0.05). Decreased chrios activity was associated with increased risk of M myet myoma.
Researchers have re-examined the concept of herpes simplex virus (HSV) latency, a state where the virus remains dormant in the body without causing symptoms. Traditionally, HSV was thought to have two phases: an acute phase where the virus replicates and a latent phase where it remains dormant. However, new evidence suggests that the latent phase is not as clear-cut as previously thought. Studies have shown that lytic genes, responsible for viral replication, can be transcribed during latency, but it was unclear if they were translated into proteins. This study used a sensitive model to show that lytic and latent phases are not as distinct as previously thought. Half of the virus spread to latent sites occurred after the initial infection, and lytic promoters drove protein expression during latency. This is the most direct evidence to date that lytic promoters can generate proteins during latency. The study also linked this to CD8 T cell activation in latently infected nerve cells with viral gene expression during latency. This is consistent with either limited lytic gene expression being part of latency or early presentation of proteins to CD8 cells halting reactivation by immune mechanism.
Researchers studied the accumulation of a misfolded protein called PrP in the brains of mice infected with three different strains of scrapie, a type of prion disease. They used a technique called dual-staining immunohistochemistry to see where PrP was accumulating in the brain cells. The results showed that each strain had a different pattern of PrP accumulation, with strain 22 mainly in astroglia, strain 7 in neurons, and strain ML in both astroia in thalamus and cortex but in substantia nigra. The researchers also looked at the expression of genes involved in neuroinflammation in the thalamus and found that despite the differences in Pr accumulation, the pattern of upregulated genes was similar for all three strains. The upregulated genes correlated with activation of astroia and microglia early in the disease before vacu pathology or clinical signs. The profile of upregulated genes in scrapie differed from two viral diseases with similar gliosis levels.
Researchers have developed a new approach to study the 3D organization of chromosomes, which is crucial for gene expression and cell function. Chromosomes are long, densely packed, and topologically constrained polymers, making it challenging to model and simulate their behavior. The team created a generic coarse-grained model for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice, accounting for entanglement and volumetric density. This model captures steady-state and dynamic properties and tracks dynamics at different scales, offering a significant numerical efficiency gain and a systematic way to define coarse-grained models for chromosomes. They used this approach to study the evolution of chromosome 3R (20Mbp) in Drosophila during a cell cycle (20h), combining it with a block copolymer model integrating epigen-driven interactions to reproduce experimental data and predict chromatin dynamics is dynamic during the cycle. 

The model achieved high efficiency by introducing rigidity and controlling volume fraction, allowing simulation of chromosome dynamics during a cycle on a desktop within a day. A coarse-grained model for chromatin was built with a copoly framework based on epigen data to investigate folding and dynamics of a large chromosomeR of Doph. This is the first study to describe behavior and evolution of large regions (20M) during a cycle (h) with high precision (10bp). The approach is generic and can be applied to self-avoiding polymers and off-lattice systems, emphasizing neglecting topological constraints leads to erroneous fine-scale description and supplementary interactions may lead to misinterpretation.
Researchers analyzed genetic data from 11 studies on 7 cell types to identify quantitative trait loci (eQTL) associated with gene expression. They integrated QTL data with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project to understand the mechanisms underlying cell specificity of QTL. The study found that QTL associated with hundreds of cell-specific CRE, including enhancers, promoters, repressive chromatin regions, open chromatin, and DNA binding proteins. This provides insight into the molecular mechanisms generating cell specificity of QTL and regulation. A classifier was built to predict cell specificity of QTL using CRE-SNP overlap features, demonstrating its feasibility. The study also showed that CRE from a trait-associated cell can annotate GW associations in the absence of QTL data for that cell. This integrative modeling will improve understanding of complex phenotypic variation in humans.
Researchers have developed a new cell line of Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells that limits glycosylation to early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. This was achieved by using the CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing system to inactivate the gene encoding Mannosyl Alpha-1,3-Glycoprotein Beta-2-N-Acetylglucosyltransferase (MG1), an enzyme involved in glycosylation. The new cell line, called MG1-CHO, produces gp120 proteins with improved binding to glycan-dependent monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) directed to the V2 and V3 domains, while preserving glycan-independent epitopes. The MG-CHO cell line can grow at high densities and does not impair doubling time, making it suitable for biopharm production of HIV-1 immunogens. This is a step towards developing a vaccine that elicits broadly neutralizing Abs (NAbs) that recognize glycan epitopes on the HIV envelope protein gp120. Previous vaccines have failed to elicit NAbs to glycan epitopes due to differences in glycosylation. The new cell line may be used to produce glycan-optimized gp120 vaccine.
Researchers have identified trehalose-6-phosphatase (T6) from the parasitic nematode Brugia malayi as a potential target for anthelmint drugs. T6 is essential for the survival of the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans due to the toxic effects of trehal 6-phosphate accumulation, and is also present in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The X-ray crystal structure of T from B. malayi revealed a stabilizing N-terminal domain and catalytic C-terminal C2-type H phosphat fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses with competitive inhibitor trehal 6-sulf identified five residues important for binding and catalysis. A model of the T6-trehal 6-phosphate complex indicates substrate binding driven by shape complementarity and van der Waals interactions, contrasting with sucrose-6-phosphatase which relies on hydrogen bonds. This suggests high-affinity inhibitors will bind to the phosphoryl pocket and non-native to the trehal pocket. Conservation of key residues in TPP enzymes from parasitic nematodes and pathogenic bacteria indicates a common strategy for TPP design, potentially applicable to antibiotics and anthelmics. The trehal site is dominated by hydrophobic residues, unlike other carbohydrate binding proteins. A model of TPP with trehal 6-phosphate was constructed for inhibitor design. T is present in bacteria, fungi, plants, and invertebrates, but not mammals, and RNAi knockdown of the tps-1 gene causes lethality due to trehal 6-phosphate accumulation. A T inhibitor could bring the same result, making T a target for small molecule anthelmics.
Researchers have developed a new computer model to simulate how fluids move through tumors, taking into account the unique and varied blood vessel structures found in different tumors. This is important because tumors have leaky and disorganized blood vessels, which makes it hard for treatments to be effective. The model uses real data from actual tumors and simulates blood and fluid flow in the tumor in a way that is computationally efficient. It combines two descriptions of blood and fluid flow in the vessels and the space between cells to make accurate predictions of tumor dynamics. The model allows for controlled experiments to be performed to understand how tumor heterogeneity affects fluid transport. The researchers applied the model to two types of tumors, a brain and colon cancer, and found that incorporating realistic blood vessels is key to modeling fluid response. They also found that reducing pressure in the tumor is not necessary to increase fluid flow and that treatments should aim to create a pressure gradient. Additionally, they suggest that stabilizing vessel sizes and permeability is key after treatment and normalizing the environment may increase fluid flow.
Researchers have investigated how the role of cell-to-cell transmission in HIV infection and how it is affected by neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors. They found that neutralizing antibodies that target the CD4 binding site (CDbs) of the virus, such as the potent antibody VRC01, lose potency during cell-to-cell transmission, while those that target the gp41 region remain active. This suggests that CDbs antibodies primarily block free virus transmission, allowing HIV to spread through cell-to-cell contacts. This could explain why HIV maintains infectivity and evades potent CDbs antibody responses in the body. The study shows that neutralizing antibodies, depending on their mode of action, differ in blocking free and cell-to-cell transmission. HIV uses both modes to infect in the body, so the effectiveness of entry inhibitors and antibodies in blocking cell-to-cell transmission needs to be considered. A panel of neutralizing antibodies and inhibitors were tested for potency against free and cell-associated virus. The study aimed to dissect the efficacy of neutral antibodies and inhibitors in cell-to-cell HIV transmission. Neutral antibodies recognize epitopes on the HIV envelope glycoproteins gp120 and gp41, accessible in the oligomeric form. HIV spreads efficiently through various cell contacts, but the action of antibodies during this process is unclear.
Researchers have proposed a new model to explain how attention affects neural responses in the brain, particularly in the visual system. The model suggests that attention's effects on neural firing rates and receptive fields come from top-down modulation of higher visual areas, such as V4 and MT, rather than input areas like V1. The model requires feedback connections between areas and short-range inhibition within each area, redistributing top-down modulation to lower areas, altering inputs of higher cells, including those not initially modulated. This produces rate modulations and receptive field shifts. Simultaneously, short-range inhibition between cells produce competitive effects scaling receptive field size. The model reproduces observed effects on rates (response gain, input, gain, competition scaled field) and receptive structure (shifts, resizing spatial and feature space) without modifying parameters. It also predicts attention effects shift from gain to contrast as focus drifts away from cell.
In Drosophila larvae, a group of specialized cells called the posterior signalling centre (P) controls blood cell homeostasis in the hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland. This role is similar to the microenvironment of hematopoietic stem cells in vertebrates. The P acts non-autonomously to maintain janus tyrosine kinase/signal transducers and activators (J/STAT) signalling in hematietic progenitors, preserving their multipotent character for differentiation into lamlocytes, a cell type required to fight specific threats such as wasp parasit. A study found that a type I cytokine receptor, CG142/Lat, is required to switch off J/STAT signalling in hematiet progen. This is necessary for differentiation of lamytes upon wasp parasitisation. Lat forms heteromers with Dome, a Drosila type cytokine receptor related to mammalian GP130, and antagonizes Dome activity in a dose-dependent manner. An immune response to wasp parasit is a decrease in cytokine mRNA in lymph, followed by increase in Lat/Dome ratio. This sequence leads to inhibition of J/STAT signalling by Lat. J/STAT is associated with human diseases like leukaemia and mouse studies point to its role in hematopoies and immune regulation.
Researchers studied the process of genetic recombination in geminiviruses, a family of single-stranded DNA viruses, during co-infections in tomato plants. They found that recombination patterns between two viruses, Tomato yellow curl virus and Tomato leaf curl virus, were complex and influenced by factors such as local sequence similarity, not secondary structure, and selection against recombinants with disrupted protein and nucleic acid interactions. The study showed that selection favored preservation of co-evolved protein-protein and DNA interactions was strong enough to identify exact sequence tracts involved in these interactions. In contrast to previous experiments, this study found varying outcomes due to the complexity of fitness landscape in tomato and recombinant progeny. Geminiviruses are ideal subjects due to emergence of numerous crop pathogens attributed to inter-species recombination and well-characterized intra-protein, interprotein, and protein-DNA interactions. Local sequence similarity, not secondary structure, influenced recombin sequences. Selection influenced overall patterns of recombination, favoring survival of recombinants with intact protein and nucleic interactions. Recombinants with up to 58 breakpoints were observed, more complex than previously reported in maize virus experiments.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between nucleosomes, the basic units of eukotic chromatin, and evolution. Contrary to the idea that nucleosomes are unique to eukotes, histone proteins have been found in archaea. However, archae nucleosomes differ from eukotic counterparts in many ways, including assembly into tetramers rather than octamers and lack of N and C-terminal tails. Despite these differences, the association between nucleosome footprints and evolution is conserved between humans and the archaeon Halofer volcanii. The study examined whether mutation or selection could explain concord substitution patterns in the two kingdoms, but found neither model sufficient to explain the association. Instead, nucleosome substitution patterns are consistent with a model where sequence results in frequent reposition of nucleosomes during evolution. The study shows that nucleosome reposition is necessary and sufficient to explain the association between current nucleosome positions and biased patterns. This highlights the importance of considering causality between genetic and epigenetic change. 

The study compared substitution patterns around nucleosomes in humans to dynamics in Halofera, a group of halophilic archaea, including the model Halofer volcan, which nucleosome organization was determined at high resolution. Nucleosomes may reflect reposition in response to sequence changes, as both archae and eukotic histones share preference for GC sequence and show similar reposition behavior when sequence changes. Archae nucleosomes differ from euk counterparts, assembling into tetramers, not octers, and wrapping less DNA, with shorter linkers between nucleosomes. Like euk, archae histones form multimer complexes onto bend DNA, sequences with higher GC content in both e and archae. Nucle organization shows dy-oriented trends break in lineages, not consistent with mutation or purifying selection on static nucleosomes. Instead, patterns consistent with local reposition of nucle in response substitutions.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify key positions on a protein that are crucial for its ability to change shape when binding to a ligand. This shape change is important for the protein's function. The method looks at normal modes, or vibrations, of the protein that are involved in this change and how they are affected by mutations. A dataset of 188 protein structures in both with and without ligand was used to test the method. Results show a correlation between mutations that alter these modes and evolutionary conserved positions. These positions are mostly buried, non-polar residues in regular protein regions like beta-sheets and alpha-helixes. They are important for mediating ligand conformation change. The study suggests these positions are conserved due to their role in protein function. Conformation diversity of the native state is central to protein function, with different conformers in equilibrium for ligand binding. Intramolecular motions allow transitions between them. This diversity should be conserved due to its importance. A database of conformation diversity in native proteins has been developed, with collections of structures for same proteins. Lig-free and lig-bound conformations coexist as minima in protein energy landscape. Conformation change between them by intramolecular vibrations.
Researchers studied the role of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldase (FBA) in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M), a bacterium responsible for tuberculosis, to understand its pathogenesis and develop new treatments. They engineered an M strain with reduced FBA levels and found that it was cleared in both acute and chronic infections in vivo and lost viability when cultured on single carbon sources. However, M can co-catabolize multiple sources, so FBA was not essential when cultured on mixtures of glycolytic and gluogenic sources, generating a knockout (Δfba) strain. In vitro studies of Δba showed lack of F could be compensated by balance of glucose and butyrate, with growth and butrate determined by M's ability to coatabol glucose. These results evaluate F as a drug target for both replicating and persistent M, and expand understanding conditions defining M's FBA essentiality in vivo.
Researchers have investigated the role of a specific enzyme called mitochondrial 2-cysteine peroxiredoxin (mTXx) in the parasite Leishmania, which causes leishmaniasis, a disease. They created a mutant version of the parasite that lacked this enzyme and found that it was unable to infect mice. However, this was not due to the enzyme's ability to remove peroxides, as the mutant behaved normally when exposed to peroxides. The mutant was also unable to infect mice that could not produce perox, suggesting that the enzyme's role is not related to peroxide removal. Further, a version of the enzyme that could not remove perox was able to rescue the mutant's inability to infect, indicating a new function for TXx. The researchers propose that TXx acts as a molecular chaper, helping to prevent protein misfolding. This is supported by the enzyme's ability to prevent aggregation of citrate synthase in vitro and the mutant's increased sensitivity to temperature change. These findings change the understanding of 2-cystine periredoxins in trypanosids and show that they can be important for pathogenicity independently of their peroxide activity.
Researchers conducted a multicenter study to evaluate the accuracy of the Histoplas urine antigen (HAg) test for diagnosing disseminated histoplasis (PD) in HIV patients. The study included 288 patients with suspected PD and used the HAg test as a reference standard against Histlas capsulatum growth, blood, bone, and tissue cultures, or histopath exam results. The test showed a sensitivity of 67.1% and specificity of 97.5.5. The positive likelihood ratio was 27.2. In 10.5% of patients with proven PD, a co-infection was diagnosed, mostly Mycobacterium avium complex. The study found a high specificity but low sensitivity of the HAg test, suggesting it may be useful for starting antifungal treatment, but a culture-based approach is necessary due to frequent co-infections and a negative result does not rule out PD. 

A previous study in Brazil reported 100 sensitivity and 92.9 specificity for HAg in 78 proven PD cases among AIDS patients. The current study's sensitivity and specificity are higher than a previous report of 22.7 and 30 from a subset with culture-proven or histopath cases and healthy controls. The US Centers for Disease Control developed a urinary assay validated in 106 patients with culture-proven histlasis, showing 84 sensitivity and 94 specificity. However, results are difficult to compare due to study design.
Researchers conducted a metagenomic analysis of viral communities in stool samples from 12 children with diarrhea to identify the spectrum of viruses, including novel ones, present during acute episodes. They employed a "microassay" sequencing method requiring minimal sample quantity (<100mg), purification, and sequencing (384 reads per sample). This approach allowed detection of known enteric viruses and multiple putative novel viruses with limited similarity to GenBank sequences. The study aimed to assess whether novel or unexpected viruses play a causal role in diarrhea, as up to 40% of cases have no identified etiologic agent. Metagen sequencing enabled systematic and unbiased characterization of microbial populations, providing a foundation for future studies on novel viruses' roles in human diarrhea. 

The study explored viral diversity in pediatric patients with diarrhea, anticipating variation between specimens and desirability to sample multiple patients for overall perspective on diversity. Sequencing afforded systematic exploration of known and novel viruses in stool, laying groundwork for assessing novel viruses' causal role. Microay sequencing defined viral communities in fecal samples from patients, detecting known and novel viruses from few colonies per library. This serves as a springboard for interrogating diverse viruses' roles in the gastrointestinal tract.
A study was conducted in the Dominican Republic to compare the Zika and deng outbreaks using national surveillance data. The study found that 75% of deng cases were reported in individuals under 20 years old, while Zika infections were more dispersed among the population. Dengue rates were higher among males (25.9 per 10,000 population) compared to females (21.5 per 10,000). In contrast, Zika infections were highly clustered among females (73.8%) with age-adjusted attack rates of 7.64 per 10,000 in females compared to 2.72 per 10,000 in males. Stratification by sex showed higher rates among females (1.84) compared to males (1.72). However, GBS rates stratified by sex revealed higher risk in males (0.62) compared to females (0.57). The study suggests little impact of existing deng immunity on Zika attack rates at the population level. Confounding R and incident calculations by sex-specific reporting can alter reliability of epidemiological metrics, which can be addressed using proxy syndromes or conditions to explore sex-skewed incidence. The findings indicate community campaigns influencing short-term health behavior remain plausible behind increased reporting among women of reproductive age, although biological susceptibility cannot be ruled out. Media and screening are recommended for women of reproductive age during Zika outbreaks. Future research should focus on Zika outcomes among deng seropositive individuals.
Researchers have investigated the role of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerases (PARPs) in Arabidopsis thaliana, a plant species, in response to DNA damage and immune responses. Unlike in animals, where PAR1 is the primary PAR enzyme responsible for poly(ADP-ri)ation, PAR2 is the main contributor in Arabidopsis. PAR2 carries a SAP binding motif, not a zinc finger domain found in animal PAR1. PAR2 also plays a significant role in plant immune responses, such as restricting Pseudomonas syringae growth and reducing DNA double-strand breaks. Poly(AD-ri)glycohydrolase (PARG) enzymes were also studied, with Arabidopsis P1 being the primary remover of poly(AD-ri) from proteins. PAR2 activity is influenced by PAR1 and P1, and they physically interact with each other and P1 and2. PAR and P2 are structurally distinct from their animal counterparts, suggesting differences in regulation. In Arabidopsis PAR1 and PAR2 mutants were tested for sensitivity to genotoxic agents, with PAR2 mutants showing reduced poly(AD-ri)ation. PAR1 and PAR2 interact with P1 and2, suggesting regulation through physical interactions. Overall, PAR2 is the primary Arabid enzyme for poly(AD-riation in response to DNA damage.
Researchers have identified a new signaling pathway in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans that regulates the formation of synapses, the connections between neurons. This pathway, called the M-15/JNK-1, opposes the action of the RPM-1 protein, which is involved in synapse formation and axon termination. The M-15/J-1 pathway includes four kinases: M-15, NS-1, JKK-1, and JNK-1, which work together to suppress synapse defects in the mechanosensory neurons of RPM-1 mutants. Overexpression of these kinases in the M-15/J-1 pathway in wild-type animals impairs synapse formation. The M-15/J-1 pathway functions autonomously in the mechanensory neurons and localizes to presynaptic terminals, indicating its role in synapse development. Loss of M-15/J-1 signaling also suppresses habituation to repeated stimuli in RPM-1 mutants, a behavioral deficit likely due to impaired glutamatergic synapse formation. Habituation is consistent with M-15/J-1 functioning as a parallel pathway to RPM-1, indicating it can restrict glutamateric synapse and short-term learning.
Researchers have investigated the role of the TR-1 protein in sex determination in Caenorhabditis brigae and Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that TR-1 is a bipotential protein, meaning it can both activate and repress the same target genes in response to different signals. In C brigae, TR-1 is required for spermatogenesis and works with the Tip60 Histone Acetylase complex to promote the expression of fog-3, a gene needed for spermatogenesis. Epistasis tests showed that TR-1 works with TR-1 to activate fog-3 and control the sperm/oocyte decision. Since TR-1 can also repress fog-3, these observations demonstrate it is bipot. TR- regulates the development of the male tail and two branches of the switch control TR-1 activity. However, the relationship between the two halves of the bipot switch has changed during evolution. C. brigae TR-1 mutants prevent hermaphrodite spermatogenesis, but C-f mutants do not, while C eleg TR- mutants prevent spermatogenesis but C-tr-1 mutants do not. Synthetic interactions confirm both halves of the switch exist in each species. The relationship between the two halves of the bipot switch can shift rapidly during evolution, producing the same phenotype by alternative mechanisms.
Researchers have developed two new measures, ΦE and ΦAR, to quantify the extent to which a system generates more information than the sum of its parts as it transitions between states, reflecting levels of consciousness generated by neural systems. These measures can be applied to time-series data, overcoming the limitations of previous measure ΦDM, which is only defined for discrete Markov systems and rare in biology. Simulations demonstrate the practical applicability of the new measures and explore their properties. The results provide opportunities for examining integration in real and model systems and carry implications for relations between integrated information, consciousness, and neurocognitive processes. However, findings pose challenges for theories ascribing physical meaning to measured quantities.

Previous measures of integrated information were formulated in the context of the Integrated Information Theory of Consciousness (IT), which considers consciousness as a fundamental property of the universe. The new measures, Φ and Φ, are framed in terms of process, easy to apply in practice, permitting testable hypotheses and synthetic models examining the role of information in neurocognitive processes. The ITC ascribes physical meaning to integrated information, considering low value as low conscious level. The distinction carries implications for theories like ITC, which characterize consciousness in capacity, not process.

The new measures, Φ and Φ, can be applied to time-series data from neuroimaging and biological datasets to test intuitions regarding consciousness and neuroognitive processes. They will investigate how integrated is modulated by input and output of a system in and surrounding environment, and theoretically determine the measures under different assumptions and practicality.
Researchers studied the spread of Rhodesian African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Uganda, which has increased in recent years, potentially overlapping with the Gambian form of the disease. They aimed to identify environmental and climatic factors controlling the disease distribution. A previous study used logistic regression to explore the relationship between H prevalence and social, environmental, and climatic variables in two affected districts, suggesting disease spread due to infected, untreated livestock movement. This study extends to account for spatial autocorrelation, uncertainty in data and model parameters, and predictive mapping of future H prevalence. A Bayesian geostatistical model was used, accounting for spatial autocorrelation and uncertainty, resulting in more accurate estimates and increased predictive accuracy. Analysis supports livestock movement of infected animals from endemic areas introduced H to the area. Health care accessibility and land temperature effects on H distribution were also confirmed. Predictive mapping shows increased risk in areas surrounding livestock markets, highlighting trading's role in spread. Treating livestock at sale is essential to prevent spread.
Researchers have challenged the long-held assumption that complexity leads to stability in ecosystems, particularly in the 1970s, and more recently in ecologically-inspired networks. They assumed the existence of a feasible equilibrium with positive abundances, but this assumption has not been tested. Analytical results and simulations show that equilibrium vanishes in species-rich systems, leaving the existence of a feasible equilibrium in stability criteria far from granted. Changing interaction structure and intensity, feasibility and stability are warranted regardless of species richness with weak interactions. Dynamical behavior of ecologically-inspired architectures is different and richer than unstructured systems. Results suggest understanding ecosystem dynamics requires interplay between interaction strength, network structure, and architecture. 

The feasibility of systems is critical to study. May's paradox that complexity decreases stability in models led to exploration of topological structure effects on dynamics. Several works show particular architectures stabilize ecological networks. However, feasibility of different architectures for interaction regimes has not been explored. Feasibility can be easily evaluated. Results indicate information on dynamics will be obtained by concentrating on interplay between structure, strengths, and how strengths are distributed. Many aspects should be taken to reach conclusions about feasibility and stability that fit natural systems. A refinement of May's approach mixing interaction types is considered. In species-rich communities, interactions should moderate equilibrium stability. Simulations study stability in randomly generated architecture mimics empirically observed food webs. Species richness and connectance are treated as independent, but decreases in different systems, restricting parameter space. Topology has been suggested minor role in stability, but architecture plays non-trivial on abundances. Equilibrium is not guaranteed, probability decreases exponentially as network size grows. Weak interactions, non-trivial equilibria found ecologically, ecologically sensible.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Western Kenya to assess the epidemiology of Coxiella burnii, a bacterial pathogen causing Q fever, in humans and cattle. Serum samples from 204 humans and 955 cattle in 416 households were analyzed for C. burnii antibodies, and questionnaires on demographic, socio-economic, and husbandry information were administered. Data were linked to environmental datasets on geographical locations. The overall seroprevalence of C. burnii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle, but no correlation was found between cattle and human serreval within households or spatial proximity. Multilevel analysis indicated factors for exposure included cattle from markets and lower precipitation areas. For humans, the youngest group had highest odds of serositivity, variations observed between ethnic groups and frequent contact with livestock was a risk. Results show endemicity of C burnii in Kenya, with low prevalence. Analysis suggests environmental factors play role in cattle exposure, human patterns likely driven by livestock contact. Implication of markets in cattle exposure suggests a target for interventions.
Researchers have analyzed the genome of the parasite Schistosoma mansoni, a blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis, a major neglected tropical disease. They identified 33 DEAD-box RNA helicases, a family of enzymes involved in RNA processing, and found three vasa-like genes, Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3, which are specific to germ cells. These genes are essential for the development and survival of the parasite. Vasa, an ATP-dependent RNA helicase, is a marker of primordial germ cells in metazoa and was used as a reference to identify the vasa-like genes in S. mansoni. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed that Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3 are members of the Vasa/10 DEAD-box family.
