Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infects the skin through the mucous membrane before entering nerve endings. In the skin, epidermal Langerh cells (LCs) are the first dendritic cells (DCs) to encounter HSV, but it is CD103+ dermal DCs that carry viral antigen to lymph nodes for presentation, suggesting cross-talk in the skin. This study compared topically HSV-1 infected human skin explants with biops of initial human herpes lesions, showing LCs are initially infected then emigrate into the dermis. LC bearing markers of maturation and apoptosis formed large clusters with BD3+ dermal DC (thought to be equivalent to murine CD+ dermal DC) and DC-S+ macrophages. HSV-expressing LC were observed inside dermal DC/macrophages and BD3 dermal DC had upregulated damaged uptake receptor CLEC9. No infected epidermal cells interacted with dermal DC. Correspondingly, LC isolated from skin infected with HSV-1 in vitro underwent apoptosis and were taken by BD3 dermal DC and S+ cells. A viral relay takes place where infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken by dermal DC for antigen presentation. This provides rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or intradermal immunization.
Researchers studied the formation of parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in mouse macrophages infected with Leishmania parasites. They compared PV formation in macrophages exposed to Leish amastigotes of Leishmania major and Leish amazonensis. Tight-fitting PVs, housing one or two L major amastigotes, and giant PVs housing many L amazon amastotes were observed. Using multidimensional imaging, they characterized PV formation and remodeling in macrophages hosting amastotes of L major or amazon and loaded with lysotracker, a lysosotropic probe. Three features of Leish amigote-hosting PVs were documented: entry of lysacker into tight-fitting, fission-prone L major PV, decrease in macrophage vesicles during L major PV and amazon PV enlargement, and amazon PV remodeling homotypic fusion. Multidimensional images provided new insights into Leish species differences in PVogenesis and remodeling, useful for studying other intracellular microorganisms.
Researchers investigated how chromatin structure influences the use of homologous sequences as donors for repair in the chicken cell line DT40. Immunoglobulin genes undergo sequence diversification through gene conversion templated by pseudogene donors. The immunoglobulin V pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. The study demonstrated the importance of chrom structure for conversion using a regulatable system where heterochrom protein HP (Drosoph melanogaster Su) was expressed as a fusion to Escheria lactose repressor, tethered to polymerase operators within the pseudoλ array. Tethered HP diminished histone acetylation within pseudoλ and altered the outcome ofλ diversification, favoring non-templated mutations over templated mutations. Chromatin regulates homology repair. Histone modifications may contribute to genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences.

The study used immunoglob gene diversification in chicken cells as a model for homolog recombination. Mutations accumulated in Lac-1 transfectants resembled thwarted recombinational repair, characteristic of cells lacking transacting factors for recombination or some of the V donor array. HP regulates chrom structure and heteroch gene silencing by partnering histone transferase and deacetylase. Tethering HP to LacO inrosila showed chrom inactivation of neighboring genes. Tethering vertebrate hist methylase to GAL site impaired nonolog-mediated recombination.

Chromatin regulates homolog re has practical implications. Effort is directed toward harnessing homology repair for gene therapy by providing a donor gene to replace deficient. Results suggest permissive structure at the donor will be important in developing genes for therapy. The study manipulated chromatin at Ig locus in DT40, finding pseudo donors acetylated histones, indicating open structure.
Researchers studied how the cerebellum, a part of the brain that helps adjust motor behavior in response to changing situations, learns from past mistakes. It's thought that the cerebellum uses the difference between desired and actual behavior, or "error", to guide learning. This error not only affects immediate behavior but also leads to lasting changes in connections between brain cells that help adjust behavior. Climbing fibers, which connect to these cells, are believed to carry error information for learning but not memory. The study tested monkeys in a task that challenges this idea. They found a clear signal of error at the time of mistake and a repeat of this signal before a new behavior to improve it. This contradicts the idea that climbing fibers only communicate immediate errors. A previous study on short-term sacc adaptation, a model of cerebell learning, found patterns that didn't match this idea. The study looked at how climbing fiber signals relate to motor learning and wondered if they might be secondary to changes in simple spike discharge. A random sacc adaptation task was used to avoid gradual changes and diminishing error that could obscure the error's fingerprint. The study found changes in climbing fiber discharge before upcoming sacc were a reflection of past errors. The role of climbing fibers in sacc learning has been debated with conflicting findings. It's thought they convey information for future behavior improvement through two types of fibers, climbing from the olive.
Researchers have studied the protein TDP-43, which is often found in the cells of people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a neurodegenerative disease that causes loss of motor neurons. In a yeast model of ALS, they found that overexpressing T-43 causes cell damage and reduces the cell's ability to break down misfolded proteins. They also found that overexpressing the protein S1, a type of chaperone, reduces T-43's effect on cell damage and protein breakdown. This effect was influenced by the presence of a yeast protein, Pin1. Overexpressing S1 changed T-43's pattern, but did not physically bind to it, suggesting an indirect effect on T-43 aggregation. Overexpressing the mammalian S1 homologue, DNA1, relieved T-43 toxicity in rodent neurons, suggesting S1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS. T-43 aggregation is associated with ALS and other diseases and overexpressed T-43 is toxic in yeast and mammalian neurons. The study found that T-43 inhibits the cell's ability to break down misfolded proteins by the ubiquitin proteome system. There are many chaperones in mammalian cells, one of which, DNA1, is similar to S1. The researchers overexpressed WT and mutant T-43 with familial ALS in rodent neurons and found that overing S1 and DNA1 reduces T-43 toxicity. This study identifies S1 as a modifier of T-43 toxicity and suggests S1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS.
A study was conducted to investigate the parasite load and molecular diversity of Trypanosoma cruzi in patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. Sixty-five patients were recruited, aged 26-76, with a median of 54 years, 34 females and 31 males. Thirty-five (53.8%) presented amplification by real-time PCR, 20 (30.7%) with the indeterminate form and 15 (23.1%) the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite load for all positive patients was 2.54 [1.43-11.14] parasite/mL, ranging from 0.12 to 153.66.66. Notably, the load was higher in patients over 70 years (20.05 [18.29-86] parasite/mL). Using guanidine-ED blood spiked with T. cruzi strains, it was possible to genotype up to 0.5 parasite/mL with high specificity. Of patients positive PCR, 28 (80%) were identified T. cruzi DT, while 20% had partial results. Analysis showed prevalence of TVI, TII, and mixed TVI+II equal 40%, 17.1%, and 14.3%, respectively. Two were infected by TV and one co-infected by III+VI, all in chronic chag cardiomyopathy stage, born in Bahia State, northeast Brazil. T cruz genotypes compared to load showed elevated loads in infected II (7.56 parasite/mL) compared to VI (2.35/mL). However, frequency of cardiomyopathy was 50% in VI and 16.7% in II.
A study on rabies in bats was conducted in Guatemala between 2009 and 2011, as part of a larger pathogen detection program. A total of 672 bats from 31 species were sampled and tested for rabies virus (RV). The prevalence of RV among all bats was low, at 0.3%. Viral antigens and infectious virus were detected in the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotus). RV was also found in oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, while viral RNA was detected in all tissues except the liver of one. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein showed both viruses were 100% identical, while glycoprotein sequencing revealed one nonsynonymous substitution. The two vampire RV isolates were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in eastern Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, 7% of 398 sera from bats demonstrated RV neutralizing antibodies. The proportion of seropositive bats varied across troph guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RV perpetuation.
Researchers investigated the role of lamin A in herpes simplex virus (HSV) replication and found that it plays a crucial role in targeting the viral genome to the nuclear periphery and reducing heterochromatin on viral promoters. HSV replication compartments were smaller and failed to target the periphery in lamin-deficient cells compared to wild-type cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies showed HSV associated with increased heterochatin in lamin-deficient cells. This suggests lamin is required for viral expression, replication, and growth, with greatest effect on replication at low multiplicity of infection. Lamin/C serves as a scaffold for DNA and protein complexes regulating euchatin and heterochatin modifications. The study provides evidence for lamin-dependent targeting of HSV to the periphery associated with reduction of heterochatin on lytic genes and suggests a role in lamin maintenance of heterochatin and silencing.
Researchers studied the structure of the TOM (translocase of the outer membrane) complex in hydrogenosomes, a type of mitochondria found in the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. Hydrogenosomes are metabolically anaerobic, meaning they don't use oxygen to produce energy, and are found in excavates, a group of eukaryotes. The TOM complex is crucial for importing proteins into mitochondria, but its structure varies between eukotic lineages. The study found that the hydrogenosomal TOM complex, TvOM, has a divergent β-barrel structure and forms a trans channel for protein import. It's composed of four subunits: Tom40, Tom36, Tom46, and Tom22, and an outer membrane protein19. Tom40 and Tom46 have domains that bind to hydrogenosomal proteins, likely acting as receptors. Tom22 has a short domain and conserved transmembrane segment but lacks a domain. Protein19 has no known homology. The study also found that TvOM is associated with sorting and assembly machinery, involved in β-bar assembly. Electron microscopy revealed TvOM has three pores and an unusual skull-like shape, despite lacking Tom7. Phylogenetic profiling predicted Tom7 in freeivingates. The results suggest that the triplet-p TOM complex, composed of three conserved subunits, was present in the last eukotic ancestor, while receptors for substrate binding evolved in different euk lineages.
Researchers have studied the role of CD4 and CD8 T cells in autoimmune diseases, which occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own cells. They analyzed genetic variations in these cells to understand how they contribute to disease. The study found specific genes associated with autoimmune diseases in CD4 and CD8 cells, including a region on chromosome 12 that affects the R26 gene. A variant in the IL27 gene was linked to type 1 diabetes, reducing protein activity and expression of IR1 and STAT in CD4 cells. This suggests IL27 may promote autoimmunity in the pancreas by upregulating the STAT pathway. CD4 regulatory T cells play a key role in controlling autoimmune diseases. Genome studies have identified thousands of genetic variations linked to immune diseases. This study mapped genetic variations in CD4 and CD8 cells, revealing effects on genes associated with autoimmune diseases, showing high specificity and sensitivity. A variant in the R26 gene may affect protein stability or translation of many mRNAs, but its role in type 1 diabetes is unclear. Other genes in the region, such as IK4, ER3, and CD2, may also be involved. A variant in IL27 was found to significantly affect IR1 and STAT in CD4 cells, suggesting it may promote autoimmunity in the pancreas by upregulating the STAT pathway.
In the Democratic Republic of Congo, socio-economic factors and cultural barriers hinder the uptake of screening and treatment for Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT). A qualitative study was conducted in two provinces, Bandu and Kasai Oriental, to understand these barriers. Interviews with current and former H patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the National Trypanosomiasis Control Program revealed prohibitions after H treatment: no work, no sex, no food, and no sun exposure. Violating these restrictions is believed to cause severe and deadly complications. These prohibitions are well-known by the community, leading people to avoid H screening due to fear of observing tabo upon diagnosis. Originally to mitigate melarsol's adverse effects, they are now obsolete with new safer drugs. Health providers must address community concerns through dialogue to keep up with treatment transformations.

The study aimed to understand these prohibitions' origin and rationale to improve H control in DRC, coordinated by the National Trypaniasis Control Program. Medical advice on H management transformed into tabo, impacting suboptimal uptake of H screening. Tabo might be abandoned with safer options, as seen with NECT. Restrictions negatively affected participation and adherence. Their origin unclear, whether self-imposed or provider-imposed, and basis unknown. Given impact, perceptions were explored in depth. Conducted in provinces with high H prevalence, where tabos identified. Not explored in lower prevalence areas. Follow-up after H no longer recommended by WHO. Non-participation compromises control objectives, explained by multiple factors, including community-enforced prohibitions associated with H treatment.
In Eastern Sudan's Gedare State, Médecins Sans Frontières has been treating patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) at Tabarak Hospital since 2009. A survey was conducted to estimate VL incidence in villages around Tabarak. Between May 5-17, 2011, an exhaustive door-to-door survey was done in 45 villages of Alure locality. Deaths were investigated by verbal autopsies. Individuals with fever for at least two weeks, VL diagnosed in previous year, and clinical post-kala-azar dermal leishiasis (PKDL) suspicion were referred to medical teams for ascertainment. A new VL case was a suspect with positive rk39 rapid or direct agglut test. In 45 villages, 17,702 households were interviewed for 94,369 inhabitants. Crude rate over 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people. VL was possible probable cause for 19% deaths. VL-specific rate was 0.9/100 per year. Teams examined 551 for fever at least two weeks, 16 diagnosed primary VL. Incidence over year 7.0/100 persons or 7.9/100 when possibly due were included. 12.5% reported past treatment. VL represents significant burden in Gedare State. Active case detection had low yield with adequate care, not priority to enhance in similar contexts.
Researchers studied how supercoiling in bacterial chromosomes is controlled in Escherichia coli and Salmonella. They found that supercoiling occurs in two forms: diffusible and constrained. Diffible supercoils are free to move around the chromosome, while constrained supercoils are caused by proteins that bend, loop, or unwind DNA. Both forms contribute equally to total supercoiling in cells. However, Escheria coli has 15% higher supercoiling than Salmonella. To understand how diffible supercoiling is controlled, they analyzed Salmonella with a supercoil sensor inserted at 10 positions around the genome. The sensor monitored supercoiling and transcription rates in wild-type and mutant strains. Transcription increased supercoiling upstream and decreased it downstream of highly expressed genes. Topoisomerase I relaxed excess supercoiling, while gyrase replenished it to maintain equilibrium. Strains with gyrase mutations at permissive temperature showed supercoil losses from 30% of WT to total loss at most locations. Supercoiling was influenced by transcription, as rifampicin caused superco to rebound throughout the chromosome. Gyrase mutants also reduced transcription rates throughout the genome. The study found a link between RNA polymerase elongation and gyrase turnover, suggesting fast-growing bacteria may have higher supercoiling than slow-growing species.
Researchers studied how the parasite Leishmania amazonensis, which causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, grows inside host cells. They found that the parasite grows in parasitophorous vacuoles (PV), which are similar to late endosomes and lysosomes, and that expand during infection. However, the impact of PV size on parasite survival was unknown. The study showed that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate the gene LYSTBe, which regulates lysosome size. Mutations in LYSTBe caused PV expansion and enhanced L. amazonensis replication, while overexpression of LBe led to small PV that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of LBe overexpressing cells with vacolin reversed this, expanding PV and promoting growth. The opposite was seen with E-64, which reduced PV in LBe mutant cells and inhibited amazon replication. Large PV appear to protect parasites from oxidative damage, as inhibition of nitric oxide synth had no effect on amazon viability in large PV, but enhanced growth in LBe-induced small PV. The study found that upregulation of LBe in infected cells functions as a host response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV and inhibiting intracellular survival.
Researchers have been trying to understand the mechanisms and treatments for psychomotoration, a condition characterized by motor and cognitive impairment. Allan-Hndonudley syndrome (AH) is an X-linked psychotoration characterized by delayed development, severe intellectual disability, muscle hypotonia, and spastic parapleg, with disturbed thyroid hormone (TH) parameters. Mutations in the monocarboxyl transporter 8 (M8) gene, a TH transporter, have been associated with AH. To determine the pathophysiology of AH, M8 knockout mice were studied, but they replicated abnormal TH levels, but not neurological symptoms. An M8 mutant zebraf were generated using zinc-finger nuc (Z) mediated gene editing. Elimination of M8 decreased TH levels, but not other TH-related genes. Similar to patients, M8 larvae exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies. High-throughput assays showed reduced locomotor activity, response to light and dark transitions, and increased sleep. Deficiencies were associated with myelin and neuron formation. Time-lapse imaging revealed reduced filopodia, axon branching, and synaptic density in sensory and motor neurons. This suggests M8 regulates neural assembly, mediating sensory and motor performance. Administration of TH analogs restored myelin and axon growth in M larvae.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a common virus that affects newborns and immunocompromised or immunosuppressed patients. It infects various cell types using different entry pathways involving forms of the g/g glycoprotein: g/gL/g, gL, and g/UL-131, as well as the fusion glycoprotein B. However, the minimal core machinery for cell fusion is gL and B. This study shows that CMV B and g/g form a stable complex early in the absence of other proteins. g can interact with B mutants unable to mediate cell fusion. B-gL complexes make up to 16-50% of total g in CM virus particles. In contrast, small amounts of g/gL and g/UL-131 complexes are associated with B. Herpesviruses express B and g/g molecules, and most models suggest g interacts B to mediate fusion, but there is no direct evidence. For herpes simplex virus (HSV-1), it has been suggested that after binding gL binds B either before or coincident with fusion. This study's results have implications for these models, demonstrating CM B and g form stable B-gL complexes in virions without receptor or fusion. Data supports the proposal that g interacts B.
Researchers have discovered a gene called Gimap that plays a crucial role in regulating the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in a specific types of cells called leukocytes. Mitochondrial DNA is the genetic material found inside the mitochondria, the energy-producing structures within cells. The segregation of mtDNA variants, or mutations, determines the onset and severity of certain diseases. In this study, scientists used a mouse model to show that Gimap, an outer membrane protein, regulates mtDNA in leukocytes. Gimap is essential for cell development and survival, suggesting that cell survival may be a factor in regulating mtDNA variants and human diseases.

The study found that Gimap is the first nuclear-encoded gene influencing mtDNA segregation in mammals. It regulates the rate of mtDNA in hematopoietic tissues, which produce blood cells. The segregation of mtDNA in these tissues is complex and age-dependent, but not related to the number of mtDNA copies. A variation in the G3 gene, called CASTi, changes the protein sequence but not its membrane anchoring domain. The protein localizes to the mitochondrial outer membrane.

Gimap's role in younger mice is unclear, but it's critical in regulating mtDNA in hematietic tissues. The protein doesn't directly interact with mtDNA as it doesn't span the membrane. Overexpression of G3 in cells didn't affect heteroplas levels. This suggests a cell-specific pathway is required for mtDNA segregation. Mitochondrial copy number may influence mtDNA segregation and human mutations.
Researchers in Victoria, Australia studied the incubation period of Buruli ulcer (BU), a skin and soft tissue infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, to understand how long it takes for symptoms to appear after exposure to the bacteria. Most people who get BU live in areas where it's common, but in Victoria, a significant number of cases come from visitors to these areas. The researchers looked at 443 cases between 2013-2016 and found the mean incubation period, or time between exposure and symptom onset, was 143 days (4.8 months), similar to a previous estimate of 135 (4.5) months. This was despite the area where people got infected shifting from the Bellarine to Morning peninsula. They found no link between incubation period and age, sex, exposure duration, or location of the lesion. The study confirms the incubation period of BU in Victoria is 4-5 months, which can help guide clinicians and suggests the mode of transmission is similar in different regions.
Researchers have identified a protein in the Toxoplas parasite that is related to the human Niemann-Pick type 1 protein (NPC), which plays a crucial role in cholesterol regulation and lipid trafficking. The protein, named TCR1, shares similarities with NPC and contains residues associated with human disease. Unlike NPC, TCR lacks endosomal targeting signals and localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the parasite's plasma membrane. When expressed in mammalian NPC mutant cells, TCR restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from endosomes. Disrupting TCR in the parasite results in normal cholesterol levels but overaccumulation of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyins, and ceramides. The mutant parasites exhibit abundant lipid storage bodies and membranous tubules from parasitoph vacuoles. They replicate faster in vitro and are more virulent in mice than the parental strain. This suggests TCR's role in lipid homeostasis in Tooplas is to control intracellular lipid levels, leading to stimulation of storage, biosynthesis, and division.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the SMOC1 gene as the cause of ophthalmoacelic syndrome (AS), a rare disorder characterized by eye malformations, including anophthalmia, and postaxial oligodactyly. Homozygosity mapping and targeted mutation analysis of the SM1 gene on chromosome 14q24 identified mutations in eight unrelated families, four of which were nonsense, frameshift, and two missense. Missense mutations were in the thyrogulin-1 domain of the protein. The mouse ortholog, Sm1, shows site and stage-specific expression during eye, limb, craniofac, and somite development. A targeted gene-trap mutation of Sm1 reduced mRNA to 10% of wild-type levels, resulting in highly penetrant hindlim postax oligodactly in homozyg mutant animals. Eye malform, coloma and cleft occurred in a proportion of mutant embryos and pups. Loss of Sm1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the disease. SM1 is a mammalian paralog of Drosoph Pentone, an inhibitor of decaplegic, and Xenopus Sm1 functions as BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagon during mammalian development explains limb and eye phenotypes in humans and mice.
Researchers have found that a protein called TRIM22 plays a key role in restricting the replication of the HIV virus in human cells treated with type 1 interferon. They identified TR22 as one of the most upregulated genes in cells treated with interferon and confirmed that overexpression of TR22 inhibited HIV replication. To understand the role of TR22 under natural conditions, they compared the effects of interferon in cells depleted of TR22 using RNA interference and found that HIV release was significantly increased in knockdown, indicating TR22 acts as an antiviral effector. Further studies showed that TR22 inhibited the release of virus particles containing Gag, indicating G was the target of TR22. TR22 did not block the release of ML or EIA G particles. Inhibition was associated with diffuse cytoplasmic staining of G rather than accumulation at the plasma membrane, suggesting TR22 disrupts proper trafficking. Mutational analyses of TR22 showed that catalytic amino acids Cys and Cys of the R domain are required for TR22 antiral activity. The study discloses a pathway by which type 1 interferons obstruct HIV replication.
Researchers studied the relationship between fig trees (Ficus) and their specific pollinators (Agonid wasps) to understand why this mutualism is stable. In figs are pollinated by wasps that lay their eggs in the tree's "fruits" (syconia). However, not all wasps can lay eggs in all parts of the fig, and some areas are more vulnerable to parasitic wasps that lay eggs from outside the sycon. The study found that in one fig species, Ficus rubosa, outer areas are more vulnerable to parasitic wasps, but inner areas are safer. This difference in viability may encourage wasps to focus on inner areas, reducing galling rates and contributing to mutualism stability. This is a new explanation for why wasps favor inner areas for oviposition, previously unexplained by other factors such as plant defenses or pollinator constraints. In most fig species, syia receive more wasps than needed, leaving some seeds unexplained, suggesting parasitic wasps play a role in stability. The fig-poll mutualism is a classic example of obligate mutualism, where wasps pollinate and trees provide resources for was offspring. Parasitic wasps may contribute to this stability by selecting inner areas for oviposition due to reduced parasitism. The study shows wasps gain fitness by choosing inner areas with lower parasitism, controlled by the fig, the larger partner in the symbiosis.
Researchers studied how genetic and environmental factors affect plant height in a specific type of grass called Setaria. They grew a group of plants with a mix of genetic traits from two different types of Setaria, one wild and one domesticated, in controlled environments with varying water and density. The study found that plant height is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors, with water and density affecting growth. The results suggest that plant height is a complex trait controlled by multiple genes that work together, but can be influenced by environment. The study also found that genetic factors that control height change over time, with some genes affecting early growth and others later in development. The researchers identified 37 genetic locations associated with height in the plants, but found that only a small part of these are from known genes from other plants in the same family. The study contributes to understanding how plant growth is influenced by genetic and environmental factors over time, which is important for understanding how traits are determined. Plant height is a key component of architecture, easy to measure, and important for agriculture, making it a focus of study for over a century.
A study was conducted in the Pantanal wetlands of western Brazil to investigate the circulation of zoonotic arboviruses, which are viruses that can be transmitted between animals and humans. The region is home to a diverse range of wildlife and hematophagous arthropods, such as mosquitoes, which can facilitate the spread of these viruses. Previous research had shown that horses in the area had antibodies to various flaviviruses, including the Ilus virus (ILV), but virus isolation had not been confirmed. To further investigate, 3,234 adult mosquitoes from 16 species were collected in 2009-2010 and tested for infectious virus and flaviral RNA. One pool of 50 non-engorged female Aedes aegypti mosquitoes tested positive for ILV by culture and real-time PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1,000. The full genomic sequence showed 95% identity to the only available ILV genome. This confirms ILV circulation in the Pantanal. The region's wetlands host diverse wildlife and arthropods, favoring zoonotic virus circulation. Despite scarce data on arboirus vectors, local mosquito species reported as vectors have been found in the north and south Pantanal. In 2009, a flavivirus survey among equines in the Ncolia sub-region detected past infection with increasing seroprevalence, Cipore virus, West Nile, Louis encephalitis, and IL. The Pantanal is a seasonally flooded 140,000 km. The high prevalence of IL antibodies in horses combined with IL isolation in mosquitoes confirms an arv of medical importance.
A preclinical study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of single-dose mectin (MO) as a new oral treatment for scabies compared to two-dose ivermectin (IVM) in a porcine model. Scabies is a common dermatological condition affecting millions globally, but current treatments are insufficient and resistance is emerging. MO has a more favorable pharmacological profile, making it a promising alternative. Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive MO (0.3mg/kg once) or IV (0.2mg twice) or no treatment. Treatment efficacy was assessed by mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S scabei Ig antibodies. Plasma and skin pharmacokinetic profiles were determined. At 14 post-treatment, all MO-treated pigs were mite-free, while only two IV-treated were. MO efficacy was 100% and unchanged until study-end, compared to 62% (26-100) for IV. Clinical scabies, pritus, and anti-Sabei Ig antibodies disappeared in all MO-treated but 75% IV-treated. MO persisted 9 times longer in plasma and skin, enabling long-lasting efficacy. The study demonstrates single-dose MO was more effective than consecutive IV, supporting MO as a therapeutic approach for scabies.
Scientists have studied the process of peptoglycan (PG) synthesis in Staphlococcus aureus, a type of bacteria that causes infections and is resistant to many antibiotics. PG is a key component of the bacterial cell wall and target of many antibiotics. The researchers created a strain of S. aureus with the minimum number of proteins needed for PG synthesis, deleting seven of the nine genes responsible for this process. The remaining two proteins, penicillin-binding protein 1 (PBP1) and bi-functional protein 2 (BP2), were enough for the bacteria to grow and divide. However, in real-world environments, this minimal PG machinery made the bacteria more susceptible to antibiotics and weakened its ability to cause infection in fruit flies, which rely on specific PG receptors. This shows that most PG enzymes are redundant in the lab but important for survival and virulence in the wild. The study aims to identify targets for new antibiotics that inhibit the final stages of PG synthesis.
Researchers studied the bacterium Burkholderia pseudallei, which causes a difficult-to-treat disease called meloidosis in humans. Despite proper diagnosis and treatment, mortality rates are high, ranging from 20% in Australia to 40 in Thailand. Little is known about how the bacterium infects, invades, and survives in hosts, and its iron acquisition mechanisms. It was thought to use common iron-acquisition systems found in other bacteria, but a previous discovery of a clinical isolate with a large chromosomal deletion of the malleactin gene, which encodes its major-affinity siderore, showed other systems might contribute to virulence. The researchers deleted the major siderore mactin and pyelin gene clusters in a strain and found residual activity unrelated to known Burkia siderores, not due to increased secretion of chelators. Deletion of the hem uptake loci showed H is required for utilization of hem and hemoglobin, and cannot complement a deficiency. Prolong incubation of H mutant in hemoglobin medium yielded variants able to utilize hemoglobin and hem, suggesting alternate pathways. Utilization was dependent on mact, not pyelin synthesis/uptake. A quadruple mutant could use ferritin as source and was lethal in murine meloid model. Data suggest Burkia may employ a ferritin-iron pathway to sustain in vivo.
Researchers have developed a new tool called COMM (COnsensus Metabolic Model GENeration) to improve the accuracy of genome-scale metabolic models by reconciling inconsistencies between different models of the same organism. These models, called genome-scale constraint metabolic models (GSMs), provide a comprehensive representation of cellular function but are often hampered by inconsistencies. COMM automatically identifies similarities and differences between models and resolves them, resulting in a more accurate and comprehensive representation of metabolic function. The tool was tested on four organisms and showed that automatically generated consensus models were predictive and increased coherence of knowledge. This tool is particularly useful for complex scenarios where manual curation does not scale, such as eukaryotic organisms, microbial communities, and host-pathogen interactions.

 Genome-scale metabolic models are integrated knowledge and predictive models. A consensus model should be more comprehensive than individual models due to shared and unique parts, and accurate due to reconciliation of inconsistencies. COMM reconciles two or more GSMs of the same organism beyond common namespace. It identifies similarities, dissimilarities, and complements of metabolic networks based on classification problems during integration and algorithms to resolve. Identifying similar reactions in different compartments is difficult but an extension could progress this by combining metabolite information prior to matching. COMM forms a bridge between automation and high-quality curation for consensus model generation.

Genome-scale models are organism-specific knowledge repositories integrating entities, metabolites, reactions, and genes. Automatically generated consensus models have higher predictive power than manually curated models and comparable to manually constructed models. COMM increases coherence with biological while maintaining power. This is important for usability and reliability to elucidate interactions.
Researchers have identified two genes, famb and xyl1, that play a crucial role in the development of cartilage and bone in the body. Cartilage is a type of connective tissue that provides cushioning and support to joints, while bone is the hard, calcified tissue that makes up the skeleton. Cartilage cells, called chondrocytes, interact with a protein-rich matrix and undergo a process called maturation, where they express genes that induce bone formation in the surrounding tissue, perichrium. The study used zebraf mutants to investigate the interaction between cartilage and perichrium and found that cartilage inhibits chrocy maturation, which determines the timing of perichral bone development. Mutations in famb and xyl resulted in decreased cartilage and increased perichral bone formation. Positional cloning identified the genes, which encode enzymes that synthesize proteoglycans, a type of protein found in cartilage and perich. Mutants lacked normal levels of chroit sulfate, a key component of cartilage, and formed perichral bone earlier than wild-type siblings. Chrocy defects may induce bone formation secondarily due to premature maturation, shown by increased expression of markers such as run2, collagen 10, and ih. Ultrastructural analysis revealed aberrant matrix and cellular features of chro hypertrophy in mutants. The study demonstrates that famb and x1 function in cartilage production and regulate the timing of skeletal development.
Researchers studied the role of Topoisomerase II (Top) in the separation of heterochromatic regions during meiosis in Drosila melanogaster females. They found that knocking down Top in the later stages of meiosis resulted in defects in the separation of heteroch regions after spindle assembly. In Top-expressing oocytes, heteroch regions of achmate and chmate chromosomes failed to separate during prometaph and metaphase, and were stretched into long projections with centromeres localizing near the tips. Despite this, bipolar spindles were formed in Top-express oocytes, but achmate chromosomes failed to move towards the poles during prometaph. Both ach and chmate chromosomes showed defects in orientation. Euchromatic regions separate earlier in prophase, no defects were observed in their separation upon Top knockdown at midphase. Embryos from Top-express females failed to initiate mitotic divisions. The study suggests Topois II is involved in resolving heteroch DNA entang during meiosis and these entang must be resolved to complete meiosis.
Researchers conducted a study to evaluate the effectiveness of using deltamethrin-impregnated collars as a public health measure to prevent canine visceral leishmaniasis (CV) in a highly endemic area in Brazil. The study took place in two areas: an intervention area where dogs were collared and a control area with conventional CV control measures. At baseline, seropositive dogs were removed and seronegative dogs included. Dogs were reevaluated every 7-8 months for two years. In the intervention area, serone dogs received new collars and serone dogs were included. Authorities were notified of seropitive dogs in both areas, which were euthanized as mandated by the Ministry of Health. The first serological survey showed similar seropreval in both areas. The second evaluation showed significant reductions in serreval in both areas, with 6.0% in the intervention and 11.0 in the control. The relative risk (RR) indicated protection against CV in the intervention. Although CV incidence didn't differ, a tendency was observed in the control, possibly due to low seroconversion or loss to follow-up. Deltamrinimpregnated collars likely provide protection over time in endemic areas.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the structure of the X chromosome and gene expression levels in mammals. They found that the X chromosome has a non-random gene content, which is often discussed in the context of sexual antagonism and avoidance in the germline. However, they propose that the biased gene content may be shaped by the limits on gene expression due to haploid expression of the X. Using data from the Encyclopedia of DNA (ENCODE) and Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome (FANT5) projects, they found that the maximal expression of X-linked genes is lower than autosomal genes, with an average expression three times lower on the X than autosomes. Autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower expression of retrogenes on the X than X-to-autosome retrogenes on autos. X-linked genes have a lesser increase in expression than autosomal ones compared to the human-chimpanzee ancestor if highly expressed, but not lowly expressed. The "traffic jam" model explains the lower breadth of expression for genes on X and Z, as broad expression is associated with high expression. Highly tissue-specific genes are rare on X, and broadly expressed genes on X tend to be lowly expressed, indicating the trend is shaped by maximal expression not breadth. A limit to maximal expression explains biased tissue profiles of X-linked genes. Tissues with specific genes highly expressed (e.g., secretory, structural) are in gene rare on X. This cannot be accounted for by alternative models of biased expression. The notion that X is hard for genes to be highly expressed due to transcription jams provides a rationale for features of X content, expression, and evolution.
A recent study investigated the prevalence and population structure of Helicobacter pylori, a gastric pathogen, in Baka Pygmies, a subgroup of Pygmies from Cameroon. The results showed a significantly lower infection rate of 20.8% among Baka compared to 80.2% in non-Baka agriculturalists. Multilocus haplotypes were generated for each isolate, but no Baka-specific lineages were identified, with most assigned to hpAfrica or hpAfrica populations. The hpAfrica population, associated with the Nilo-Saharan language family, was divided into East and West African subpopulations, while hp1, mainly found in Cameroonians, supported Bantu language expansions. An age-structured model suggested low H. pyl prevalence in Baka within a few hundred years due to demographic factors such as small size and low life expectancy. Baka were either H pyl-free or lost lineages during past fluctuations. Coalescent simulations and phylogenetic inference showed Baka acquired H pyl through contact with agricultural neighbors. 

The study analyzed 178 Cameroonians, 77 Baka and 101 non-B, by bacterial culture from gastric biopsies. Among Baka, 46.8% were male, mean age 38.9, while non-B 21.8% male, mean 46. Similar age differences for males and females. High H pyl prevalence was found in non-B. The population structure of H pyl in Baka and Pyies was unknown. Bantu agriculturalists have high H pyl rates, but bacterial structure unknown. H pyl from non-B multiple groups to quantify gene flow between hunter-gather and agriculturalists. H pyl from agriculturalists, whom Baka acquired B language, were tested.
Dengue virus NS5, a highly conserved non-structural protein, plays a crucial role in capping and replication of the flavivirus genome and interacts with host proteins to modulate immune responses. Unusually, DENV2 NS localizes to the nucleus, but its role in replication and pathogenesis is unclear. Researchers examined NS of DENV1 and 2, which differ in localization, using a combination of functional and structural analyses. Gene swapping identified the C-terminal 18 residues (C18) of NS as sufficient to direct the protein to cytoplasm or nucleus. Low-mic affinity between NS C18 and nuclear receptor importin-alpha (Imp) allowed complex purification and crystallization at 2.2 Å resolution. Structure-guided mutational analysis revealed critical residues for NS subcell localization. Notably, proline 884 allows Imp binding, mutating to threonine in D1 NS results in mislocalization to cytoplasm without compromising virus fitness. Mutation to alanine at position 888, conserved in flaviviruses, results in non-viable virus, while R888 mutation leads to attenuated phenotype. R forms hydrogen bond with Y conserved in flaviruses. Data suggests conserved function C18, possibly in RNA interactions critical for replication, independent of subcell localization.
Researchers developed an integrated mapping protocol, called the Integrated Threshold Mapping (IT) Methodology, to control and eliminate neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) such as lymphatic filariasis (LF), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths (STH). The protocol is designed to be efficient and determine whether a threshold for public health interventions has been reached in a unit. It relies on World Health Organization (WHO) recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups. The study tested the protocol by comparing it to current mapping methodologies for each disease in one district in Mali and Senegal. Results were compared in terms of public health intervention and feasibility, including cost. The IT methodology reached the same conclusions as WHO regarding initiation of public interventions for trach, LF, and STH, but resulted in more targeted recommendations for schosiasis. It was practical and demonstrated an overall saving compared to standard, non-integrated WHO methodologies. The integrated tool could facilitate implementation in endemic countries. 

The IT methodology determines if a disease has reached threshold for public intervention by balancing epidemiologic rigor and practicality. It is logistically practical, cost-efficient and flexible. For schosias, the approach results in more targeted MDAs compared to district implementation by integrated NTD programs. The protocol uses age-specific indicators as recommended by WHO. The study tested the protocol in one district in Mali and Senegal, comparing to current methodologies for each disease.
In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the phosphatase C14 is required for exit from mitosis and is anchored to nucleolar chromatin by the C1/Net protein until anaphase, at which time it is released into the nucleoplasm. Two pathways, the FEAR (C fourteen early release network) and MEN (mitotic network), promote C14 release, but the mechanisms are poorly understood. Researchers found that ubiquitination of histone H2 by the ubiquitin ligase Bre1 is necessary for C14 release from nucleolar chrom when MEN is inactivated. This function is mediated by histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79, but not histone deacetylase (HD) Sir2, which associates with C14 onolar chrom as part of the RENT complex. Defects in C14 release were also observed in cells lacking H3 lysine methylation and in cells with HD recruited by this modification. These histone modifications are new factors for accessibility and/or action onolar chrom of FEAR components. A redundant role for these modifications contrasts the notion of a combinatorial code of histone marks controlling biological processes.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework called GeneProgram to analyze large datasets of human gene expression data. The goal is to identify groups of co-expressed genes that orchestrate normal or pathological processes and characterize the breadth of these groups. Gene uses Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes to address challenges such as cellular heterogeneity within samples, genetic variation across samples, uncertainty in number of groups and populations, and temporal behavior. Gene organizes tissues and genes into overlapping programs with consistent behavior, producing maps of programs sorted by generality scores that exploit learned groupings. Using synthetic and real data, Gene outperformed popular analysis methods. Applied to a compend of 62 time-series expression datasets, Gene produced a map of 104 programs, many enriched for genes in key pathways and bound by NF-κ transcription factors. Discovered programs implicating surprising pathways or types in response to infection, including Wnt and neurotransmitter receptors. The map will guide future experiments; genes with low generality may be new targets, and high generality maintain common responses in disease states. Gene is multipurpose and can be applied to novel data.
Human cytomegalovirus (CMV) drives epigenetic imprinting of the interferon-gamma (IFN) locus in NKGChi natural killer (NK) cells. NKGChi cells, a subset of NK cells, play a crucial role in defense against CMV and produce IF-γ. Research showed that NKGChi cells in CMV seropositive individuals undergo epigen remodeling of the IF conserved non-coding sequence 1 (CNS1) region, similar to memory CD8+ T cells and TH1 cells. The C1 region enhances IF transcription activity in response to NKG2 and 4 engagement, leading to IF-γ production in NChi NK cells. Epigen imprinting of the IF locus is a hallmark and crucial mechanism driving stable IF- expression in CMV-specific NK expansions, providing a basis for regulation of adaptive features in innate cells.

NKGChi cells in CM+ individuals and cytok-primed NK cells, described as memory-like NK, share an open configuration of the IF locus. The C1 is a crucial enhancer of IF transcription in TH cells, especially in response to TCR triggering. To analyze epigen regulation of IF locus contribution to IF competence and stability in memory-like NK, CM-specific NChi expansions and cytok-prim cells displayed an open at IF C, acting as enhancer of IF activity in response N2 and activating receptors engagement. Epigen imprint in C of IF locus is a hallmark and underlying adaptive features IF- in NK. Epigen remodeling accompanies adaptive features, demonstrating both inflammatory and pathogen induce epigen remodeling NK.

CMV infection shapes the NK repertoire and epigen features of memory-like NK and T cells. It is unclear to what extent adaptive NChi expansions depend on low viral reactivation events in healthy CM+ individuals.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which the bacterium Legionella pneumophila regulates its effector proteins within host cells. An effector proteins are molecules secreted by the bacterium to manipulate host cellular processes for infection. Temporal regulation is crucial for distinct effector activities at different stages of infection. The study found a protein, Lub, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, hijacks the host proteasome to target another effector, Sid, for degradation. Delayed delivery of Lub to the cytoplasm leads to shutdown of Sid at later stages of infection. This demonstrates a sophisticated co-evolution between host and bacterium involving an effector as a key regulator of cognate effector function. 

The regulation of Sid by Lub and the host proteasome illustrates a novel mechanism of effector regulation. Previously, membrane ruffling by Salmonella effectors was shown to be susceptible to ubiquitin-mediated degradation. Lub acts as a negative regulator of Sid within host cells, the first example of an eff that targets a cognate eff within host. The designation "metaeffector" is proposed for this class of bacterial effectors. Determinants of susceptibility are encoded in effectors themselves. Sid is an intrinsically stable within cells; Lub controls instability by targeting for ubiquination. Lub represents a metaeff, an eff that regulates another eff within host.
Researchers studied the evolution of HIV-1 in 81 individuals in the early stages of infection to understand how the virus adapts to its new host and immune system. They found that some parts of the virus's genetic code changed rapidly, more than expected, suggesting adaptation to the host's immune responses. This rapid change was seen in 24 sites, 14 of which were in areas targeted by the immune system's T-cells (CTL) and 10 in areas where the virus's genetic code was altered by APOB, a mechanism that helps the virus escape immune response. Some sites were both targeted by CTL and APO, suggesting APO facilitates early escape. Other sites changed rapidly, but not due to CTL or APO, including the most mutated site in the virus's fusion protein gp41. The study also found that insertions and deletions in the virus's envelope protein were due to selection, not random mutations. This research provides insight into how HIV-1 adapts in new hosts, highlighting the role of CTL and APO in shaping the virus's evolution during early infection.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to understand how epigenetic silencing works in yeast, focusing on two key chromatin marks: H4 acetylation and H3 methylation. They found that having both modifications is crucial for the stability of epigen states. The model shows that under certain conditions, chromatin can have both active and silenced marks, a state called bivalent. This bivalent state is stable under perturbations such as mutations or inhibition of enzymatic activity. The researchers also found that a limited supply of silencing proteins can lead to counterintuitive responses. They investigated the design of the silencing system and compared it to experimental observations, including the role of Sir protein, spreading, and stability of silenced regions in mutants like Sas2 and Dot1. The model can be extended to include other silencing and active marks, like methylation, to understand which marks are essential for epigen fate and which reinforce one over another. The model captures mechanisms of cooperativity at the molecular level in yeast silencing, including histone modification and protein interactions. Active chromatin sites are not only acetylated but also hypermethylated at certain residues. One protein, Dot, methylates H79 and competes with Sir for the same patch on histone region. Co-occurrence of sil and active marks, called bivalent chromatin, has been discussed in Poly silencing and HP binding. The model shows how bivalent states emerge from known interactions.
Researchers in Uganda studied the gut microbiota (GM) of children hospitalized with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) to see if it differed between those with edemat and non-edemat forms of the condition. Edemat malnutrition, also known as kwashiork, is the most severe form of SAM. The study included 87 children aged 6-24 months, with 62% having edemat malnutrition and 66% being boys with a mean age of 16.1 months. GM composition differed between the two groups, with non-edemat children having lower diversity. However, beta diversity analysis did not show significant differences between the GM of edemat and non-ed SAM children. The study suggests non-ed SAM children have lower GM diversity, but no clear compositional differences were found. Previous research links GM to malnutrition, with pathogenic bacteria in the guts of malnourished children. A study transplanted fecal samples from Malian twins discordant for edemat mal, kwashi, into germ-free mice. GM dysbiosis is associated with malnutrition, but it's unclear if GM differs between edemat and nonemat SAM. The study's finding of GM diversity differences justifies further research on therapeutic strategies.
Researchers studied the variation in telomere length in 112 wild-type Saccharomy sensu stricto isolates, a type of yeast, and found extensive variation in telere length among them. The variation correlated with their geographic origin, with European isolates having shorter telomeres (<150bp) and American isolates having longer telomeres (>400bp). They inserted a URA gene near the telomeres to analyze individual telere lengths and telomere position (TPE) and found that crossing American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telere lengths, suggesting multiple loci are involved in length. Variation in TPE was weakly correlated with telere length. Genotyping F1 segregants indicated several quantitative trait loci (QTLs) associated with telere length and silencing variation, including candidate genes and regions with no known telom properties. They detected transgressive segregation for both phenotypes and validated by reciprocal hemizosity that YU and TLC are telere QTLs in two S paradox subpopulations. They propose sequence divergence within Kuod generates negative epistasis in allelic combinations (American-YU and EuropeanU) resulting in short teleres.
Researchers investigated how people make decisions when they are not forced to respond immediately, but can take their time to gather information. Traditional models, called sequential sampling models (SMs), assume decisions emerge from a gradual accumulation of evidence, making response times (RTs) predictable. However, these models don't account for when people choose to delay or terminate the process. A new SM was developed to predict RTs from electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies, where participants bought or rejected stocks based on sequentially presented cues and could respond at any time. Standard SMs didn't accurately describe RT distributions, but adding a mechanism for postponing decisions improved the fit. Time-frequency analysis of EEG data showed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta frequencies (14-30Hz), indicating responses were prepared and inhibited, supporting the existence of a decision to not decide. The model also accounted for results of an adapted paradigm where participants pressed a button for more information. Results show computational modeling supports understanding of hidden dynamics in cognition.
Researchers identified a genetic mutation in the SUVH2 gene as the cause of hereditary nasal parakerosis (HN) in Labrador Retrievers, a rare skin disorder leading to crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study of 13 HN cases and 23 controls revealed a strong association on chromosome 2. Resequencing of one case's genome detected a non-synonymous variant in the SUVH gene, a histone lysine 9 (H3) methyltransferase, which mediates chromatin silencing. The variant c.972G>T is predicted to change a conserved asparagine to lysine in the catalytically active domain of the enzyme. Histopathological analysis of the epidermis in vivo suggests HN is not caused by hyperproliferation but delayed differentiation of kerocytes. SUVH is involved in epetic regulation of kerocyte differentiation, ensuring proper stratification and sealing of mammalian epidermis.
Researchers investigated the emergence of transmissible reassortant viruses during co-infection of avian and swine influenza A viruses in swine. They found that swine can serve as a "mixing vessel" for generating reassortants of avian and mammalian influenza viruses that could pose a risk to mammals, including humans. Genomic analysis of 571 isolates from nasal samples and respiratory tissues of co-housed pigs (influenza-negative, avian H1N1 IAV-infected and swine H3N2 IAV-infected) identified 30 distinct genotypes of reassortant viruses. Viruses from lower respiratory tissues had the largest diversity, while those from turbinate and nasal fluids had the least. Reassants from lower tracts had the largest variations in growth in respiratory epithelial cells, and temperature in sw nasal cells selected the type of reassant shed by pigs. One reassant in nasal samples was consistently identified in upper, middle, and lower tract, and was efficiently transmitted between pigs. The study suggests that during co-infections of av and sw IAV, reassortments likely occur in lower tracts and tropism is a factor for selecting transmissible reassant.
A study was conducted to investigate the effect of maternal Schistosoma mansoni infection and prazantel treatment during pregnancy on Schistoma mans infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at age five. Offspring of Schistoma-infected women in endemic areas may be sensitized in utero, which may influence their immune responsiveness to Schoma infection and associated morbidity. The study examined the effects of prantel treatment of S mans during pregnancy on the risk of mans infection among offspring and their immune responsiveness when exposed to mans. In a trial, offspring of women treated with prant or placebo during pregnancy were examined for mans infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SW and SEA, as well as T cell expression FoxP at five. Of 134 children, 2.4 had mans infection at five years based on single sample. Infection did not differ between treated or untreated. Cytokine IF, IL, IL, and IL and antibody Ig, Ig and Ig responses SW and FoxP were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazant treatment mans during pregnancy had no effect on responses, exception IL to SW which was higher offspring women received prazant than did not. No evidence found maternal mans infection and treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence intensity mans infection or immune response mans infection offspring five years, but observed on IL suggest mans and treatment during pregnancy may affect immunoreg responsiveness childhood schosiasis.
Macrophages play a crucial role in clearing infectious pathogens from the body, but the process of how they are activated to do so is not fully understood. Researchers have discovered that inflammatory stimuli can reprogram the macrophage's endocytic machinery to switch from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macinocytosis, allowing for rapid transfer of internalized cargo to lysosomes in a receptor-independent manner. This reprogramming occurs through protein kinase-mediated phosphorylation of the macrophage protein coronin 1, activating phosphoinositol (PI)-3-kinase activity necessary for macinocytic uptake. Expression of a phosphomim form of coron 1 is sufficient to induce PI-kinase activation and macinocytosis even without inflammatory stimuli. This suggests a previously unknown mechanism for regulating internalization and degradation of infectious material during inflammation. Macrophages can internalize large amounts of cargo for direct transfer to lysosomes upon activation. Phosphorylation of coron 1 is the key switch from phagytic to macinocytic mode. Expression of a phosphim coron 1 mutant resulted in mycobacteria being transferred to lysosomes for elimination regardless of macroage state. Macroph expressed a phosphim glutamic acid mutant coron 1, Ig-coated beads were internalized through macinocyt in absence interferon. Phosphorylation of coron 1 is crucial for switch from phag to macin uptake upon macroage activation.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in Arua District, North Uganda to assess the acceptance of tset baits (insecticide-treated targets) in communities where they had not been previously used. The study involved focus group discussions with male and female participants in eight villages across the district. Results showed that villagers who had never seen the baits before expressed fear and anxiety due to associations with witchcraft and "ghosts from the river", which are linked to illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers in areas where ba had been used previously had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. The latter group reported similar negative perceptions when tse control started a decade ago. The study suggests acceptance varies between villages and is related to duration of experience with tse programs. Success of community-based interventions against tse will depend on engagement and sensitization that reaches all communities, especially new areas. Community acceptance is vital for effective tse control, as seen in a previous study in DRC where negative attitudes led to damage and failure. The study was conducted in an area where government programs against Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) have been used. Efforts to enhance community participation in tse ba range from encouragement to active construction and maintenance. In all studies, acceptance was crucial for success. Three years before the study, 70 ba were deployed per parish, but efforts did not result in sustainable tse control due to lack of monitoring and maintenance.
Researchers have studied the process of recombination in fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) to understand its role in evolution. Recombination is a process where genetic material is exchanged between chromosomes, increasing the effectiveness of natural selection in populations. However, previous studies have been limited due to lack of detailed understanding of recombination rates across and within species. This study provides the first high-resolution description of genomic and population variation in recombination, distinguishing between two outcomes: crossing over (CO) and gene conversion (GC). The researchers analyzed 5,860 meioses of Drosila melanogaster, genotyping 139 million SNPs and mapping 106,964 recombination events at 2-kilobase resolution. This allowed for whole-genome CO and GC maps, as well as detailed variation in recombination among individuals. The study found large-scale variation in recombination rates, with hotspots and coldspots along chromosomes, and intra-specific variation associated with hotspots at low frequency. Gene conversion rates were uniformly distributed across the genome, detectable in regions with reduced or absent CO. Local recombination events were associated with sequence motifs, occurring within transcript regions, suggesting chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks. This variation in recombination needs to be considered in population genetic models to understand interaction between selection and linkage.
Researchers have identified ID2 (ID2) as a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thalian, but its function in RDM was unknown. They purified ID2 and found it co-purified with two ID paralogs, ID1 and ID2. The coiled domain between the X and X domains of ID2 is essential for ID homodimerization, while the X domain is required for ID interaction with ID1 and ID2. Introducing wild-type ID2 and mutated derivatives into the id2 mutant showed that the uncharacterized X domain is required for ID-ID1/ID2 formation and function. ID1 is required for de novo methylation, RNA accumulation, and transcriptional silencing, while ID2 has overlapping roles with ID1. Unlike ID2, ID1 and ID2 cannot bind double-stranded RNA, suggesting their roles differ from ID2 in the ID-ID/ID complex and are essential for RDM.
Researchers studied how neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, respond to Leishmania braziliensis, a type of parasite. Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to the site of infection. In Leish brazili infection, depletion of neutils significantly increases parasite load. However, co-culture of neutils and L brazili had opposite effect, inducing parasite killing. The study focused on interaction between neutils and Lili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized Lili promastigotes mice neutil in vivo, peaking at 24 hours. In vitro exposure of inflammatory bone marrow neutils to Lili modulated expression of molecules CD18 and CD62, and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-express Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected not bystander cells. Neutil activation with Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils infected Lili but not L major displayed markers of apoptosis. Lili induces neutil recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed to parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This may impact parasite elimination at early stages of infection.
Researchers explored the potential benefits of vaccination as a supplementary control measure for bovine tuberculosis (TB) in cattle. Currently, vaccination is not used in international control programs and is prohibited in the EU due to interference with the tuberculin skin test, used to determine if herds and countries are officially TB-free. New diagnostic tests, Differentiated Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIV), offer the potential to introduce vaccination into existing eradication programs. Using herd models from historical data in Great Britain, they estimated the feasibility of supplemental vaccination. The economic impact of bovine tuberculosis on farmers is dominated by costs associated with testing and restrictions on animal movements. Farmers' willingness to adopt vaccination requires not only reducing the burden of infection but also the risk of restrictions imposed. The study found that under intensive testing in GB, the specificity of DIV test rather than sensitivity is the greatest barrier to herd benefit of vaccination. The negative effects of vaccination could be mitigated through testing relaxation, potentially increasing hidden infection in officially free herds. Models explored the range of DIV characteristics necessary for a protective level of vaccination, estimating a specificity of at least 99.85% and sensitivity of 40% required. Data from experimentally infected animals suggest this target could be achieved with a cocktail of DIV antigens while maintaining sensitivity of 73.3% relative to post-mortem detection.
Researchers have identified a new class of compounds called dihydrobenz[e][1,4]azin-2(3)-ones that show promise as a potential treatment for Trichuris, a parasitic worm infecting over 500 million people worldwide. Current treatments are limited and ineffective, hindering eradication efforts. Using a mouse model for Truris, a library of 480 small molecules was screened for activity against adult parasites, leading to the discovery of dihydrozazepones with anthelmint activity. Further screening and synthesis of related compounds identified 20 active dihydrozepinones, a new class not previously implicated in nematode control. The most potent compounds immobilized adult Tris with EC50 values around 25-50μM, comparable to existing anthelmint levamis, with low cytotoxicity against murine epithelial cells, showing selectivity for the parasite. Dihydrozepin O029 also reduced embryonated Tris eggs' ability to infect mice in vivo, suggesting a potential for a therapeutic that acts in the environment, interrupting the parasite lifecycle. These results demonstrate dihydrozepones as a new anthint active against both egg and adult stages of Tris, with selectivity and scope for optimisation to improve potency and pharmacokinetic properties for a clinical agent.
Researchers have re-examined the concept of "date" and "party" hubs in protein-protein interaction networks, where "date" hubs have low co-expression with partners and "party" hubs have high co. They found that the importance of "date" hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of extremely central hubs, which do not display low expression, contradicting the idea of a link between quantity and function. The "date/party distinction was motivated by an approximately bimodal distribution of hub-expression, but this feature is not robust to methodological changes. Topological properties of hubs do not correlate with co-expression, but there is a significant correlation between centrality and functional similarity of interacting proteins. The authors suggest conceiving roles for protein-protein interactions rather than individual proteins is more useful.
Researchers have developed methods to reconstruct transmission trees of infectious diseases using whole genome sequences, but a major limitation is the need for genetic diversity to occur on epidemiological timescales. This means that the position of individuals in a transmission tree can only be resolved by genetic data if mutations have accumulated between pathogen genomes. To address this, the concept of "transmission" is introduced, defined as the number of mutations separating genome sequences from transmission pairs. Using literature values, scenarios are simulated with two evolution models to describe transmission of major pathogens. Results show that mean transmission varies between pathogens, but is generally low, with many outbreaks having genetically identical pairs. This limits the ability to reconstruct outbreaks using genetic data, especially for pathogens with low transmission like Streptoccus, Shigella, and Clostrid. Conversely, rapidly evolving pathogens like RNA viruses provide valuable information on individual events. The study highlights limitations of genetic data in certain scenarios and the need to expand tools to integrate other epidemiological data.
Researchers studied how genes on the X chromosome that escape inactivation, a process that silences most genes on one X in female mammals, in mouse tissues and cells. They analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes with single nucleotide polymorphisms to identify escape genes and mechanisms. A continuum between silencing and expression from the inactive X (Xi) was found, with few genes escaping in most tissues (3-7%) but more in embryonic-kid-derived Pki cells (21%). Alle-specific RNA polymerase occupancy and DNase hypersensitivity at promoters correlated with escape, indicating open chromatin structure. CTCF binding on Xi was denser in brain compared to Pki cells, contributing to compartmentalized Xi and fewer escape genes in brain.

A minority of genes escaped X in tissue and cell-specific manner, indicating X and escape are tightly controlled. Bi-allelic versus monoallelic expression probability was calculated using an algorithm applicable to any gene. Surveys in human/mouse cells showed 8-15% consistently escape, 10-13 variable, and 10-20 varying between lines/individuals. Escape results in sexual dimorphisms and bi-alle expression is important for normal females. Mouse 3-7 escape may differ from other mammals with similar human patterns. Pki cells had more escape than tissues, possibly epigenetic changes or cell property.

Escape genes were distributed along X, not influenced by distance from XIC, and play roles in transcription/translation, dosage-sensitive. Tissue-specific genes were identified for sex differences.
Researchers have identified a novel cystine protease, VX-4, in the parasite Plasmod viv, which is a major cause of human malaria worldwide. This protease is involved in the parasite's survival and egress from the erythrocyte. VX-4 has different properties compared to its orthologs in other Plasmod species, showing strong affinity to rodent Plasmod. Recomb VX-4 has dual specificity depending on the microenvironment pH, with highest activity against benzyycarbonyl-Le-Arg-ethyl-amide at acidic pH 5.5 and against Z-Arg-M at neutral pH 6.5-7.5. It prefers positively charged amino acids at P1, with less specificity at P3 and P4, which depends on pH. Three amino acids in the S pocket are different in VX-4 compared to VX-2 and VX-3. Replacement of Glu180 abolished activity against Z-Arg-M at neutral pH, indicating its importance in pH-dependent preference. VX-4 is localized in the vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocy stage of P. viv. It shows maximal activity at neutral pH and against P. viv plasm and hemoglobin at acidic/neutral pH. VX-4 demonstrates pH-dependent switching, which might cleave different substrates in intracellular environments. It might function as hemase in acidic foodu, mase P viv plasm at neutral/acidic, and cytos-degrading in erythrocytos.
Researchers have developed a new genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME) for the bacterium Clostridium ljungahli, a type of acetogen that can ferment a wide range of substrates. This model, named iL965ME, captures all major metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for these reactions. It's the first ME model of a Gram-positive bacterium and broadens predictability. The model shows how protein and media allocation influence metabolic pathways and energy in acetogens, and accurately predicts secretion of multiple products. Predicting overflow metabolism is crucial for designing new strategies, such as glycerol production, a novel product for C. ljungahli, expanding its metabolic capability. The model also predicts changing secretion rates based on metal availability, opening fermentation optimization and knowledge about proteome and carbon flux in acetogens. 

The iLME includes major metabolic, amino, acid, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin synthesis pathways, and RNA and protein synthesis for catalyzing reactions. It also includes WLP with cofactors and mechanisms for energy conservation. The model predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycer during carbon and metal availability revealed protein and media influence metabolic and energy in this acetogen.
Researchers used a panel of human osteoblast cells to conduct a transcriptomic survey, similar to previous studies in lymphoblast cell lines, to investigate the genetic control of transcript variation. The study found that osteoblast and lymphlast cells have distinct gene expression profiles, with tissue-specific and functionally relevant pathways. They performed cis-association analysis with single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to identify genetic variations in transcript forms and found that differential expression of transcript forms in osteoblast is partly controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants. These forms are regulated by variants in both tissue-specific and tissue-independent manners, confirmed by RT-PCR validation. The study suggests that multiple transcript forms are present in both tissues and genetic may affect the expression of one form over another, rather than an all-or-no effect. Examination of top SNPs from genome-wide association studies of bone density showed overlap with associations in this study, including the FAM118 gene, which was tested in additional clinical studies revealing a novel transcript variant. This approach to examining transcript variation in multiple tissues is useful for detecting common genetic variation between cell types and identifying cell-specific variants that may be functionally relevant, an important follow-up for genome-wide association studies.
Researchers studied the yeast Saccharomyces eayan, a parent of the lager-brew hybrid Saccharcesorian, to understand why it can't use maltotose, a key sugar in brewer's wort. Unlike most Saccharces cerevisiae and Saccharorian strains, Sacchar eayan can't use maltose, which is encoded by the MAL gene family and requires transporters for uptake. Sac eayan strain CBS57 has genes for α-glucos maltose uptake but lacks maltose transporters. Sac cerevis sequence suggests maltose and maltose transporters evolved from a shared gene. To study maltose utilization in eayan CBS57, mutants were evolved on maltose-enriched wort and showed improved maltose and maltose fermentation. Whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel SeALT gene from gene introgression of three SeALT genes. The predicted structure SeALT is similar to original transporters but overexpression enabled growth on maltose, indicating neofunctionalization. The mosaic SeALT resembles Sacorian maltose-transporter SpY with high identity to cerevis MAL1, parayan MAL1 and eayan SeALT.
Researchers have developed a new method to estimate the impact of influenza virus strains on human mortality by studying the relationship between the virus's antigen variation and the number of deaths it causes.
