The model incorporates running cost and dependence on exertion, revealing dependencies of distance to glyc depletion and pace.
Researchers studied how different strains of Toxoplas, a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis, interact with mouse immune cells called macrophages. They infected mouse macrophages with 29 different Tooplas strains from around the world and used a technique called RNA-sequencing to look at the genes expressed by both the parasite and the host. The study found large differences in gene expression between strains, including some that affect how the parasite interacts with the host. They also identified novel host pathways regulated by atypical Tooplas strains, such as the type I interferon response, which helps kill the parasite without the need for interferon gamma and is dependent on Toll-like receptors and a protein called RIG. 

The study found that non-canonical Tooplas strains have unique interactions with host cells, which may explain why some strains cause more severe disease in humans. They also showed that Tooplas strains differ in how they activate the inflammatory response, a key part of the immune system. The study provides a global view of how host and parasite respond to infection with both typical and atypical Tooplas, and identifies strain-specific host responses and parasite effectors. The results suggest Tooplas adapt to certain hosts, as different species show large differences in susceptibility and Tooplas differ in virulence in the same species.
Researchers have investigated the process of recombination in enteroviruses, a mechanism that allows viruses to acquire new genetic material and is thought to contribute to the emergence of new disease-causing variants. Despite its importance, the process is not well understood. They used a new approach to isolate chimeric poliovirus genomes with duplicated sequences at the recombination site and found that viruses with imprecise junctions had increased fitness. Mutations affecting polymerase or replication altered the yield of recombinants but not non-recombinant viruses, indicating the process is replicative and can be enhanced or reduced. The study proposes that recombinants result from a biphasic process: initial recombination followed by resolution of extraneous sequences and optimization of fitness. This has implications for understanding evolution in positive-strand RNA viruses.

A panel of poliovirus type 1/type 3 recombinants with 21% sequence divergence showed 70% contained additional sequences and 85% distinct junctions. In contrast, another study found sequence and structure correlated with recombination hotspots. Most recombinants contained sequences within the recombination region. Since previous recombin poliruses did not, imprecise recomants might be disadvantageous. Inhibiting polirus replication with guanidine hydrochloride yielded no recombinants. Cloned intra-type recombinants showed conservation at the junction, making recombination identification difficult. The study suggests recombination is biphasic, generating imprec followed by precise recombinants with enhanced fitness.
Researchers have identified a new route for the clearance of norepinephrine (NE) in white adipose tissue, which is mediated by the organic cation transporter 3 (Oct) in adipocytes. This route is distinct from previously known routes such as sympathetic neurons or macrophages. Oct is highly expressed in white adipose tissue and has the greatest uptake rate of NE compared to other routes. Adipocytes express high levels of degradation enzymes Mao, Maob, and Com, providing molecular basis for NE clearance by adipocytes with reuptake Oct. Administration of Oct ablation induces higher thermogenesis and lipolysis compared to littermate controls. After prolonged cold challenge, inguinal white adipose (W) in adip-specific Oct-deficient mice shows stronger browning and elevated thermogenic genes than litter controls, involving β-adrenergic receptor (β-AR)/protein kinase (PK)/cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-responsive binding (Cre) pathway. Glycolytic genes are reprogrammed higher to compensate for loss of ATP in adip-specific Oct knockout (KO) mice, indicating fundamental role of glucose metabolism beig. Inhibition β- largely abolishes higher lipoly and therm activities in Oct-deficient W, indicating NE overload in vicinity adipocytes Oct KO. Reduced alleles in OCT are associated with increased basal metabolic rate (BMR). Oct governs β-activity as NE transporter in whiteocytes, offering therapeutic applications for metabolic disorders.
HP1 proteins play a crucial role in regulating gene expression by interacting with chromatin. They have two domains: the chromo and chromadow. The chrom domain binds to histone H3 when it's methylated on lysine 9, but in vivo and vitro experiments show that HP proteins don't bind well to methylated chromatin. This led researchers to investigate if HP have other histone binding activities. They found the chromadow domain interacts with histone H in a region inside the nucleosome. This region is also contacted by the SWI/SNF complex's catalytic subunits. In vitro, SW/SNF needs this contact to remodel chromatin and is blocked by HP proteins. This antagonism is seen in vivo on interferon-regulated genes. SWNF helps load HP proteins onto chrom in vivo and vitro. The study suggests HP chromadow domains use nucleosome opening to bind chromatin and HP use this to stop chrom remodeling.
Researchers have identified a property called "self-containment" in RNA molecules, which refers to their tendency to maintain a specific secondary structure regardless of their surrounding sequence context. They developed a scoring method called the self-containment index to measure this property and found that microRNAs (miRNAs) exhibit high self-containment, consistent with their requirement for structural invariance during biogenesis. In contrast, most other structured RNAs do not show self-containment. Analysis revealed a trend towards higher self-containment among conserved miRNAs, suggesting it may be a characteristic of miRN acquiring new genomic contexts. miRNAs display enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs, with a trend towards natural selection for self-cont in functional classes. The study suggests self-cont arises from selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis, and modular composition of function. Containment analysis is important for RNA annotation and design.
Researchers have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that play a crucial role in limiting the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens, such as Botrytis cinerea and Plectphaella cucina. Mutants defective in any of these TFs showed increased susceptibility to these pathogens, indicating their importance in disease resistance. Transcriptome analysis revealed a common signature of 77 up-regulated genes in these mutants, including several encoding secreted peptides named PROIR (provulence factors). Forward and reverse genetic analysis showed many PROIRs contribute to disease susceptibility to necrophic pathogens. The TFs and PROIRs identified are novel determinants of plant susceptibility to necrophic fungal pathogens.
A transcription factor called FOXO1 plays a crucial role in making the uterus receptive for embryo implantation. The uterus needs to be in a specific state to allow the embryo to attach and grow. If the uterus is not receptive, it can lead to failed pregnancies or unsuccessful in vitro fertilization attempts. Researchers found that removing FOX1 in the uterus using a mouse model resulted in infertility due to changes in the lining of the uterus, preventing the embryo from attaching. Analyzing the uterus after FOX1 removal showed changes in genes involved in cell invasion, transport, apoptosis, and signaling pathways. Progesterone receptor (PGR) signaling increased due to P being present in the uterus lining during receptivity. Constitutive expression of P in the lining during receptivity inhibited FOX1 in the nucleus of the uterus. In human samples, P and FOX1 expression were found to be reciprocal during the proliferative and secretory phase. This suggests that FOX1 and loss of P during receptivity are related and critical for implantation. The interaction between the embryo and receptive uterus is necessary for successful implantation, and the uterus conditions are regulated by progesterone via P-mediated activity. P interacts with factors for endometrial receptivity, including FOX1. FOX1 ablation in the uterus affects multiple pathways, including P and inflammatory and growth factors required for proper function. Transcript analysis showed activation of the P pathway. Observations indicate spatiotemporal and localization of FOX1 and P in the epithelium requires mutual regulation for implantation. FOX1 expression was analyzed with P in human endrial tissue across the menstrual cycle. It is possible that FOX is involved in downregulation of P, leading to infertility. FOX and P may be in a regulatory relationship in the epithelium at the window of receptivity, substantiated by sequestration of FOX in response to constitutive P in nuclei during implantation.
Researchers developed a statistical model to map the spread of deng cases in Bangladesh, accounting for under-reporting and spatial and temporal effects. They analyzed district-level data from 2000 to 2009, using a negative binomial generalized linear mixed model with integrated Laplace approximation. The study found that mean temperature and its interaction with mean diurnal temperature lagged by two months were significantly associated with deng incidence, while mean rainfall two months prior was positively associated. Densely populated districts and those bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated 92% of annual deng cases occurred between August and September, with 94% in the capital Dhaka. Less than half of affected districts reported cases were observed from surveillance data, varying by month with higher in high-incidence districts and lower towards the end of transmission.
Researchers have identified a new type of preferred location in mice called "knots" that are characterized by high tortuosity, or winding paths with twists and turns, during exploratory behavior in an open field. These locations, termed "knots", are distinct from "home bases" which are marked by frequent visits and high cumulative time spent. Mice tend to visit nots sporadically, tracing them with a tortuous paths, and perform a behavior called "knotcribbling" during these visits. Nots are typically established at the point of introduction into the arena, away from walls, and are not characterized by high inbound speed and low outbound speed. The establishment of nots is enhanced by injecting mice with saline and placing them in an exposed portion of the arena, suggesting stress and arousal consolidate a long-term contingency between locale and notcribling. In an environment devoid of proximal cues, mice mark a locale with twisting and turning, creating a self-generated, centrally located landmark. The tortuosity of path during notcribling implies multiple views of the environment, allowing recalibration of the mouse's locale and compass directions. Rich vestibular input from notcribling may improve interpretation of the scene.
Researchers have identified a potential new target for antifungal compounds in a protein called Sec14, which is essential for the growth and virulence of the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans. The compound NG04, an ergoline, was found to inhibit the growth of C. neoans with selectivity over mammalian cells. High-resolution chemogenomics identified Sec14 as the target of NG04, and mutations in Sec14 defined the compound interactions in the binding pocket of the protein. Sec14 is involved in lipid transfer and virulence in pathogenic fungi, making it an attractive antif target. NG04 inhibited growth of two clinical isolates of C. neoans and related compounds showed equal or higher potency. NG04 also showed fungicidal activity against fluconazole-resistant C. neoans strain. Sec14 is conserved in S. cerevisiae and C. neoans, with critical sites for NG04 sensitivity conserved. Testing NG04 and related ergoline analogs against C. neo was prioritized due to high medical need. NG04 binds to fungal proteins in a similar way, with conserved residues Y, Y, Y, Y, S, and T. In vitro, NG04 showed anti-cryptoccal activity and potent derivatives were identified. Secp-dependent virulence is only described for C neo, but not other pathogens.
Researchers have investigated the antischosomal properties of mefloquine, a drug used to treat malaria, in mice infected with Schistosoma mansoni and S japonicum, two major schistosome species. A single oral dose of meflo (200-400mg/kg) resulted in 72.3-100% to 100% worm burden reduction in adult worms, and high reductions in young stages of S mansoni and japon in mice. Both meflo enantiomers showed comparable worm reductions in mice with subpatent or patent S mans infection. These findings suggest a potential for a new antischosomal drug based on aminoal functionality. Further in vitro and in vivo studies aim to elucidate meflo's mechanism and effect on S haematium and other trematodes. Mefloquine, used to treat malaria, may also impact schosomias in areas where both diseases coexist.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to map the distribution of podoiosis, a non-filar elephantiasis causing massive swelling of the lower legs, identified as a neglected disease by WHO in 2011. A multi-stage sampling design stratified the country by environmental risk of podoiosis, with 76 villages from 40 districts in 10 regions surveyed. Individuals 15 years old or older were house-to-house screened for lymphedema. A clinical algorithm diagnosed podoiosis excluding filarial lymphema. Individuals with lymphema were tested for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen and IgG using Alere Filasis Strips and Standard Diagnostics BIOLymphatic filasis Ig4 tests. No microfilar W bancft were found in blood of individuals with lymphema. 52 people with podoiosis were identified after applying the algorithm. Prevalence of podoiosis was 0.5% (95 CI 0.4-0.7). At least one case podo was found in every region except Adamawa. 40 districts had no cases, 15 had 0.2-1% and 8 had 1.2-2.7%. The study demonstrated low but widespread podo in Cameroon. Designing podo control is vital. A health response to burden podo is important through surveillance and morbidity services.
Researchers investigated how aging affects the ability of germline stem cells (GSCs) to occupy their niche in Drosophila. They found that Notch signaling increases with age in Gs, leading to their removal from the niche. Analysis showed that Gs with low levels of Notch signaling have increased adhesion to the niche, outcompeting neighbors with higher levels of Notch. Adhesion is altered through regulation of E-cadherin expression. Enhancing Not signaling in Gs hastens age-dependent loss from niche, and is partially mediated by lethal. Disrupting Not signaling in Gs does not delay loss during aging or affect BMP signaling, which promotes self-renewal of Gs. In contrast, Not activation in niche maintains niche integrity and mediates G retention, and is reduced with age. This suggests Notch regulates G-niche adhesion both intrinsically and extrinsically. The study reveals a novel role of Notch in G-niche response to aging and is relevant to metastatic cancer, where Not suppresses cell adhesion.
Researchers studied the conserved herpesvirus protein kinases (CHPKs), a group of kinases encoded by eight human herpesviruses, to determine if they share cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk) activity. They found that the beta and gamma herpesvirus PKs, but not alpha herpesvirus PKs, can phosphorylate the retinoblastoma (R) tumor suppressor protein and lamin A, and disrupt the nuclear lamina. In a yeast assay, the beta and gamma PKs displayed authentic Cdk activity, while alpha PKs did not. The PKs were also found to have non-dk activities, such as disrupting promyelocytic leukemia nuclear bodies and cytoplasmic aggres, but these were not conserved among all PKs. The study suggests that these kinases, some of which are targets of antiviral drugs, have overlapping and non-overlapping functions during infections.
A systematic review was conducted to define the global distribution of Burkholderia pseudalle, a Tier 1 select agent and cause of meloidosis, in the environment. The study aimed to update the risk map for meloidosis and propose international guidelines for soil sampling. A working party, the Detection Environmental Burkholder pseudalle Working Party (DEBP), was formed during the 6th Meloidosis Congress in 2010. PubMed was searched from 1912 to 2011 using MeSH terms pseudalle and meloidosis. The geographical distribution of pseudalle in the environment was mapped as definite, probable, or possible, and the methodology for detecting pseudalle was extracted. Coverage was patchy, with a lack of studies in areas where meloid is suspected. Sampling and identification methods were variable and not robust. Consensus guidelines were developed to reduce false results and provide affordable, low-tech methods for developed and developing countries. The guidelines provide a basis for a comprehensive global map of pseudalle.
Researchers have discovered that peptides derived from the stem region of the Dengue virus protein can inhibit the virus's ability to enter cells by targeting a specific intermediate stage of the fusion process. This stage, called the post-fusion conformation, is a crucial for the virus to merge with the cell membrane and release its genetic material. The peptides bind to this conformation and prevent the virus from fusing with the cell membrane, reducing its infectivity. The effectiveness of the peptides is directly related to how well they bind to the conformation, even if they are removed from the virus before it enters the cell. This suggests that the peptides attach to the virus before it reaches the cell and are carried with it into the endosome, where fusion occurs. The process is temperature-dependent, with no effect at 4°C but not at 37°C. The study proposes a two-step mechanism for fusion inhibition by targeting the viral entry pathway, which could be an effective way to block infection. The findings support existing theories on how the conformation change promotes fusion and suggest strategies for inhibiting flavivirus entry.
Researchers have developed a method to sequence the entire genome of Vibrio cholera, the bacteria that causes cholera, from dried stool samples preserved on filter paper. This is significant because cholera is a major global health concern, with approximately 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually, and recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen highlight the need for effective control measures. The new method allows for low-cost, safe, and sustainable sequencing of cholera strains in resource-limited settings, providing valuable data for public health policy. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) was used to recover a complete sequence of V. cholera O genome from stool enriched alkaline peptone water (APW) and culture isolates spotted on filter, with a minimum DNA concentration of 0.02 ng/μL required for quality information. GS confirmed the presence or absence of genes of interest, including cholera toxin and pilus loci, and identified co-infecting pathogens that may impact disease severity. GS placed the strains within the global cholera phylogenetic tree, identifying them as the 7th pandemic El Tor. GS allowed mapping of reads from AP-enrich specimen and culture isolate filter papers provided molecular epidemiological information on V cholera strains in remote, low-resource settings. Analysis of 700 V cholera genomes from Asia, Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean showed epidemics stem from a single pandemic lineage introduction from Africa and Asia, possible due to WGS phylogenetic measures. DNA from AP-enrich and isolate filter papers showed a correlation (Spearman score 0.42, p<0.1), with a minimum 0.02 ng/μL V cholera DNA generating 75% coverage. Meta-analysis of AP-enrich spotted papers identified V cholera through assemblies in more samples than isolate filter papers. Preliminary species analysis showed V cholera represented the most abundant species in majority of samples.
Researchers have identified a protein called Dyne that plays a crucial role in maintaining the structure and organization of epithelial cells, which are a type of cell layer that forms the lining of organs and glands. Epithelial cells have a distinct top and bottom side, known as apical and basolateral, and precise targeting of proteins to these areas is necessary for their proper function. A genetic study in fruit flies, Drosophila, found that Dyne is essential for apical-bas polarity, or the arrangement of proteins on the top and bottom of epithelial cells. Dyne works with a protein called Stardust (Sdt) to target a protein called Crumbs, which is on the surface of epithelial cells, by localizing it to the apical side. The study found that a specific part of the Stardust mRNA, or genetic material, is responsible for this localization and that is only present in early stages of epithelial development, but not in mature epithelia. This is the first time Dyne has been shown to be necessary for epithelial polarity and suggests that localization of mRNA may play a role in regulating ap-bas organization. Additionally, the study found that an alternative splicing, or variation, of the Stard mRNA, is used to control its localization during development.
Researchers have investigated the reproductive mode of Leishmania infantum, a parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, and found evidence of intraclonal genetic exchange within its natural vector, the sand fly Phlebotom periciosus. They created transgenic L. infant lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters and hypothesized that cells with identical genotypes could recognize each other and mate. The markers were successfully exchanged within the sand midgut of the vector when individuals were fed a mixture of parental clones. Using yellow and drug markers, they provided evidence of genetic exchange in L. infant. Hybrid progeny appeared to be triploid based on DNA analysis and was stable throughout the parasite life cycle. Infections by the hybrid in BAL/c mice showed reduced parasite loads in spleen and liver and weight similar to uninfected mice. Sple argin activity was also reduced relative to parental strains.
Researchers studied Leishmania donani strains from patients in Ethiopia with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and HIV co-infections. They analyzed DNA from 63 strains using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS), cystine protease (cp), and HASPB. The ITS and cp PCR identified the strains as Leishmania donani. However, the HAS PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic origin. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia produced a 290bp product, while a minority gave 410 amplicons, all from HIV-VL co-infections. Southwestern strains produced 450 amplicons, with smaller products observed in three. Sudanese strains had amplicons identical to northwestern, while Kenyan gave larger products 500-650bp. High-resolution analysis distinguished different products. Sequence analysis showed the HAS repeat region in Leish donani comprised polymorphic 13-14 amino motifs. The 13 amino peptide, prevalent in Leish donani, is rare in Leishum. The order of repeats in Leishani varies between regions. The HAS region shows considerable polymorphism among Leish strains from East Africa. This should be considered when designing diagnostic and vaccine assays based on this antigen.
Researchers studied the distribution of HIV-1 recombinant breakpoints to understand how they contribute to the diversity of the HIV pandemic. They developed a probabilistic model of HIV-1 recombination based on sequence identity and compared it to the distribution of breakpoints in the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The model accurately predicted the frequencies of inter-sub recombination across much of the HIV genome, indicating that local sequence-dependent recombination is sufficient to explain breakpoint locations. However, some regions showed significant over or underrepresentation of breakpoints, suggesting natural selection influences the recombination pattern. The envelope gene had fewer breakpoints, indicating recombinants in this region are less likely to be successful. Breakpoints at higher than predicted were near the envelope, indicating selection for recombinants due to this region's tendency to be recombined as a unit. The study found a specific portion of the genome deviates from the probabilistic model, suggesting only a minority of recombination events contribute to HIV-1 evolution.
Researchers in neuroscience have traditionally used separate statistical methods to address two interconnected problems: estimating model parameters for a population of subjects and comparing candidate models to individual data. However, these methods are interdependent, as the population parameters of a model depend on which subjects express the model. A new hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework is proposed for concurrent model comparison and parameter estimation at the population level, combining previous approaches. This framework has advantages for both parameter estimation and model comparison theoretically and experimentally, with estimated parameters showing smaller errors compared to other methods. Model comparison by H is robust against outliers and not biased towards simplistic models. A fully Bayesian approach enables researchers to make inference on group parameters by H-test.

A novel hierarchical and Bayesian method is introduced to address both model fitting and comparison within the same framework using variational techniques. The approach has consequences for both parameter and model estimation. A fully Bayesian quantifying uncertainty at the group level enabled statistical tests about parameters and corresponding errors. Empirical Bayes play a role in modern statistics.

The HBI framework is hierarchical, with individual parameters regularized by statistics across individuals, and Bayesian with uncertainties at both levels represented by distributions. Evaluating a model for a subject's data precedes estimation of its values; previous research used separate tools for these problems. However, they are interconnected, as parameters and fit depend on subjects belonging to the population expressing the model. This is addressed from a Bayesian viewpoint.

The work addresses statistical inference both parameters and models, elusive with previous methods. Notably, the best-fitting model may vary subject to subject, hierarchical estimation assumed the model expressed all subjects.
Researchers studied how the development of the auditory circuitry in the brainstem, specifically the part of the brain responsible for processing sound, in mice. They found that a group of cells called rhombomeres, which contribute to brainstem development, play a crucial role in forming sensory and motor components of the auditory system, including the ventral nucleus of the lemniscus, ventral cochlear nuclei, and olivochlear neurons. The assembly of these components is necessary for sound perception and relies on interactions between Hox1 and H2 genes. In mice lacking these genes, transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is impaired. On the other hand, H2 regulates axon guidance and contralateral projections from the ventral cochlear to the trapezoid nucleus, a circuit involved in sound localization. Each rhomere and its associated H codes control distinct subcircuits in the developing brainstem. The study also found that a single rhomere, r4, contributes to various derivatives of the auditory pathway distributed across multiple rhomeres. H1 and H2 are crucial in rhom patterning, and r4 changes identity in their absence. The study suggests H genes are involved in assembling sensorimotor circuits in the hindbrain. The researchers found that rostral rhomeres and associated H genes are required for two major circuits in the central auditory system with different origins.
Scientists have sequenced the complete genome of a marine bacterium called Saccharagus deans strain 2-40, which is capable of breaking down complex carbohydrates. This bacterium is part of a newly discovered group of marine and estuarine bacteria that recycle polysaccharides. The genome analysis reveals an unusually large number of enzymes that degrade complex polyscharides, with many exhibiting novel combinations of catalytic and substrate modules. These features are thought to facilitate depolymerization of complex polyschar in the marine environment. This is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium that can degrade plant cell walls, a component of the carbon cycle not well-characterized in the marine.

The bacter's carbohydrases are regulated by multiple mechanisms, with more enzymes induced for more complex polyschar complexes. Glucose is a key regulation mechanism. The carbohydrases are functional in microcos as S2-40 grows on plants as sole carbon sources, fully degrading them. This is the first marine proary shown to do so. Saccharagus deans 2-40 is a free-living marine bacterium capable of degrading cellulos algae and plant material. 16 rDNA analysis shows it's a member of the gamma-class of phylum Proteacteria, related to cellulitic nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

The bacter's enzym capabilities suggest a significant role in the marine carbon cycle, functioning as a "supergrader" breaking down complex polyschar from plants and invertebrates. It's an understudied system. The S2-40 genome is sequenced and closed. Polyschar degrading systems contain multiple enzymes with synergistic activities, such as cellulase with endo and exo-acting enzymes.
Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes significant childhood neurological infections in Asia. Over the past 20 years, JEV genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI). The mechanism of this shift is unknown. Culex (Cx) mosquitoes are common in China and play a key role in JE transmission. This study used Cx pipiens mosquitoes from China to explore if they played a role in JEV shift. Female Cx pip mosquitoes were exposed to GI or GIII JEV strains. Midgut, organs, and salivary glands of infected mosquitoes were collected at 7 and 14 days post-infection (dpi) to measure infection, replication, dissemination, and transmission of JEV in Cx pip. Cx pip was competent for both GI and GIII infection with similar rates and kinetics. Both genotypes disseminated to secondary organs at similar rates. GI-infected saliv glands were 16.2% positive at 7dpi, while GIII was undetectable. However, 29.4% and 36.3% were positive at 14dpi. No difference in transmission rate between GI and G-infected was detected. Data showed GI and GIII have similar infectivity in Cx pip, suggesting C pip may not play a role in J shift.
A two-year review of the epidemiology and clinical characteristics of deng deaths in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014 was conducted. Dengue is a rapidly spreading mosquito-borne viral disease affecting people in tropical and subtropical countries. The study aimed to investigate demographics and clinical characteristics associated with deng deaths in Malaysia. A retrospective review of all deng deaths nationwide between January 1, 2013 and December 31,2014 was conducted. Data were extracted from mortality reports and investigational forms. Cases were categorized into children (<15 years), adults (15-59 years), and elderly (≥60) to compare clinical characteristics. A total 322 deng deaths were reviewed, with a mean age of 40.7±19.7 years, half were females, and 72.5% were adults. Diabetes and hypertension were common co-morbidities among adults and elderly. The most reported symptoms were lethargy and vomiting, with lethargy being more common in children and abdominal pain in adults. 22.4% had no symptoms. Only 34% were suspected deng at initial presentation. Adults developed severe plasma leakage more often. More than half suffered multi-organ involvement and 20.2 had no organ involvement. Deaths occurred at 3 days post-admission. Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) caused 70% of deaths, followed by severe involvement 69% and bleeding 29.7%. In Malaysia, deng deaths primarily occurred in adults, with SS leading cause regardless of age. Atypical presentation and progression prompts early recognition and intervention to prevent deaths.
Researchers studied how female fruit flies, Drosophila melanogaster, choose their mates and what makes them attractive to males. They found that insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway, affects female attractiveness. Insulin signaling in the body's fat and ovarian follicle cells makes females more attractive, while insulin in the body's fat makes them less attractive. The ovaries are necessary for insulin's effect on attractiveness, and manipulating insulin in follicle cells alone replicates global effects. Insulin in the body and follicle have opposite effects, suggesting a competitive relationship. Modulating insulin in these tissues changes attractiveness and fecundity in the same direction, pointing to insulin as a link between the two. Cues, cuticular hydrocarbons, respond differently to body and follicle manipulations, indicating independent activity from these tissues. A system is described where attractiveness results from connection between cues and organism's state of fecundity, both created by insulin in body and follicle.
Researchers analyzed data from the 2013-2015 Ebola outbreak in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone to understand how the virus spread differently across districts within and between countries. They used a statistical model to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for each district and country, which measures how many people one infected person can infect on average. R ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone. At the national level, R was estimated at 0.97 for Guinea, 1.26 for Liberia, and 1.66 for Sierra. The study found that urbanization, high population density, and wealth were linked to higher R, suggesting rapid urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the spread of Ebola.
Researchers investigated the factors that influence a protein's rate of evolution, focusing on the interplay between its structural properties and age. They analyzed a large dataset of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins with mapped PDB structures and found that previously observed correlations between structural properties and evolutionary rates also held within each age group, including relationships between solvent accessibility, designability, and rates. However, age also played a role in modulating the relationship between solvent and rate. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, tended to evolve faster than older ones. The researchers showed that reported relationships between age and rate could not be explained by structural biases among groups. They introduced a knowledge-based function to study protein stability through large-scale computation and found that older proteins were more stable in their native structure and robust to mutations than younger ones.
Researchers have identified a protein called Polycomb-like 3 (P3) as a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (P2) that plays a crucial role in regulating embryonic stem cell (ES) self-renewal. P3 is found to interact with Suz12, a core component of P2, and promotes the methylation of histone H3 at lysine 27 (H3me3), a mark associated with gene repression. Knocking down P3 in ES cells leads to increased differentiation, but not affecting early cell fate decisions, indicating P3's specific role in self-renew. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing reveal P3 co-localizes with Suz12 and depletion of P3 decreases Suz binding at 60% of P2 targets. Mutation of conserved residues in P3's Tudor domain, implicated in recognizing methylated histones, compromises H3me formation. P3 and its paralog P2 exist in different P2 complexes, binding many of the same targets, particularly Cp islands regulated by P3. P3 is critical for ESC-renew, histone methylation, and P2 recruitment to a subset genomic sites.
Researchers have investigated how the nematode C. elegans modifies its chemosensory behavior in response to changes in feeding state. They focused on the chemoreceptor gene sr-234, which is expressed in the AD sensory neuron of C. elegans and is regulated by the transcription factor MEF-2. The study found that MEF-2 acts together with basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) transcription factors to regulate sr-234 expression as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory M2 site is necessary for starvation-induced downregulation of sr-234, while an E-box binds HL factors to drive sr- expression in AD neurons. HL-2, HL-3, and HL-4 transcription factors act in AD neurons to regulate sr-234. The study also showed that MX-3 and HL-30 in the intestine regulate sr- expression in AD neurons, dependent on insulin signaling in AD neurons and a subset of insulin peptides. These results suggest that chemore gene expression is regulated by cell-autonomous and non-autonomous mechanisms mediated by M2 and HL factors, allowing C. elegans to fine-tune chemens responses to changes in feeding state.
A study was conducted to investigate the association between the detection of Mycobacterium ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of Buruli ulcer disease in southeastern Australia. Adult mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula, Victoria, from 2004 to 2009, and screened for M. ulcer using real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed cases of BU in residents during the same period was tallied to determine the average incidence in each location. A strong correlation was found between the detection of M. ulcer in mosquitoes and the risk of disease (r = 0.99; 95% CI 0.92-0.99; p<0.001). The study suggests that mosquitoes are involved in the transmission of M. ulcer in southeastern Australia. This has implications for the development of strategies to control and prevent BU. In the absence of alternative transmission theory, mosquitoes are believed to play a role in spreading M ulcer to humans in Australia, and measures to minimize bites in residents and visitors should be encouraged in endemic areas. The study also raises questions whether mosquitoes are involved in transmission in other BU areas, such as Queensland and Africa, where majority of cases occur.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the MRS2 gene, which codes for a magnesium ion channel in the mitochondria, as the cause of demyelination in rats. The mutation leads to severe myelin breakdown in the central nervous system after normal myelination is complete. By cloning, they found a G-to-A transition in the MRS2 gene created a new splice site, inactivating the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type MRS2DNA confirmed the findings. M2 encodes a component of the major magnesium influx system in mitochondria of yeast and human cells. Rats with the mutation have major mitochondrial deficits, high lactic acid in cerebrospinal fluid, 60% reduction in ATP, and swollen mitochondria in oligodendrocy cytoplasm. M2-GFP transgenic rats showed M2 expressed in neurons, not oligodrocytes, and ultrastructurally in inner mitochondria membrane. Observations suggest demy rats suffer mitochondrial disease, myelin maintenance different from production. Mg2 homeostasis in mitochondria essential for myelin maintenance.
Researchers analyzed eight publicly available clinical microarray studies to evaluate the consistency of gene expression signatures in diagnosing diseases. They found that current documentation standards for signatures do not allow for unambiguous application to external studies, hindering independent evaluation and clinical use. The study showed that discrepancies between internal and external diagnoses can be as high as 30% in the worst-case and 18% in median. A proposed documentation strategy, which includes quantitative information, reduced the discrepancy to 1%. The process of bringing microarray gene expression signatures to clinical practice can be improved and made more reliable with better documentation. 

The study used eight clinicalarray studies involving different diseases and diagnostic problems. Rawarray data is subject to noise, and preprocessing is common prior to analysis. The consistency of diagnoses depends on the documentation of the signature, with optimal obtained using the proposed strategy. No strong evidence was found favoring one approach over the other. Microarray signatures hold promise to improve diagnosis and prognosis, but evaluation is difficult and subject to research. A signature needs to hold independent information to existing prognostic markers. To impact clinical practice, signatures need to be communicated for external evaluation and use, requiring unambiguous documentation.
Researchers have studied the structure of amyloid fibrils produced by a type of bacteria called Enterobacteriaceae, which help the bacteria stick to host cells and form biofilms, making them resistant to environmental stress. They found that these amyloid fibrils have a similar structure to those found in human diseases like Alzheimer's, and used peptides designed to stop Alzheimer's amyloid formation also stopped the bacteria's amyloid formation and biofilm growth. The study also showed that the bacteria's amyloid can trigger human amyloid formation, suggesting a possible link between the two. The researchers found that two peptides, designed to stop Alzheimer amyloid, also stopped the bacteria's amyloid formation and biofilm growth. They also found that the bacteria's amyloid can trigger human amyloid formation, suggesting a possible link between the two. The study provides insights into amyloid regions important for biofilm formation and suggests a strategy to disrupt amyloid biofilms and hypothesizes that amyloid from bacteria could contribute to neurodegenerative diseases.
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is a significant cause of encephal in Asia, with high case fatality rates and neurologic sequelae among survivors. In the Philippines, the epidemiology of JE is not well-defined. A systematic review of literature and surveillance data from 2011-2014 was conducted to support consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule. 29 reports on JE in the Philippines were identified, including 5 serologic, 18 clinical, and 8 animal studies. Clinical studies reported 257 laboratory-confirmed JE cases from 1972-2013, with JE virus as causative in 7-18% of meningitis and encephalitis, and 16-40% encephal cases. Predominantly affected children under 15, with 6-7% resulting in death. Surveillance 2011-2014 identified 73 laboratory-confirmed JE out of 497 tested. This review demonstrates endemicity and geographic range of JE in the Philippines, supporting vaccine use in the country. Continued surveillance and laboratory confirmation are needed to quantify the burden, guide prioritization of high-risk areas, and age and schedule of vaccine introduction, and measure preventive measures against this public health threat.
Researchers investigated the origins of genetic robustness in bacteria by studying the metabolic networks of hundreds of species across various environments. They found that variations in robustness among species reflect adaptations to their ecological niches. Robustness was decoupled into two components: environmental, responsible for 20% of non-essential reactions and associated with lifestyle (specialized/generalist), and environmental-independent, associated with intrinsic metabolic capacities (0.6 correlation). Higher robustness was observed in fast growers and organisms with extensive secondary metabolite production. Reactions uniquely susceptible to perturbations in pathogens were identified as potential drug targets.

The study used a large-scale computational approach to analyze metabolic networks, providing a significantly improved fit over individual measures. The association suggests that increased metabolic capacities drove the evolution of robustness in bacterial networks. Robustness can be studied at various biological levels, from molecular to organismal, where it's considered robust if a mutation has insignificant effect on a trait. Environmental robust differs across species, with some tolerating wide habitats and others having specialized requirements.

The contribution of environmental robust to genetic was demonstrated by a new pathway allowing a species to use an external metabolite as an alternative to an existing one, promoting robustness. Environmental robust correlates with modularity of networks (-0.43, P<e-16). The effect of environmental on genetic in networks was studied in yeast, where half of non-essential genes were active under restricting conditions. However, environmental cannot fully explain dispensability, two other hypotheses proposed: adaptive and intrinsic origins.
Researchers conducted a randomized trial to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni infection on antibody responses to measles catch-up immunization in pre-school children and the impact of prazantel treatment on this outcome. The study, called the Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunization (IMCI) study, took place in Enteb, Uganda, and included 193 Schistoma-infected and 61 uninfected children aged 3-5 years. Infected children were randomly assigned to receive prantel 2 weeks before, at the time of, or 1 week after measles immunization. Plasma-meas IgG was measured at enrollment, 1 and 24 weeks after immunization. The primary outcomes were IgG levels and percentage of participants with levels considered protective against measles. Results showed that Schistoma-infected children had lower anti-meas Ig levels at 1 week post-immun compared to uninf children (adjusted mean ratio 0.4, 95 CI 0.2-0.7) and lower percentage with protective levels (odds ratio 0.1, 0.9). However, among Schoma-inf children, anti-meas Ig 1 post-imm was higher in those treated with prant than those not (treated before immun, ratio 2.3,1.5-4.8; at immun ratio 1.8,1.3.5). At 24 post-imm, Ig levels did not differ between groups but tended to be lower in previously-inf children still Schoma-positive than those who became negative. The study suggests Schoma infection impairs antibody response to measles immun in pre-school children and prant treatment improves it.
Researchers have made significant progress in understanding bacterial evolution by analyzing large-scale population samples of DNA sequences. However, traditional methods like phylogenetic analysis are limited when dealing with extensive sampling and recombination. To address this, new statistical tools for detecting recombination and population representation are introduced, along with a model describing population sequence space in terms of variability and affinity to other populations. These tools are combined with phylogen analysis to demonstrate their potential using Neisseria data. The software BAPS 5.2 is available for download, capable of capturing various biological signals in molecular data, but interpretation requires complementary phylogen methods and knowledge. A population of 508 Neisser strains is analyzed, assuming a simplified evolutionary model with a common local ancestor and global ancestor. Traditional genetic tools are not applicable to bacterial data due to lack of population conditions, while phylogen may distort relationships with recombination. The introduced tools in BAPS enable large-scale population analysis, overcoming computational complexity of standard methods. Neisser species are chosen for validation due to frequent recombination and horizontal gene flow.
Researchers investigated the role of top-down beta rhythms in attentional modulation using a computational model of cortical areas. Beta rhythms in the 20 Hz frequency band have been linked to attention in previous studies, with top-down beta from higher areas to sensory areas supporting attentional gain. The model showed that top beta can activate ascending projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3, responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow inhibitory interneurons resonated to 20 Hz and modulated superficial activity in an attention-related manner, providing a potential mechanism for cholinergic support of selective attention.

The study explored top beta projected to L5 interneurons, finding mechanisms for selective attention: L cells resonating to beta modulated superficial activity by ascending to upper layers. Excitatory and inhibitory projections from L5 to upper layers were associated with top beta activity in superficial layers, consistent with neural modulation by attention. The model proposed interamin interaction regulated by top beta supported selective attention. Biased competition has been thought to underlie attentional control, with beta associated with top-down attention in recent studies. The model addressed whether top beta can bias competition and how it achieves this. Top beta reproduced neurophysiological findings that stimulus generated gamma and elevated spiking, and attention enhanced neural responses. Bottom-up inputs simulated 100 Hz trains of EPs to L4 and FS cells of columns.
Researchers have developed a new method called Multiple Shooting for Stochastic Systems (MSS) to calibrate and predict stochastic compartmental models of epidemics. These models are useful for studying the emergence of new pathogens when the number of infected individuals is small, but current methods for estimating and predicting these models are limited. SS uses a linear approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the epidemic state with each new observation. The method was tested on simulated outbreaks of a viral pathogen and showed accurate estimates of key parameters, such as duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff, and the number of unobserved individuals during the epidemic. It also accurately predicted future hospitalizations and attack rate. SS outperformed three benchmark methods: likelihood with Poisson assumption, particle filtering, and Kalman filter in most scenarios. The method addresses challenges in estimating and predicting epidemics when the state is partially observed and spread is stochastic. The posterior from one observation can be used as prior for the next. The goal is to improve predictions of future epidemics. The method was tested with competing approaches in accuracy, estimating parameters, predicting behaviors, and inferring the state, and sensitivity to noise and misspecification.
Researchers have discovered that human perception is influenced by two opposing forces: adaptation and past decisions. In a series of experiments, they used multilevel modeling and cross-validation to investigate the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during forced-choice tasks. The results showed that perceptual reports are biased by a hierarchy of serial processes: low-level adaptation repels perception away from previous stimuli, whereas decisional attracts percept reports towards the past. This hierarchy of dependence arises from decisional inertia, not low sensory processes. A two-process model suggests persistence compensates for adaptation, leading to attractive biases in perception. A unified account proposes distinct mechanisms at different stages promote differentiation and integration of visual information over time.

The study used multile modeling and cross-validation to characterize serial dependence, concluding: two forces interact at any moment shaping perception, biasing appearance towards or away from past. Repulsive forces, low-level adaptation dominate stimuli requiring perception. The goal was to determine if dependence depends on past stimuli or previous response. Recent work showed past biases decisions about sensory input, but decisions may represent a source of bias combining or outweighing stimuli. This result supports a hierarchical view and shows decisional affect percept even with new stimuli.

The study provides a unified account of perceptual and decision processes, proposing a hierarchical model of dependence. Two contrasting forces, adaptation and decision inertia, interact shaping experience and reactions to stimuli. In line with low continuity, dependence should originate from early neurons and be immune to later stages. However, results revealed mechanisms: repulsive after sensory and attractive percept.
Researchers have investigated the role of transcription in circadian timekeeping in Drosila by analyzing the effects of a CY-viral protein 16 (VP) fusion in the Drosila system. The addition of the potent transcriptional activator VP to the CLKCY-VP complex enhanced transcriptional activity compared to the normal CLKCY heterodimer. This increase was observed in S2 cells and flies expressing CY-VP, which also had increased levels of CLKCY direct gene mRNAs and a short period, indicating circadian transcription contributes to period determination. Examination of reporter gene expression in CYVP-expressing flies suggested the short period was due to rapid transcriptional phase. Behavioral effects required the per promoter and were not merely a consequence of higher PER levels, indicating CLKCYVP effects were due to increased transcription. The study suggests timing of transcription activation, not activation itself, is key to behavioral effects in CYVP-express flies. The results indicate circadian transcription contributes to core function in Dila.
Researchers investigated how a horizontally acquired gene, pmr, functions in two closely related bacteria, Salmonella and E. coli. They found that pmr activates the Pmr/PB system in Salmonella, but not in E. coli, suggesting a difference in an additional component controlling PA levels. The E. coli pmr protein has higher phosphatase activity towards PA-P than the Salmonella pmr, and replacing the E. coli pmr gene with the Salmon homolog renders E. coli resistant to polymyxin B under pm-inducing conditions. This shows that quantitative differences in biochemical activities of ancestral proteins dictate the ability of a horizontally acquired gene to confer species-specific traits. The study suggests horizontally acquired genes can potentiate at ancestral loci. The pmr was likely acquired by lateral transfer, as the divergent E. coli pmD can rescue a Salmonella pmD mutant to activate Pmr/PB in low Mg+. E. coli with Salmonella pmB requires pmD for transcription of PA-activated genes in low Mg+, but not in high Mg+. E. coli is resistant to polymin in Fe+, but not in Mg+, a process requiring pmr and pbg.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify genes involved in the early stages of cell differentiation, a process where stem cells become specialized. This method, called Differentiation-Test, analyzes gene expression data from a mixture of cells without separating them into types. Traditional methods often include genes that respond to differentiation, not regulate it. The test was applied to mouse embryonic stem cells differentiating into embryoid bodies and identified Smad1, a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renew. This approach can be used for other differentiation processes.

 Cell differentiation is a process where a cell becomes more specialized by expressing specific genes. Finding these genes is crucial, but a clear method is lacking. Different-Test assumes cells start homogeneous and become heterogeneous with gene expression changes. It was tested on mouse embryonic stem cells differentiating into embryoid bodies. Early on, subsets show expression changes towards different lineages.

The test identified regulators of pluripotency and selfnew. Selfnew regulators have lower expression in differentiated cells and should be detectable in 4-day embryoid bodies. Short hairpin RNA was used to study two regulators, Smad and P2. Expression was compared in Oct4 expressing and non-expressing cells. Regulators were separated into two modules: upregulated during differentiation (differentiation) and downregulated (pluripotency).
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze genetic data from next-generation sequencing studies, called unbiased clustering of gene variants with phenotypic-link network. This method addresses a common issue in previous studies where genes with longer coding sequences were more likely to be associated with disease, leading to false positives. The new method uses a large database of mammalian genotype-phenotype relations and semantic similarity to identify functional links between genes. It was tested on different types of data and networks and found that genes associated with the same disease clustered more in the phenotypic-link network than other networks. This method can identify functional associations between genes in the same disease, even after accounting for sequencing bias, and is suitable for polygenic disorders. 

The method was compared to other networks, including NETAG, and found to be more powerful. Functional enrichment approaches are used to identify shared functions in mutated genes, as case-control studies have limited power to associate rare variants with disease. Associations between genes are often inferred from large-scale data, such as protein-protein interactions and gene-expression networks. Statistical significance is assessed by comparing mutated genes to random sets. However, this can be affected by bias, leading to false findings. The new method controls for bias in coding sequence length and uses over 100,000 mammalian genotype-phenotype relations to enhance the phenotyp-link network.
Mexico implemented an 8% tax on non-essential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100g and a peso-per tax on sugar-sweet beverages (SBs) in January 2014 to prevent obesity and diabetes. This study evaluated changes in volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases in response to these taxes, stratified by socioeconomic status (SES). Data from 6,248 households in Nielsen's Mexico Consumer Panel (2012-2014) showed taxed food purchases declined by 5.1% in 2014 compared to expected pre-tax trends, with no change in untaxed foods. Low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods, medium SES 5.8% less, while high SES didn't change. Taxes were implemented nationally, limiting inference of causality, and sample only representative of urban areas. Purchases of non-essential energy-dense foods declined in the first year after implementation. Future studies should evaluate impact on energy intake, dietary, and food patterns.
Researchers have proposed a new model to explain the behavior of collision-sensitive neurons, such as the Lobula Giant Detector (LG) neuron in the locust, which responds to objects approaching on a collision course. Previous models used a power law for scaling inhibitory input, but this new model assumes noisy channels with a response threshold. By pooling these channels, an approximate power law is obtained. This mechanism can predict many characteristics of the LG neuron's response, and is robust against noise in the excitatory pathway but sensitive to noise in the inhibitory pathway. The model, called n-ψ, is biophysically plausible but not as detailed as previous models. It's based on predecessor η, which used an exact power law for scaling inhibitory input. The nψ model is for a class of collision-sensitive neurons with maximum response before collision to objects with constant velocity. Noise approximates a power in the inhibitory pathway through threshold smoothing, predicted by integrating many inhibitory inputs. A power law alone doesn't suffice, as η would distort the LG's response to approaching objects. The new model, nψ, is based on an equation describing the LG neuron's membrane potential, receives Θ(t) and Θ(t) as input. Integration could be carried out by the LG's dendritic tree. Conditions are noise across channels and a response threshold.
Cameroon has been endemic for Buruli ulcer (BU) since 1969, but institutional control efforts began in 2002. The National Buruli Ulcer Control Programme (NBPUC) aimed to detect cases early, confirm 70% of clinical cases by PCR, treat all cases according to guidelines, and heal 95% of patients without joint limitation. From 2001-2014, 370 cases were reported, with a significant drop in detection rate from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants. The number of endemic districts increased from 2 to 64, with 5 functional diagnostic and 2 planned treatment centers. The health system was strengthened, research and education gained interest. Although control began 30 years after first cases, progress was made in detection, management, system reinforcement, and research. However, reduced resources led to steady decline since 2010.
Researchers investigated how people's confidence in their choices affects learning and decision-making when outcomes are framed as gains or losses. They found that participants were more confident in their choices when learning to gain compared to avoiding losses, despite equal performance and difficulty between the two contexts. A computational model revealed that this bias is driven by context-value, a dynamic estimate of the average value of options, necessary to explain performance in both gain and loss domains. This bias effect is domain-general and has significant consequences, showing that individuals' flexibility in learning strategies differs when outcomes are framed as gains or losses. 

A previous study showed that stakes can influence confidence in choices, regardless of correctness, with gains and losses biasing confidence upwards and downwards, respectively. Confidence is crucial in mediating learning strategies in changing environments, so investigating judgments and biases in reinforcement-learning is important. Confidence impacts subsequent decision processes and information seeking, and acts as a currency to trade-off between strategies. Biases could have critical consequences on learning and reveal features of learning and decision-making in different contexts. 

The researchers hypothesized that individuals would exhibit lower confidence in choices while learning to avoid losses compared to seeking, despite equal performance and difficulty between contexts. This bias was generated by learned-value, a latent variable in reinforcement models. The study investigated behavior and estimations in a reinforcement task where outcome valence was manipulated (gains versus losses). Participants performed equally well in gain-seeking and loss-avoid contexts. Confidence can be a meta-cognitive variable for comparing learning and deciding to adjust strategies. Despite models of confidence in decision and prediction, how-makers estimate confidence in reinforcement remains poorly investigated.
Researchers have investigated the function of the non-structural protein 3 (ns3) of alphaviruses, a group of viruses that includes Semliki Forest virus (SFV), Sindbis virus (SINV), and Chikungunya virus (CHV). Ns3 is a component of the viral replication complex and has a conserved amino-terminal domain involved in RNA synthesis and a poorly conserved carbox-terminal region. Despite the lack of overall homology, a carbox-terminal proline-rich motif is shared among alphavirus ns3 proteins and serves as a target for Src-homology 3 (SH) domains of amphiphin-1 and -2. The study found that ns3 of SF, SINV, and CHV show avid and SH-dependent binding to amphins. Upon alphavirus infection, intracellular distribution of amphin is altered and colocalized with ns3. Mutations in ns3 disrupting amphin SH binding and RNA-mediated silencing of amphin-2 resulted in impaired RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SF. Infection of Bal/c mice with SF carrying SH binding-defective ns3 was associated with decreased mortality.
Researchers studied 123 strains of a disease-causing fungi in Brazil, known as chromoblastycosis, to understand its diversity. They used DNA sequencing to identify the genetic makeup of the fungi. The results showed that the disease-causing fungi were divided into three groups, with Fonseea being the most common, making up 80% of the cases, followed by F. monora and F. nica. Two new species, Rhinadiella and Cyphora, were also found, making up 3% and 1% of cases respectively. 

The study found that Fonsea pedso was the most prevalent in humid climates of South America, while F monora was more common in southern China. Four Fonsea species were found in Brazil, with pedso and nica strictly associated with the disease. All isolates were from humid zones, with no Cladophora found, which is common in arid conditions. Two new species of fungi causing chromobyc were identified, Fonsea, Rhinella, and Cyphora.
Researchers have studied how the bacterium Listeria monocytogenes interacts with its host cells to cause infection. They found that L monocytogenes induces DNA breaks in host cells, but surprisingly, the cells' response to these breaks is only moderately activated. The team discovered that the bacterium's toxin, listeriolysin O (LO), blocks the cellular response to DNA damage by degrading a key sensor protein, Mre11. Knocking out or inactivating proteins involved in the DNA damage response pathway promotes bacterial replication, highlighting the importance of this mechanism in controlling infection. The study shows that dampening the DNA damage response is crucial for successful Listerial infection. 

Further, researchers found that deleting or inhibiting proteins involved in the DNA response leads to higher infection levels, demonstrating that the response can be a negative regulator of bacterial infection. Other bacteria, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Neisseria gonorrhoe, have been shown to induce DNA damage, but this has not been studied during Lister infection. The study reveals that LO degrades M11, a major sensor of DNA damage, through a proteasome-independent mechanism. Additionally, dampening the response is important for infection, as inhibiting proteins in this pathway increases bacterial infection. The study uncovers L monocogen's subversion of the DNA response during infection and a role in blocking bacterial proliferation.
Researchers have identified a protein called bromodomain protein 4 (BRD4) as a key player in the infection of two common human viruses, HSV-1 and HSV-2. They found that blocking a specific part of the protein, called the BD domain, with a compound called JQ, increased the viruses' ability to infect cells. This was confirmed by showing that knocking down BR4 expression, or blocking its activity, reduced JQ's effect on infection. BR4 regulates viral replication by forming a complex with other proteins CD9 and RNA polymerase II, while J1 promotes infection by directing this complex to viral gene promoters. Suppressing BR4 or CD9 activity hindered infection. The study suggests J1 enhances infection by switching BR4 to regulate viral gene expression by targeting chromatin.
Researchers investigated the microbial communities in the mouths of children with noma, a rare and devastating disease that causes severe facial disfigurement in over 140,000 malnourished children every year. The cause of noma is still unknown, but a mix of microbial infection, poor oral hygiene, and weakened immune system likely contribute to the development of oral lesions. These lesions are entry points for unidentified microorganisms that trigger gangren facial infections. The study analyzed 16S rRNA gene fragments from samples of gingival fluid from 12 healthy children, 12 with noma lesions, and 12 with Acute Necrotizing Gingitis (AN) lesions and healthy sites. Compared to healthy individuals, samples from diseased mouths were enriched with Spirocha and depleted for Proteobacteria. Samples from healthy sites of diseased had similar proportions of Spiro and Proteobacteria to healthy controls. Samples from n mouths did not have higher abundance of Fusobacter, casting doubt on its role as causative agent. Microbial communities from n and AN lesions were dominated by Prevotella intermedia OT, less abundant in healthy sites from same mouths. Multivariate analysis confirmed different bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites. Several OTUs in Erysotrichales, Cloidales, Boid, and Spirotales were identified as indicators of n, suggesting one or more microbes within these orders associated with n lesions.
Bacillus thuringis, a bacterium that infects insects, uses a communication system called quorum sensing to adapt to its environment and decide whether to form spores or commit to a necrotrophic lifestyle. The quorum sensing system is regulated by proteins belonging to the RNPP family, which are controlled by internal signaling peptides. One of these regulators, Npr, acts as a transcription factor with its cognate peptide Npr, regulating genes for survival in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of Npr, Npr independently controls sporulation by inhibiting the expression of SpoA-regulated genes, preventing Kin-dependent phosphorylation of phosphotransferase SpoF, thus delaying the sporulation process. Npr's function is similar to Rap proteins, which belong to RNPP but lack DNA-binding and control gene expression through protein interactions. Conservation of residues interacting with SpoF suggests common inhibition of sporulation. The structure of Npr shows a flexible Rap-like structure, proposing a regulatory mechanism where Npr's key residues are involved in two functions: Npr binding switches from dimer inhibitor to tetramer transcription activator in necrotrophic lifestyle. N thus coordinates sporulation and necrotism, ensuring survival and dissemination during infection.
Researchers have developed a new computational model to predict the effectiveness of HIV treatment for individual patients based on their viral genotype. Current models only use sequence data from genotyping, but this new model combines chemical and protein properties to improve accuracy. A large dataset of 300,000 data points was used to train the model, which achieved a prediction error rate below 0.5 log change. Compared to previous models, this new model performed better in resistance prediction and classification, with a 0.76 log unit difference. The model was also able to identify known and unknown resistance-conferring mutations in HIV Reverse Transcriptase and Protease. The model was applied to a public database and achieved a correct prediction rate of 84%, higher than previous work on a high-quality subset. This model can predict phenotypic resistance from genotyp data, even for novel and mixed mutants, and informs users about prediction reliability.
Researchers have proposed an alternative mechanism for chemotaxis, the process by which cells move towards or away from chemical attractants. The traditional view is that attractants cause actin polymerization, leading to pseudop formation and movement. However, this study suggests that pseudops are formed by a self-generated cycle, and attractants modulate the cycle rather than directly causing actin polymerization. A computational model based on pseudop autocatalysis was developed to test the explanatory and predictive powers of this mechanism. The model reproduces a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemotaxis, simulates cell polarization and persistence, and predicts pseudop bias in attractant gradients. It also predicts lateral pseudop initiation in high attractant gradients. To test the model's ability, a prediction was made that the angle between successive pseudops at the front of the cell would increase with the difference between the cell's direction and the attractant gradient. This was measured in Dictyostelium cells under different conditions and agreed with the model. The model and data suggest that rapidly moving cells like Dictyostelium and neutrophils have an intrinsic pseudop cycle at the heart of motility, implying the mechanism relies on modification of pseudop behaviour rather than generation or actin polymerization by attractants.
Researchers studied how fleas transmit the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which causes plague, to rodents. They found that fleas can transmit the bacterium in two ways: early-phase transmission (EPT) and bio-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and rodent species. To understand the mechanism of E, they fed fleas bacteremic blood from mice, rats, guinea pigs, or gerbils and observed the location and characteristics of infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pest. Surprisingly, 10-28% of fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea blood regurgitated a portion of the infected meal into the esophagus within 24 hours. This phenomenon is called post-infection esophageal reflux (PIER). In contrast, P was rarely observed in fleas fed bacteremic mouse or gerbil blood. P correlated with accumulation of dense aggregates of Y. pest, red blood cells, and hemoglobin that filled the proventulus. At next feeding, fleas with P were 3-25 times more likely to be blocked with blood retained in the esagus than fleas without P. Three days after feeding on bacteremic blood, Oropsa montana transmitted significantly more CFU than groups using mouse blood, and this transmission was bio-dependent.
Researchers have found that positive correlations between the activity of neurons in the brain can actually improve the accuracy of coding, rather than hinder it. Contrary to previous studies, which suggested that correlations were detrimental or only marginally beneficial, this study shows that they can enhance performance by several orders of magnitude. The probability of error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude and the number of stimuli encoded, or capacity, can be increased more than tenfold. These effects do not require unrealistic correlation values and can occur in populations with just a few neurons. The study also found that heterogeneity in activity is beneficial and that both error suppression and enhancement depend on a specific pattern of correlation. Tuning one or several parameters can lead to perfect coding, where the pattern of positive correlation leads to a "locking" of probabilities that eliminates variability in the space relevant for stimulus discrimination.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine against cholera, a severe diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholera, by combining the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholera O1 Inaba strain with a recombinant fragment of tetanus toxin heavy chain (rTHC). This conjugate vaccine, called OSP:rTH, was tested in mice to assess its ability to induce immune responses and protect against cholera. The study found that mice immunized with OSP:rTH developed antibodies against OSP and tetanus toxin, as well as vibriidal antibodies and memory cell responses after intramuscular or intradermal vaccination. Intestinal IgA responses targeting OSP occurred after intradermal vaccination. Results showed comparable immune responses in mice immunized with different vaccine variations, although memory and vibri responses were lower in mice receiving the highest dose. Administration of OSPTH resulted in 55% protection in a mouse cholera challenge model. The study reports development of an Inaba:rTH conjugate vaccine that induces responses and protection against cholera in mice. An effective cholera conjugate vaccine that induces high and long-term responses against OSP would be beneficial, especially in children who poorly respond to polyschar antigens.
A study was conducted to investigate the cross-reactivity of immunochromatographic test (ICT) cards in areas with contrasting endemicity of Loa loa and Mansonella perans in Cameroon. The study assessed the prevalence and intensity of Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Mansonella perans in 42 villages across three regions of the Cameroon rainforest domain. Blood samples were collected for detection of circulating filarial antigen by ICT and assessment of microfilaria using thick smear. Clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis were also assessed. Overall, 219 individuals participated, with 24 testing positive by ICT, ranging from 0% in South-west to 2.1% in North. Lymphedema was diagnosed in 20 individuals, with majority in North, none tested positive by ICT. No microf W. bancfti found in blood of individuals with positive ICT or lymphedema. Positive ICT associated with high Loa microf intensity, 21 with over 8,000 Loa/ml blood (odds ratio 15.4; 95%CI 6.1-39.0; p<0.001). Strong association observed between Loa prevalence and ICT area (Spearman rho 0.900; p0.037). No association between ICT and perans prevalence (Spearman -0.200; p0.747) and microf (odds 1.8;95CI0.8-4.2; p0.192). The study confirmed association between ICT and Loa intensity and demonstrated ICT strongly associated with high Lo prevalence. Results suggest main confounding factor for positive test results are high Lo levels. Findings indicate W bancft less prevalent in Central region than previously assumed, accurate re-mapping useful for shrinking LF distribution map.
Researchers have studied how the SARS-CoV virus replicates in host cells and found that it uses a network of modified endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membranes to support its replication. This network includes double-membrane vesicles (DMVs) and convoluted membranes that are not previously thought to be involved in RNA synthesis. The study used electron tomography to image infected cells at high resolution and found that DMVs are not isolated vesicles but part of a reticuloves network of ER membranes. The convol membranes were mainly labeled with viral replicase subunits, while double-stranded RNA, likely the site of RNA synthesis, was found in the DM interior. The study raises questions about how DMs form and where SARSV RNA is synthesized. The virus reorganizes host membranes into a network to replicate and possibly hide from antiviral mechanisms.
Researchers have investigated the role of suberin, a chemical compound found in plant roots, in regulating water and nutrient uptake from the soil. They used a genetically modified Arabidopsis plant, es1, with increased suberin levels, to study its effects on water and nutrient transport. Results showed reduced transpiration rates and increased water efficiency during growth, and changes in nutrient accumulation in the shoot, including increased sodium, sulfur, selenium, and molybdenum, and decreased calcium and manganese. This suggests suberin acts as a barrier controlling water and ion transport to the leaves. The study provides direct evidence that suberin plays a critical role in regulating water and nutrient uptake.
Researchers investigated the kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation and its role in regulating the reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. They used a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CT) model based on the biochemistry of rhodin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction.
