Centrioles are essential for cell division and their number is tightly regulated to prevent cancer and birth defects. A protein called ZYG-1 is required for centri duplication, but how its levels are regulated was unclear. Two proteins, GSP-1 and G-2, and their regulators I-2 and SDS-22, were found to control Z-1 levels. Reducing their activity restored centri duplication in Z- mutant embryos by increasing Z- levels. This is achieved through a post-translational mechanism. However, strong inhibition of activity in wild-type worms led to centri amplification, producing more than one centri. This pathway limits the number of daughter centri produced each cycle. The study shows activity is a critical regulator of Z- and centri duplication, previously implicated in centrosome separation at mitosis. The SC complex regulates Z- levels and its depletion increases centros-associated Z. Data suggest G-1, I-2, and SDS-22 cooperate to regulate overall Z- levels. Reducing activity leads to excess Z- and elevated in wild-type Z- drives centri overduplication, similar to overexpression in humans and flies. Modulating activity may impact centri duplication.
A study was conducted in an environmentally protected area (EPA) in southeastern Brazil to investigate the transmission of visceral leishmanias (VL) in dogs, wild mammals, and sand flies. The area had previously reported VL cases in dogs in 2009, and the disease remained restricted to two contiguous condominiums within the PA. Canine seroprevalence was 1.5% in 2013 and 1.2% in 2015. Six species of sand flies were identified as potential vectors or transmitters of Leishmania, including Lutzia longipalis, the main vector in Brazil. Infection by Leishmania infantum was found in two species of sand flies and a white-eared opossum, a known reservoir of VL. Geographical coordinates of infected animals were plotted on a map, showing proximity to human residences and infected dogs. The PA has an active VL focus, and risk of transmission in similar areas with environmental modifications is evident. Different epidemiological profiles must be considered for prevention and control measures. 

A previous investigation in 2009 found 2% seropreval in dogs and no infected wild mammals. Sand flies were present in 18.8% of residences, and Lutzia longalis was found in three. The emergence in dogs and humans in a region with low canine prevalence is compatible with wild reservoirs and transmission. This scenario is similar to the focus in Campinas PA. A serology showed 1 sensitivity and 73.9 specificity, useful for surveys. Proximity of seropositive dogs to wild and infected sandflies supports their relation. Infection in wild fauna was confirmed for the first time, with another trypanid, T rangeli. Proximity of 100m between human and forest areas where flies and mammals were captured was demonstrated. Natural infection in sand flies and Leish in a reservoir species provides evidence of sylvatic transmission. However, VL in Campinas may not be due to wild cycle transmission.
Epstein-Barr virus (EB)-encoded microRNA miR-B9 promotes tumor metastasis by targeting E-cadherin in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. MicroRNAs (mi) are small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression and play critical roles in various cellular processes. EB, an oncogenic virus, is associated with nasaryngeal carcinoma (NPC), a highly metastatic tumor common in Asia. Previous studies found viral proteins promote NPC migration and invasiveness, but not all tissues express these oncoproteins, suggesting other mechanisms contribute to tumor behavior. A study revealed EB miR9 expressed high in EB-positive NPC tissues. This study investigated miR9 effect in EB-negative and EB-positive NPC cells using gain and loss-function approaches. mi9 promotes migration and invas in cultured cells, and enhanced metastatic ability in vivo. Computational analysis revealed mi9 targets Eadher, a protein preserving cell junctions and epithelial phenotype. Biochemical and functional assays confirmed mi9 inhibits Ead to induce mesenchymal phenotype and promote NPC migration. Results indicate mi9 a promastatic viralRNA and high levels mi9 in EB-positive cells contribute to tumor aggressiveness.

High mi9 and downmodulated cellular mi200 members in EB tumors drive epithelial cells to mesenchal with enhanced motility and metastatic behavior. mi9 and mi200 share same sequence critical for interaction. Studies shown mi200 significantly downmodulated in NPC. This study demonstrated EB-encoded miR9 highly in NPC and mi9 directly targets Ead to mesenchal phenotype and migratory NPC cells. Sequencing revealed mi9 most abundantly expressed EB in tumors. Taq-based PCR confirmed majority NPC mi9 higher than abundant oncogenic mi21. Depletion mi9 increased luciferase activities, indicating suppression mi9 activities 50-70 with treatment lentiviral-mi9 expressing NPC. Ectopic mi9 physiological promotes migration and invas EB-negative cells confirmed mi9 promatory viral. Unlike LMP and L proteins, transcripts consistently detected high NPC. Findings indicate mi significant contributor migr and invasive EB-infected cells.
Researchers have developed a new command-line tool called gashimi for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. Given a specified genomic region, gimi creates sash plots for individual RNA-seq experiments and aggregated plots for groups of experiments, a feature unique to this software. Unlike existing tools, gimi uses popular bioinformatics formats, is annotation-independent, and visualizes splicing for large regions by scaling genomic segments between splice sites. Gimi is available on GitHub and implemented in Python, generating R code for plotting.

A tool for drawing sash plots was initially part of the MISO software, quantifying alternative splicing from RNAq experiments. Current implementations include a standalone utility creating sash plots for MISO-index splicing and built-in IGV. Visualizing RNAq data is crucial for exploratory analysis, but splicing is not integrated in common browsers or standalone software. Visualizing splicing is challenging as events occur between non-contiguous regions, distant tens or hundreds of kilobases.

Gimi was compared to IGV's built-in sash plot for a genomic region, aggregating samples with same group and shrinking intron lengths, enhancing visualization. The sash representation splicing is a standard, but current implementations have limitations. Gimi solves these issues, eliminating specialized formats and supporting hundreds of samples. A splicing implies a connective element illustrating splice junctions between sites.
Researchers have developed a new model to predict and align cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) across species, which are crucial for understanding gene regulation. Current methods struggle with aligning non-coding sequences and existing models of DNA evolution don't account for CRMs' unique properties. The proposed model captures evolution of transcription factor binding sites (TFs) and background sequences, including gains and losses of TFs, a key part of regulatory evolution. A computational framework uses this model to solve CRM alignment and prediction, similar to statistical methods but improves with conserved sites. The method deals with uncertainties of site annotations and alignment in a probabilistic framework. Simulated and real data show it outperforms state-of-the-art methods. Alignments were used to study transcription factor binding in Drosophila melanogaster, revealing strong constraints on factor-bound sequences even if neighboring genes are not expressed and conserved sites in distal to transcription start are more conserved than proximal. The approach is implemented as software, EM (Evolutionary Model-based cis-regulatory Module) for broad application.
Researchers have investigated the role of the piRNA pathway in Drosophila, a type of fruit fly, in maintaining genome integrity and telomere protection. They found that mutations in genes arm, aub, ago3, and rhi lead to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during cleavage stage embryonic divisions. Additionally, aub and arm show defects in telomere resolution during meiosis and cleavage divisions, while mutations in lig-IV, which disrupt non-homous end joining, suppress fusions. By contrast, lig-IV mutations enhance chromosome fragmentation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies show aub and arm mutations disrupt telom binding of HO, a component of the telom protection complex, and reduce expression of a subpopulation 19-22-ntelom-specific piRN. Mutations in r andago, however, do not block HO binding or production of theseRNAs. These findings reveal genetically separable functions for the Dophila pi pathway. The a, arm, r, andago genes silence transons and maintain chromosome integrity during cleavage embryonic divisions. However, a and arm have an additional function in assembly of the telom protection complex. The researchers also found that a and arm are required for TPC recruitment, consistent with ligation of chromosome in mutant embryos.
Researchers have identified a new species of the Ebola virus responsible for a hemorrhagic fever outbreak in Uganda, which occurred in November 2007. The new virus, named Bundibugyo ebolavirus, is closely related to the Côte d'Ivoire ebavirus, found in western Africa, despite being geographically distant. The virus was detected in 8 out of 29 suspect blood specimens using a broad ebavirus antigen capture assay and IgM assay. The Ugandan Ministry of Health was notified on November 28, 2007. The new virus diverges significantly from known ebaviruses, suggesting differences in antigen and pathogenicity. Current ebavirus vaccines include Zaire and Sudan, but cross-protection studies are needed to determine if Bundibyo needs to be included. This has implications for antiviral and vaccine development. The Bundibyo outbreak resulted in 149 cases and 37 deaths, with a fatality rate of 36%, lower than Zaire (80-90%) and Sudan (50-55%). Studies in non-human primates are needed to compare pathogenicity.
Researchers studied the progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD) in a group of 648 patients with an average follow-up time of 4.78 years. They used the Global Deteration Scale (GDS) and Functional Staging (FAST) procedures, which characterize seven stages of AD from normal to severe dementia. Each G/FAST stage has a published mean duration, but the variance was unknown. The study found that the standard deviations for G/FAST stages 4-6 were similar to their mean durations, indicating large variations in AD progression among patients. This heterogeneity is consistent with the existence of subgroups of patients with different decline patterns. A large dataset analysis revealed significant variation in lengths of G/FAST 4-6 of AD, with standard deviations similar to mean durations. This suggests cognitive and functional decline vary significantly from patient to patient. The study supports the idea that AD is a heterogeneous disease, as proposed in literature. The progression of AD shows high variability, with stage times ranging from months to decades. The underlying reasons for variations are uncertain, but a combination of factors may be responsible. The study's finding of heterogeneity in GFAST durations is consistent with previous reports.
Researchers studied the role of neurogenesis and synaptic plasticity in a simplified hippocampal memory model that encodes and decodes patterns despite changing input statistics. They found that neurogenesis was a more effective strategy than conventional plasticity and turnover, allowing the network to adapt to changes while preserving earlier representations. The model was extended to include spatially driven input patterns from grid cells in the entorinal cortex, comparing performance across three strategies: synaptic plasticity, turnover, and neurogenesis. Neurogenesis was confirmed as the superior strategy. A more biologically plausible rule incorporating cell death and plasticity of new granule cells outperformed individual strategies. This rule can be tailored for short or long-term memory. Neurogenesis was examined over an animal's lifetime under different rearing conditions, with distinct profiles that could be tested experimentally. Place cells emerged in a realistic manner due to sparsification by the dentate gyrus layer.
African trypanosomes, a type of parasite that causes sleeping sickness in humans and animals, have three identical glutathione peroxidase (Px) enzymes in their cells. These enzymes protect the cells from damage caused by lipid hydroperoxides, a type of oxidative stress. Research has shown that when one of these enzymes, PxIII, is missing, the parasite's growth is slightly affected, but when another, PxI and PxII, are missing, the parasite dies quickly due to lipid peroxidation and cell lysis. This damage can be prevented by supplementing the parasite's medium with α-tocopherol derivative Trolox. However, the reason behind this rapid death was unclear. Scientists found that the lysosome, a part of the cell responsible for breaking down waste, is the origin of the damage. When parasites lacking PxII were fed with a substance that stains lysosomes, the stain appeared in lysosomes, but disappeared when Trolox was removed. Parasites acquire iron by endocytosis, a process of taking in from host transferrin. Adding iron or transferrin to the medium, or chelating with deferoxamine and apo-transferrin, reduced lysis of PxII cells. Microscopy showed that lysosome disintegration precedes mitochondrial damage. Experiments confirmed that mitochondrial peroxidase is not crucial, as infected parasites lacking PxIII had only slightly delayed development. Data show that in African trypanosomes, lysosome, not mitochondrion, is primary site of damage and cytos trypanione/tryparedin peroxides protect lysosome from iron-induced peroxidation. This is linked to high endytic rate and iron acquisition of infective stage T. bruce.
Researchers have investigated the role of the protein PMEL in melanosome formation and pigmentation by creating a mouse line with the Pmel gene inactivated (P−/−). These mice are viable, fertile, and show no developmental defects. However, their melanosomes are spherical, unlike the elongated shape in wild-type mice. Inactivation of Pmel has a mild effect on coat color in different genetic backgrounds, with the most notable effect in mice carrying the brown/Tp mutation. This is similar to the silver mutation in mice, suggesting other described alleles in vertebrates with striking effects are dominant mutations. Despite mild pigmentation, P−/− mice have reduced eum in hair, indicating PMEL's role in efficient epidermal pigmentation. 

The study shows PM is essential for rod-shaped melanos in eelan-producing melanocytes, but not cell survival in several tissues. Amyloid fibrils formed by PM fragments play a role in characteristic melanos shape, but P knockout has mild effect on pigmentation. A knockout mice on black backgrounds have spherical melanos and reduced eum, similar to Pels mice. Another possibility is polymerization eelan on PM fibrils facilitates transfer to keratinocytes, reduced in P−− skin. The phenotype is similar to the silver allele causing premature stop codon truncating last 25 PM residues. Graying decreases with age in out mice, unlike progressive graying black.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental methods for deng vector control. Nineteen studies were eligible, with sixteen contributing to the meta-analysis. The methods evaluated were: (a) container covers with insecticides, (b) waste management and clean-up campaigns, and (c) elimination of breeding sites by rendering mosquito breeding sites unusable. Quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste management without direct collection and elimination of breeding sites. Both review and meta showed a weak effect on larval populations, with no differences between individual results. Meta-analysis showed container without insecticides (BI: -7.9, DOE-5) and waste with garbage collection (BI: -8.83, DOE-6.2) achieved strongest reductions for BI, while P results were opposite with covers insect (P: -0.83, 0.09) and elimination (P: -0.95, -0.83). Each method showed effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes mosquitoes. However, high-quality studies are needed to strengthen evidence. A previous studies concluded environmental management was effective, and community-based interventions reduced deng risk. This study aimed to review and meta-analyze effectiveness of environmental methods. Searches were finished May 2017, with no further studies altering results. Both review and meta showed environmental interventions reduced lar and pupal densities Aedes.
Researchers have identified small molecules that selectively inhibit protein synthesis by stalling the ribosome, a potential strategy for developing new therapeutic compounds. One such compound, PF-06303 (PF3), inhibits PCSK9, a regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, reducing LDL in preclinical models and affecting only a few off-target proteins. However, its impact on cell physiology and ribosome control pathways is unknown. A genome-wide CRISPR screen was used to identify proteins and pathways that modulate growth in the presence of high doses of PF03. The most potent genetic modifiers of fitness were ubiquitin binding protein ASC2 and helicase ASC3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of high concentrations. Surprisingly, translation control proteins Pelota (PELO) and H1 sensitize cells to PF3 treatment. Genetic experiments showed ASC3 acts with ASC2 and downstream of H1. These results connect ribosome control pathways and provide insights into selectivity of compounds that stall translation, aiding development of next-generation compounds to treat disease.
Researchers have discovered that the Kaposi's sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV) protein, SO, induces widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNA (mRNA) in host cells by a novel mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. Polyadenylation is the process of adding a poly A tail to the end of RNA transcripts, which is crucial for their stability and function. In cells expressing SO, transcripts exhibit extended poly A tails and linked to mRNA turnover. The study found that SO-induced polyadenylation correlates with RNA function and inhibiting poly A tail formation blocks SO activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly A binding proteins are critical for SO function, with the latter undergoing striking nuclear localization by SO. This mechanism represents a new way for viruses to shut off host gene expression and a model to study poly A-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells. The research suggests a link between polyadenylation and RNA surveillance, as yeast mutants defective in RNA processing accumulate hyperadenylated transcripts. In mammalian cells, polyadenated precursors to RNA have been detected. This is the first example of enhanced turnover coupled to hyperadenylation in metazoans. The study proposes that SO-induced alterations in processing render nascent RNAs targets of cellular control machinery.
Researchers investigated the role of type III interferon (IFλ) in the immune response to bacterial pathogens, specifically Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, in the lung. They found that these bacteria induce IFλ production, which leads to the clearance of bacteria and reduced lung pathology in mice lacking the IFλ receptor, IL-28. Improved clearance correlated with reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines and increased anti-inflammatory cytokines in the airway. In human epithelial cells, IFλ inhibits miR-21, resulting in upregulation of PDC4, a protein promoting inflammatory signaling. In vivo, 18 hours post-infection, mi-21 was reduced and PDC increased in wild-type mice compared to IL-28 null mice. Infection of PDC null mice with USA resulted in improved clearance, reduced pathology, and reduced cytokine production. The study suggests IFλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting mi-21 regulation of PDC in bacterial pneumonia.
Researchers conducted a study on 781 cases of advanced-stage 2 sleeping sickness in the Democratic Republic of Congo between 1989 and 2012. The study aimed to identify mortality trends and risk factors. Death was the outcome variable, and age, gender, disease duration, location of trypanosomes in body fluids, cyach, protach, clinical status on admission, and treatment were predictors in logistic models. Death rates were 17.2% in standard melop schedule, 12.1 in short melop, 5.4 in eflorine, 9.1 NECT, and 36% in severely affected patients given eorine. After adjusting for treatment, death ratios were: 10.40 for clinical dysfunction on admission, 2.14 for protach, 1.99 for parasites in CSF, and 1.7 for cyach. Multivariate analysis retained clinical status and protach as predictors of death. An algorithm for clinical assessment used in the study may serve as basis for further development of standardized tools for H management and epidemiological reports.
Researchers have developed a new method to study the effects of isolation on social behavior in fruit flies, specifically Drosophila melanogaster. They created an imaging system to track large groups of flies and an algorithm to analyze their social interactions. This allowed them to quantify changes in social networks in response to isolation. The study found that isolation significantly altered individual and social behavior, particularly near-neighbor relationships. The researchers also analyzed the genetic changes in response to isolation and found that gene expression changes occurred within one day, mostly in metabolic genes. Metabolic changes were verified by increased lipid content in isolated flies. The study provides a reliable pipeline to analyze large groups of flies, revealing behavioral, molecular, and physiological impacts of isolation on social dynamics in Dophila.

The researchers used this pipeline to study the effects of isolation on social dynamics and correlated with genome-wide gene expression changes. Results showed strong effects on social dynamics, gene expression, and physiology. The method includes social network analysis, molecular, genetic, individual, and grouped behavioral analysis. Dophila is a powerful model to study social behavior and its mechanisms. Behavioral and gene changes initiated early, but lasted, while expression changes were transient. Data suggest flies alter physiology and behavior after one day of isolation to interact with neighboring flies. Walking distance was an individual parameter that changed and persisted. This approach differs from previous studies in classification and dataset extraction. A previous study found no effect of isolation on social networks, but this study found significant changes.
Researchers conducted a pilot study in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization's (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines, including a modality for age-based weight estimation. The study took place in two hospitals that lacked scales, necessitating weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with 10-day post-discharge follow-up. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. A total of 841 patients were enrolled (325 pre-intervention, 516 intervention). During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at both hospitals (p < 0.001) with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. However, when IV fluids were prescribed, the volume adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the antibiotic azithromycin increased (p < 0.001; p= 0.035) with RR of 6.9 and 1.6, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased; zinc adherence increased. The study demonstrates that a smartphone tool can improve guideline adherence.
Researchers studied the relationship between temperature and parasite dynamics within a host-parasite system using data from Daphnia magna and a microidian parasite. They developed a mechanistic model of within-parasite population dynamics based on metabolic theory of ecology, which predicts host survival, parasite growth, and infection cost across temperatures with fewer parameters than traditional models. The model integrates temperature dependencies of host and parasite traits such as aging, mortality, virulence, growth, and abundance. The study demonstrates the potential of linking metabolic models with mechanistic host-parite framework to predict temperature responses of parasite dynamics at the within-host level. Accurate predictions of climate change impacts on host-parite and disease require models that integrate distinct thermal dependencies of host and parasite traits. Development, survival, and movement can be described by simple formulae from metabolic theory, informing classical host-parite models to estimate temperature effects on disease prevalence and severity. The study empirically shows the power of linking metabolic thermal relationships for host and parasite in mechanistic within-parite models to understand temperature impacts on disease. The framework is valuable for predicting outcomes and consequences of infections for hosts and parasites under climate change due to its simplicity and generality.
Researchers studied how different types of inhibitory neurons, called interneurons, control the activity of excitatory neurons called pyramidal cells (PCs) in the brain. They found that three types of interneurons, parvalbum (PV), somostatin (SOM), and vaso intestinal (VIP), play a crucial role in shaping the activity of PCs. PV interneurons mainly target the soma and dendrites of PCs, while SOMneurons target the apical dendrites and inhibit other interneurons. VIPneurons connect to SOMneurons, creating a disinhibitory circuit for the distal dendrites of PCs. The researchers proposed that a network of SOM and VIP interneurons can control the redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition of PCs. Using a computational model, they showed that the properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. They demonstrated that the SOM-VIP motif allows the circuit to switch between two processing modes, either integrating or canceling top inputs onto the apical dendrites of PCs. The study suggests that this network can efficiently control different streams of information and processing modes.
Researchers have found that interactions between microorganisms in the microbiome can create false associations between specific microbes and host phenotypes, making it difficult to determine which microbes are directly linked to a particular disease or condition. They developed a method, called Direct Association Analysis, to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. The method corrected inflated p-values in association tests and showed only a small subset of associations are directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate, and brain-gut axis as factors in inflammatory disease. The study suggests that realistic interactions produce many spurious associations between microbiome and phenotypes, which can be removed by a procedure based on maximum entropy models from statistical physics. Microbiome association studies have been carried out for various disorders, including diabetes, arthritis, cancer, and autism. However, non-causal relationships give rise to spurious associations in both synthetic and real microbiome data. The study used parameters from a large case-control study on Crohn's disease and found traditional methods lost power to identify link between phenotype and microbiota. The number of detections increased for real data, suggesting many reported associations between microbi and IBD could be indirect.
Researchers compared the effect of Wolbachia infection on the replication and transmission of two flaviviruses, Dengue (DENV) and West Nile (WNV) viruses, in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes using two Wolbach infection models: stably infected and transiently infected. The study found that Wolia had a blocking effect on both models, but the magnitude was lower in transiently infected mosquitoes. No evidence was found for enhancement of either DENV or WNV infection in Wolia infected mosquitoes, suggesting Wolia as a safe means to restrict transmission of these viruses. Wolia has been shown to inhibit various pathogens, including DENV, CHV, WNV, YF, and Plasium, but some studies suggest infection can lead to enhanced pathogen replication. The interaction between Wolia and pathogen is influenced by host-Wolia interaction and infection model. In this study, Wolia density was lower in transiently infected mosquitoes, which may explain reduced D blocking effect. Experiments were repeated with WNV Kun strain, with similar results.
In the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans, cilia are microtub-based organelles that mediate signal transduction and are organized into structurally and functionally distinct compartments: the basal body, the transition zone (TZ), and the cilium. The mechanisms that establish and maintain the Invers compartment (Inv), a region of the cilium adjacent to the TZ, are unknown in vertebrates. In C elegans, the cilium of amphid and phasm sensory cilia are subdivided into regions by different microtub ultrastructure: a proximal doublet region adjacent to TZ and distal singlet region. It has been suggested that C elegans cilia possess an Inv, similar to mammalian primary cilia. This study explored the biogenesis, structure, and composition of Cans ciliary double region and Inv. Results show that Inv is conserved and distinct from double region. n-2 (Cans Invers homolog) and double region genes l-13, l-11, and unc-119 are redundantly required for cilogenesis. Inv and double region can be sorted into modules n-2p-11 and l-13-119, which are antagonized by hd-6 deacetyl. Genes of this network modulate sizes of N-2 Inv and A-13 double region. Glutlation, a tub-transl modification, is not required for ciliary of Inv and double region components; rather, glutlation is modulated by n-2, l- and-119. Ciliary and localization of N-, A- and UNC does not require TZ double region and Inv-associated genes. N- requires its calcium EF domain for targeting Inv.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Scribble plays a crucial role in the development and regeneration of myelin, the fatty insulation that surrounds nerve fibers in the central nervous system. Myelin is formed by oligodendrocytes, specialized cells that undergo significant shape changes to create the myelin sheath. Scribble is present throughout oligodendrocy development and is upregulated in mature oligodrocytes, where it is found in both developing and mature myelin sheaths. When Scri expression is knocked down in cultured oligodrocy, myelin initiation is disrupted. Scri is conditionally eliminated in myelinating glia of transgenic mice, myelin in CNS is disrupted during development and following demyelination, and myelin sheath extension is disrupted. Scri acts to regulate myelin thickness by suppressing the extracellular signal-related kinase (ER)/mitogen-activated protein (MAP) pathway and localizes to non-compact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier where it is required for axo-glial adhesion. Scri is essential for myelination and remyelination. Scri function is compartmentalized through interactions with different protein complexes at radial or longitudinal growth sites. Scri regulates oligodrocy morphological differentiation, myelin initiation, and myelin regulation. Scri also plays a role in myelin regeneration. In the absence of Scri, oligodrotes fail to initiate myelinate. Scri is restricted to noncompact myelin membranes and localizes to axo-gl adhesion. Scri regulates cell signaling and myelin thickness. Small diameter axons lack myelin sheaths in Scri CNS. Myelin thickness following development is not recapitulated remyel.
Researchers have discovered a new insights into the pathogenesis of several Gram-positive bacteria, including Listeria monocytogen, Staphylococcus aureus, and Clostridium botulin. Until now, modified virulence peptides have been rarely reported and Streptolysin-like peptides have been associated with Streptoccus species, including Group A and G streptococcus and Streptoccus iniae, a fish pathogen. However, evidence suggests that a number of gene clusters can be identified in other Gram-positive pathogens, including L monocytogen, aureus, and botulin. A specific focus on the monocogen cluster revealed an inducible cytotoxic and hemolytic peptide, Listerin S, which plays a role in survival of the pathogen in polymorphonuclear neutrophils and contributes to virulence in mouse model. Notably, the Listerin-associated cluster is variable, present in subset isolates from lineage I, evolutionary associated with majority of epidemics of this fatal pathogen. In silico analysis demonstrates gene clusters encoding S-like factors in notorious Gram pathogens, including monocogen, aureus, and botulin.
A study was conducted to investigate the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma granuloma, a persistent granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. The study found that IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, and less in Zone III, while MMP-9 was mainly in Zones II and III, and least in I. MMP-9 was highly expressed in Actinadura pelletii and Streptomyces somensis biopsies compared to Madure myetomatis biops. MMP-9 levels were directly proportional to IL-17 levels (p=0.001). The only association between MMP9 and patients' characteristics was disease duration (p<0.001). There was no correlation between IL-17 levels and patients' demographic characteristics. The study demonstrated that IL-17 and MMP-9 are present in myet granuloma, with IL-17 more in larger lesions and longer disease duration. A positive correlation was found between IL-17 and MMP-9 expression. Immunohistochemistry showed IL-17 and MMP-9 presence, but not formation time. Further studies are needed to determine IL-17 and MMP-9 roles in granuloma formation and myet immunogenesis.
Researchers studied the molecular recognition mechanism of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs), which are proteins that don't have a fixed 3D structure. They found that some IDPs remain disordered even when bound to a target protein, a phenomenon called "fuzziness". To understand this, they looked at the Ewing Sarcoma protein, a type of cancer-causing protein that is an ID. The protein has many aromatic side chains that help it bind to targets. They hypothesized that these chains interact with basic residues on the target through cation-π interactions, a common in protein-protein interactions. They tested this by changing the protein's sequence and found that c-π interactions are crucial for binding. A computer model of the protein also supported this. The study shows that ID binding is a balance between the protein's flexibility and favorable interactions with the target. This type of recognition is common in cancer-causing proteins and offers a new understanding of how they work.
Researchers studied the functions of two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2, in the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease and is transmitted by ticks. Previous work showed that Lon-1 is upregulated when exposed to blood, while Lon-2 is not. The study aimed to clarify the roles of these proteases in B. burgorferi. Phylogenetic analysis showed Lon-1 and Lon- cluster separately due to differences in substrate binding domains, suggesting different specificity. Recombinant Lon-1 had ATP-dependent chaperone-protease properties but did not complement E. coli mutant, while Lon-2 corrected Lon-mut phenotypes. The study concludes that B. burgorfer Lon-1 and-2 have distinct roles. Lon-2 functions like canonical Lon in cellular homeostasis, while Lon-1, induced by blood, may be important for host adaptation from arthropod to warm-blood host.
Researchers investigated the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in controlling HIV-1 infection. AD is a process where antibodies help cells engulf and internalize foreign particles, but its role in HIV is unknown. They tested the ability of HIV-specific antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-infected cells by phagocytes. Using a green-fluorescent protein-expressing HIV-1 clone and polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies, they found minimal or no AD of virions with any antibodies. However, coating virions with gp41 or gp-derived peptides, but not gp120, specific antibodies efficiently mediated phagytosis. A few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagytosis, similar to the number on influenza virus. Fluorescence correlation spectroscopy showed a clear association between virus aggregation and AD. In contrast, vir-decorated cells were targets for AD orgocytosis in presence of HIV antibodies. Findings indicate AD of vir may not play a role in preventing infection due to paucity of trimers and inability of vir-bound antibody to cross FcRs on phocytes. However, AD orocyt could play in clearing infected cells on verge of infection.
A new study estimated the global economic and health burden of hookworm infection in 2016 from a societal perspective. The results showed that hookworm resulted in 2,126,280 disability-adjusted life years (DALs) using 200 disability estimates and 4,087,803 DALs using 201 estimates, excluding cognitive impairment. Including cognitive impairment did not significantly increase DALs worldwide. Productivity losses varied depending on the probability of anemia and calculation method, ranging from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as proxy wages. Hookworm is classified as a neglected disease, but its economic burden exceeded estimates of diseases that received more attention, such as rotavirus. Countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face significant hookworm burden. A previous study reported 3,230,800 DALs annually due to hook among all ages in 21 regions, but did not include cognitive impairment. Assuming median anemia, hook infections resulted in productivity losses of $11.1 billion (95%: $5.5-18.5) using method 1, $87.9 (95:1.7-302.3) method 2, and $23.1 (11.4-38.4) method 3. Using minimum wage, global burden was $3.3 billion. The number of hook infections with health outcomes and DALs varied by region and country due to productivity proxy, estimates, and estimates. China had 35,917,360 hook infections resulting in $6.7 billion losses.
Researchers studied how oxygen deprivation (hypoxia) affects the developing brain in vertebrates, such as zebraf fish, and found that it disrupts the pathfinding of brain neurons, leading to errors in crossing the midline of commissural axons. This is similar to what happens in in invertebrates, such as Caenorhabditis elegans, where hypox causes axon pathfinding errors in certain neurons and motorneurons. They found that hypia activates the hypox-inducible transcription factor (h1) pathway, which is mimicked by chemical inducers of h1 or expression of constitutively active h1. Blocking transcription activation of h1 prevented the defects. EphrinB2, a protein, was identified as a target of h1 activation, and its knockdown rescued the errors. EphA4, a receptor, is expressed in a pattern complementary to misrouting axons. Constitutively active EphB2 targeted to neurons showed Eph2 mediates errors via reverse-signaling. Magnesium, used to improve outcomes in preterm births, protects against errors by preventing upregulation of Eph2.
Researchers studied pulmonary abnormalities in mice infected with paracidiomycosis, a fungal disease caused by Paracidi brasiliensis, using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathology. Fifty male mice were inoculated with the fungus or a placebo. HRCT scans were taken every four weeks to track lung lesions, density, and lung structure. Histology and histometry were also analyzed. Three types of lesions were found: nodular-diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-tum. Lesions were mainly around the hilus, affecting the left lung. At four weeks post-infection, 80% of infected mice had peri-bronial consolidations with increased lung density compared to controls. After eight and twelve weeks, consolidation spread to middle regions. Histology showed consolidation as confl granulomatous reaction, nodules as compact granomas. At sixteen weeks, confl granomas formed pseudooral masses obstructing bronchi. Discrete fibrosis was visible around granomas, only by histology. This study showed HRCT is useful for evaluating and quantifying damage in experimental paridiomycosis.
Researchers investigated the use of an interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γ) as a marker for latent Leishmania donovani infection in areas where visceral leishmaniasis is endemic. They modified a commercial kit, QuFERON, with five Leishmania antigens to detect cell-mediated immune response. The study included 13 active VL patients, 15 cured patients, 11 non-endemic controls, and 19 endemic controls. The assay based on soluble Leish antigen (SL) had 80% sensitivity and 100 specificity. The results suggest a whole-blood SL-based QuFER assay can measure cell-mediated response to Leish infection. A surprising finding was IF-γ production in active VL patients upon Leish antigen stimulation, contradicting previous non-proliferative antigen response in peripheral mononuclear cells. All groups showed positive IF- responses to PH, a non-specific T-cell activator, indicating immunocompetence. Antigens H2, H-PS2, H-Le12, CSA, and SL were positive in 0, 9, 18, and 63 of subjects respectively. Antigen-specific IF- levels were determined by subtracting non-stimulated levels. The highest response was with SL (84.6). CSA, containing the promastigote part, showed positive responses in non-endemic controls, while Le12, a nuclear protein, showed low sensitivity and specificity.
Researchers have discovered that a toxin called CNFY plays a crucial role in making Yersinia pseudotuberculosis persistent in the body. This bacterium causes gastrointestinal infections that can lead to complications such as relapsing enteritis and autoimmune disorders. To establish a persistent infection, the bacteria must navigate through the intestinal lining and colonize the underlying lymphatic tissues, evading the host's immune response. The study found that CNFY toxin enhances the transfer of anti-phagocytic effectors, leading to inflammatory responses and tissue destruction of the intestinal microbiota and bacterial clearance. However, suppressing CNFY function increases interferon-mediated responses, non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities, and tolerogenesis, allowing the pathogen to reprogram its transcription towards persistence. This adaptation gives the bacteria an advantage against host responses and facilitates a commensal lifestyle.

The study shows that removing a single virulence factor, CNFY, is sufficient to dampen inflammation and evade the host's defense, favoring Yers persistence. The mechanisms behind this process are unclear, but the impact of CNFY suggests a set of immune responses, such as IL-6 levels, modulators, bactericidal activities, and anti-inflammatory factors, contributing to this process. The study also found that CN-promoted tissue damage accelerates pathogen access to deeper tissues and facilitates systemic infections, beneficial to strains with reduced invasion properties. CN toxin constitutively activates Rho GTPases deidation and Y translocation into host, enhancing inflammation and damage. Suppressing CN function shifts the balance towards immune suppression, promoting asymptomatic persistent infection.
Researchers have identified a novel gene, DES1, in the fungus Magnaporthe oryza, that plays a crucial role in its ability to colonize and reproduce in plants. To do this, the fungus must overcome the plant's innate defenses. DES1 was found by screening for mutants that had reduced pathogenicity in a library of T-DNA insertions. Bioinformatics analysis showed it encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown function, and its homologs are conserved in filamentous Ascomycetes. Deleting DES1 had no effect on growth, conidial germination, appressium formation, and penetration, but conid size was smaller. The mutant was hypersensitive to oxidative stress and had decreased extracellular enzyme activity, including peroxidases and laccases, and ferrous ion leakage. In interaction with rice, cells inoculated with the mutant showed strong defense responses, including brown granules, ROS, autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction. The mutant had reduced infectious hyph extension and pathity. Suppressing ROS with DPI, an inhibitor of NAD oxidases, reduced defense responses and allowed the mutant to grow normally. This suggests DES functions as a pathogenic gene that regulates ROS-mediated plant defense.
Researchers in Ghana evaluated the accuracy of a mathematical model used to predict the prevalence of Schistosoma haematium infection, a type of schistosomiasis, in schools across the country. They compared the model's predictions to actual infection rates found in 79 schools surveyed in 2010. The study found that using the model alone, 21 schools with high infection rates would have been undertreated and 20% would have been treated unnecessarily. This would have meant 28% of children in those schools were undertreated and 12% received treatment without need. The researchers suggest the model should not be used as a one-time tool, but rather an iterative process that incorporates testing and refining to create updated versions for disease control managers. 

The study used school-based data from 2010 surveys in previously and newly sampled districts to evaluate the 2008 model predictions. Schosoma haemat is Ghana's most common schistome infection. The model's predictions were compared to empiric results from the 201 survey. Extrapolating to Ghana's endemic area, many people would have been undertreated and praziquel used inappropriately in other areas. The approach tested a geospatial model for schosiasis in Ghana based on treating areas by examining school children and basing treatment on findings. WHO does not recommend treating at district level as done in Ghana. The model aggregating estimates to district level was not accurate enough for the program. Certain areas predicted to be endemic had no infection when empirically evaluated.
Researchers have investigated the mechanisms that guide sperm through the female reproductive tract to the egg in Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that the worm's oocytes synthesize a mixture of prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUA) precursors in yolk protein complexes. Using genetics and mass spectrometry, they identified prostland metabolism pathways and showed that omega-6 and omega-3 PAs, including arachid and eicosapentaic acids, are converted into more than 10 structurally related prostagins. These prostins collectively and redundantly promote sperm guidance. Disrupting omega-3 PU synthesis triggers compensatory upregulation of prostins from omega-6 PAs. C elegans prostin synthesis involves mechanisms distinct from mammalian cycxygen pathways, yet PG2 stereomers are still synthesized. A conserved cytochrome P enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Biet's Crystine dystrophy, regulates prostin synthesis. Results support the model that multiple cycxygen-independent prostins function to promote sperm motility for fertilization.
Researchers have developed a new method to design biotherapeutic proteins that are less likely to trigger an immune response while maintaining their function. This approach, called Pareto optimal design, optimizes for both reduced T cell epitope content and high-level function. In silico analysis showed that there is no single best design, but rather a spectrum of designs that trade off between immunogenic potential and function. The Pareto frontier is the set of designs that are not dominated by any other design in both criteria.

Eight Pareto optimal variants were produced and experimentally analyzed, showing a correlation between computational and experimental results. This work outlines a design-based approach to functional deimmization of biotherapeutic candidates. Next-generation protein design tools integrate immunoinform epitope prediction and in silico analysis of functional consequences of deimmizing mutations, enabling global design on a compressed time scale. Predictions correlated with experimental function, with incremental T epitope deletion leading to loss of function.

Inspection of Pareto designs reveals an inverse relationship: greater deimmization at expense of reduced function. To assess tradeoffs, 18 enzymes were recombinantly produced and characterized for stability, activity, and immunactivity with human MHC proteins.
Researchers studied how temperature affects the process of meiosis in Arabidopsis thalian, a type of plant. Meiosis is a critical for sexual reproduction and involves the exchange of genetic material between chromosomes to ensure proper segregation. The frequency and distribution of these exchanges, called crossovers (CO), are regulated by internal and external factors, but more is known about the internal mechanisms than external. The study found that increased temperature leads to more crossovers in Arabidopsis and used genetic analysis to show that these are from the Type I pathway, sensitive to interference, not the insensitive Type II pathway. They also found that increased crosso are not due to more DNA breaks and the hyper-recombination is specific to heat stress, not a general response. This provides insight into how environmental cues affect meiotic recombination and may have practical applications.
Researchers have developed a novel computational approach to navigate the vast and rapidly evolving landscape of biomedical literature, particularly in molecular medicine. The system, called Hanalyzer, combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods to facilitate analysis of experimental data. It extracts information from external resources, structured or unstructured data, and tracks provenance. Reasoning enriches the results by noting genes annotated to the same term or database, and combines sources into a network representing relationships between genes, calculating a reliability score. Reporting combines the network with congruent constructed from data and visualizes in a tool for knowledge-based analysis. Hanalyzer was demonstrated on a large gene array dataset relevant to craniofacial development, identifying roles of four previously uncharacterized genes, validated by further work.

The system includes a plugin, Coscape, tracing provenance links and accessing sources (Figure 2). It identified explanations by exploiting inferences not in individual sources. To present knowledge relevant to a dataset, sub-networks are selected and presented in a comprehensible way. A simple approach visualizes fidials, a list generating sub-network including them. A more effective method creates a data network from experimental results and combines in various ways. Here, a data is constructed from gene expression experiment.

Biomedical knowledge is expanding exponentially, with over 10 million PubMed indexed in 20 years, 4.8% annual growth. Combining knowledge with data highlights supported linkages, facilitating explanation, or unsupported linkages generating hypotheses. Both can be together, demonstrated.
Researchers have studied the molecules on the surface of extracellular vesicles (EVs) secreted by the parasite Fasciola hepatica, a liver fluke that infects humans and animals. These EVs can be internalized by host cells, modulating the immune response. While the cargo of EVs has been characterized in many parasites, little is known about the surface molecules that interact with host cells to initiate internalization. The study used a membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins on the outer surface of two EV populations (15k and 120) released by adult F. hepatica, identifying 380 proteins including virulence factors, transport and molecules involved in EV biogenesis. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis showed 120 EVs have an endosomal origin and are released via the protonephial excretory system, while larger 15 EVs are from gastrodermal cells lining the gut. Lectin microarray profiled surface oligosaccharides of intact EVs displayed to the host, showing identical profiles for 15 and 120 EV but distinct from parasite tegument, with high mannose sugars. EV were resistant to exo and endoglycosidases, but glycosidase remodelled surface and blocked uptake by macrophages. Pre-treatment with host antibodies or purified against EV surface proteins enhanced internalization.
Researchers have identified a protein called Arabidopsis CDF2 that plays a crucial role in regulating microRNA (miRNA) production in plants. miRNAs are small molecules that help control gene expression and are essential for plant development. CDF2 interacts with an enzyme called Dicer 1 (D1) that cuts miRNA precursors into mature miRNAs. C2 binds to the promoters of some miRNA genes, acting as an activator or repressor to control their expression. It also binds to miRNA precursors (pri-miRNAs) regulated by itself and affects D1 processing. C2 works in the same pathway as mi156 and mi172 to control flowering. C2 regulates a group of pri-miRNAs at both transcription and post-transcription levels to maintain proper miRNA levels for plant development. This regulation involves coordination of transcription and processing of pri-mRNAs. C2 also affects expressions of components involved in miRNA biogenesis, potentially affecting biogenesis. Some C2-regulated miRNAs are involved in flowering, including mi156,160,167,172,165/166, and319. The study focused on mi156 and172, two well-studied miRNAs. Results suggest C2 may regulate biogenesis by regulating mi processing proteins in addition to direct transcription and postcription regulations of pri-mRN. The study supports a role of C2 in mi regulation.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GG) plays a crucial role in the communication between the oocyte and granulosa cells in the ovary. This communication is essential for the development of follicles, which provide eggs for reproduction. The study found that GG levels increase in oocytes during early follicular development. Depletion of GG in oocytes impaired granosa cell proliferation, primary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GG inhibited Rho GTPase gergeranylation and GTP activity, leading to accumulation of cell proteins in the oocyte cytoplasm and loss of connection between oocyte and granosa. GG also blocked Rab27 geranylation, affecting secretion of o materials such as G9. Administration of GG restored defects in o-granosa contact, granosa proliferation, and primary transition in Gpps mice. The study shows GG-mediated geranylation contributes to o-granosa communication and regulates primary follicle transition, a key phase of follicogenesis for female function.
Researchers have created a detailed model of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) enzyme, which is responsible for synthesizing messenger RNA from DNA, to understand how nucleotide triphosphate (NTP) enters the enzyme's active site during transcription. Despite previous studies, it was unclear whether the secondary channel or main channel was the primary route for NTP entry. The researchers built a structural model of Pol II with a complete transcription bubble using existing data and molecular dynamics simulations to shed light on NTP pathways. They found that both channels have enough space for NTP, but the secondary channel has a higher percentage of conformations with enough space for N loading. Simulations showed that NTP diffusion through the main channel is disfavored by electrostatic repulsion with the negatively charged backbone of non-template DNA. The study suggests the secondary channel is the major route for NTP entry during Pol transcription.
In Thailand and Cambodia, deng is a reportable disease, but the reported incidence underestimates the true burden. Researchers used laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases from prospective studies to estimate the magnitude of underrecognition and establish accurate disease estimates. Two cohort studies were conducted among children under 15 in deng field sites over two seasons. Age-specific multiplication factors (MF) were calculated by comparing cohort data to national surveillance in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14,493 from one in Cambodia. Annual incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand, and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated MF varied by age and year (0.4-29). Average age-specific MF applied to country data indicated in Thailand 229,886 (210,612-331,236) deng cases annually 2003-2007 and 111,178 (80,452,357,135) in Cambodia. Underrecognition total inpatient deng cases was 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand, and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. During high incidence 2007, over 95,000 in Thailand and 58,000 in Cambodia were estimated hospitalized due to deng. Calculating MF by cohort to surveillance is one approach to assess burden. Data indicate deng reported in many countries underestimates true burden.
Researchers investigated how natural killer (NK) cells contribute to the immune response against cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. They found that NK cells accelerate the development of CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that fights infection, by controlling the production of immunosuppressive cytokines, which can dampen the immune response. This is achieved by limiting the activation of plasmacyoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and preserving conventional dendritic cells (DC), allowing for optimal CD8 cell activation. In contrast, administering exogenous interferon-alpha (IFN) ablated DCs and delayed CD8 cell activation when NK cells controlled viral replication. The study demonstrates that NK cells' ability to respond early to CMV infection is crucial for balancing innate responses, preventing immunopathology, and promoting adaptive immunity.
Researchers studied the regulation of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes in Arabidopsis thalian plants, a small flowering plant commonly used in scientific research. r genes are organized in arrays of hundreds to thousands of copies, but not all are transcribed under normal conditions. They found four rRNA variants in Arabid thalian, with one induced and others repressed or unchanged in plants with a disrupted nucleolin-like gene (At-L). Notably, the most represented rRNA variant, inactive in normal plants, was reactivated in mutants. They showed pre-rNAs originate from RNA I transcription and are processed. Disrupting theNU-L gene caused loss of DNA methylation without affecting histone marks on r genes. The study reveals a mechanism for r gene regulation, with nucleolin controlling active and repressed r variants.
Researchers have identified a protein from the human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) called UL29 that interacts with a cellular complex called NuRD, which is involved in histone deacetylation. Histone deetylation is a process that regulates gene expression by adding or removing acetyl groups to histone proteins. The interaction between UL29 and Nu was confirmed using a technique called immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry. The researchers found that UL29 and another viral protein, UL38, also interact with HD1, a component of the Nu complex. Knocking down two other components of Nu, RBP and CH4, inhibited CMV immediateearly RNA and DNA accumulation, suggesting that multiple Nu components are needed for efficient CM replication. Inhibiting histone deety with a drug, trichatin A, did not rescue UL29 or UL38 deficient viruses, indicating a positive role for Nu in CM replication. Expressing UL29 alone enhanced the CM major early promoter in a reporter assay, and required Nu components to do so. The researchers propose that UL29 modifies Nu to stimulate early RNA accumulation.
Researchers studied the immune response to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in children to understand how the body's immune system reacts to the virus and how it changes over time. They used a technique called whole-genome-fragment display libraries to analyze the antibodies in the blood of infants before and after they got infected with RSV. The results showed that the antibodies to the fusion protein (F) didn't change much, but the antibodies to the attachment protein (G) increased 100 times after infection. The antibodies to G targeted different parts of the G protein, including the central conserved domain. The researchers made synthetic peptides and proteins to test the antibodies in children, adolescents, and adults. They found that the antibodies to F increased over time and identified new sites on the protein. Importantly, antibodies to the pre-fusion form of F were 2-3 times stronger than to the post-fusion form. Antibodies to G were high in children after infection but decreased in adults. This study shows that the immune response to F and G are linked and supports the idea that the virus evolves to evade the immune system. These findings can help develop effective countermeasures like vaccines.
Emodeide, a veterinary drug used to treat nematode infections in cats and dogs, has been shown to have macrofidal effects on adult Brug mal, a parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis. Researchers studied how emide works on Brug mal and found it potently inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. They discovered that emide targets S-1 channels, a type of potassium channel, and found that a specific isoform of S-1 found in males is more sensitive to emide than the isoform found in females. They also found that knocking down the isoform in females increased emide potency. Onchercavolus, another parasite that causes blindness, has two isoforms of S-1 with similar to Brug mal. Modeling showed that emide binds to a pocket in the R1 region of S-1, which is affected by splicing variations. This suggests that emide has potent macroidal effects and splicing in the R1 pocket affects potency. The study highlights the importance of evaluating sex-dependent effects of anthelmint compounds to prevent underdosing one gender of nematodes in patients.
Researchers have identified Loa antigens responsible for cross-reacting with rapid diagnostic tests for lymphatic filariasis. These tests are used to determine where mass drug administration for lymphatic filariasis is required and when it can be stopped. The tests detect Wuchereria bancrofti glycoprotein in the blood of infected persons via a carbohydrate moiety recognized by monoclonal antibodies AD12 and DH.5. However, Loa cross-reactivity with these tests has hindered lymphatic filariasis elimination in Loa-endemic areas. To understand this cross-reactivity, researchers used the DH.5 antibody to immunoaffinity purify Loa antigens from sera of individuals with positive tests due to Loa. Immunlot analysis revealed many AD/DH.5-reactive antigens and proteomic analysis identified multiple Lo proteins in Lo-positive sera. These included secreted and somatic proteins, suggesting they may be released by dying Lo adult worms and microfilar. Unlike the single molecular W. bancft circulating antigen, Lo antigens appeared transiently present in blood of a subset persons with Lo. Differences between antigens of W. bancft and Lo can be used to differentiate results generated by species and lead to improved tests for lymphatic and Lo.
Researchers used the nematode C. elegans to identify new genes associated with cilia, specialized sensory and signaling devices on cell surfaces. Defects in cilia cause human disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bardet-Bied syndrome (BBS), affecting multiple physiological and developmental processes across organs. Whole-organ RNA-Seq libraries revealed a signature profile highly enriched for known ciliary transcripts, including FAM161, CC104, and RP1. From a list of 185 candidates, orthologs of MAP, YAP, CC149, and R28 were conserved ciliary components. C. elegans R-28, associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, is a small GTPase exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons, dynamically associating with intraflagellar transport (IFT) trains. Inactive R-28 displays no IFT and diffuse localization, while GTP-bound R-28 concentrates at the periciliary membrane in BBS-dependent manner and undergoes bidirectional IFT. Functional analyses show normal cilium, sensory, and I in a-28 null, but overexpression of GDP or GTP locked R-28 perturbs cil and sensory morphogenesis.
Researchers investigated how the brain represents the outside world using neural responses from the brain, without direct access to external stimuli. They used hippocampal place cells as a model and found that knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals structure in the stimulus space, enabling the brain to construct its own representations. This is different from previous approaches that required knowing place fields or functions relating to position. The study showed that knowing which groups of hippocal cells fire is enough to extract global features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of space, including the animal's position. This was done without assuming place fields have a stereotypical form or knowing actual fields or prior measurements of position. In contrast, previous approaches to reconstructing position from place activity required knowing place fields. The study found that coarse features of population spiking activity yield a great deal of information about the environment, making it possible to track the animal's position.
Researchers investigated the role of the NLRP inflamome and IL-1β in viral fulminant hepatitis (FH), a severe liver disease caused by excessive inflammation. Mice infected with the murine hepatitis virus-3 (MH-3), a model for FH, showed severe disease and high mortality associated with increased IL-1β in the liver and serum. Mice lacking IL-1 receptor (IL-1-) or treated with IL-1 antagonist (IL-Ra) had reduced virus replication, disease, and mortality.IL-1 deficiency debilitated virus-induced fibrinogen-like protein-2 (F2) production in macrophages and CD45+Gr1 neutrophil infiltration in the liver. The release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by infected macrophages suggested plausible initiation of NLR3 inflamome activation. Experiments showed mice deficient in p47ph, a nicotin adenine dinucleotide (NAD) oxidase subunit controlling ROS production, had reduced NLR inflamome activation and IL-β secretion during viral infection, responsible for resilience to FH. Viral animals deficient in NLR and Casp-1, inflamome components, had reduced IL-β and ameliorated hepatitis. Results demonstrate the ROS/NLR/IL-β axis essential pathway, activated causing severe liver disease during infection, shedding light on treatments for human FH and inflammatory diseases.
Researchers conducted a study in Malawi to investigate the role of hookworm infections in severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. They used multiplex real-time PCR to assess hook species-specific prevalence, load, and their contribution to anemia and iron deficiency. The study found 34.1% of severely anemic children and 27.0% non-severely anemic controls had hookworm infections, with 5.6% detected by microscopy. Ancylostoma duale and Necator american DNA were present in 26.1% and 4.9% of children, respectively. Moderate to high A. duale infections were associated with severe anemia (adjusted odds ratio 2.49, 95%CI 1.16-5.33 and 9.04, 95CI 2.52-32.47) and iron deficiency (odds ratio 3.63, 95CI 1.18-11.20, 16.98 95CI 3.88.74.35 and 44.91 95 5.23-385.77 for low, moderate, and high load). This is the first study to assess hook load and species with anemia and bone iron deficiency. The results show a higher than expected prevalence of A duale and significant association with anemia and iron in pre-school children in Malawi, highlighting the need for species-specific screening. Multiplex real PCR is a powerful tool for public health to combat anemia and iron deficiency in resource settings.
Researchers have identified a protein called COM-1 in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans that plays a crucial role in the process of meiosis, a type of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells. Meiosis requires the repair of double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA, which can be done through two ways: homologous recombination (HR) or non-homous joining (NJ). HR is necessary for the formation of interchromosomal crossovers (COs) that allow for proper chromosome segregation. Without COM-1, cells repair DS via the error-prone NJ pathway, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal abnormalities, and near-complete embryonic lethality. COM1 is not required for the initiation of meiotic DS repair, but promotes HR by counteracting the NJ complex Ku. In fact, animals lacking both COM1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. COM acts parallel to the nuclease EX-1 to promote interolog HR at the early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase, safeguarding CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD-51 recruitment at late pachene, when hom-independent pathways predominate, suggesting redundancy and regulation of DNA resection during meiotic pro. The study reveals the lethal properties of NJ during meiosis and a critical role for COM1 in NJ inhibition and CO in germ cells.
Researchers studied the immune response of goats to Burkholderia pseudallei, a bacterium that causes meloidosis, a severe pneumonia and sepsis in Southeast Asia and Australia. They used an aerosol infection model to mimic the disease in goats, which is more similar to human infection than previous mouse models. The study aimed to identify proteins that trigger an immune response, which could lead to new diagnostics and vaccines. The researchers found that goats developed a strong immune response to the bacterium, with more IgG antibodies than IgM antibodies. Before infection, goats already had some immune proteins reactive to the bacterium, and after infection, the number of Ig reactive proteins increased. Early in the disease, goats reacted to proteins GroEL, EF-T, and Dna, which were detected in all samples. Six antigens were selected for further analysis, and heat shock protein Gro1 elicited the strongest immune response. Most antigens showed peak IgM reactivity at day 14, while IgG increased as disease progressed. Comparison with human sera showed many reactive proteins common between goats and humans with meloidosis. The study found a diverse and increasing antibody response over disease in goats, with Ig and IgM responses in individual serum samples. The researchers used ELISA, 2D electrophores, and western blots to analyze the immune response. They also developed ELISA to quantify antibodies to whole lysate and individual antigens. Total IgM was stable with most antigens throughout 7-14 days. The study compared goat response with human antigens in meloid patients and found similar responses in goats and humans.
Cyclin B–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk1) plays a crucial role in initiating mitosis by triggering a positive feedback loop at the end of the G2 phase. However, its activation during mitosis has been poorly understood. Researchers used a novel approach to study the temporal development of cyclin B–C1dk activity in single cells by quantifying dephosphorylation of C1 and phosphorylation of its target anaphase-promoting complex/cycome 3. They found that cyclin B–C1 continues to be activated after centros separation and can be maintained in the cytoplasm even when cyclin B translocates to the nucleus in prophase. This suggests that increasing cyclin B–1C1 activity after centros separation is critical for mitotic progression. 

The study indicates that mitotic cyclin B–1C1 activity needs to increase after entry and pass a threshold before metaphase to allow mitotic progression and exit. Distinct thresholds for cyclin B–1C1 activity control successive mitotic events. Cyclin B–1C1 is activated in late G2 and increases between centros separation and prometaph. Reducing C1 levels affects mitotic progression, with a threshold that autocatalyzes cyclin B–1C1 activation and entry into mitosis. Cyclin B–1C1 contributes to centros separation in G. In human cells, active cyclin–1C1 is detected on centros before they start to migrate at end G or pro.
Researchers studied the immune responses of 21 Kenyan women who were infected with HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D after being exposed to different partners, a median of 1.07 years after initial infection. The women's plasma samples were collected 2.72 years post-infection. The study focused on 4 main HIV-1 envelope epitopes: the CD4 binding site, V1/V glycan, N332 site in V3, and gp41 membrane proximal region. Epitope mapping and computational analysis showed no dominant response to these epitopes in any of the women's plasma. This suggests that superinfection with diverse subtypes promotes a broad polyclonal response, supporting vaccine designs using multivalent immunogens to elicit diverse Nabs. 

Previous studies on singly infected individuals with broad and potent responses showed 72-94% targeting 4 main epitopes. This study is the first to examine specificities in a superinfected cohort. Exposure to diverse HIV antigens after superfection may drive broad and potent response mediated by polycl antibodies targeting multiple epitopes.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide, but the underlying mechanisms are not well-defined. Research has shown that CMV dysregulates the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hairy Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) is essential for NPC fate and brain development as an important downstream effector of Notch signaling. This study reports that CMV downregulates Hes protein levels in NPCs. The CMV 72Da immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) is involved in Hes degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting Hes ubiquination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of Hes. SpA, a component of PML bodies, is another target of IE-mediated ubiquination. The C-terminal region of IE, amino acids 451-475, is required for IE/Hes interaction and IE-mediated Hes ubiquination, but dispensable for IE/SpA interaction and ubiquination. This study suggests a novel mechanism linking downregulation of Hes protein to neurodevelopment disorders caused by CMV infection, complementing knowledge of herpesviruses by identifying IE as the first CM-encoded E3 ubiquitin ligase.
Researchers studied how changes in the binding of transcription factors to DNA affect gene expression in embryos of four Drosophila species: D. melanogaster, D. yakuba, D. pseudoobscura, and D. virilis. They compared the binding of four transcription factors involved in early anterior-posterior patterning using ChIP-seq and measured gene expression using mRNA-seq. The study found that gene expression levels are more conserved than individual transcription factor binding events, and changes in gene expression are not well explained by changes in transcription factor binding. However, highly bound sites in regions bound by multiple factors and near genes are conserved more than other binding sites, suggesting weak or non-functional transcription factor binding not subject to purifying selection.

The study found that the extent of conservation for each factor decreased with increasing phylogenetic distance between species. Few regions were bound by factors in all four species. Quantitative and qualitative comparisons showed transcription factor binding diverged within Dophila genus. The study compared divergence to binding divergence and found only 3-7% of variance in TF binding between species, 21% if phylogenetic inertia not considered.

mRNA-seq from embryos at end of cellularization showed mRNA levels highly correlated between species, decaying with phylogenetic distance. Divergence of mRNA was lower than TF binding, measured by variance along Doph tree. On a gene-by-gene basis, matched each gene to closest bound by highest TFs, focusing on 4,846 annotated in all species and expressed at least one.
A large-scale epidemiological study was conducted in two primary health centers in Thanjav district, India, which is endemic for bancroftian filariasis, to assess the effectiveness of eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) and identify potential transmission "hotspots". The study covered 70% of the 50,363 population and found a microfilaria (M) prevalence of 0.2% and intensity 0.004 per 60µl blood, and antigena (Ag) prevalence 2.3% and 17.3 units. The Ag prevalence ranged from 0.7 to 0.9% in children 2-10 years and 2.7 to 3.0 in adults. Despite M levels <1% and Ag <2 in sentinel sites, "residual" M prevalence ≥1 was found in 7% of children and "transmission" at least one Ag-positive child during M period hotspots were identified. Antigenemic persons were clustered at household and site levels. An Ag prevalence of 1% in children (0.4 community M prevalence) was suggested as a threshold for stopping MDA. The study indicates the need for developing surveillance strategies to detect hotspots, adopting evidence-based sampling, and evaluation size for transmission assessment surveys.
A systematic review was conducted to assess the effectiveness of temeph, an organophosphate laricide, in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other methods. A comprehensive search of six databases and grey literature was performed, and 27 studies were included. Single intervention studies showed temeph reduced entomological indices, while 11 of 16 combined studies showed tem with other chemical methods reduced entom indices, but this was not sustained or failed to reduce immature stages in five. Effectiveness depended on factors such as delivery quality, water rate, type, debris, temperature, and sunlight. Timing, reapplication, reluctance, cost, supplies, time, and labour were limitations. As a single intervention, tem was effective in suppressing entom indices, but not when combined with other interventions. No evidence suggests tem use reduces deng transmission. The review highlights effectiveness of tem varies greatly, and lack of data on entom indices to d transmission remains a gap in deng epidemiology and control.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Ctf19 kinetore complex and the replication factor C3 in establishing cohesion at the pericentere, the region surrounding the centrom.
