They found that these two components act through distinct mechanisms, with the C19 complex directing the association of cohes with the pericere and C3 ensuring its functionality in holding sister centrom together. The C19 complex consists of proteins I3 and Ch4, which increase cohes binding to the pericere during mitosis and meiosis, and are essential for sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation. In contrast, C3 is crucial for the integrity of the replisome and its association with cohesion factors as it traverses the protein-DNA barrier surrounding the centrom. The researchers propose that the C19 complex loads cohes at the centrom prior to replication fork passage, ensuring its incorporation through a process requiring C3. Delaying replication rescues the defect in cells lacking C19 components, but not C3. Cells lacking both C19 and C3 show additive cohesion defects.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a widespread arbovirus that infects approximately 100 million people annually, primarily in tropical and subtropical regions. Dengue fever (DF) and deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF) are major public health concerns. To understand the underlying mechanisms of deng pathogenesis, researchers analyzed the serum metabolome and lipidome of adult patients at three stages of infection: early fever, defervescence, and convalescence. Using liquid chromatography and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, they identified 60 differential metabolites in a large sample size (n=44) across stages. The main metabolite classes were fatty acids, acylcarnines, phospholids, and amino acids. Perturbed pathways included fatty biosynthesis, β-oxidation, phosphid catabolism, and steroid. Analysis of phospholids and sphingolids showed temporal trends and association with lymphocytes and platelets. These metabolites were perturbed early and normalized to control levels at convales stage, suggesting potential as prognostic markers. DENV causes distinct serumome and lipidome changes, with many metabolites involved in inflammatory responses. The study revealed anti-inflammatory responses modulating early-inflammatory processes, preventing excessive or prolonged inflammation. This is the first example of omic approach divulging concurrent, dynamic host responses to DENV, offering physiological insights into why DF is self-limiting.
Research on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) has increased in recent years, with significant gaps in diagnostic and treatment remaining. Analyzing bibliometric data from research is a powerful method to reveal research efforts, partnerships, and expertise. This study aimed to map NTD research in Germany and its partners to enable informed and transparent evaluation of German contributions to NTD. A SCOPUS database search for articles with German affiliations published between 2002-2012 was conducted for kinoplast and helminth diseases. From 26,833 publications worldwide, 1,187 (4.4%) had at least one German affiliation, and 972 were processed for five most-published diseases. 4,007 authors and 863 institutions were extracted to construct co-author networks. Most co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries, Brazil. Collaborations with Africa remain scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. Strong performers were identified on individual level using parameters (publications, h-index) and social analysis (between centrality). Network varied between diseases. Share of N publications with German affiliations is half of other medical fields. This underlines need to identify and expand Germany's strong research towards NTD. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad can support decisions to strengthen capacity, particularly low-middle countries involved less than high. Identifying knowledge within researcher complements traditional indicators opportunities for collaboration.
In Haiti, a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) has been implemented since 2000 by the Ministry of Health and its international partners. By 2012, the program had reached national scale with high epidemiological coverage, allowing treatment to be stopped in most of the country. Key to this success were program elements: community awareness through multi-channel education, voluntary distributors, community trust through training and supervision, directly observed treatment, easy access, and data-driven strategies. High coverage (100% in 2012) and significant reduction in infection (45 communes reached LF threshold) show these strategies were effective. Haiti's campaign, with international support, resulted in progress toward LF elimination and strong STH control foundation. 

The likelihood of taking treatment was associated with knowledge, disease understanding, transmission, strategy, risk, and side effects in other studies. In Haiti, knowledge was low and not associated with MDA participation. In Grand'An department, with 72% prevalence in 2001, decline was less than others, remaining at 55. Results show progress addressing STH, but question how to continue after MDA ceases. A successful campaign was launched in 200 with high rates, progress toward LF elimination (more rounds in high prevalence, fewer low). A foundation for STH control was established. Factors determining treatment were knowing M place and ease of access. Direct observation increased participation in other settings. M activities now stopping, Haiti turned to morbidity efforts, building on hydro surgery and lymphema support.
Researchers studied the role of the master regulator Ctr in the cell cycle of Sinorhizob meli, an alphrotebacter that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume hosts. In this symbiosis, S. meli undergoes cellular differentiation, resulting in genome amplification, cell elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The researchers found that depletion of Ctr causes cell elongation and genome amplification, similar to nitrogen-fixing bacteroids. They also showed that cell cycle-regulated proteolytic degradation of Ctr is essential in S. meli, suggesting a mechanism of Ctr depletion in differentiated bacteroids. Using ChIP-Seq and gene microarray analysis, they found that S. mel Ctr regulates similar processes as C cresus Ctr, but through different genes. For example, Ctr does not control the expression of the F complex to control timing cell division, but negatively regulates the septum-inhibiting Min system. This study provides insight into how conserved networks evolve to fit diverse lifestyles of bacteria. The model of Ctr cell regulation in S mel will help elucidate how bacterial cycle is modulated by plant during symbiosis.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes tularemia, a zoonotic disease. Its ability to multiply and survive in macrophages is crucial for its virulence. Researchers screened a library of Himar transposon mutants of the F. tularens vaccine strain L to isolate intracellular growth-deficient mutants and found a mutant in a gene encoding a putative glutamyl transpeptase (GT). The mutant showed impaired intracellular multiplication and was attenuated virulence in mice. The GT activity of F. tulns allows the utilization of glutathione (GSH, γ-glutyl-cystyl-glycine) and γ-glutyl-cystine dipeptide as cystine to ensure intracellular growth. This is the first demonstration of the role of a nutrient system in intracellular multiplication of F. tulns. SH is the most abundant source of cystine in host cytos. The capacity of this intracellular pathogen to utilize G as source cystine in host cytos constitutes a paradigm of bacteria-host adaptation.
Researchers studied the interaction between two types of Leishmania parasites, Leishmania amazonensis and Leishmania major, which infect humans and animals. These parasites have different forms: flagellated promastigotes in insects and round amastigotes in mammalian cells. Leish amazonensis amastotes occupy large vacuoles, while Leish major amastotes are in small, tight vacuoles that divide as they multiply. To see if these vacoles can fuse, researchers infected mouse cells with non-fluorescent Leish amazon amastotes and 48 hours later added fluorescent Leish major amast or promastigotes. They used time-lapse imaging to see if parasites of both species were in the same vacoles. Survival and multiplication of parasites not in same vacoles were also studied. Leish amazon and major vacoles did not fuse, but Le major promastotes fused with established Leish amazon vacoles. In these mixed vacoles, majorast remained motile and multiplied but did not turn into amastotes. In contrast, in separate vacoles, Le major promastotes multiplied but did not turn into amotes. This shows that Leish vacoles, made by majorast or promast, differ in ability to fuse with Leish amazon vacoles. Also, species-specific vac is required for Le major differentiation, a mechanism unknown. This study helps understand interactions between vacoles of different Leish parasites and how they recognize and fuse.
Researchers have been working to develop a vaccine that can elicit broad neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) against HIV-1, a type of antibody that can block the virus from infecting cells. To achieve this, they investigated the ability of native, membrane-expressed Env trimers (a part of the HIV virus) to elicit nAbs. In a study, 8 rabbits were immunized with virus-like particles (VLP) expressing trimers and 20 with DNA expressing Env trimer followed by a protein boost. The results showed that potent nAb titers developed in 2 of the rabbits immunized with VLP and 1 of those immunized with DNA trimer. These nAb neutralized quatern epitopes, exploiting gaps in the glycan shield of the conserved region of JRFL gp120. Specifically, VLP sera took advantage of the absence of a glycan residue at 197, present in 98.7% of Envs. Removing this glycan made 50% of clade 2 isolates sensitive to VLP sera, showing neutralization masked by the glycan. The nAb targeted epitopes overlap with the CD binding site, suggesting the gly acts as a "fence" limiting access to this region. Bioinformatics analysis showed features of VLP sera and monoclonal antibody PG, consistent with trimer dependency. The trimer serum took advantage of absence of gly at 230, also proximal to CD site, suggesting epitope similar to monoclonal 8, albeit lacking breadth. The study shows strain-specific holes in glycan allow nAb to native spikes and cross-neutralization can occur without gly. This provides insights for future nAb vaccine development.
Researchers investigated the use of immunohistochemistry to monitor wound healing in patients with Buruli ulcers (BU) treated with antibiotics. Traditionally, surgery has been the primary treatment for BU, but a combination of oral rifampicin and intramus streptomycin has improved treatment and reduced recurrence rates. However, managing extensive lesions after successful therapy remains a challenge, particularly in rural areas with high disease burden. The study aimed to identify markers to monitor wound progression. Specimens from eight patients with plaque lesions before and after chemotherapy were analyzed for markers of connective tissue formation, remodeling, and epidermal activation. Several proteins were found suitable to monitor healing. α-smooth muscle actin positive myofiblasts were not present in untreated lesions but emerged during healing, producing extracellular matrix proteins like pro-collagen and tenascin. After treatment, cells including myoflasts showed activated phenotype with ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a translation marker. Wounds also showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 in epidermis. A set of markers was identified to monitor healing in treated BU lesions by immunohchemistry. Studies with this panel may help understand delays in wound healing in some patients.
Researchers studied how mitochondria, the energy-producing structures within cells, move along axons, the long extensions of nerve cells in the body, in response to electrical activity. They used confocal imaging to observe saphous nerve axons in anesthetized mice and stimulated electrically and pharmacologically. They found that low-frequency electrical activity increased anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial traffic in both myelinated and unmyinated axons. Higher frequency, within a physiological range of 50 Hz, increased anterog but not retrograde traffic, by increasing mobile mitochondria number and velocity. Capsaicin, a substance applied to skin innervated by saphous nerve, increased traffic in both myinated and uninated axons. Mitochondria in axons conducting higher frequency became shorter, supplying more to trafficking, presumably through fission. Recruited mitochondria did not accumulate at Nodes of Ranvier but continued anterly. This pattern suggests peripheral sensory ax terminals have high metabolic demand during high frequency conduction. Most biogenesis occurs at cell body, antograde traffic may ensure uniform density along ax during high load.
Researchers studied a genetic disorder called spondylocarparsal synostosis (SCT), which causes progressive vertebral fusions due to mutations in the Filamin B (FLNB) gene. Filamin acts as a scaffold linking the actin cytoskeleton to signaling systems, but the disease mechanisms are unclear. They used a Filamin knockout mouse model and found that intervertebral discs (IVDs) of Filamin-deficient mice undergo rapid degeneration during development due to abnormal cell changes in the annulus fibros (AF). AF cells lose their fibroblast characteristics and acquire hypertrophic chondrocy features, including collagen changes, apoptosis, and ossification. This conversion coincides with upregulated TGF signaling via Smad/3 and BMP, and sustained activation of canonical and non-canonical genes p21 and Ctg. The study shows Filamin is involved in attenuating TGF/BMP signaling and AF fate. Disruptions in Filamin-deficient mice resemble degenerative discs, providing insights into vertebral fusions and degeneration.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism by which the orthomyxovirus Thog virus (TH) uses to evade the immune system. The virus targets a general transcription factor called TFI, which is essential for the recruitment of the polymerase II enzyme to gene promoters. This enzyme is necessary for the expression of many immune-related genes, such as cytokines and antiviral effector molecules. By depleting TFI, THOV creates an environment where these genes cannot be expressed, impairing the immune response. However, other genes not dependent on TFI for expression remain unaffected. This allows the virus to evade the immune response while keeping other cellular processes intact. The study suggests targeting TFI could be a therapeutic strategy to control inflammation. 

The immune system is a network of cytokines and antiral effector molecules that defends against viruses. THOV targets a single transcription factor, TFI, disrupting the immune at a broad scale with minimal impact on other processes. Mimicking TH with its inhibitory domain, one can modulate pro-inflammatory cytokines and effector molecules requiring polymerase recruitment without affecting general expression. This is beneficial for infection: pro-inflammatory cytokines are inhibited, while negative regulators and tissue factors are expressed. If TFI is dissociated or depleted, genes with polymerase can still be transcribed, but those dependent on novo recruitment are not. Many inflammatory cytokines and antiral molecules are dependent on novo recruitment. TH also targets polymer through its protein with TFI, but unlike RVV, it does not inhibit general expression. Instead, it impairs interferon genes through IRF.
Human parvovirus B19 (B19) infection of primary erythroid progenitor cells (EPCs) causes cell cycle arrest at both late S-phase and G2, containing 4 DNA. The virus induces a DNA damage response (DDR) that facilitates viral replication but is not necessary for G2 arrest. A putative terminal activation domain (TAD) within NS1 is responsible for G arrest. To understand the mechanism of NS-induced G arrest, doxycine-inducible B-permissive UT/E-S cell lines were established that express NS or NSmAD. Results confirm the TAD plays a role in G arrest. Mechanistically, NS activates gene expression through T, which activates ATR, phosphorylates CDC25 at serine, inactivating cyclin/CDK without affecting nuclear import. The ATR-CHK-CDC25-CD1 pathway is activated during B infection, with A playing a role in G arrest. B19 infection induces DDR for replication, but not G arrest. The TAD domain of NS is crucial for dysregulation of the cycle. B19-infected cells at S and G contain 4 DNA. ATR plays a role in G arrest of EPCs expressing NS, mediated by T. The ATR-CHK-CDC25-CD1 pathway is activated in cells at G during B infection.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes a range of diseases from mild to life-threatening, characterized by endothelial dysfunction and vascular leakage. The virus's non-structural protein 1 (NS1) has been shown to induce endothelial hyperperability in mice and human endothelial cells by disrupting the endothelial glycocal layer. This study investigated the role of inflammatory mediators and endothelial-intrinsic pathways in NS-induced vascular leak. In vivo, DENV NS triggered vascular leak in the dermis of wild-type C57/6 mice, but not West Nile virus NS. In vitro, human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV NS did not produce inflammatory cytokines (TN-α, IL-6, IL-8) and blocking these cytokines did not affect D NS-induced endothelial hyperability. Further, DENV induced leak in TLR- or TN-receptor-deficient mice similar to wild-type animals. Blocking D NS-induced leak in vivo using glycocal inhibitors showed that NS-induced endothelial leak is independent of cytokines but dependent on glycocal components. This suggests potential targets for therapeutics that inhibit glyc components degradation for severe deng treatment.
In budding yeast, the formation of a septin ring at the site of bud emergence is crucial for proper cytokinesis, spindle positioning, and the spindle position (SPO) checkpoint. The PO checkpoint delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis until the anaphase spindle is properly aligned with the division axis. The PO requires Kin4 protein and the Kin-regulating Elm kinase, which also controls septin dynamics. This study shows that the ubiquitin-lases Dma1 and D2 control septin dynamics and PO by promoting the recruitment of Elm to the bud. Dma1 D2 mutant cells have reduced Elm at the bud and Elm-dependent Kin4 activation. Artificially recruiting Elm to the bud of cells restores normal septin, spindle, and PO in Dma D2 cells. The data indicate that septin and PO function are linked and that the integrity of the bud is crucial for PO signalling. The study also implicates the ubiquitin-lases in septin ring, spindle, cytokinesis, and PO regulation. Constitutive recruitment of Elm at the bud through a chimera rescues septin and PO defects in Dma D cells, indicating the defect is due to Elm association with the bud.
Humans have adapted to live in a wide range of environments, and natural selection has likely played a key role in their ability to survive and thrive in extreme climates. Unlike previous studies that only used genetic data to search for evidence of selection, this study scanned the human genome for signals of selection by identifying single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with the strongest correlations with climate across 61 worldwide populations. The study found an enrichment of genetic and non-synonymous SNPs relative to non-genic SNPs among those strongly correlated with climate variables. Among the strongest signals, several overlapped with those from Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS), including SNPs associated with pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. The study also found an enrichment of signals in genes related to UV radiation, infection, and cancer. The results suggest that adaptations to climate shaped the distribution of human variation.

The study presented a genome-wide scan for evidence of positive selection in response to climate variation. Climate influences the distribution of human pathogens, and many signals coincided with SNPs associated with immune response in GW studies. It is likely that the analysis detected selective pressures due to climate are broadly mediated by climate. The study found evidence for selection at individual SNPs identified by GW, sets of genes in cardiovascular and immune diseases, and differentially genes in response to chemical perturbations. Common themes were genes and variants in pigmentation, response to UV, immune, autoimmune, and cancer with strongest signals.

A subset of SN with large effect sizes for climate were associated with traits based on GW results. SN strongly correlated with climate were implicated in pigmentation and autoimmune. The study used allele data to test adaptations to climate at genome level and identified loci under adaptations. Several genome scans have been conducted in humans, but only two used environment to detect signatures on scale.
Researchers studied the genetic condition known as short QT syndrome (SQTS), which is characterized by a shortened QT interval in the heart's electrical cycle and increased risk of abnormal heart rhythms and sudden death. They focused on the SQ1 variant linked to the N588 mutation in the ERG gene, which codes for a potassium channel in the heart cells. Using computer models, they found that this mutation shortens the time it takes for the heart cells to repolarize, or return to a resting state, and increases the difference in repolarization time between different parts of the heart, which can lead to abnormal heart rhythms. However, in a more detailed model of the heart tissue, they found that the mutation also increases the risk of reentrant excitation, a type of abnormal heart rhythm, due to uneven distribution of potassium channels in the heart tissue. The study suggests that the N588 mutation in the ERG gene increases the risk of reentrant excitation and abnormal heart rhythms in SQ1. This is the first study to show how the N mutation affects reentrant excitation in the heart tissue. Previous studies have looked at how other mutations in the ERG gene affect the heart's electrical activity, but not this specific mutation. The findings support the link between the N588 mutation and shortened QT interval and increased risk of abnormal heart rhythms.
Researchers have developed a new model using deep networks to understand the collective behavior of zebraf, a type of fish, in groups. The model is both predictive and insightful, meaning it can accurately describe the motion of individual fish in the group and the interactions between them. The model uses two parts: a pair-interaction network, which describes the interaction between a fish and its closest neighbors, and an aggregation network which combines the outputs of the pair-interaction network. The pair network takes 6 inputs and outputs 128 values, while the aggregation network takes 128 values and outputs a single number. The model was tested on simulated and real trajectories of 60-100 zebraf and found that interactions can be described as repulsive, attractive, or alignment, but only when moving slowly. At high speeds, interactions are alignment or repulsion at close distances. The model also found that each fish decides where to move by aggregating information from the group, with higher weights for neighbors close, in collision, or moving in frontal and lateral locations. The number of interacting individuals is dynamic, typically 8-22, with 1-10 important ones. The results suggest each fish decides by selecting information from the collective.
Researchers have developed a new method to measure the impact of HIV-1 drug resistance mutations on the virus's ability to spread from person to person. This is a concern for long-term effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment, as around 10% of new HIV-1 patients in Europe have drug-resistant strains. The study used data from the Swiss HIV Cohort Study and drug resistance database to create a "family tree" of viral lineages and model the spread of resistant and sensitive strains. They found that one mutation in the protease gene made the virus more transmissible, while six reverse transcriptase mutations made it less transmissible. The remaining mutations had no significant effect on transmission. This method can help assess risk of drug resistance in resource-limited settings where testing is possible but demographic data is missing.
Researchers have found that a protein complex called Elong, which includes histone acetylase Sin3/El3, plays a crucial role in modifying transfer RNAs (tRNAs) to regulate translation efficiency. They discovered that in yeast cells lacking Elong subunits, there are transcription defects. However, Elong also mediates the modification of some tRNAs, modulating translation efficiency. The study found that fission yeast Sin/3El3 is important for oxidative stress survival. The transcription program governed by Sty1-Atf1-P1 pathway is affected in mutant cells, but not severely. Cells lacking Sin3/3 cannot modify uridine wobble nucleotide of tRNAs and other tRNA activities such as Ctu-C2 are essential for normal tolerance to H2O. A plasm overexpressing tRNALUU complements stress-related phenotypes of Sin3El3 mutant. Determined that H2O-dependent genes, including transcription factors At1 and P1, are highly expressed mRNAs with biased lysine codons. Their mRNAs are poorly translated in stress cells lacking Sin3 or C2, whereas mutated At1 with AAG codons is efficiently translated in all backgrounds. The study shows that lack of functional Elong results in stress phenotypes due to tRNA modification and translation inefficiency of stress-induced mRN.
Researchers have discovered a new function of the HIV-1 protein Nef, which makes the virus resistant to certain antibodies that target the membrane-proxternal region of the Env protein gp41. This region is crucial for the virus to infect cells and cause AIDS. They found that Nef makes the virus 50 times more resistant to two potent antibodies, 2F and 4, but not to other antibodies that target different parts of Env. This effect was seen in various HIV-1 and SIV isolates, including different types of viruses and primary isolates. Analysis of N mutants showed that this activity requires Nef to be myristoylated, but is separate from its other functions like enhancing infectivity and downregulating CD4. Glycosylatedag, a protein from a different virus, substituted Nef in conferring resistance to 2 and 4, indicating this activity is conserved in retroviruses without N. N and Glycosylag decreased virion capture by 2 and 4, but not other antibodies. This study shows N protects lentiviruses from one of the most broadly-acting neutralizing antibodies, with implications for anti-HIV immunity and AIDS pathogenesis.
Researchers studied the genetic changes that occur in the snail host, Bithia siam gomphos, when infected with the liver fluke parasite, Opisthoris vivini, which causes cholangiocarcinoma in the Mekong region of Thailand. They used high-throughput sequencing and bioinformatics to compare gene expression in infected and uninfected snails, identifying 7,655 differentially expressed genes associated with 43 biological pathways, including immune responses to parasites. Genes encoding proteases were downregulated in infected snails, while heat shock proteins and actins were upregulated. This study lays groundwork for understanding genes involved in parasite colonization of snail host and provides a resource for studying susceptibility and resistance mechanisms.
A study investigated the role of complement receptor 1 (CR1, also known as CD35) in the susceptibility to leprosy, a public health issue in Brazil. Researchers analyzed CR polymorphisms, gene expression, and soluble CR levels in a case-control study with 213 lepro patients (47% multibillary) and 297 controls. They found that individuals with the most common recombinant haplotype harboring rs926*T in intron 21 and rs700*T in exon 26 presented twice higher susceptibility to lepro (OR=2.43, p=0.017). Paibillary patients with these variants had lower CR levels, reducing anti-inflammatory response (p=0.040 and p=0.046). The most haplotype increased susceptibility to multib clinical form (OR=3.04, p=0.01) and presented intronic rs343*G allele, associated higher gene expression (p=0.043), probably increasing parasite internalization. There was an inverse correlation between CR and mannose lectin-binding molecule (initiator of lectin pathway, recognized by CR) (R=-0.52, p=0.007). The study suggests a regulatory role for CR polymorph on mRNA and CR levels, haplotype effects increasing lepro, probably enhancing phagocytosis and inflammation.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate sex-specific differences in serum metabolite concentrations and their genetic determinants. They analyzed data from over 3,300 individuals with measurements of 131 metabolites, including amino acids, phospholipids, sphingolines, acylcarnines, and C-sugars. Linear regression revealed significant differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites. Genome-wide association studies showed significant differences in beta-estimates for SNPs in the CPS1 locus for glycine. The study found that metabolite profiles of males and females are different, and genetic variants in metabolism-related genes depict sexual dimorphism. This provides new insights into sex-specific regulatory processes and underscores the importance of considering sex-specific effects in studies. 

The study assessed the effect of sex on serum metabolites in a large cohort and investigated sex-specific genetic determination of metabotypes. Findings shed light on sex architecture of the human metabolome and provide clues on biochemical mechanisms explaining differences in disease susceptibility and development between males and females. A meta-analysis of two cohorts revealed 113 metabolites with significant sex effect. The study calculated partial correlation between metabolites, age, and sex, and BMI, and identified differences in genetically determined metabotypes in a subpopulation. Replication was done in independent samples. Genome-wide analysis adjusted for age and BMI showed significant effects of sex in 102 of 131 metabolites.
Researchers have been using genome-scale metabolic networks to model the relationship between a cell's genetic makeup (genotype) and its function (phenotype) through simulations. However, the large number of possible metabolic states makes it difficult to predict the cell's active state under specific conditions, leading to the use of optimization algorithms. The objective function used in these algorithms is linked to the biological model's underlying hypothesis, making it a crucial parameter for successful modeling. Current methods use a combination of selected fluxes to formulate the objective, but show sensitivity to stoichiometry representation of the network, leading to different results when using numerically equivalent but biochemically different representations, making interpretation ambiguous. A new method, Minimization of Metabolites (MiBl), decouples stoichiometry from objective formulation by using metabolite turnovers instead of flux. Simulations demonstrate stoichi representation independence is key to unambiguously linking results with biological interpretation. MiBl allowed expanding metabolic modeling to elucidate genetic interactions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the distribution of plague, a highly virulent and re-emerging disease, and the genetic structure of the black rat population, Rattus rattus, the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. They conducted a comparative study of seroprevalence and genetic (microsatellite markers) in rat populations from four geographic areas differing in topology, covering 150-200 km within the Madagas plague focus. The results showed that serreval levels in rat populations mimicked those reported for humans, and populations displayed more genetic structure with increasing relief. However, the relationship between serval data and genetic differed between areas, suggesting plague distribution not solely related to rat dispersal. Genetic estimates suggested plague epizotics had weak impact on population sizes. In highlands Madagascar, plague cannot be accounted for solely by dispersal of reservoir. Human activities may be involved in spreading disease in rat and human populations.
Researchers investigated the Schistosoma mansoni Ly6 (Sm6) family, a group of proteins on the parasite's surface that helps it stay inside the host for a long time. They found 11 members of this family, including 3 new ones, and confirmed that one of the previously known proteins, Sm29, has a unique structure. These proteins are likely attached to the parasite's surface. To see if they trigger an immune response in humans, the researchers looked at IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies in a group of infected Ugandan men before and after treatment with praziquel. Before treatment, 7.4% and 25.3% of the group had IgG against Sm6A and SmB, respectively, higher than 2.7% against another surface antigen SmAL. After treatment, IgG against SmA and SmB dropped, while Ig against SmAL rose. This study expands the number of Sm6 proteins and shows that SmA and SmB trigger an immune response in infected communities.
Researchers have developed a computer simulation model to understand how cells in the Drosila retina develop their shape during tissue formation. The model focuses on the role of cadherin, a protein that helps cells stick together, and how it changes over time. They tested the model with data from normal and mutant cells that don't have or have too much cadin. The results show that the model can explain the shapes of normal and mutant cells and how cadin works. The simulations also highlight the importance of cadin's timing and how it affects cell connections between cells. Additionally, the model shows that cadin is moved from inactive to active areas, changing the strength of cell connections.

 The study builds on previous knowledge that cell adhesion is key in tissue formation and morphogenesis. It uses a new approach to simulate tissues like the Drosila retina, showing cadin's role goes beyond sorting cells to shape details of their geometry. The model demonstrates three key points: it describes shape changes in mutants, distinguishes how cadin levels are controlled, and includes dynamic features like timing of cad expression and cell contact. These features are established without extra parameters.

 The model considers cadin's distribution and dynamics to understand its control of cell shape. It applies this to a mechanical model and tests with data from mutants with altered cadin levels. Cells in the retina have two adhesion molecules, Eadher and Nadin. All have Ead, but only cones have Nadin. Cadin is localized in a thin area of cell membrane, the adherens junction, where cells stick together.
Researchers have developed a computational model to study the role of a protein called MT-MT-M in the degradation of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in cancer cells. MT-M is a protein that helps cancer cells invade by breaking down the surrounding tissue. The study found that MT-M is quickly turned over, or replaced, in the cells' membrane protrusions called invadodia, where it plays a key role in breaking down the ECM. They used a technique called FRAP (Fluorescence Recovery After Photobleaching) to track the movement of tagged-MT-M in invodia and found that it recovers quickly, with a time constants of 26 and 259 seconds. The recovery was mainly due to vesicle transport, not diffusion. A computational model was built based on these findings and simulated the FRAP results. When vesicle transport was blocked, both experimentally and in simulation, ECM degradation was also blocked. The degree of ECM degradation depended on the rate of MT-M turnover. The study suggests that both proteolytic activity and MT-M turnover contribute to ECM degradation, with a non-linear reduction when both are reduced. This model can be used to design strategies to intervene in cancer invasion.
Researchers studied how the spread of drug-resistant HIV-1 within an infected individual by examining viral sequences from four macaques with a simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) containing HIV-1 reverse transcriptase. The macques were treated with inhibitors, and viral DNA and RNA were isolated from blood, lymph nodes, gut, and vagina at four time points. Single-genome sequencing revealed a dynamic process where RNA rapidly acquires resistance across compartments through multiple mutations, with similar genotypes present across compartments but not equally distributed. Blood and lymph nodes were compartmentalized, while blood and lymph were different from mucosal tissues. The study suggests that sampled blood does not capture viral dynamics in other parts of the body, especially gut, where RNA turnover was faster and DNA retained fewer wild-type viruses. This compartmentalization may explain previous conflicting results in HIV-1 studies. 

The researchers obtained single-genome data from four compartments in four macques with SIV containing HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, treated with monotherapy to induce drug-resistant mutations. Viral RNA was sampled from blood, lymph, nodes, vagina, and gut before, during, and after detection of resistant variants in blood. Observations suggest intra-host SIV population mimics intra-patient HIV undergoing monotherapy. Similarities between SIV macques and HIV make S a good model for HIV. S can be sampled more intensively, including tissue biops, than HIV. Estimate of effective population size is similar to HIV, showing S and HIV have dynamics.
Researchers have investigated the role of feedback regulation in tissue morphogenesis, or the process by which tissues develop their shape and form. They used mathematical modeling to show that a specific type of feedback, where both positive and negative signals act on stem and progenitor cells, can lead to unique behaviors such as bistable growth, ultrasensitivity to external cues, growth-driven budding, and self-organization in the form of lamellar fingers. These behaviors arise not through cell cycle regulation, but through control of stem and progenitor self-renewal. The patterns that emerge are a result of interactions between diffusible factors with opposing effects, but morphogenesis is not due to Turing instabilities.

The study found that regulation of stem and progenitor selfnew can lead to bistability and ultras, with switching between high and low or zero growth states. A necessary condition for this behavior is the presence of both positive and negative feedback. In vivo examples of these phenomena include growth bistability, ultras, and feedback-regulated morph.

The researchers showed that simultaneous positive and negative regulation of renewal by diffus signals leads to emergence of spatial dynamic behaviors, manifesting as localized growth differences. They mathematically defined conditions for phenomena such as bistability, ultras and selforganization to arise in systems, and how they drive formation of induced or spontaneous bulges and fingers. These are basic blocks of many morphogenesis. Although patterns arise from opposing diffible interactions, they are not Turing patterns.

Tissue morph often occurs quickly, relative to cell lifespan, final models may represent lineage dynamics during morph, even in selfnew tissues. The study explored effects of feedback in final systems.
Researchers conducted the largest genome-wide study to date on myopia (nearsightedness) in Europeans, analyzing data from 45,771 participants. They found 22 significant associations with the age of onset of myopia, 10 of which were previously unknown. These associations explain 2.9% of the variation in age of myopia onset and suggest multiple mechanisms behind its development. One association is in the PRSS56 gene, linked to abnormally small eyes, one in LAMA, part of the extracellular matrix, two in regeneration of 11-cis-ret (RGR and RD5), two in growth of retinal ganglion cells (ZIC and SP1), and five in neuronal development. The study points to complex interactions between extracellular remodeling, neuronal, and visual signals from the retina in myopia in humans.
A study investigated the role of curvature feedback in the energetics and dynamics of lamprey swimming using a closed-loop model. The lamprey, like other animals, have a central pattern generator (CPG) circuit that activates locomotion and adjusts to sensory inputs from the environment. Feedback is crucial for responding to perturbations, but also active during unperturbed swimming, influencing the baseline pattern. The study evaluated different forms of body-based feedback and their effects on steady swimming energetics and kinematics. The CP was modeled as coupled oscillators, pairs representing left and right segments along the lamprey body, activating muscles to move through a simulated fluid using a Navier-Stokes model. Emergent curvature served as input to the oscillators, closing the loop. Two forms of feedback were considered, consistent with experimental results on lamp proprioceptive receptors. Directional feedback excites or inhibits oscillators on the same side, opposite on the other. It did not affect frequency, but changed duration of activity. Magnitude feedback provided a symmetric effect on both sides, increasing frequency and reducing energetic cost when gain was high. Both types had similar curvature magnitude. Results indicate magnitude-based feedback with different forms can cause distinct swimming performance.
A study investigated the dynamics of HIV epidemics in populations, focusing on the competition between different strains of the virus. It was found that the strain that first to colonize a population has an advantage over others, slowing down the spread of new strains and diversification of the epidemic. A stochastic modeling framework was developed to simulate HIV epidemics over contact networks, where a second strain was introduced into a population where the first strain had established a steady state. Simulations showed the second strain spread occurred on a slower scale than the first, and needed a 25% advantage in transmission efficiency to become dominant over decades. The effect was weaker if the second was introduced during the first's growth phase. Interference mechanisms such as inhibition, superinfection, depletion of highly connected nodes, and one-time peak infectiousness were also tested, confirming a strong first advantage in HIV competition at the population level. This may explain the global geography of the virus and influence the evolution of the pandemic. In sexually transmitted epidemics, strains with higher transmission potential replace less efficient ones, and the pace of this process needs to be characterized. A model was developed to monitor competition of strains with varying transmission rates, showing the strain with highest potential drives others extinct in the long term. However, mechanisms can slow invasion and the pandemic is not static, with shifts between lineages occurring. The expansion of HIV-1 at the expense of D in Eastern Africa was used to estimate the required transmission advantage. A stochastic individual-based model tracked HIV spread over a dynamic network of heterosexual contacts, consisting of males, females, and sex workers.
Researchers studied how muscle cells organize their internal structure and function at different scales, from the smallest units called sarcomeres to the entire muscle. They found that the environment outside space around the cells, called the extracellular space, plays a crucial role in organizing the cell's internal structure, specifically the cytoskeleton. The cytoskeleton is a network of proteins that gives cells their shape and allows them to move and contract. The researchers developed a model to understand how the cytoskeleton of heart muscle cells, called myocytes, organizes in response to cues from the extracellular space. They found that the cytoskeleton forms through a series of steps: actin fibers, myofibrils, and focal adhesions interact, and then myofils align and bundle together. The study suggests a hierarchy of mechanisms regulates the cytoskeleton's organization and a feedback loop from the extracellular space is necessary for the cytos to become polarized, or have direction. This is important for the muscle to contract.

The researchers also created a computational model to mimic the process of sarere assembly, where proteins assemble along actin fibers. They compared their model to other models of cytoskeleton assembly and found differences. Myofils mature in a force-dependent manner, meaning the muscle's ability to contract may influence their organization. This has been seen in non-muscle cells where cytos architecture becomes polarized with increasing forces. They developed a model of myofillar patterning to see how intracellular architecture responds to extracellular space. The goal was to understand global organization of contractile apparatus in myocytes during development.
Researchers investigated the potential of Wolbachia, a symbiotic bacterium being trialed as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission, to invade and spread in wild mosquito populations. To do so, it requires high maternal transmission rates, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, and low fitness costs in the host. However, differences in climate, field protocols, urbanization, and human density amongst deployment sites have limited comparison of Wolia's invasive potential. The study examined phenotypic effects of the Wolia strain in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes with Brazilian background to characterize its invasive potential. Results showed strong cytoplasm incompatibility, high maternal transmission rates, and no detrimental effects on host fecundity or fertility. To understand urban landscape effects on mosquito survival, mark-release experiments were performed using Wolia-infected mosquitoes in two areas of Rio de Janeiro where Wolia will be deployed. Mosquito populations were characterized in relation to socio-demographic conditions at sites and three future release areas. Mathematical models were constructed using laboratory and field data to describe influence of environmental conditions on likelihood of Wolia infection reaching 100% following release. Predicted successful invasion at five sites, conditions varying greatly between sites and influenced by local mosquito population size. Laboratory and field data showed Melia strain Wolia possesses characteristics to spread in urban-demographic environments in Rio Janeiro, including Eliminate Program release sites.
Researchers have identified a protein called JMJ703 that is responsible for removing a specific type of epigenetic modification called histone lysine methylation from histone H3 (H3) in rice plants. Histone lysine methylation is an important for regulating chromatin structure and gene expression, and histone H3 lysine methylation (H3Kme) has been shown to play a role in plant development and stress response. JMJ703 is a histone demethylase that specifically removes all three forms of H3me: mono, di, and trimethyl. Loss of JMJ function affects plant stem elongation and growth, possibly due to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase genes. The researchers analyzed the structure of JMJ's catalytic core and found similarities with mammalian and yeast JM2 proteins, but also unique features that interact with cofactors and methylated H3 substrate. Key residues are conserved in known H4 demethylases, suggesting specificity for H4 demylation. J703 is essential for plant cell division and stem elongation, and demethylates H3me in vivo and in vitro. Demethylation of Hme implies J is important for gene expression. Phenotype caused by T-DNA and RNAi and increased CK genes suggest J may regulate growth hormone metabolism.
Researchers have found that the HIV-1 capsid, a crucial for the virus's life cycle from reverse transcription to integration, interacts with multiple host and pharmacologic ligands. However, previous studies have focused on individual capsid monomers, leaving unclear how these ligands influence infection. This study shows that a multi-unit interface within hexamers mediates binding to cellular cofactors NUP and CPS6 and antiviral compounds PF and BI-2. Each ligand anchors to a phenylalanine-glyine motif in the N-terminal domain of one monomer, with BI-2 also interacting across the N-terminal: C-terminal interface of a second monomer. Disassembly of hexamer into monomers prevents high affinity with CPS6 and PF, and abolishes NUP binding. The interface is conformationally dynamic, but NUP or CPS6 binding is accommodated by one conformation. NUP and CPS6 have overlapping sites, but unique interactions when mutated, perturb cofactor dependency. This reveals multiple ligands share an interface in HIV-1 caps lost upon disassembly.
Researchers have improved the assembly of the genome of the mosquito Aedes aegypt, which transmits diseases such as dengue and yellow fever and chikunya viruses. The mosquito has a large and complex genome with many repetitive sequences, resulting in a poorly assembled genome with 4,758 scaffolds, few of which were assigned to chromosomes. To map genes affecting disease transmission, they scored many single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in recombinant progeny from a cross between two strains of Ae. aegypt and generated a genetic map. This revealed a high rate of misassemblies in the current genome, where sequences from different chromosomes were on the same scaffold. Once corrected, 60% of the genome was assigned to chromosomes and scaffolds ordered along chromosomes. Large regions of suppressed recombination around centromeres were found, extending up to 47% of chromosome. A gene making Ae.egi resistant to the parasite Brugia mal was mapped, and a list of candidate genes affecting the trait was generated.
Researchers conducted a study to compare the effectiveness of different methods for monitoring the mosquito Aedes aegypt, a vector of diseases such as dengue chikung and yellow fever, in five cities with varying climates. They used four types of traps (BG-Sent, Adultrap, MosquiAP, and ovitrap) in addition to traditional larval surveys to measure mosquito density and seasonality. The study found that larval surveys were less effective in detecting the presence of Ae. aegypt, especially in areas with low mosquito populations. Traps, however, were more sensitive in detecting the presence of Ae. aegpt, but tended to plateau at high densities. Despite this, both methods agreed on the seasonality of mosquito abundance in all cities, which was associated with temperature rather than precipitation, even in areas with small temperature variation. All traps performed better than larval surveys in measuring seasonal variation in abundance and should be considered as complements or alternatives. The study supports the use of trap-based surveillance programs in deng endemic countries and suggests traps could be used in combination with control strategies to improve response to deng and other diseases transmitted by Ae. aegypt.
Researchers have studied the protein APOBECG3, a potent inhibitor of retroviruses and transposable elements, to understand its mechanism of action. APOECG3 contains two cytidine deaminase domains, only one of which is known to mediate cytidine deamination. By analyzing the structure of a related protein APOEC2, they identified residues in APOG that facilitate oligomerization. Using yeast two-hybrid, coimmunprecipitation, and crosslinking assays, they found tyrosine and tryptan in the enzymatically inactive N-terminal domain mediate APOG oligomer and its packaging into HIV-1 virions. Oligomerization is also shown to be RNA-dependent. Modeling APO onto the A2 structure indicates a positive charge accumulation in a putative dimer interface. Substituting arginine at positions 24, 30, and 136 in this pocket reduced virus inhibition, virion, and oligomer. Consistent with RNA's central role, oligomer-deficient APO proteins associated less with cellular molecules. They propose occupation of the charged pocket by RNA promotes A oligomer, packaging into virions, and antiviral function.
Researchers have identified the genetic variations that contribute to a major-effect quantitative trait locus (QTL) in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. The QTL is responsible for cuticular pigmentation, which is the color and pattern of the fly's outer layer. The researchers found that multiple polymorphisms, or variations in the DNA sequence, near regulatory elements of the bric-br gene contribute to the effect. These elements include a promoter, a tissue-specific enhancer, and a Polycomb response element. Analysis of gene expression at the br-br locus shows that these polymorphisms modulate transcription at the regulatory level, meaning they affect how the gene is turned on or off. This study shows that a single QTL can act through a combination of mechanisms and that variation in regions flanking functional elements can have significant effects on transcription and phenotype. This has implications for understanding genetics and genomics in both basic and medical research. 

The researchers sequenced the 148 kilobase region of the brac gene in 94 inbred lines of D. melanogaster to identify the polymorphisms. They found that multiple polymorph in a single regulatory element of the ebony gene contribute to pigmentation differences between populations. Other studies have shown that multiple polym contribute to variation in protein function. This suggests accumulation of mutations at a locus may be a common mechanism of micro and macroevolutionary change. The br locus is composed of two duplicated genes, bab1 and bab, which are involved in patterning the abdomen, legs, and ovaries. Bab expression in pupal epidermis is responsible for sex-specific pigmentation and changes have played a role in macroevolution of D melanaster color patterns. This is different from cases where Qs are due to single or regulatory mutations with major effects.
Streptococcus pneumonia (pneumococcus) is a persistent cause of invasive and mucosal disease in humans, despite widespread use of antibiotics and vaccines. Its resilience is due to its ability to adapt through uptake and incorporation of new genetic material from surrounding microbial community. DNA uptake and recombination is controlled by tightly regulated quorum sensing system triggered by extracellular accumulation of competence peptide (CSP). This study demonstrates CSP stimulates production of diverse bacteriocins through increased production and secretion of bacteriophage BlC and requires functional competence system. A conserved motif in promoter of operon encoding BlC and its transporter mediates upregulation by CSP. Accumulation BlC following CSP results in activation of Bl locus. Using biofilm organisms as model for competition and genetic exchange on mucosal surface, DNA exchange is enhanced by bacterin secretion, suggesting co-stimulation of bacterins with competence provides adaptive advantage. Bl and regulatory pathways are believed to have diverged in remote pneumoccus ancestor, yet maintained connection promotes competition and adaptation by targeting lysis wide potential competitors while providing incorporation DNA.
Researchers investigated the role of cellular protein SR20 (SRp20) in poliovirus infection, a virus that causes poliomyelitis. They found that SR20 localizes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of infected cells, where it interacts with protein PC2 (PC2), a known to be involved in viral translation. The two proteins co-localize in the cytoplasm and are present in viral translation complexes. SR20 is associated with PC2 bound to polirus RNA, suggesting interaction occurs on the RNA. A mutated version of SR20 lacking its RNA recognition motif (SR20ΔM) localizes similarly, but expression results in a 100-fold decrease in virus yield, indicating a dominant negative effect. The study suggests SR20 interacts with PC2 on viral RNA to recruit ribosomes for translation initiation.
Researchers used a genetic screen to identify genes involved in the development of the neural crest (NC), a group of embryonic cells that gives rise to various cell types, including nerve cells and melanocytes. They used a mouse model with a mutation in the Sox10 gene, which is important for NC development, and exposed it to a chemical mutagen to induce random mutations. Out of 71 lines analyzed, four mutations were found that altered NC patterning. One mutation, called m1, resulted in the absence of Sox10 expression in certain cells, but not others were unaffected. Analysis showed that m1 was a new mutation in the ErbB3 gene, a receptor tyrosine kinase, with a single amino acid change in its extracellular region. The mutation did not affect protein expression but impaired signaling, causing defects similar to Erb3 null alleles. Biochemical analysis showed the protein was on the cell surface but ligand-induced phosphorylation was reduced. This highlights the importance of the mutated residue for Erb3 function.
Researchers conducted a study in a Ugandan community to investigate factors influencing Schistosoma mansoni infection, a parasitic flatworm causing schistosomiasis. They examined how age, sex, ethnicity, and IgE (a type of immune response) affect susceptibility to reinfection after anti-parasite treatment. The study used a multidisciplinary approach to account for environmental and behavioral variations in exposure to the parasite. They found that ethnic and sex-related variations in reinfection were due to differences in parasite exposure, not biological susceptibility. Age-related differences in reinfection were not explained by exposure, but linked to IgE and IgG responses to a specific antigen. This study highlights the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in complex settings to understand population ecology and draw robust conclusions. 

The study used data from a longitudinal study in a Ugandan fishing community highly endemic for schosomiasis to investigate variations in S. mansoni reinfection. To account for complex, ethnically-influenced exposure patterns, they used individual parasite exposure scores to adjust for variations. This is supported by other studies on exposure and reinfection in schosias-endemic communities, identifying individuals resistant or predisposed to infection. Genetic studies also identified genes associated with susceptibility or immunity. Small studies on risk factors for Schos infection are limited by lack of individual parasite exposure data, using proxy markers like distance to infective water can be misleading. 

The study found age-infection profiles typical of schos-endemic communities: infection greatest in children, lower in adults. Exposure scores investigated roles of age and sex in susceptibility, and whether Alur ethnic group is more susceptible. Schosome Ig or Ig4 responses could account for remaining susceptibility variation.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the number of eggs per gram of feces (EPG) and the actual worm burden of Clonorchis sinensis in humans. A total of 60 residents, 50 egg-positive and 10-negative, in Sanche-gun, Korea, participated in the study from 2006-2009. They were diagnosed by egg positivity in feces using the Kato-K method. After administration of prazantel, they were purged with cathartics the next day, and adult worms were collected from feces. EP ranged from 0 to 65,544. Adult C. sin were collected from 17-positive, and number ranged from 1 to 114 each. A correlation between EP and number of worms was demonstrated (r= 0.681, P<0.001). Recovery rates were 9.7% in EP 1-1,000 and 73.7% in EP over 1,000. No worms detected from egg-negative. Maximum count per worm per day estimated 3,770 in subject EP 2,664 and collected. Numbers of worms significantly correlated with egg in Cloniasis. Estimated at least 110 worms in body EP around 3,000 and productivity per day around 4,000.
Researchers have developed a new approach to combat the growing problem of antifungal drug resistance by identifying genetic interactions that can be targeted to prevent the emergence of resistance. They used an unbiased genome-wide screen in yeast cells expressing a gene that makes them resistant to a common antifungal drug, fluconazole. This gene is a major cause of resistance in the human fungal pathogen Candida glabrata. Eighteen genetic mutations in yeast were found to be lethal when combined with the resistant gene. One of these, a histone acetylase G5, was further studied. Deleting or inhibiting G5 made the resistant Candida cells die and prevented the emergence of resistant strains. This shows that targeting G5, a partner of the resistant gene, is a new way to treat drug-resistant infections. Candida cells lacking G5 and the resistant gene were unable to grow. Chemical inhibition of G5 also prevented the emergence of resistant strains. This study demonstrates that identifying genetic interactions that cause resistance can be targeted to prevent it. Candida strains with the resistant gene are more virulent, implying adaptation to antifungals makes them more disease-causing. An unbiased screen was used to identify lethal interactions with the resistant gene. A chemical inhibition of G5 prevented growth of yeast and resistant Candida strains.
Researchers studied how the poliovirus (PV) infection affects cell membranes and phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PI4) levels. They found that PV induces PI4 as early as 30 minutes post-infection, even in the presence of a replication inhibitor, and forms membrane tubules throughout the cytoplasm. Vesicular clusters appear in the perinuclear region at 3 hours post-infection, too late to be responsible for replication delays. Two mutants, EG and GG, with aberrant proteolytic processing of the P3 precursor, delay genome replication and assembly, similar to PI4 remodeling delays. GG fails to convert tubules into vesicles, resulting in nearly 5-log reduction in infectious virus production. The study suggests PV induces distinct membrous structures for replication (tubules) and assembly (vesicles). The pace, spatiemporal dynamics, and efficiency of replication-to-assembly conversion may be set by P3 processing rate and capacity to yield 3 and 3 proteins.
Researchers developed a multi-step strategy to identify new compounds with trypanocidal activity against Chagas disease. They used virtual screening and in vitro assays to select 23 compounds from the ZINC database, and found 12 non-peptide cruzain inhibitors with low micromolar affinity (3-60µM) through competitive inhibition. X-ray crystallography confirmed the binding mode of cruzain inhibitor Neimed176. Cruzain is a validated target for Chagas chemotherapy and shares similarity with mammalian cathepsin L. Increased catheps L activity is linked to invasive properties and metastatic cancer, so cruz inhibitors were assayed against it, showing similar affinity (4-80µM) and poor selectivity towards cruz. To select the most potent inhibitors, structure-activity (SAR) studies were done against T cruz-infected cells. Two compounds showed trypanidal activity. Compound Neimed42 was used to establish SAR, identifying the 2-acamidothiophene-3-carbox group essential for enzyme and parasite inhibition. The IC50 for Neimed against the trypastote form of TuluenZ was 10.6±0.1µM, tenfold lower than benidazole, a positive control. Employing simplification, a smaller compound (Neimed) was highlighted as a non-peptide, nonvalent cruzain trypanidal candidate for optimization.
Researchers have developed a new DNA-based vaccine against yellow fever (YF) virus, which is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical areas worldwide. The current attenuated YF vaccine generates long-lasting antibodies and T-cell responses, but can have rare fatal side effects. The new vaccine consists of two DNA formulations encoding the full-length envelope protein (pFE) or full-length protein fused to lysosomal membrane protein LAMP-1 (LFE), aiming to divert antigen presentation through major histocompatibility complex compartments. The formulations were tested in C57/6 and BAL/c mice, corresponding to C57/6 and BAL/c strains. Both induced strong T-cell responses against all epitopes generated by Y17 vaccine, with LFE performing best. Additionally, LFE stimulated high anti-Y neutralizing antibodies comparable to 17 vaccine levels, and provided 100% protection against intracereally challenged mice. These results indicate LFE is an excellent candidate for further studies.
Researchers have identified a new role for the nucleoid protein SlmA in Vibrio cholera, a pathogen that causes cholera. SlmA is a transcription activator of the chb operon, which encodes genes for chitin utilization. Chitin is essential for Vibrio cholera's persistence and horizontal gene transfer in the marine environment. The sensor kinase ChiS regulates the ch operon, but its downstream mechanisms were unclear. An unbiased transposon screen revealed SlmA as a regulator of chb. SlmA is a TetR family protein, typically transcriptional repressors. In vitro, SlmA binds to the ch oper promoter, and in vivo, this interaction is required for transcription and chitin utilization. Mutations show DNA binding, not nucleoidation, is critical for activation. This study shows SlmA's novel role as a transcription regulator in Vibrio cholera, in addition to its cell division licensing function.
Researchers have developed a new computational framework for solving complex problems that arise in modeling biological systems. These problems are challenging due to highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations and large amounts of experimental data and parameters. The proposed framework uses cutting-edge tools that are efficient, robust, and easy to use. It employs a time-discretization approach that avoids repetitive model simulations, enables algebraic computation of derivatives, and uses efficient nonlinear solvers that exploit sparse linear techniques. The framework was tested on a human gut microbiome model with 156 parameters, 144 equations, and 1,704 data points, solving it in under 3 minutes, while an off-the-shelf solution took 7 hours. Large instances showed the framework can solve up to 2,352 parameters, 2,304 equations, and 20,352 points in 15 minutes. The framework is flexible and can be applied to various biological models, enabling tasks such as uncertainty quantification, observability analysis, model selection, and outlier handling.
Researchers used a high-throughput gene expression system called nCounter to study the inflammatory response in mice infected with West Nile virus (WNV) in the Swiss Webster (SW) mouse model. They analyzed gene expression in multiple tissues over nine days following intraperitoneal injection with NV. A kit containing 179 inflammation-related genes was used to identify changes in spleen, lung, liver, and brain of infected mice. Results showed Ccl and Ilb were differentially expressed in all tested tissues except kidney. Stratification of infected (W+) versus non-infected (-) tissues allowed differentiation of systemic gene response from tissue-specific responses. Significant decrease in C1 was found in (-) spleen, while Il was upregulated, Il was downregulated in (-) lung, and M2 were downregulated in (-) liver. In (+) liver, Stat, T2, chemines Ccl, C, C, C, C, cytokine, Il, cytokine, and agonist were upregulated. In (-) tissues, C and C were upregulated. Gene and protein kinetics for C, C, C, C, and C correlated with presence of virus. The study demonstrated utility of nCounter for rapid identification of gene changes in mice with NV infection.
An outbreak of rabies occurred in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique in 2014, prompting an investigation into the epidemiology, clinical features, and risk factors of human rabies and animal bites in the two cities. Between April and August 2014, 14 cases of human rabies were detected in Maputo (n=10), Matola (n=3), and neighboring Bo district (n=1), all with a history of recent dog bites. Of the 14 rabid dogs, only one was immunized. A total of 819 animal bites were registered, with 64.6% (529/819) from Maputo City, with dogs responsible for 97.8% (801/819) of bites, but only 27.0% (126/467) were immunized. Factors associated with human rabies were age <15 years, bite by stray dog, deep wound, bite to head, by unimmun dog, no soap use, and post-exposure prophylaxis.

The study aimed to determine clinical and epidemiological features of human rab cases, risk for developing rab, and animal bites in Map and Matola. The findings will contribute to formulating recommendations for rab control in Mozambique. This is the first attempt to investigate rab outbreak and epidemiology of bites in Mozambique. In Mozambique, procedures are irregular, resulting in frequent rabies outbreaks. Maputo City health authorities alerted a possible outbreak in July 2014 when Maputo Hospital admitted patients with rab in short time. Reliable data on rab burden and risk is a challenge for policies and strategies, a major cause for underinvestment in control. Mozambique has high burden of rab in sub-Saharan Africa.

Demographic and risk factors were compared between animal bites and human rab cases to determine predictive associated with rab after bite. Age <15 (OR:4.8, p=0.05), bite stray (OR:13.6,=0.002), deep (OR:0.02), head (0.001), unimmun (0.01), no (0.001), and (0.01) were associated.
Researchers identified a new gene, SCN9, encoding the Nav1.7 sodium channel, as a cause of febrile seizures (FS) in a large family with significant linkage to chromosome 2q. A mutation in a highly conserved amino acid, p.N641, in the cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II, was found in 21 affected members but not in ethnically matched controls. To confirm the role of SCN9 in seizure susceptibility, the mutation was introduced into the murine Sc9 ortholog using homologous recombination. Compared to wild-type mice, homozygous Sc9N641/N641 knock mice showed reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures and increased kindling rates. This supports SCN9 as a disease-causing gene in the family. SCN9 was also analyzed in 92 unrelated FS patients, finding highly conserved Nav.7 missense variants in 5%. One child with FS later developed Drav syndrome, a severe myoclonic epilepsy, and SCN1 was sequenced, revealing a heterozygous frameshift mutation. Analysis of 109 Drav patients found 9 Nav.7 missense variants, 8% of patients, in conserved amino acids. Six Drav patients with SCN9 missense had either miss or splice SCN1 mutations or no SCN1 mutations. This study shows SCN9's role in human epileps, both as a cause and partner with SCN1 mutations.
Researchers have long sought to understand how complex tissue shapes arise through growth, particularly when growth occurs preferentially along certain orientations, raising the question of how these orientations are specified. Two possibilities exist: orientations are specified through stresses in the tissue (axiality system) or independently through molecular (polarity system). The axial system has been explored through computational modeling, while the polarity system is less understood. This study develops a polarity-based framework, called Growing Polarised Tissue (GPT), treating tissue as a continuous material where regionally expressed factors interact and propagate polarity is established by signals anchored in tissue organisers. Growth rates parallel or perpendicular to polarity are specified through a regulatory network, resulting in complex shapes emerging from simple rules. Asymmetries emerge through interactions between polarity fields. The PT framework is applied to a growing Snapdragon, illustrating how hypotheses can be tested computationally. Combinatorial interactions between orientations and growth, a feature of polarity systems, have been exploited to generate observed shapes.
Researchers investigated how multiple CD8+ T cell responses in early HIV infection affect the emergence of mutations that help the virus escape from the immune system. These responses put pressure on different parts of the virus's genome, leading to mutations that are beneficial for the virus. Some studies found that as these mutations emerge, they spread more slowly, a pattern known as the "escape rate decrease" (ER). This pattern can arise from different mechanisms, including interference between mutations in large populations with high mutation rates, which can delay the spread of beneficial mutations compared to sexual reproduction. The study examined how interference between concurrent mutations affects escape rates in multiple epitopes and if it's a source of ER. They developed a multi-locus Wright-Fisher model of HIV dynamics with selection, mutation, and recombination as a null model for interference, and an interference-free model assuming initial neutral evolution before immune response. Interference between equally advantageous mutations generated the ER pattern. The number of loci and recombination rates affected ER, explained by exponential decline of escape rates over time. ER in HIV individuals is consistent with both interference-free and interference effects. Interference should be considered when analyzing escape mutations. Estimating rates and selective coefficients is challenging due to interference effects, not overcome by sampling sizes or frequencies.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to predict the effectiveness of chemotherapy treatment for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) patients. The model takes into account various factors such as cancer cell proliferation, heterogeneity, hypoxia, and treatment resistance. It uses data from two points in time, before and during treatment, to estimate the effect of the tumor microenvironment and cell repopulation on treatment outcome. A sensitivity analysis found that growth rate and fraction at diagnosis are key features for accurate estimates. The model was applied to 13 patients with NSCL who received cisplatin with gemcitab, vinlb, or docetax in neoadjuvant context. Input values were guided by literature on cancer-specific kinetics. Latin hyper sampling was used to compensate for patient uncertainties. The model provides a framework for estimating in-vivo cell killing of chemotherapies. Correlation with molecular profiles could lead to personalized predictions.
Researchers studied how bacteria in biofilms develop resistance to antibiotics, specifically the antibiotic fluoroquinolofloxacin. Biofilms are communities of bacteria that adhere to surfaces and can be resistant to antibiotics due to their complex structure and heterogeneity. The study used random mutagenesis to identify mutants in Escherichia coli that formed biofilms with high tolerance to fluoroquinoloxacin. They found that amino acid-starved biofilms were more tolerant to the antibiotic than planktonic bacteria. The tolerance was dependent on the SOS response to amino acid and carbon starvation, and partially on the stringent response to leucine starvation. However, it did not involve toxin-antitoxin systems associated with highly tolerant persisters. Biofilm tolerance increased with age and was dependent on the SOS response. The study shows that SOS response in nutrient-deprived biofilm environments leads to high tolerance to fluoroquinoloxacin.
Researchers have identified a key role for cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in regulating the invasion of human red blood cells by Plasium falcumeroites, the parasite responsible for malaria. Invasion of red blood cells by P. falcumeroites requires specific interactions between host cell receptors and parasite ligands located in apical organelles called micronemes. The study found that exposure to low potassium levels, similar to those found in blood, activates a specific enzyme that raises c levels and activates protein kinase, which regulates micron secretion. They also discovered that c regulates calcium levels in the parasite through a separate pathway and that both are necessary for micron secretion. This discovery provides new targets to prevent parasite growth and malaria.
Strongyloides stercis, a soil-transmitted threadworm, is one of the most neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). A review of 20 years of studies on S. stercis global prevalence in populations and risk groups was conducted. A literature search was performed on PubMed articles from 1989 to 2011, including studies with information on infection prevalence. A Bayesian analysis was done to get country-specific estimates and compare odds ratios in risk groups, accounting for diagnostic sensitivities. 354 studies from 78 countries were included, 62.4% community-based, 34.2% hospital, and 11% refugee/immigrant. World maps with data are provided. Many African, Asian, and South American poor countries lack S.ercis information. Meta-analysis showed association with HIV/alcoholism and Sercis (OR 2.17, CI 1.18-4.01, OR 6.69 CI 1.47-3.8). High prevalence in selected countries and regions. Sercis prominent in risk groups. Adequate information lacking from many countries, but shows Serc must not be neglected. Further socio-economic and ecological assessments and integration into global health warranted.

The study aimed to get country-wide Sercis risk and assess association with risk groups. High rates in South Asia, refugees, and immigrants reported. In developed countries, strongyias an issue for immigrants, tourists, and military returning from endemic areas. This has implications for services and may call for screening before immunosuppressive treatment. Serc information patchy, incidence non-existent. Strongloides stercis a soil-trans nematode, one of most helth NTDs, world-wide, excluding north and south, estimates often guesses. More data needed for countries, socio-cultural settings. Large surveys and sensitive methods would narrow gap.
Researchers have found that stochastic noise at the cellular level plays a crucial role in circadian oscillations, influencing how groups of cells synchronize with external cues and generating cell-autonomous rhythms. However, few studies have investigated how perturbations affect stochastic noise, mainly due to the difficulty in measuring cell-autonomous noise directly. This study shows that the damping of population-level bioluminescence can serve as an accurate measure of stochastic noise, applicable to high-throughput circadian screens. Using fibroblast data, they demonstrate that higher single-cell noise results in faster population damping, and that damping can be changed by small molecule modulators in a dose-dependent fashion. A mathematical model explains the change by single-cell noise. The method is applied to a genome-wide siRNA screen, revealing stochastic altered independently from period and phase. The study hypothesizes the unperturbed clock is optimized for robust rhythms, with few perturbations capable of increasing amplitude and lowering noise.
