Chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing data showed active marks in macques but absent in chimpanze. Different mechanisms of repression, H3me versus methylation, were found in humans and chimpanze. Two segregating variants in humans reflect positive selection for lower AD2 expression. The study pinpointed cis-regulatory regions contributing to human-chimpanzee repression of AD2, including a topologically associating domain harboring AD2, with 12 DHS connected to the promoter. Derived sequences are fixed in humans and chimpan, with acceleration in lineage.
Researchers have studied the evolution of C4 photosynthesis, a complex trait that allows plants to increase productivity by 50% in tropical and subtropical areas. This trait has evolved independently in at least 60 lineages of monocots and dicots. To understand how these lineages use the same genetic networks for C4 photosynthesis, scientists developed a new framework to compare gene expression in species lacking reference genomes. They compared gene expression in two independent C lineages, Cleomeandra and Zea mays, which diverged 140 million years ago. A cohort of 3,335 genes represent conserved in leaf and photosynthetic development in these species. Genes encoding C cycle are recruited into networks related to photosynthesis. Despite wide separation and independent origins of C phenotype, species use homolog transcription factors to induce C photosynthesis and maintain specific expression for pathway. A molecular signature is shared by angiosperms derived from common ancestor of monocots and dicots. Deep comparisons reveal insight into convergence of complex phenotypes and parallel evolution of transactors underpinning C photosynthesis. Exploiting natural variation can identify regulators and shared by C lineages, targets for engineering C pathway in C crops like rice.
During the 2013-2016 Ebola virus (EBO) epidemic in West Africa, the virus spread to Europe and North America, infecting several healthcare workers. To understand how the virus behaves in the body and how it's transmitted between people, researchers studied a healthcare worker infected with EBO in Sierra Leone who was hospitalized in Italy. They collected samples from the worker's upper and lower respiratory tract and plasma over time to see if the virus was still present. The study found that the virus RNA, a sign of the virus, was still present in the lower respiratory tract even after it was cleared from the blood, suggesting it might be replicating. This study aims to understand how EBO spreads and develop ways to stop it. 

The researchers compared levels of EBO RNA in the worker's respiratory and blood samples to see if the virus was replicating. They found the virus RNA levels decreased over time in blood, but not in respiratory samples. This suggests the virus might be stable in the respiratory tract, not just lingering. The presence of RNA in respiratory samples until day 9 and 10 supports replication, not just stability. The virus was detected in respiratory but not blood from day 5, with RNA still in respiratory until day 10, indicating replication in lung tissue. A previous study showed EBO replicates in human airways, with virus in lung tissues and macrophages.
Researchers studied the Machupo virus (MAC), a New Worldnavirus that causes Bolivian hemorrhagic fever, and its relative Jun virus (JUN), which causes Argentine hemorrhagic fever. They created a recombinant chimeric virus (rMAC/Cd1-G) that expresses the glycoprotein from the Candid1 (Cd1) strain of JUN and found it to be attenuated in a murine model, protecting animals from lethal challenge with MAC. However, a single mutation in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of the glycoprotein, equivalent to the attenuating mutation in Cd1, was not sufficient to fully attenuate JUN. To investigate the role of different domains of Cd1 glycoprotein in attenuation, they created several rMACs expressing the ectomain glyprotein from Cd1 alone (MC1), with the TMD substitution (MC2), or the T of Cd1 (3). All rMAC exhibited similar growth in cultured cells. In mice, MC1 showed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMAC. MC was detected in brains and spleens of MC-infected mice, associated with tissue inflammation. On the other hand, animals survived MC and MC3 infection without detectable virus in organs, producing neutralizing antibodies against Cd. The study suggests the indispensable role of each glycoprotein domain in full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMAC/C1-G.
Researchers studied a protein called centromere histone 3 (CH3) that plays a crucial role in separating chromosomes during cell division in plants. To understand how CH3 works, they created mutant versions of the protein with single amino acid changes in its structure. Some of these mutant plants looked normal and fertile when self-poll, but produced abnormal offspring when crossed with normal plants. This is similar to what happens when CH3 from different species are combined. They found that a single mutation can create a "haploid inducer", a plant that produces offspring with only one set of chromosomes. This can be used to identify haploid inducers in crop species. They tested this by finding a mutation in CH3 in a plant and found it produced haploids when crossed with normal plants.
Researchers have investigated the role of alternative splicing in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. They modified the H9 hESC line to allow for the selection of pluripotent ESCs by neomycin resistance and cardiac progenitors by puromycin resistance. Exon microarray expression data from undifferentiated ESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common/neural differentiation patterns. Splice events corresponded to pathways of cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle control as well as genes with ser/threon kinase and helase activity. A new program, AltAnalyze, was used to identify changes in protein and microRNA site architecture that affect function and expression. Enriched isoforms oppose cell arrest in ESCs and promote signaling and development in cardiac precursors. Genome-wide predictions combined with new annotations suggest mechanisms that influence commitment and maintenance at the level of isoforms and micro regulation.
Researchers have identified trehal-6-phosphate (TP) as a potential target for developing antimicrobials against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. They created a mutant of M. tuberculosis that allows for the regulated silencing of the TP phosphatase gene oB, which is involved in trehal biosynthesis. The study found that oB is essential for the growth of M. tuberculosis in vitro and during the acute phase of infection in mice, but not during the chronic phase. This suggests that trehal metabolism is remodeled during infection. Blocking oB led to the accumulation of TP, which is toxic to cells, causing self-poison. Blocking TP production in a mutant abrogated oB essentiality. TP accumulation upregulated over 800 genes, possibly due to increased RNA stability and ribonuclease activity. A genome screen for synthetic interactions with oA identified potential targets for combination therapies to minimize resistance to oB inhibitors.
Researchers have identified Trypanosoma cruzi proline racemase (TPR) as a potential target for new treatments for Chagas disease, a life-threatening illness affecting 11-18 million people. Current treatments have poor efficacy and safety profiles. Studies suggest TPR's conformation changes when binding to a substrate expose residues that trigger a host immune response, contributing to parasite persistence. To understand these changes, researchers used accelerated molecular dynamics to simulate long-time motions, inaccessible by standard simulations. They found potential conformation epitopes near newly identified binding pockets and open TPR conformations. This study advances understanding of TPR function and provides insights for structure-based drug discovery. 

A crystal structure of TPR with pyr-carboxylic acid was used to build a model. Initial coordinates were obtained by removing inhibitors. Residues like Arg and Lys were protonated, acidic like Asp and Glu deprotonated. This suggests TPR is a promising target for therapies. Ligand-induced conformation changes in TPR expose critical residues for host response. Two TPR structures are available. Accelerated dynamics extended simulation time, combined with sequence and fragment analysis, indicate mitogenic properties of TPR are associated with conformation epitopes around unidentified pockets. This study shows a model of open TPR through molecular simulation. Results suggest mitogenic of TPR may be associated with conformation epitopes around newly identified pockets.
Researchers have developed a new method to turn genes on and off at will in mice, called the inducible knockout (iKO) system. This system uses two genetically modified mouse lines: a knockout (KO) line with a tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the target gene, and a line with tetrcline-inducible cDNA of the gene inserted into a tightly regulated (TRE) genomic locus, providing low expression and high inducibility. The KO and TRE lines have been engineered for high-throughput, large-scale and cost-effective production of iKO mice. As a proof of concept, the system was applied to the apolipoprotein (Apo) gene, allowing sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. Results showed reversible switching of Apo transcription, cholesterol levels, and atherosclerosis progression and regression. The i system demonstrates stringent regulation and versatility, easily incorporating other techniques and adapting to a wide range of applications.

The iKO system is a binary approach based on Tet-dependent technology, complementing existing inducible expression methods. It provides advantages over tamoxifen-dependent CreERT recombination, which is irreversible and tamoxifen inducibility throughout the body has not been demonstrated, and Cre/lox recombination efficiency. The design enables streamlined production of KO and TRE mice, generating iKOs for multiple genes in a cost-effective manner. KO and TRE lines can be engineered independently combined, making various applications possible. Two genetically modified strains are created: a KO line with Tet transactivator inserted into target gene, inactivating it, and a line with Tet-inducible cDNA of gene inserted into TRE locus, providing low expression and inducibility. The KO can be generated via homologous recombination or insertional mutagenesis.
Researchers studied the genetic response of the placenta to Trypanosoma cruzi infection in mice, a parasite that can be transmitted from mother to fetus during pregnancy. They infected mice with two different strains of the parasite, K and V, and analyzed the genetic changes in the placenta using a technique called microarray. The results showed that the placenta responded differently to each strain, with some genes related to immune response and inflammation increased in V, but decreased in K. The study also found that the V strain was more likely to infect the placenta, with parasite DNA and RNA detected. This is the first study to describe the genetic response of the placenta to Tryosoma cruzi in mice and suggests that the immune response to the parasite depends on the type of parasite, which may help prevent congenital transmission. The placenta is a complex environment where mother and fetus interact, and infection adds complexity by altering immune circuits. The study used a combination of transcriptomics and network analysis to highlight differences between responses to the two parasite strains, K and V, a non-lethalotropic and V, isolated from a human case of congenital infection. The goal was to understand the role of Tryosoma cruz genotypes in pregnancy and congenital infection, as little is known about the placental response to the parasite. The study found that the placenta responded differently to each strain, with some genes related to immune response and inflammation increased in V, but decreased in K, and that V was more likely to infect the placenta, with parasite DNA and RNA detected.
Sindbis virus (SINV) polyarthritis, also known as Ockbo disease in Sweden and Pog disease in Finland, has been recognized in northern Europe for about 50 years. The virus is mainly found in tropical and subtropical countries, but causes recurring outbreaks in northern Europe. A seven-year cycle of SINV outbreaks has been reported, but only based on human cases. To find a more objective signal, mosquito and SINV prevalence in vectors were evaluated in an endemic area in Sweden. Mosquitoes were collected in the Riveräl floodplains in 2000, 2001, and 2002, and assayed for virus on cell culture. Obtained isolates were sequenced and nucleotide sequences analyzed using Bayesian clade and joining analysis. One SINV strain was found in 2001, four in 200, and 15 in 200, with increased rates in both enzoot and bridge vectors in 200. Maximum likelihood infection rates were 1.0/1000 in enz Cx torrentipiens and 0.62/100 in bridge A cinus in 200, compared to 0.9/100 and 0/100 in 1 and 0/100 and 0.32 in 200. Sequence analysis showed all isolates belonged to SINV I (S-I). Genetic analysis revealed four S-I clades in Riveräl floodplains over years. Increased S-I in vectors constitutes a valuable marker for scrutinizing hypothesized seven-year S-I outbreaks and mechanisms.
Researchers studied how the locust's olfactory system, which transforms dense, synchronized signals from the antennal lobe (AL) into a sparse representation in the mushroom body (MB), a region associated with memory. They recorded from Kenyon cells (KC) in the MB and found that only a few KCs responded reliably to specific odors, with different odors inducing different responses in different KCs. The study explored a biologically plausible model that synaptic plasticity controls weights to ensure KC's specificity to familiar odors. They found that plasticity at AL-MB synapses efficiently regulated tuning, filtering AL's oscillatory output to a sparse in MB representation. Activity-dependent plasticity drove specificity, reliability, and persistence of odor representations, suggesting a role in processing and making testable predictions about plasticity at AL-MB synapses.

The locust's olfactory system is a favorable model for studying neural codes and plasticity due to its simplicity and well-characterized spatio-temporal input to the MB. PNs of the AL are the only source of olfactory information to the MB. The study focused on effects of plasticity at synapses PNs to KC in the calyx. This is consistent with recent results supporting pre-synaptic plasticity between KC and MB neurons as critical in olfactory memory. Intracellular recordings revealed synapses from KC onto targets undergo STDP on a/−25 timescale.

The locust is ideal to study the interaction of coding strategies with plasticity and learning due to known circuitry, architecture, properties of ensembles, and their role in perception. In the AL, oscillatory synchronization is a feature of population coding during odor presentation, transient ensembles are formed and participate in encoding.
Researchers conducted the Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene (ST) study to identify genes associated with the development of coronary artery disease (CAD). They analyzed transcription profiles of liver, skeletal muscle, and fat tissues from patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery, and found 60 clusters of genes related to atherosclerosis. Two clusters, one from atherosclerotic arterial wall and visceral fat, differed in the extent of coronary stenosis. These associations were validated by analyzing carotid atheros expression profiles. One cluster related to carot stenosis and 27 genes to coronary stenosis were confirmed. Genes in the transendothelial migration of leukocytes (TE) pathway were overrepresented in all clusters, referred to as the atherosclerosis module (A). The A-module was found to be enriched with CAD risk 1.8-fold. Transcription-factor LIM binding 2 (L2) was identified as a potential regulator of A, supported by subnetwork analysis and expression of 13 TE genes in L2-deficient arterial. The A-module appears to be important for atherosclerosis and L2 merits attention in CAD research.
Researchers studied the molecular mechanisms of the circadian clock in the cyanobacterium Synechoccus, focusing on the KaiC protein, a central component of the clock. They found that KaiC is involved in both activating and repressing its own transcription. Over 24 hours, KaiC undergoes different phosphorylation states, but it was unclear which state promotes transcription activation and which repression. The researchers analyzed various combinations of positive and negative transcriptional regulation using a model that considers four phosphorylation states of Kai and transcriptional/translational feedback. They found a two-loop mechanism that reproduces experimental observations, including effects of knocking out or overexpressing Kai genes. Phosphorylated KaiC activates and unphosphorylated Kai suppresses Kai transcription. The model suggests the ratio of positive and negative components of Kai expression determines how the two-loop responds to removal or overexpression of Kai genes. This model and future experiments could reveal how the circadian pathways allow Kai to control rhythmically regulate genes in the cyanobacterial genome.
Researchers investigated the characteristics of HIV-2 reservoirs in individuals with non-progressing HIV-2 infection. They found that HIV-2 was undetectable in monocytes and quantifiable in transitional-memory CD4 T cells (TCM) in some individuals, but not in central-memory CD4 T cells (TCM). HIV-2 levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) correlated with those in TCM, but not TC. HIV reactivation was observed in cells from only 3 individuals. The CCR5 co-receptor was similarly distributed in cell populations from individuals and donors, but TC had lower expression of CXCR transcripts and higher of TRIM transcripts. These findings suggest HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 by lack of monocytic infection and limited TC infection associated with lower CXCR expression and higher TRIM. This sheds light on the low pathogenicity of HIV-2 infection, similar to other attenuated HIV/SIV models. The study characterized HIV-2 peripheral cell reservoirs in individuals with poorly productive HIV-2 infection and slow disease progression. HIV-2 was undetect in monocytes and quantifiable in TCM from some individuals, but not TC. HIV- levels in PBMC correlated with TCM, not TC. HIV reactivation was observed in cells from 3. CCR coceptor was similarly distributed, but TC had lower CXCR and higher TR transcripts.
Researchers have developed a new model called the Attention Routing Circuit (ARC) that explains how selective attention affects the activity of neurons in the brain's visual cortex. This model is unique because it can reproduce a wide range of attention effects and is based on individual spiking neurons, which are the basic building blocks of the brain's neural networks. The model shows that attention only affects how neurons respond to spatial information, not other features like color or shape. It also suggests that different attention effects are caused by a single mechanism, not separate processes. This is supported by data from studies on macaque monkeys and makes specific predictions that can be tested. 

The ARC model overcomes past limitations by providing a unified explanation of attention effects, being implemented in spiking neurons, and comparing to physiological data, and making testable predictions. It describes attention as a process that routes information in the brain's hierarchy. The model predicts that more neurons in higher areas are affected by attention, as they switch from default to selective states during demanding tasks.
Researchers investigated the genetic factors contributing to atrial fibrillation (AF), a common and debilitating heart rhythm disorder, using whole-exome sequencing data from a large community-based sample of 1,734 individuals with AF and 9,423 without AF from the Framingham Study, Cardiovascular Health Study, Atherosclerosis in Communities, and NHLBI-G Exome Sequencing Project. They analyzed results and examined genetic variation in 37 suspected AF genes in cases versus controls. The study found no significant associations between common or rare coding variants and AF, suggesting that large-effect coding variation is not the predominant mechanism underlying AF. A common missense variant in SYN2 was significantly associated with AF, but its causal relationship requires further evaluation. The study highlights the need for larger sample sizes or populations with large genetic effects to identify biologically meaningful variation underlying AF. AF is heritable, with one in four individuals having a first-degree relative with the condition, and current treatments have limited efficacy and adverse effects. Genome-wide studies have identified associated variants near channels, cardiac transcription factors, and other genes in AF, but causal genes remain unknown. Whole-exome sequencing may clarify genetic contributions to AF.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 cases of alveolar echoccosis (AE) were diagnosed in Poland, with 83.6% classified as confirmed, 16 as probable, and 22 as possible. The number of cases increased over the two decades, with a mean age at diagnosis of 47.7 years and a male to female ratio of 0.86:1. The disease was fatal in 19% of patients, with a mean age at death of 54.1 years. Aggregation of AE was found in 4 foci involving 9 patients, with 76 cases diagnosed in an advanced stage. The liver was the primary location in all cases, with 24.8% showing spread to other organs. 94 patients were treated with albendazole and 73 underwent surgery, including 15 liver transplants. The study confirms AE as an emerging disease in Poland, the 4th in Europe with over 120 cases, indicating a need for a national screening program in high-risk areas (northern Poland) and public awareness of E. multular and training of primary physicians for early detection.
Researchers studied how the zinc-sensing protein Zur in E. coli responds to changes in zinc availability at the molecular level. They solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PnuABC promoter and found that it represses gene expression by cooperative binding to adjacent dimers around the core of regulated promoters. Cooperativity requires a pair of salt bridges between Arg and Asp that connect independent dimers. Analysis revealed a new member of the regulon, plG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-dependent manner. The plG promoter forms complexes with one or two dimers with less cooperativity than other regulon promoters. In vitro binding affinity varies 10,000-fold across regulon promoters, and repression in vivo parallels this trend, with a 100-fold difference in transcript copy number between wild-type and Δzur strains. This suggests that the number of Fur dimers binding varies and the thermodynamics of Zur-DNA interactions correlate with physiological response at different promoters. The study supports the idea that thermodynamics of protein-DNA interactions control gene regulation and opens understanding how zinc and metal occupancy fine-tune stress expression across promoters.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a zoonotic disease that affects livestock, causing high morbidity and mortality. In 2008-2009, a RV outbreak occurred in Madagascar, including the Anjoabe district in the highlands. An entomological surveys found no Aedes mosquitoes, the RV virus vector, and low mosquito abundance due to unfavorable climate conditions. No serological or virological signs of infection were found in wild mammals, suggesting no RV virus reservoir. However, three serological and virological follow-up in cattle showed RV circulation. To understand this, a spatial deterministic metapulation model combined with cattle trade network was designed to reproduce local conditions. Three scenarios were analyzed: (i) RV overwintering due to direct transmission between vemic cows, vectors absent during winter, (ii) low vector circulation due to residual population, no direct transmission, (iii) combination. Multi-inference resulted in model incorporating low vector transmission and direct between animals. Predictions reproduced observations, 84% attributed to vector, 16 to direct. Results were robust to sensitivity analysis. Interactions between agriculture, vector seasonality, and cattle practices are key to understanding RV circulation in Madagascar highlands.
Aedes albopictus, a highly invasive and aggressive daytime-biting mosquito, has been expanding its range and posing a major public health threat in the Indo-Pacific region. To understand its historical and contemporary movements, researchers analyzed 13 microsatellite loci from 911 individuals and mitochondrial COI sequences. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was used to test competing invasion routes of Ae. albict in the Southeast Asian-Australian region. The results show Ae. albict was introduced to New Guinea via mainland Asia, colonizing the Solomon Islands via Papua New Guinea or Asia, and the recent incursion into northern Australia's Torres Strait was seeded from Indonesia. A colonized population in the Torres Islands has undergone rapid genetic changes, possibly due to genetic drift or a secondary invasion from an unknown source. High genetic structure and gene flow exist between geographically distant populations, driven by human dispersal. This study provides a broader distribution of the species' range, revealing more spatial structure than previously shown. The invasion history of Ae. albict in the Australasian region was analyzed using ABC. Populations from the Indian Ocean, Fiji, Naur, and USA were not included due to insufficient sampling. COI and microsatellite loci were analyzed together using ABC in DIY 2.1.0. Populations from Naur, Torres Islands, Australia, and USA, and Asia were included to fit into a broader analysis. Previously developed microsat markers and COI were used to investigate Ae. albict's population in the Indo region. ABC was used to compare invasion scenarios in the Austral region and explore genetic structure of populations. Temporal structure was found in introduced Torres Island populations, demonstrating drastic changes in a short period. Established Ae. albict populations in the Indo region were also found.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Mwan Region, North-West Tanzania to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni (S. mans) infection on morbidity in 572 school-aged children. The prevalence of S. mans infection was 58.7% with a mean intensity of 207.3 eggs per gram of feces. Most infections were light (56.5%), while 16.4% had heavy infections. Girls had higher mean intensities than boys (247.4 vs 153.2, p=0.004). 30.1% were anemic with no sex difference. Stunting and wasting were less than 10% of the population. No association was found between S mans prevalence or intensities and anthropometry, anemia, or spleen pathology. However, infected children had lower emotional quality of life scores (77.3 vs 82.7, p=0.033) and higher VO2 max (51.4 vs 50.8, p=0.042) than uninfected. In multivar regression, age, S mans infection, hemoglobin, and VO max were predictors of emotional quality of life, while predictors of VO max were physical quality, height, age, and hemoglobin. S mans was not retained in multivar regression on VO max. Only the emotional dimension of quality of life was associated with S mans infection.
Researchers compared the effectiveness of three routes of Leptira infection in rats: intraperitoneal, mucosal, and subcutaneous. Leptira is a zoonotic disease caused by a spirochete, with wild rodents, including brown rats, as reservoirs. Previous studies used intraperitoneal inoculation, but this is not a natural route. The study found that all three routes resulted in asymptomatic infection and similar antibody production. However, colonization rates differed: 8/8 for intraper, 5/8 for mucosal, and 1/8 for subaneous. Mucosal inoculation was more efficient for renal colonization and urinary excretion, while subaneous induced slower infection than intraper. This study helps understand infection modalities in rats, unlike epidemiological studies in wild rats. Future studies on natural routes will increase knowledge of rat-rat transmission and infection kinetics.
Researchers have identified a new role for Annexin A2 (An2) in regulating the body's response to sepsis, a life-threatening condition characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue damage, and organ dysfunction. In seps models, mice lacking An2 showed increased inflammatory cytokines, neutrophil infiltration, and decreased bacterial clearance, and survival. An2 deficiency also led to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) and interleukin-17 (IL-17) levels. Further investigation revealed that cysteine 9 of An2 is crucial for regulating ROS levels, which in turn affects IL-17 and inflammation. Depleting IL-17 via CRISPR/C9 strategy reduced inflammation and protected An2- mice from seps. This study reveals An2's previously unknown function in regulating seps through the An2-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing insights into the disease's pathophysiology. An2 acts as a putative ROS inhibitor in seps progression, with cystine 9 being key for oxidation, helping the body cope with the disease. An2 may mitigate seps severity by modulating ROS and IL-17 levels. Targeting neutils in seps may be a therapeutic approach, as An2-induced neutil infiltration contributes to severe and distant organ injury and mortality in seps mice. Additionally, IL-17 is regulated by ROS, with reduced inflammation after IL-17 knockdown.
Researchers investigated the role of microRNA-155 (miR-155) in the anti-HIV effects of Toll-like receptor (TLR) stimulation in macrophages. Macrophages play a key role in HIV pathogenesis and progression to AIDS. Polyinos-polycidylic acid (poly I:C), a synthetic analog of dsRNA, and lipopolysaccharide (LPS), ligands for TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs). However, the mechanisms are incompletely understood. The study found that poly I:C and L-stimulation of MDs abrogated infection by CCR-using, macroageotropic HIV-1 and vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudyped HIV-1 virions, while TLR, TLR or T9 agonists partially reduced infection to varying extent. Suppression of infection or lack did not correlate with differential effects on CD or CCR expression, type interferon induction, or pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Integrated viruses were detected in unstimulated TLR and T9-stimulated cells but not T3 or T4-stim MDs, suggesting alteration post-entry preintegration events. Microarray analysis and reverse transcription PCR found increased mi-155 levels in MDs upon T3 but not T-stimulation, and mi-155 inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly I-stimulated MDs. Ectopic mi-155 diminished HIV-1 in primary MDs and cell lines. Poly I-stimulation and ectopic mi-155 resulted in accumulation late products and undetectable or low integrated viruses 2TR circles. Reduced mRNA and protein levels several HIV-1 factors involved trafficking/import preintegration (AD10, TN3, N153, LED/p75) found poly I-stim and mi-transfected MDs, reporter suggested authentic mi- targets.
Plants use daily light-dark cycles to control various physiological processes, including growth. In Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings, hypocotyl growth rates are highest at different times of the day depending on external light and internal circadian rhythms. However, the interactions between light, circadian clock, and growth-promoting hormone pathways in growth are not well understood. Researchers analyzed the Arabidopsis seedling transcriptome under multiple growth conditions and mutant backgrounds using microarrays to determine the transcriptional component associated with rhythmic growth. A group of hormone-associated genes are co-expressed when hypocotyl growth is maximal, correlating with overrepresentation of a cis-element (CAT) in hormone promoters, sufficient to confer diurnal and circadian patterns in vivo. Circadian and light mutants show both internal hormone signaling and external coincidence with darkness are required for wild-type growth. The circadian clock controls growth by permissive of hormone levels at proper time, integrating pathways for seasonal growth regulation.
Researchers have explored a new approach to control Chagas disease vectors, such as Rhodnius prolix, by modifying the insect's gut microbiota to deliver molecules that induce RNA interference. They used Escheria coli to express dsRNA for the Rhodni heme-binding protein (RH) and catalase (CAT), which are essential for the insect's development and fecundity. The bacteria were fed to nymph and adult stages, and the results showed systemic and temporal RNA interference effects. Concentrations of E coli above 3.35 × 10^7 CF/mL produced significant RH and CAT gene knockdown in nymphs and adults. RH expression in the body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal levels 10 days later. CAT expression was reduced by 99% and 96 in the ovary and posteriorgut, respectively, five days after ingestion. Mortality increased 24-30% in first instars fed RH and CAT bacteria. Molting rates were reduced 100% in first and 80 in third instars fed RH or CATRNA. Oviposition was reduced 43% RH and 84 CAT. Embogenesis was arrested 16 RH and 20 of eggs. Feeding 105 CF/mL of natural symbion Rhodoccus rhodii expressing RH-specific RNA reduced RH by 89 and oviposition. Modifying the microbiota to induce RNA in R prolix may result in a paratgenic strategy for vector control.
A study was conducted to identify the causes of fever in pregnant women on the Thai-Burm border, where malaria was previously the leading cause of death in pregnant women in refugee camps in the 1980s. Artemisinin therapy reduced malaria incidence, but remaining causes of fever are not well-documented. Pregnant women attending antenatal care with routine malaria screening were invited for comprehensive clinical and laboratory screening if they had fever. Women were hospitalized and followed until delivery, with convalescent serum collected on day 21. Outcomes were recorded. Fever episodes occurred in 5.0% (409/8,117) of pregnant women from Jan-2004 to May-2006. Malaria was the main cause in 55.5% (227/409). A cohort of 203 (49.6%409) had fever investigations and follow-up. Arthrop-borne (malaria, ricketial infections, dengue and zoon disease leptpirosis) accounted for nearly half all febr illnesses 47.3 (96). Coinfection was observed 3.9 (8) mostly malaria ricketia. Pyonephritis 19.7 (40) was also common. Once malaria pyoneph and respiratory excluded, one-third febr infections were ricketia or leptpi. Scr and murine typhus were associated with poor outcomes including stillbirth and low birth. One died with no lab tests. Malaria remains leading cause fever in Thaiurm border. Scr and murine typh important causes poor outcomes. Fever pregnant Thaiurm not malaria pyone or respiratory should be treated with azithrom typh and leptpi.
Researchers investigated the relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans by analyzing over 600,000 genetic markers in 69 French-Canadian families. They found a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, driven by chromosome-specific effects, particularly in the middle sections of chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions. This suggests that recombination may become less efficient in protecting against non-disjunction with age, contributing to higher aneuploidy rates in older women. The study proposes a model reconciling findings with associations between maternal age and recombination in trisomies. To further investigate, researchers genotyped individuals from 68 French-Canadian families and localized recombination events at high resolution. A genome-wide decrease in recombination rate was observed with advancing maternal age, consistent with previous studies. Chromosome-specific effects may determine the complex relationship between maternal and recombination, varying among populations due to genetic differences in regulating recombination machinery. Results support this hypothesis, with significant decay on nine chromosomes in the French-Canadian cohort and two in Hutter. Maternal age is a major factor in chromosomal aneupidy, but little is known about age-related non-disjunction causes. Recombination initiated during fetal development can still influence age. Not all trisomies are affected equally by maternal age, and mechanisms may not apply to anup conceptions. Data highlight distinct selective constraints on chromosomes influencing recombination over generations.
Researchers have developed a new approach to fight opportunistic infections in people with weakened immune systems by training their macrophages, a type of immune cell, to remember specific pathogens. Unlike traditional vaccines that rely on the adaptive immune system, this method induces an innate memory in macrophage that lasts for at least 70 days and provides complete protection against secondary infection without the need for adaptive cells. This was achieved by priming macroages with interferon-gamma (IF-γ) in vivo, a protein that activates the STAT1 pathway. RNA analysis showed rapid upregulation of IF-γ and STAT pathways following secondary challenge. The response was specific to the pathogen and correlated with changes in histone methylation and acetylation, and increased STAT binding to genes associated with anti-fungal immunity. The study demonstrates an alternative method to induce macroage memory in vivo that facilitates pathogen-specific vaccine responses.
Researchers studied how a group of proteins called Polycomb repressive complexes (PCs) regulate gene expression and development in plants. They found that different combinations of PC proteins work together to control different developmental programs, such as flower and embryo development, by modifying histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27) tri-methylation. A key protein called CURLY LEAF (CL) plays a crucial role in repressing flower development in seedlings by associating with LIKE HETCHROMIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). In contrast, embryo development is repressed by PC-catalytic subunits AtBMI and AtRING in common with PC-catal enzymes CL and SWINGER (SW). The researchers used a new method to compare epigenomic data and found changes in H3me3 and gene expression in mutants of PC components in Arabidopsis seedlings. They found that different PC members regulate distinct developmental programs and their specificity is modulated by transcription factors, such as MADS and ABA. This study provides insights into how PC specificity is established in plants and how they regulate gene expression.
Researchers have studied the "trigger loop" (TL) of the RNA polymerase II enzyme in yeast, which plays a crucial role in substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation. They created nearly all possible single-residue variants of the TL and found three classes of mutations linked to transcription defects or stress, with distinct residue distributions. Disrupting an intra-TL hydrophobic pocket, proposed to destabilize a catalytically inactive TL state, showed consistent with increased catalysis. Genetic interactions among TL and TL-proximal residues support the contribution of funnel and bridge helices (BH) to TL dynamics. The study provides a high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and evolution, applicable to other essential yeast proteins. 

The researchers assessed the functional contributions of all TL residues to fitness in yeast under multiple conditions, indicating intra-T interactions and TL with nearby domains (e.g. BH and funnel helices) are critical for TL function. Genetic and structural studies support a multi-step folding model for catalysis. Many gain-of-function (GOF) and loss-of-function (LOF) TL variants were identified, some predicted to confer epist interactions. TL's ability to fold into multiple conformations and convert between states is critical for its functions. Previous studies show TL is delicately balanced, perturbations result in increased or decreased catalytic activity and translocation.
Researchers investigated how rabies virus (RV) enters the central nervous system (CNS) of mice after infection. Typically, RV spreads through the nervous system from the site of infection to the CNS, but it's unclear if it can also enter through the bloodstream. They infected mice intramuscularly (i.m.) or intravenously (i.v.) with dog-associated RV (DOG) or silver-haired bat-associated RV (SB) to see if it could enter the CNS through the bloodstream. After i.m. infection, both strains caused lethal encephalopathy, but only i.v. infection with SB resulted in lethal infection. Immunohistochemistry showed i.v. administered SB directly infected the brain, specifically the hypothalamic nuclei connected to the pituitary gland. This suggests hematogenous spread can lead to fatal encephalopathy through the hypothalamus-pituitary interface. This alternative mode of spread has implications for post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies, particularly for silver bat-associated RV.
Researchers studied the evolutionary history of the H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus, which has caused significant illness and death in humans since the 1918 pandemic. They analyzed 71 complete genome sequences of the virus from 1918 to 2006 and found that segment reassortment, or the swapping of genetic material between viruses, played a key role in the virus's evolution. Specifically, they found that an H1 virus from 1947 acquired new genes through reassort, which may explain its sudden change in severity. Similarly, the 195 epidemic may have been caused by reassorted H1 viruses. The study suggests reassort is more important in H1 evolution than previously thought. Reassort between viruses from different species can create pandemic viruses, such as the 1957 and 196 pandemics. The H1 genome showed congruent patterns, but distinct reassort events affected specific segments. The researchers analyzed 71 whole-genome sequences from 191 to 200, representing 17 countries and 5 continents. Few studies have looked at reassort in H1 viruses. H1 is thought to evolve slowly compared to H2, needing less frequent vaccine updates.
Researchers investigated how nicotine affects the brain's ventral tegmental area (VTA), a key region involved in reward and motivation, by stimulating nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nACh) and boosting dopamine (DA) output. The study aimed to determine whether nicotine's primary action is direct stimulation of DA cells through nCh activation or inhibition through desensitization of nCh on GABA interneurons. A computational model of V circuitry and nCh function showed that α2-containing nCh on DA or GABA cells mediate acute nicotine's effects, accounting for in vitro and in vivo data. The model predicted conditions for direct stimulation or inhibition to cause DA increases. Experiments were proposed to disentangle both mechanisms. Endogenous acetylcholine's rate crucially determines DA response for both mechanisms. Results suggest acetylcholine dependence for nicotine's rewarding properties. 

The study used a novel computational approach to model V's DA and GABA neurons and nCh responses, clarifying interplay of nicotine's pharmacodynamics and dopaminergic signal. Identified endogenous cholin input's low rate for direct stimulation and high for inhibition to observe DA increase, from α2 nCh activation and desensization. Experimental results supported GABA cells' role in nicotine action. A model with nCh dynamics captured in vitro modulation of excitatory and inhibitory inputs to DA neurons. In vivo studies emphasized direct activation of β-containing nCh on DA neurons. The study clarified mechanisms linking nCh activation/desitization and DA control. A network model included affer and local V connectivity and nCh location/desit properties.
Researchers conducted a two-armed, randomized, double-blinded phase II trial in Kabul, Afghanistan to study a novel treatment for cutaneous leishmanias (CL) caused by Leishmania (L) trop infection. The study aimed to prevent superinfections, accelerate wound closure, and improve cosmetic outcome of CL. From 2004 to 2008, patients with CL were treated with bipolar-frequency electrocauter (EC) followed by moist-wound-treatment (MWT) with polyacrylate hydrogel (group I) or without (group II) pharmaceutical chlorite (DAC-055). Patients under 5, with facial lesions, pregnancy, or comorbidities were excluded. The primary outcome was time for complete epithelialization. Biops for parasitological and immunopath analyses were taken before EC, after wound closure, and after 6 months. The mean for complete closure was 59.1 days in group I and 54.2 days in II (p= 0.83). Leish-positive biops DAC-055 caused rapid epithialization 37.2 vs 58.3 days (p=0.08). Superfections occurred in both groups at 8.8%. Except one, recurrences 10.2 in I, 18.5 II (p=0.158) were in cases with high parasite loads after healing. DAC-055 showed leishicidal effect on amastigotes. Compared to intraional injections, EC plus M led to rapid closure and lower relapse rate.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosila cells to identify factors impacting RAS-MAP signaling. They found 101 validated hits, most of which were previously associated with the pathway. Epist experiments revealed new factors acting at different steps, including a protein modulating RAF activation. Unexpectedly, most hits worked downstream of ME and influenced MAP expression, mainly through constitutive splicing. Two members of this group were characterized and found to regulate MAP alternative splicing. This study provides a comprehensive view of factors modulating R-MAP signaling in Dila. It suggests pathway output relies not only on classical events like RAF activation, but also MAP regulation. Additionally, splicing components can impact alternative splicing.

The screen involved three steps: primary RNAi, validation, and secondary screens to establish regulatory position relative to pathway components. G-loaded R triggers sequential activation of RAF, ME, and MAP; RAF activates ME, which phosphorylates and activates MAP. Unlike RAF and ME, MAP has cytoplasmic and nuclear substrates, such as transcription factors c-Jun, c-Fos, p53, EL1, c-Myc, c-My, STAT3, SRF, and SM1/2/4.

Validated hits were submitted to secondary assays to position regulatory with core kinases. In addition to known components mediating R-induced MAP activation, the screen discovered new factors at different steps. Notably, five act upstream of RAF. Most hits, at R-RA and RAF-M, did not change R/MK components. However, some caused fluctuations in proteins or transcripts. These also impacted non-R related assays.
A study was conducted to investigate the genetic diversity of Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptoccus gattii isolates in Thailand. A total of 498 isolates were studied, with 386 from clinical and 112 from environmental and veterinary sources. The majority of isolates (68.9%) were from males with a mean age of 37.97 years, and 88.5% of Cryptoccus neoans and 37.5 of Cryptoccus gatt were from HIV patients. Molecular typing revealed that 94.8% of isolates were Cryptoccus neoans type V, regardless of source, followed by 2.4% type II, 0.2 type IV, 0.2 type I, and 2.4 type II. Multilocus Sequence Typing (MLST) analysis identified 20 sequence types (ST) in Thailand, with 30 for Cryptoccus gatt and 82, 83, 137, 141, 172, and 173 for Cryptoccus neoans unique to Thailand. Most Cryptoccus gatt isolates were ST7-VGb, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak strain, indicating Thailand as a stepping stone for global spread. The study found greater diversity and range of molecular types amongst Thai cryptococcal isolates than previously reported.
Researchers studied the evolution of a specific type of transcription factor (TF) called C2-H2 zinc finger (CH-ZF) in 12 Drosoph species over 45 million years. They found that a significant fraction of CH-Z 1-1 orthologs in flies have variations that affect their DNA-binding specificities. In addition to losing or gaining CH-Z domains, they discovered diverging DNA-contact residues in 44% of domains between D melanogaster and other species. These diverging residues, found in 70% of D melanaster CH-Z genes and 26% of all melan TFs, show evidence of constraint, being conserved across phylogenetic clades and evolving slower than other residues. These variations were rarely found as polymorphisms in a D melanaster population, indicating rapid fixation. The specificities of these domains change gradually across phylogen distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Proteins with conserved CH domains are enriched in developmental functions, while those with varying domains show no enrichments. The study suggests a subset of dynamic and understudied TFs are a source of variation in Dophila and metazoa.
Researchers have developed a new PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay to identify and differentiate between two types of Salmonella bacteria, Typhi and Paraty A, which cause typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. These bacteria can be difficult to diagnose due to a lack of typing sera and sometimes requiring culture. The new assay uses a repeated DNA sequence called CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindrom repeats) as a target, which is specific to each serotype. The researchers tested the assay on 188 Typhi and 74 Paraty A strains from diverse origins and time periods, and 70 strains of other bacteria, including 29 Salmonella and 38 other species. The results showed 100% sensitivity and specificity, meaning it can accurately detect and distinguish between the two serotypes. The assay can be used with DNA from cultured isolates, and with modifications, the CRPR target can be used for clinical samples. This can facilitate rapid and accurate identification in clinical and public laboratories with PCR access.
Researchers investigated the role of Notch signaling in the differentiation of CD4+ T helper 1 (Th1) cells during infection with the parasite Leishmania major. Notch receptors Not1 and Not2 are expressed on CD4 T cells, but their role in Th1 differentiation is not well understood. Mice with specific deletion of Not1 and Not2 (NNΔ4CDCre) on a C57/6 background developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia due to impaired IFγ secretion by CD4 T cells and increased IL-5 and IL-13 cytokines. In contrast, mice with single deletion of Not1 or Not were resistant to infection and developed a Th1 response. Notch signaling is required for IFγ secretion by Th cells, independent of CSL/RBPκ, the major effector of Notch. Mice with RBPκ deletion in T cells were able to develop IFγ-secre Th cells, kill parasites and heal lesions. The study shows a crucial role for RBP-independent Notch in Th1 differentiation following L major infection.
Researchers investigated whether infection with the parasitic worm Schistosoma mansoni increases susceptibility to HIV infection in rhes macaques. The study found that animals infected with the worm were more likely to become infected with the AIDS virus after exposure, even at lower doses that were not enough to infect uninfected animals. In fact, the amount of virus needed to cause infection was 17 times lower in infected animals compared to controls. Infected animals also had higher levels of the virus in their blood and increased viral replication in immune cells. This suggests that controlling parasitic infections may help reduce the spread of HIV in areas where both are common.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study how the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh) affects neural activity in the brain's cortex, specifically during sleep and wakefulness. Acetylcholine is known to regulate neural excitability and is involved in sleep regulation. The model shows how changes in neural excitability and network structure create three distinct patterns: localized, asynchronous, traveling, and synchronous. These patterns match those observed in brain activity during slow wave sleep (SWS) and REM or waking states. During WS, traveling patterns occur in the cortex, while in other states, stationary patterns do. The model consists of Hodgkin-Hux type neurons with M-current regulated by ACh. ACh regulation can account for dynamical changes between regimes. Reducing the magnitude of this current recreates reduction in spike-frequency adaptation (SFA) and shift in phase response curve (RC) observed with ACh. When FA is minimal (waking or REM state, high ACh), patterns are localized and easily pinned by network inhomogeneities. When FA is present (decreasing A), traveling activity arises. Further decrease in A leads to high synchrony within waves. ACh also determines network sensitivity to synaptic heterogeneity. These regimes may have functional significance: stationary patterns may encode external input as memory, while traveling could lead to synaptic regularization.
Researchers investigated the impact of mutations in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway on the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), a type of cancer that occurs in the esophagus. They found that non-synonymous mutations in the TLR pathway were present in 14.6% of 171 EAC samples, with TLR4 being the most frequently mutated gene with 5.8% of samples. These mutations were associated with more proximal and metastatic disease, indicating potential clinical significance. The study also found TLR mutations in other solid tumors exposed to microbiomes, including colorectal adenocarcin, stomach adenocarcin, uterine endrioid carcinoma, and cutaneous melanoma. TLR mutants showed impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide, suggesting a possible role in disease pathogenesis in a subset of patients.
Researchers investigated the development of taste cells in mice using a novel approach combining in silico and in vivo analyses. They found that taste receptor molecules (TRMs) colocalized in the developing circumvallate papillae (CVP) and analyzed the regulatory regions of TRMs to identify a common network. This led to the identification of Hes as a likely regulatory factor, which was further examined in vivo. Expression analyses showed decreased nuclear H1 correlated with type II taste cell markers. After E18, CVP of H1-/- mutants had 5-fold more TRM-immunactive cells than wild-type littermates. The study suggests H1 plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing buds.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling root elongation, a process crucial for plant growth and development. Unlike the dicotyledonous plant Arabidopsis, the interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice is not well understood. The study found that the activation of OsIL on the expression of YUC8/IN and indole-3-pyric acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using a YUC inhibitor, which regulates auxin biosynthesis by converting IPA to indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), they showed that ethylene-inhibited primary root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. A rice mutant, rein-1, insensitive to ethylene, was identified with Y8IN truncated at its C-terminus. Mutation in YIN reduced auxin biosynthesis in rice, while overexpression of YIN enhanced ethylene sensitivity in roots. YIN catalyzed the conversion of IPA to IAA, and a truncated version of YIN resulted in reduced enzymatic activity, indicating YIN is required for IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis and eth-inhibited elong in rice seedlings. Further, eth induced YIN expression and promoted auxin accumulation in roots. Low concentrations of IAA rescued the eth response in rein-1, demonstrating eth-in elong depends on IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis. Genetic studies revealed YIN-mediated aux biosynthesis functions downstream of OsIL, which directly activates YIN expression. The findings reveal a model of interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling root elong, enhancing understanding of eth signaling in rice.
A nationwide epidemiological study in Saudi Arabia investigated the trend of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NT) diseases, which are reportedly increasing globally. The study collected 527 isolates over 24 months and identified 34 NT species, including 17 rare ones, with M. simiae (22.6%), M. fortuitum (18.1%), and M. absus (17.8%) being predominant. New cases of M. riyense, a rare species, were also found. The study showed rare events like mycobacteremia, abscess, peritonitis, and ascites caused by M. woli, M. hatic, M. duii, and M. monence. Diabetes and previous tuberculosis history were risk factors associated with NT diseases. NT disease and pathogen diversity pose a challenge to the nation, including Saudi Arabia. A plan for mycobacterial control and management should be developed urgently.
Researchers studied how yeast cells enter a state of dormancy, called quiescence, in response to starvation, and how it affects their lifespan. They screened a library of yeast genes involved in signaling and found that Rim15, Mck, and Yak1 kinases, the SNF/AMP complex, cell integrity pathway, and cell cycle regulators are necessary for quies establishment and lifespan extension. Quies requires integration of signals from multiple pathways. The lifespan of mutants and single, double, and triple mutants of Rim, Yak, and Mck correlates with carbohydrate accumulation, not cell cycle status. Removing glycogen and trehalose biosynthesis genes severely reduces lifespan. Overexpressing glycogen and trehal or supplementing treose improves lifespan in mutants. Yak, Rim, and Mck kinases control reactive oxygen species and mediate TOR-regulated carbohydrate accumulation and lifespan. The study suggests that energy storage and antioxidant systems are coordinated by Yak, Rim, and Mck to ensure quies and lifespan.
Researchers have discovered that the influenza A virus's hemagglutinin (HA) protein undergoes glycosylation, or the addition of sugar molecules, to compensate for fitness defects caused by mutations that allow the virus to evade antibodies. This process, called antigenic drift, enables the virus to persist in human populations despite widespread immunity. The study used a method called primer error-correct viral sequencing to reveal this unexpected role of glycosylation in increasing the virus's ability to bind to host cells. Mutations that added N-linked glycans to the HA's globular domain allowed the virus to rapidly propagate in the absence of antibodies. This finding expands understanding of viral mechanisms that maintain fitness during antigen evolution and highlights the power of high-definition virus sequencing to reveal new adaptive mechanisms. 

Glycosylation can play a role in antigen drift, increasing the fitness of escape variants by restoring HA interactions with receptors, even without antibody pressure. This may contribute to the accumulation of glycans in the globular domain during H1 and H3 virus circulation. The study demonstrates glycos can compensate for fitness costs imposed by escape substitutions on HA, increasing viability and emergence of antibody-escape variants. The virus may have evolved to maximize compensatory pathways during antigen drift.
Researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of ventricular myocyte models to identify targets that exhibit favorable rate dependence, a property of antiarrhythmic drugs that could overcome the problems of reverse dependence. Reverse dependence is a property of antiarrhythmic drugs that prolongs the cardiac action potential (AP) and is more pronounced at slow heart rates, leading to reduced arrhythm suppression at fast rates and increased arrhythm risk at slow rates. The opposite, forward dependence would theoretically resolve these issues, yet forward dependent (FR) antiarrhythmics remain elusive. The study simulated populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzed results statistically, predicting rate-dependent effects on multiple parameters. Average 40 parameters were tested in each model, and AP duration assessed at slow (0.2 Hz) and fast (2 Hz) rates. The analysis identified FR ionic perturbations and specific mechanisms, such as an increase in L-type current accompanied by indirect rate-dependent changes in delayed rectifier potassium current. Inward rectifier current and sodium-potassium pump were the most likely to produce FR AP prolongation. Statistical analysis showed models with minimal rate changes in AP have little FR potential, while those with large changes have considerable FR. This explains differences between species and ventricular types. The study provides insights into determinants of AP rate dependence and a strategy for beneficial antihythmic design.
Researchers have developed a new method to study the relationship between genetic variations in a person's DNA and their response to certain medications. They applied this method to thiopurine-methyltransferase (TPMT) enzyme activity in patients treated with thiopine drugs. Thiopine is a medication used to treat certain conditions such as iron-deficiency anemia and diabetes. The researchers analyzed data from 442 patients at a French hospital between 2010 and 2013. They found that patients with high TPMT activity were more likely to have iron-deficiency anemia and diabetes. This suggests that thiopine may not be effective for these patients. The study used a new approach called Phen-Wide Association Studies (PAS) that combines medical diagnosis codes and test results to identify subgroups of patients who may need personalized treatment. This is the first study to use International Classification of Diseases 10th edition (ICD-10) codes, previously studies used International Classification of Diseases 9th edition (IC-9) codes. The results were validated by comparing with biological test results. This method can help identify patients who may not respond to thiopine and need alternative treatment.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of animal studies on stem cell transplantation in spinal cord injury found that allogenic stem cells improved motor function by 27.2% (95% CI 25.0-29.4) in 5,628 animals and sensory function by 26.3% (95 CI 7.9-44.7) in 473 animals. Autologous stem cells were not used in any studies. Different facets of stem cell biology, such as differentiation and delivery route, influenced sensory outcomes, with intravenous delivery showing better results. Stem cell implantation did not improve sensory outcomes in female animals and was enhanced by isoflurane anesthesia. A dose-response relationship supported biological plausibility. For motor outcomes, facets of stem biology had little effect, while heterogeneity was explained by experimental design and outcome measures. Location, injury method, and immunosuppression impacted results. Reporting bias was higher than in neuroscience but still suboptimal, with motor studies not reporting blinded outcomes giving inflated estimates. Efficacy may be lower than reported due to internal validity and publication bias.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to assess the patterns and dynamics of soil-transmitted helminth (STH) reinfection after treatment. The review included 154 studies, with 51 providing STH rates pre- and post-treatment, and 42 reporting determinants of predisposition to reinfection. At 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, Ascaris lumbricoid prevalence reached 26%, 68%, and 94% of pretreatment levels, respectively. Trichuris trura reinfection prevalence were 36%, 67, and 82, and hookworm 30, 55, and 57. Prevalence and intensity of reinfection were correlated with pretreatment status. STH reinfections occurred rapidly after treatment, particularly for A. lumbricoid and T. trura. Frequent anthelmint drug administrations are needed to maximize preventive chemotherapy benefit. Integrated approaches emphasizing health and sanitation are required to interrupt transmission. The review suggests using egg reduction rate (ERR) rather than cure rate (CR) for anthelmint drug evaluations and studying reinfection after treatment. Intensity of infection was not well addressed in pooled estimates. Relationships between STH rein and socioeconomic factors were not definitively assessed. Analysis was performed by helmin species and follow-up intervals. Prevalence ratio (PRR) was used to estimate reinfection risk.
Researchers investigated the deregulation of metabolic processes in nonalcoholic liver disease (NAFLD) using a new method called Minimum Enrichment Analysis (MiA) applied to mouse and human omics data. NAD is a spectrum of diseases from simple steatosis to complex nonal steatohepatitis. Traditional pathway analysis requires predefined maps, which can be biased due to different annotations and cannot capture complex interactions. MiA generates minimal networks (Mi) of reactions for a target metabolite, applied to deregulated Mi in NAD phenotypes, such as fatty liver and inflammation in humans and mice. Key deregulations were found in cholesteryl ester, cholesterol, and hexadecate synthesis, and regulators of hydrogen peroxide synthesis differed between humans and mice. MiA identified general and specific characteristics of NAD phenotypes. This method is applicable to any genome-scale metabolic network and target metabolite, making it flexible for studying metabolism in any disease or organism.
Researchers studied how the olfactory system identifies odors and found that primacy coding, where the identity is encoded by the types of receptors that respond earliest, provides a compact and informative representation that can be efficiently interpreted by the brain. They analyzed a simple model of primacy using numerical and statistical simulations and showed that the encoded information depends on the number of receptor types in the prim representation but weakly on the size of the repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity and the information is useful for typical olfactory tasks close to experimentally measured. Interestingly, they found situations where a smaller repertoire is advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests overly sensitive receptors can dominate the response and make the array useless, allowing prediction of receptor adaptation to environmental changes. Primacy is more useful than binary and normalized coding because sparsity of representations is independent of odor statistics, unlike alternatives. It provides efficient representation independent of intensity and helps identify odors in olfactory cortex.
Researchers studied the neutralization profiles of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnMA) against HIV, specifically PG9, PG16, PGT, and P152. They found that some bnMA displayed unusual neutralization profiles with non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus at less than 100% neutralization. The study aimed to determine the extent of non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus less than 100 for bnMA generally. Using a panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4-T cell assay and 117 viruses in the TZ-bl assay, they found that bnMA targeting various epitopes of the spike had neutral profiles that plateaued at less than 90. Across both panels, bnMA targeting the V apex of Env and gp41 were most likely to show neutral curves that plateaued less than 100. Conversely, bnMA targeting high-mann epitopes were less likely to show this behavior. CD4 binding Abs also showed this behavior infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was observed in a peripheral blood mononuclear cell-grown virus panel from patient swarms. Additionally, five bnMA were compared against 18-virus of clones produced in 293 cells and PBs and assayed in TZ-bl. Examples of plateaus less 90 were seen with both types of virus with no consistent patterns. The study suggests that incomplete neutralization and nonigmoid neutral curves are possible for all bnMA against a range of viruses produced and assayed in cell and primary cells, with implications for use in therapy and vaccine design.
Researchers developed a computational model to study how cancer cells use glucose and glutamine to produce energy and biomass. They found that when glutamine levels are high, cells produce more lactate from glutamine instead of glucose, even in the presence of oxygen. This occurs when oxygen is not enough to fully oxidize carbon from glucose and glutamine. The model showed that this pattern is optimal for biomass and ATP production, requiring a branched TCA cycle and redox-controlled reactions. Experiments in a cancer cell line confirmed these findings, validating the model's predictions. This metabolic rewiring may occur in various tumor cells, suggesting competition between glucose and glutamine plays a role in cancer growth.
Researchers investigated the interactions of the prion protein (Pr) and its mammalian paralogs, Doppel (PrPnd) and Shadoo (Spr), in a cell culture model that allows prion replication. They found that the three proteins share a similar environment in neuroblastoma cells and interact with each other. Additionally, they confirmed interactions between Pr and the cell adhesion molecule laminin, Na+/K ATPases, and protein disulfide isomerases (PDI), reconciling previous findings. Experiments showed that Pr interactions with PDIs may occur outside the endoplasmic reticulum and play a previously unknown role in PrSc accumulation. A hypothesis proposes that Pr organizes its environment by binding adhesion molecules with immunoglobulin domains, recognizing oligann-bearing membrane proteins.
During influenza virus infection, the immune system typically responds with a type 1 inflammatory cytokine response, but type 2 cytokines are also produced. Type 2 cytokines are linked to asthma exacerbation, but may also provide protection. Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is a type 2 cytokine essential for eosinophil maturation and egress from the bone marrow. In a mouse model of influenza infection, IL-5 was released into the airways and eosin accumulated in the lungs, particularly after virus clearance. The source of IL-5 was group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC) in the infected lungs. IL-5 production by IL2 was enhanced by interaction with NKT cells and alveolar macrophages, which produce IL-33. This interaction led to abundant IL-5 production by IL2 and eosin accumulation in the lungs during recovery phase of infection.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial testing was performed on all organisms. 71% of NT patients were HIV-infected, 90% were adults, 71 were male, and 33 reported intravenous use. 26/92 (28) patients had known outcome; HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis Sequence (ST) 11 (43/89) and Typhimium (ST 19, 34, 44) (23/89) were most identified serovars. Tyim was more common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates from HIV-inf patients were more likely exhibit reduced susceptibility trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037). NT disease is severe in Vietnam with high mortality. In sub-Saharan, HIV was risk for death with majority burden in population HIV-inf adult.
Researchers have developed a method to identify viral and phage structural proteins using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). These proteins are crucial for the survival and pathogenicity of viruses, and understanding their functions can aid in disease detection, diagnosis, vaccine development, and environmental impact on microbial communities. However, most phage ORFs (open reading frames) are dissimilar to known genes, making identification challenging. Traditional methods rely on sequence similarity, but structural proteins have low conservation, few conserved sites, and limited data. The researchers trained ANNs to classify structural proteins by amino acid frequency, achieving high specificity and sensitivity. They then added isoelectric point as a feature to classify major and tail proteins, increasing accuracy. Electron microscopy validated predicted proteins with no known similarities, self-assembling into virion structures. The ANNs are a new tool for identifying phage and prophage proteins difficult to detect by bioinformatic analysis. They will be valuable when propagation is not practical or possible.
Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSH) is a cancer-causing virus with a large genome that encodes over 85 proteins, including unique and conserved herpesviral proteins. SH ORF20 is a member of the herpesiral UL24 family, but its function and role in the viral life cycle are not well understood. OR20 encodes three uncharacterized isoforms localized in the nuclei and nucleoli. Quantitative purification coupled to mass spectrometry (q-APMS) identified specific partners of OR20, including ribosomal and interferon-stimulated gene (IS) oligoadylate synthase-like (OL) protein. Both endogenous and transiently transfected OL co-immoprecipitated with OR20, conserved among OR isoforms and OR20 homologs of UL family in herpesviruses. Characterization of OL partners by-MS identified a similar interactome to OR20. Both OR20 and OL copurified with 40 and 60 ribosomal subunits, when coexpressed, associated polys. OR20 did not affect translation, but enhanced R-I expression of endogenous OL in IR3 but IFN-independent manner. OL has antiviral activity against some viruses, but role in gammaherpesviruses unknown. We show OL and OR20 expression induced after reactivation latently infected HuLT-rSH.219 cells. Intriguingly, OL enhanced KSH infection with OR20 mutant, however, OL-dependent infectivity lost.
A study was conducted to determine the prevalence and presentation of Lassa virus disease (LVD) in febrile children with and without convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. A total of 913 feile children aged 1-15 years were admitted to a hospital over a year. 373 (40.9%) had fever, of which 108 (29%) presented with convuls. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13/373 (3.5%; 95% CI 1.9, 5.7) in feile admissions, 3/108 (2.8%) in Cases and 10/265 (3.8) in Controls. Only vomiting and bleeding were significantly associated with increased prevalence of L. L is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas but not associated with convuls in feile. Its prevalence and lack of clinical differentiation underscores importance of high suspicion in diagnosis. Screening feile with undifferent fever in endemic for L could be important public health measure.
Researchers investigated the role of the karri receptor K2 (KAR2) in drought resistance in Arabidopsis thalian, a model plant species. They found that mutations in the K2 gene, which encodes the karri receptor, make plants more sensitive to water deprivation. Analyzing K2 mutants, they discovered increased water loss and cell damage, enlarged stomatal apertures, and higher cuticular permeability. Additionally, K2 plants had reduced anthocyan biosynthesis during drought and were hypersensitive to abscisic acid (ABA) in stomatal and cotyledon assays. A genome-wide transcript analysis identified genes associated with these changes. The study suggests crosstalk between ABA and K2 signaling in drought responses. Comparing the strigact receptor mutant d14 to K2, strigactones also contribute to drought adaptation, but not through cuticle development. The findings indicate chemical or genetic manipulation of K2 and 14 may improve drought resistance.
Researchers have investigated the role of insulin signaling in the growth and development of Schistosoma japonicum, a parasite that causes schistosomiasis in humans. They focused on the insulin receptors (SIR) of S. japonicum, which they had previously cloned and characterized. They found that human insulin binds to a specific part of the IR, called the L subdomain, using a technique called biolayer interferometry. They then used a method called RNA interference (RNAi) to reduce the expression of IR in adult S. japon in a lab dish and found that this reduced the transcription of other genes involved in insulin signaling and glucose metabolism. They also observed a decrease in glucose uptake in the IR-knockdown worms compared to controls. In vaccine experiments, they found that the L sub of IR reduced growth, intestinal worm density and egg production in S. japon in mice with a low infection. These results suggest that the IR could be a target for a vaccine against schistosomiasis in China and the Philippines.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a significant cause of disability in the Pacific region, affecting over 96% of the 1.7 million population at risk of infection. Mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced lymphatic filariasis prevalence, but vector biology complicates the MDA strategy in some regions. The goal of LF elimination cannot be attained via MDA alone in some areas. Obligate mosquitoes provide targets for breaking the LF cycle, but existing methods are ineffective for controlling the primary vector, Aedes aegypti, in the South Pacific. Researchers demonstrate that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in A aedes aegypt strain (CP) stably infected with endosymbiotic Wolbachia from Aedes albopictus. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays show CP males are equally competitive, resulting in population elimination when introduced into wild Aedes aegpt populations. The findings demonstrate feasibility and encourage field tests of the vector strategy as a supplement to ongoing MDA efforts.
A study was conducted in Uram District, Tanzania to estimate the burden of Rhodesian trypanosomiasis (HAT) in terms of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) and financial costs. Data from 143 patients admitted to Kali Health Centre in 2004 for HAT treatment was used. Direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. DALs were estimated using the Global Burden Project methods and previous H estimates, assuming 45% under-reporting. The estimated DALs for H in Uram District with and without weighting were 215.7 (95% CI 155.3-287.5) and 281.6 (95% CI 209.1-362.6) respectively. When 45% underreporting was included, results were 622.5 (95 CI 155.3-109.9) and 978.9 (95 CI 201.1-187.8). The cost of treating 143 patients was estimated at $15,514, with patients paying $3,673 and services $11,841. Indirect non-medical costs for 143 patients were $9,781.
