The development of improved search and selection algorithms for complex spaces is crucial for research. FoS was designed for complex dynamics in large spaces and diverse structures. Without prior knowledge, comparing models allows data-driven inference of important processes. There's a need for algorithms efficiently searching large spaces to describe observed dynamics. A previous algorithm worked well on theoretical systems but relied on dense sampling and neglected compensating effects. Other algorithms rely on exhaustive or predefined structures. FoS was motivated for complex systems and can be applied to various problems, unlike others designed for specific structures.
Researchers conducted a 12-month follow-up study in Bolivia to evaluate the effectiveness of benznidazole (BN) treatment in children infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite that causes Chagas disease. The study involved 103 seropositive children who received BN treatment, with 3 experiencing side effects. Blood samples were taken before, during, and after treatment, and analyzed for serology, conventional PCR, and real-time PCR, and Th1/Th/2/17 cytokines, including IL-17. Among 57 children who completed follow-up, 6 (11%) showed both PCR+ and qPCR+, 24 (42%) PCR- but q+, and 27 (47%) PCR- and q-. IL-17 levels were significantly higher in seropitive children before treatment and decreased to normal levels after one year. IL-17 levels were positively related to parasite counts by qPCR. At 12 months, IL-17 levels in non-reactive subjects were higher than reactive or ambiguous, suggesting IL-17 as a potential biomarker for BN treatment response. Plasma IL-17 might detect persistent T. cruzi infection and inflammation.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary cause of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, nearly 2% of which is occupied by a small transposon called Coria. Bioinformatic analysis identified eight subtypes of the element with four distinct transcriptional ends. Transcription analysis using PCR and lacZ reporter revealed two ends encode strong promoters. The strongest promoter is dictated by polymorphism Y128 at the right end of the element. Examples of elements drive transcription of adjacent genes, while others express non-coding RNAs. Pairwise comparisons of three meningococ genomes show more than two-thirds of Coria maintain subtype at any locus due to recombinational switching between elements in a strain. Upon switching, a new allele spreads through population by natural transformation. This may represent a new mechanism for variation in meningococcus. The strain-to-strain variability of Coria and number of strong promoters allows for widespread effects within population. Defining strength of promoters by subtypes Cor ends provides resource to predict transcription of subtype at locus.
Researchers have identified two genes, Chae and Vel, in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostus, which regulate the production of a toxin called Txin. This toxin promotes virulence, or the ability of the pathogen to cause disease, in maize plants with a specific genetic trait called Texas sterile cytoplasm (Tms). The toxin is produced more in the dark and less in the light, and its production is linked to the expression of a gene called Tox1. Mutants of Chae and Vel produce less toxin and have reduced virulence on maize with Tms and normal cytoplasm. Deletion of Chae or Vel reduces tolerance to hydrogen peroxide and expression of a gene CAT, one of three catalase genes. Chae and Vel mutants also have reduced aerial growth, increased sporulation, and sterility, while overexpression of Chae strains are sterile and Vel strains more fertile. Chae and Vel repress melanin biosynthesis genes, leading to enhanced melanization in mutants and reduced in overexpression strains. The study suggests Chae and Vel positively regulate toxin production, virulence, oxidative stress, development, and growth, and negatively control melanin biosynthesis and differentiation.
Researchers have studied the mechanism of ion selectivity in bacterial Nav channels, which are channels that allow certain ions to pass through the cell membrane while blocking others. They used a combination of non-equilibrium simulations and two-dimensional free energy landscapes to understand how ions move through the selectivity filter of the bacterial Nav channel. The results showed that two potassium ions can block the entrance of the selectivity filter when forces are applied in the inward direction, but not outward. This block occurs in a local minimum of the free energy landscape where two ions can be "locked" in place by forces. In contrast, sodium ions move through the selectivity filter as a unit in a "knock-on" mechanism in both inward and outward directions, with no local minimum in the free landscape for a block state. The non-equilibrium simulations predicted the energy required to break the potassium block is consistent with experimentally measured for bacterial channels to induce inward currents of potassium ions. This study highlights the importance of including non-equilibrium factors in simulations to understand ion selectivity mechanisms. The results differ from those from crystal structures or equilibrium free landscapes and are consistent with electrophysiological measurements of bacterial channels.
Researchers studied the spread of rabies virus in the brains of dogs with furious and paralytic forms of the disease. They found that the furious form had more rapid viral colonization of the cerebral hemispheres, measured by viral antigen in neuronal bodies and RNA. The study quantitatively assessed the amount of rabies antigen in cell processes in a cohort of naturally infected dogs (5 furious and 5 paraly) shortly after illness. Measurements were taken at different levels of spinal cord, brain, and cerebrum. Results compared the amount of rab viral antigen in neuronal bodies. The amount of rab viral antigen in processes decreased in rostral direction, following the pattern of rab antigen in neuronal bodies and percentage of involved bodies. However, there was a delay in process following body involvement, consistent with replication in body and transport to processes. Greater amounts were seen in processes in furious compared to paraly at all levels examined. This was evident when comparing (1) neurons with similar antigen, (2) percentages involved, and (3) levels 100% positive. Findings suggest intracellular transport of virus may be slower in paraly, resulting in slower propagation. Possible mechanisms involve host differences in intracellular transport, possibly cytokine-mediated, as previous studies showed greater inflammation in paraly.
Researchers have studied the role of the protein CTC in regulating gene expression in fruit flies (Drosophila) by identifying its binding sites in the genome. CTC is a zinc-finger protein known to block enhancer-promoter interactions in vertebrates, but its function in Dophila was only recently characterized. One known CTC binding site was previously identified in the Fab-8 insulator in the Bithax complex (BX). The study used chromatin immunoprecipitation with microarray analysis to find CTC sites in BX, 3-M Adh, and Antennedia regions. CTC sites in BX map to known insulators Mc, Fab-6, and Fab-8, and new elements Fab-2, Fab-3, and Fab-4. CTC is associated with all known or predicted insulators in BX except Fab-7, suggesting a common CTC-dependent mechanism. Comparison with Polycomb target sites and histone modification supports BX regulation model. ChIP analysis of CTC sites in BX, 3-Mh, and Antennedia enabled a CTC consensus sequence. CTC clusters may form and mediate chromatin loops, partitioning regulatory elements into domains. CTC is required for Fab-8 insulator function in BX. ChIP analysis of CTC and Su(Hw binding sites shows similar patterns.
Scientists have long understood that enzymes recognize and bind to their substrates through a process called molecular recognition, which often involves conformational changes that prepare the active site for catalysis. However, the details of this process have been poorly understood due to its dynamic nature. Researchers studied the enzyme peptidyl deformase, a metal-dependent enzyme, and its interaction with a slow-binding inhibitor called actin. They solved crystal structures of the initial and final states, as well as intermediate snapshots during the process. The study found that the ligand reshapes a hydrophobic pocket, driving closure of the site, which is then secured by additional interactions. Biochemical and computational analyses allowed reconstruction of the sequence of events from encounter to key binding. A "movie" of the process was created, which can be extrapolated to catalysis.

The study integrated biophysical, computational, and kinetic analyses to better understand the slow-binding mechanism. It focused on induced-fit enzyme inhibition, but the phenomenon is applicable to broader receptor-lig interactions. Slow-binding inhibitors are favored for therapeutics due to unique properties, including potency and long-lasting effects. Actin is a slow-binding inhibitor of peptidase, a metal-dependent enzyme. Crystallographic analysis of enzyme variants, motions and reconstructions of catalytic events have been documented, but often with unnatural inhibitors not mimicking the substrate or transition state of actin. The slow binding kinetics of actin (10 seconds) is puzzling compared to catalysis (10 milliseconds). A conformational effect during hydrogen bond formation, aligning substrate and stabilizing the complex, may explain this.
Researchers have investigated how sensory information is transferred from the thalamus to the cortex, the primary gateway that relays sensory information to the brain. They found that a single cortical cell receives input from many thal cells, but each thal cell also receives feedback from the cortex. During sensory processing, the influence of this feedback loop is largely ignored. The study used dynamic-clamp techniques on thal slices in vitro and combined theoretical approaches to mimic the retinthalocortical pathway. They mimicked cortical input through a mixture of excitatory and inhibitory conductances, resulting in varying levels of afferent activity in thal cells. The study found that efficiency of sensory transmission depends on three factors: the number of thocortical cells, cortthal synaptic statistics, and correlation between thal cells. Counterintuitively, efficiency increases when correlation between thal cells decreases. This suggests that relay cells can be amplified when desynchronized by cortical feedback. This mechanism could direct attention to specific thal subassemblies and select input to cortex based on cortically-defined priorities.
Researchers have investigated the role of a protein called NMAD-1 in regulating DNA replication and repair during meiosis in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that worms lacking NM-1 have reduced fertility and defects in the first stage of meiosis, leading to fewer embryos and more males due to incorrect chromosome segregation. Analysis of the worm's germline showed reduced DNA replication and repair, and increased apoptosis of maturing cells. To understand how NM-1 works, the researchers identified proteins it binds to, including topoisomerase-2, which is involved in DNA repair and replication. NM-1 also localizes with top-2 on chromatin, and most top-2 binding depends on NM-1. This suggests NM-1 acts on chromatin to regulate replication and repair during meiosis in C. elegans. The study aimed to understand NM-1's role in reproduction by analyzing a strain with a deletion of the gene, which removes most of the protein's activity. NM-1 binds to the same sites on chromatin as top-2 and interacts with it in vitro and in vivo, indicating NM- acts on chrom to regulate these processes in meiosis in C. elegans.
Researchers have identified a new protein called adipocyte membrane-associated protein (AAP) that plays a crucial role in the early stage of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection. CMV is a common virus that can cause serious diseases in newborns and people with weakened immune systems. The virus has a large genome and complex proteins that can infect many types of human cells, but the way it infects cells is not fully understood. The study found that AAP is necessary for CMV infection in two types of cells: epithelial and fibroblasts. When AAP was knocked out, CMV infection was reduced in these cells. However, when AAP was added to cells that are not usually resistant to CMV, such as canine and murine cells, CM infection increased. The study also found that AAP helps CMV enter cells by interacting with a specific protein on the virus at low pH and moving a protein called pp65 to the nucleus. This suggests AAP is a key player in CMV infection and helps the virus infect multiple types of cells.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model that combines intrinsic and extrinsic factors to understand how hematopoietic progenitor cells make decisions to commit to specific lineages. The model shows that cytokine-mediated receptor feedback can induce a "switch-like" response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to both bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced decommitment. This supports both instruct and stochastic theories of commitment: cell fates are driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling strongly biases lineage by regulating inherently noisy cell decisions. The model suggests that kinetics of differentiation to a mature state depend on the progenitor state and chosen route of commitment. It also agrees with lineage receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a framework to integrate classical and alternative paths in hematopoies observed experimentally.
Researchers have used electron microscopy to study the structure of the Bunyamwera virus, a member of the Orthunavirus genus, which poses a threat to human and animal health. The virus particles are irregularly shaped but have a repeating pattern of glycoprotein spikes on their surface. Each spike is 18 nanometers long and changes shape when introduced to an acidic environment. Using a technique called subtomography, a three-dimensional model of the trimeric glycoprotein spike was created at a resolution of 3 nanometers. The glycoprotein consists of a fusion protein and has a unique tripod-like arrangement with protein contacts between spikes at the base and tips. This structure is different from previously known fusion protein arrangements, suggesting a wider variety of viral protein combinations. The study shows a change in shape occurs when the virus enters a host cell and provides a blueprint for this group of emerging pathogens. 

The glycoproteins of Bunyamwera virus are similar to those of related viruses that cause disease, sharing 54 and 53% similarity with the segments of SBV and ORO. Despite the impact on health and economy, little is known about Orthunavirus structure. This study uses electron microscopy of the prototypic virus to address the lack of information. Upon acidification, a major change is seen in the head of the trimer spike corresponding to the fusion protein. The results provide the first detailed 3D analysis of Orthunavirus and a model for this group of medically important viruses, showing a unique mode of protein oligomerization.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study on 5,308 individuals of Asian descent to identify genes associated with primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG), a major cause of blindness in Asia. They found a significant association between a variant in the ABCC5 gene and anterior chamber depth (ACD), a key anatomical risk factor for PG. The AB5 variant was linked to an increased risk of PG in a separate case-control study of 4,276 cases and 18,801 controls. The association strengthened when a subgroup of controls with open angles were included. The study suggests genetic variants influencing AC dimensions may contribute to PG risk. AB5 is expressed in ocular tissues relevant to PG, such as the iris, ciliary body, and lens. The study provides clues to mechanisms underlying PG, a global cause of blindness. The prevalence of precursor to PG, narrow angles, is 10% in many Asian populations. The association between angle closure and shallow AC makes it appropriate to remove at-risk individuals from controls to assess the relationship between AC and PG.
Researchers have identified developmental enhancers, called bilaterally conserved regulatory elements (Bico), that are shared between deuterostomes and protomes, two groups of animals that were previously thought to have distinct developmental toolkits. These enhancers show sequence and gene conservation, suggesting a common regulatory apparatus. Bico are predicted to act as response elements to signaling pathways and drive expression of transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate central nervous system. The discovery of Bico expands our understanding of how developmental logic is encoded in the genome and how it evolves. The small number of identified Bico implies extensive rewiring of cis-regulation between protome and deuterome clades, but additional Bres may be revealed as our understanding of cis-reg logic and bilian genomes grows. Bico are developmental enhancers that encode complex patterns of transcription factor binding sites, such as Bore, an enhancer of Id, which is predicted to function as a BMP responsive element and drives expression in the developing nervous system. The discovery of Bico offers a new avenue for exploring how developmental logic is encoded in the genome and how it evolves.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the impact of vaccination on the diversity of influenza viruses within an individual hosts. They analyzed data from a randomized, controlled trial of vaccine efficacy and used next-generation sequencing to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and assess the effect of vaccine-induced immunity within populations. The study isolated the impact of vaccination while allowing for natural infection to occur. They found 166 cases of H3N2 influenza over 3 seasons and 19 years and obtained genome data for 119 samples, identifying intrah single nucleotide variants ≥1% frequency. Phylogenetic analysis showed no stratification by pre-hemagglutination and neuraminase inhibition titers. The majority of intrah single nucleotide variants were rare and few were found in more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 nucleotide variants across the genome, and diversity did not vary by sampling day, vaccination status, or pre-antibody titer. Contrary to expectations, vaccination had little impact on intrah diversity in natural infection and vaccine immunity may be a minor contributor to antigen drift at local scales.
Researchers investigated the effectiveness of a genetically modified, live attenuated Leishmania donovani parasite (LC-/-) in inducing a protective immune response against visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in mice of different ages. VL is a severe disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donani, with no effective vaccine available for any age group. Previous studies showed LC- induced a strong immune response in young mice. This study compared LC- mediated immune response in 18-month-old (aged) and 2-month (young) mice. Analysis of bone marrow-derived dendritic cells from infected with LC- showed enhanced effector responses, augmenting CD4+ T cell function compared to wild-type (WT) infected cells. Similarly, splenic dendritic cells from LC-infected young and aged mice induced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-12, IL-6, IF-γ, TNF) and down-regulated anti-inflammatory (IL-10) genes compared to WT. Immunization with LC- induced IgG2 antibodies, lymphoproliferative response, pro-inflammatory responses, and heightened leishicidal activity in young and aged mice. Upon virulent Leish challenge, LC-immunized mice displayed multifunctional Th1 CD and cytotoxic CD T cells, reducing parasite burden in spleen and liver compared to naive. However, LC-induced response in aged mice was reduced compared to young, correlating less protection.
Researchers created chimeric viruses by combining the capsid proteins of enteric and respiratory enteroviruses (EVs) to understand why these viruses have different properties and cause various diseases. They found that the capsid proteins determine the viruses' sensitivity to acid, optimal growth temperature, and tissue preference for replication in the respiratory or gastrointestinal tract, which are key factors in their virulence. Using a chimeric virus with the capsid of EV68 (respiratory) and EV94 (enteric), they showed that capsid proteins are necessary and sufficient for acid sensitivity and tropism in cell lines and tissues. They also found that capsid genes influence optimal growth temperature, as EV94 adapted to higher temperatures with a mutation in VP1, while EV68 capsid did not. Additionally, EV68 maintained infectivity after acid treatment, but non-structural proteins modulated the immune response. This study reveals another layer of diversity in one of the most prevalent pathogens and may aid in vaccine or antiviral development.
Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) glycoprotein gE-I is a transmembrane receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G (Ig). It can also participate in antibody bridging (ABB), a process where antigen fragments (Fab) of Ig bind viral antigen while Fc binds to gE-I. IgFc binds g-E at basic, but not acidic pH, suggesting Ig bound extracellularly by surface g-E would dissociate and degrade in acidic endosomes/lysosomes if endocytosed. The fate of viral antigens associated with g-E bound Ig was unknown: could remain surface or endocyt with Ig. Researchers developed an in vitro system to study ABB and trafficking using 4-D confocal imaging of A complexes with transferrin or epidermal growth, characterized intracellular markers. Data showed cells expressing g-E and viral HSV-1 endocyt anti-D Ig and g in g-E dependent, resulting lysosomal localization. This suggests g-E can mediate clearance of infected surfaces of anti-viral host Ig and viral antig to evade Ig-mediated responses, a mechanism for viral receptors in evasion and pathogenesis.
Researchers studied the transcriptome of the protoscoleces (PSC) of Echinococcus granulosus, a parasite that causes cistic hydatid disease in humans and animals. They used Roche 454 sequencing and in silico analysis to explore the excretory-secretory proteins (ESPs) released by the parasite. The study generated 26,514 non-reduant sequences, of which 22,910 (86.4%) were mapped to the published E. granus genome and 17,705 (66.8%) were in coding sequence (CDS) regions. Of the 2,280 predicted ESPs, 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism, 124 in protein metabolism, and 11 in glycolysis/glucone (GLN) pathways. Additionally, 44 antigen proteins, molecular chaperones, and proteases were identified. Many proteins were enriched in development-related pathways, such as TGF receptor and insulin pathways. This study provides valuable information on parasite adaptation to hosts, aiding novel intervention targets for hydat treatment and control.
In the fungus Aspergillus nidans, the protein NirA plays a crucial role in regulating the assimilation of nitrate, a major nitrogen source in soil. When nitrate is present, NirA accumulates in the nucleus and activates transcription of genes involved in nit assimilation. However, in the absence of nit, Nir is predominantly found in the cytosol and inactive. Researchers used mass spectrometry to find that in the absence of nit, methion 169 in Nir's nuclear export sequence (NES) is oxidized to methion sulfox (Metox). This oxidation depends on Fmo, a flav-containing monxygen, which uses methion and cystine but not glutathione as substrates. The function of Fmo cannot be replaced by alternative F proteins in A. nidans. Exposure to nit led to rapid reduction of Nir-Met169 to Met169, independent of thiorexin and methion sulfox reductases. Replacement of Met169 with isoleuc, a sterically similar but not oxidizable residue, led to partial loss of Nir activity and insensitivity to Fmo-mediated export. In contrast, replacement of Met with alanine transformed the protein into a permanently nuclear and active factor. Co-immoprecipitation of Nir-Kap interactions and subcell localization of Nir mutants provided evidence that Met oxidation leads to change in Nir conformation.
Researchers studied how functional constraints shape the evolution of mammalian voltage-gated sodium channels, which are crucial for propagating action potentials. Since the 1950s, mathematical models by Hodgkin and Hux suggested that sodium channel properties need to be tightly constrained for action potential to propagate. There are nine mammalian genes encoding voltage-gated channels, many of which are more than 90% identical in sequence, suggesting similar function. However, the multiplicity of genes raises the question: why so many? The researchers demonstrated that the simplest constraints - membrane excitability and uniqueness of resting potential - directly constrain sodium properties. They compared predicted constraints with data on mammalian channel properties from literature, including 172 sets of measurements from 40 publications, wild-type and mutant, under various conditions. Data from all channels, including mutants, obeyed the excitability constraint, while channels in muscle obeyed the resting constraint. Excitability alone distinguished nine channels into four groups consistent with phylogenetic analysis. Calculations suggest functional differences between groups.
Researchers have been searching for new antiviral drugs to treat serious influenza infections, as current options are prone to resistance. The influenza polymerase, which transcribes and replicates the virus genome, is a target for antiv drugs as it can stop replication early. Studies on the polymer's domains have led to a structure-based approach to optimize inhibitors. The unique cap-snatching mechanism of transcription can be inhibited by targeting the PB cap-binding or endonuc domains. This study presents high-resolution X-ray crystal structures of the 2009 H1N1 PA endonuc domain with specific inhibitors, including diketo compounds and green tea catechin, which chelate manganese ions in the active site. The binding modes of different compounds and mononucleotide phosphate show how substituents on the metal scaffold can bind in distinct pockets and the active site's plasticity. This will help design more potent inhibitors for the capatching enduc activity of the virus polymer. 

The enduc structure provides detailed information on inhibitor binding to the polymer. New options for targeting the virus are needed. This will guide medicinal chemistry to optimize lead compounds for efficient enduc inhibition. Additional enduc-inhibitor structures and sequence variations for resistance will advance novel and efficacious therapeutics. The capatching mechanism has been a target since it stalls replication, is conserved, and no host counterpart. Despite trials, no H3 enduc structures have been obtained with inhibitors or analogs, limiting structure optimization. The enduc from other strains with different sequences yielded crystals. This study reports pH1 enduc with divalent ions and 4-substit 2-dioxo acid.
A new immunization protocol has been developed to produce potent polyspecific antiven against three medically important vipers in Thailand and neighboring countries, namely Caloselasma rhodoma, Cryptelyrops alab, and Dabo siensis. The protocol uses a "low dose, low multi-site" immunization method, which has been shown to be effective in producing antiven against elapid and cobra venoms. Four horses were immunized with a mixture of the three viper venoms, resulting in a rapid increase in ELISA titers against all three venoms, reaching a plateau at the 8th week post-immunization. The in vivo neutralization potency of the antisera against the venoms was 10.40, 2.42, and 0.76 mg/ml, respectively, exceeding the minimal limits set by the Queen Saoh Memorial Institute. The polyspecific antisera also effectively neutralized the procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and nephroxic activities of the venoms. This immunization protocol is useful for producing potent polyspecific antiven against snake venoms and equine antiserum against tetanus, diphtheria, and rabies.
Researchers have found that a protein called Sse, produced by the Salmonella bacteria, helps the bacteria to maintain a long-term infection in the body by stopping the movement of immune cells called macrophages and dendritic cells. These cells are important for fighting off infections, but when they can't move properly, the body can't clear the bacteria. Sse works by binding to a host protein called IQAP, which is involved in cell movement. A mutation in Sse eliminates its function. In mice infected with Salmonella, fewer immune cells were found in the spleen when Sse was present compared to when it was not. This suggests that Sse is crucial for the bacteria to stay in the body for a long time.
Researchers have identified a genetic mechanism behind the increased virulence of community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA), a pathogen that causes severe disease in healthy individuals. CA-MRSA is more virulent than hospital-acquired-MRSA (HARSA). The study found that the product of the p-mec gene, located in the mobile genetic element SCCm of HARS, but not CA, suppresses the expression of phenol-sol-soluble modulin (PSM), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. The p-m RNA inhibits translation of the agr gene encoding a transcription factor for PSM via specific binding to agr mRNA. Mutations in the p-m promoter in 25% of 325 clinical MRSA isolates attenuated transcription, and 9% had no p-m. Most p-mutated or p-m-deleted HARSAs had increased PSM expression compared to intact p-m strains, and some produced high amounts comparable to CA-MRSA. Deletion of p-m from HARS carrying p-m increased expression of Agr and P, and virulence in mice. p-m suppresses MRSA virulence via inhibition of agr translation and absence of p-m in CARSA causes high virulence.
Researchers investigated the phenomenon of antibody-mediated disease enhancement (ADE) in type I interferon-deficient mice, which occurs when maternal antibodies from a previous deng infection enhance the severity of a subsequent infection with a different deng virus serotype. They found that 5-week-old A129 mice born to DENV-immune mothers succumbed to D2 infection within 4 days, whereas those born to naïve mothers survived. Clinical manifestations included hepatocyte vacuolation, vascular leakage, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNF therapy protected the mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes, while blocking IL-6 did not impact virus titers or outcome. This model may help dissect mechanisms in deng pathogenesis and evaluate vaccine/therapeutic candidates. ADE has been reported in mice with cross-reactive, non-neutral antibodies and matally acquired heterotyp deng antibodies induced A in AG129 mice with earlier death, increased viremia and vascular permeability upon D2 infection of mice to D1-imm mothers compared to naïve mothers. The study used immunocomised AG129 mice, deficient in type I and II IF receptors, which are not susceptible to D infection due to virus inability to interfere with murine IF response.
Researchers conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to identify factors associated with visceral leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania infantum parasite, in the Americas. They analyzed 51 studies and found that male sex was associated with visceral leishiasis when diagnosed by skin test, but not when diagnosed serologically. Younger individuals were less likely to be infected but more prone to illness. Presence of dogs at home, higher seropositivity in nearby, lower socioeconomic status, and vegetated areas were linked to infection, while chickens in the house and nutritional status were not. Ecological studies showed dog seropositivity associated with human visceral leishias, highlighting dogs as a marker for disease occurrence. This is the first review of its kind in the Americas, clarifying some aspects and raising new questions about the disease dynamics. However, results cannot be applied to other contexts due to the disease's unique characteristics. A review of risk factors in Asia showed similar patterns, such as clustering, household conditions, vegetation, and poverty. In Brazil, case-fatality rates varied between 4.2-10% in treated patients. Diagnosis methods include hypersensitivity, parasitological, serological, and molecular tests.
Inhalation of Francisella tularens (Ft) causes acute and fatal pneumonia, and the mechanisms underlying pathogenesis and lethality remain unclear. Research reveals that an innate cellular response, not bacterial burden or cytokine production, drives pathology and mortality in pulmonary tularem. Leth infection elicits medullary and extra-medullary myelopoiesis, recruiting immature myeloid and myeloid suppressor cells (IM/MD) to the lungs, which fail to mature and die, leading to necrotic lung damage, loss of function, and host death. This process is partially dependent on Ly6+ cells. Acceleration of this process may account for rapid lethality with Schu4. In contrast, sub-lethal infection with LVS shows a predominance of mature neutrophils and monocytes, required for protection, suggesting a threshold for lethal infection. Eliciting mature phagocytic response provides transient protection against Schu4. The study suggests the nature of myoid response determines host mortality versus survival in Francisella infection.
Aedes albopictus, the Asian tiger mosquito, is an invasive species that spreads rapidly and can transmit diseases such as chikungunya, dengue, and Zika viruses. To understand its spread and mitigate risks, researchers reconstructed its colonization pattern using population genetics and Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) approaches. The study found that in Southeast Asia, populations from China, Thailand, and Japan have low differentiation and high co-ancestry values, indicating a common origin and high connectivity. China appears to be the oldest population. Outside Asia, invasion in La Reunion, America, and the Mediterranean is supported by chaotic distribution, maintaining high diversity in adventive populations. Independent introductions may have facilitated establishment through admixture of unrelated genomes, resulting in intra-population variability. This may extend to genetic mechanisms controlling vector competence. In the invasion context, ancestry and admixture create conditions for efficient transmission and outbreaks. The study provides origins of populations from Southeast Asia, Indian Ocean, Mediterranean, Pacific, and North America, valuable for predicting vector capacity and risk models. Variation in eco-geographic populations may result from interactions between genetic and environmental factors, crucial for assessing arvirus outbreaks in old and new areas. Invasion routes were inferred using Approx Bayesian computation, implemented in DIY2.0. The Chinese sample, collected in Southeast coastal native area, has low differentiation and high coance values with other Asian samples, confirming ancestral origin. albict was primarily supported by chaotic distribution mediated by human activity.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes chronic infections in wounds and found that its ability to grow in high-density environments, rather than its virulence or biofilm functions, is key to its fitness in these infections. They analyzed clinical isolates from human wounds and found that many were defective in virulence and biofilm formation, and that these functions were not necessary for bacterial fitness in mouse wounds. In contrast, genes involved in anaerobic growth, metabolism, energy production, and membrane integrity were crucial. This was consistent with findings that impaired mutants' fitness could be represented by anaerobic, oxidative, and membrane stress conditions in vitro and high-density bacterial growth in the absence of a host. These results shed light on bacterial functions in chronic infections, the nature of stresses on bacteria at infection sites, and suggest targets to compromise infection pathogenesis.
A study was conducted at the Center for Teaching, Research, and Referral for Bancrofilariasis (NEF) in a bancrofilariasis endemic area to evaluate the occurrence of intrascrot lymphangiectasia, testis morphology, and consistency, and hydrocele recurrence in patients who underwent hydrocelectomy. A total of 968 patients with unilateral or bilateral hydrocele (Group 1) and 218 patients from the same area who had undergone hydrocele-sparing hydrolectomy elsewhere (Comparison Group) were enrolled. Twenty patients from the Comparison with hydrocele were reoperated at NEF and constitute Group 2. In Group 1, 1128 hydrolectomies were performed (mean age 30.3yr, mean follow-up 8.6yr). Hydro recurrence rates in Group 1 and Comparison (age 31.5) were 0.3% and 19.3, respectively (p<0.001). There was no recurrence in Group 2 (age 25.1, mean follow 6yr). Perioperatively, leaking or dilated lymphatic vessels were seen on the inner or outer surface of hydrocele wall or surrounding tissue in 30.9% and 46.3 of patients in Group 1 and 2, respectively (p=0.081). Testicles were abnormal in shape, volume, and consistency in 203/128 (18%) and 10/28 (35.7) patients from Group 1 and 2, respectively (p=0.025). Lymph fluid from dilated lymphatic vessels is a component of chronic hydrocele fluid threatening test integrity in bancfilari endemic areas. To prevent recurrence, authors advise complete excision of hydrocele when leaking or dilated vessels are sutured or excised.
Researchers have identified a deubiquinating enzyme, Ts37, in the parasite Trichella spiralis, a zoonotic nematode that causes trichlos, a disease found on all continents except Antarctica. Trich spir infects skeletal muscle cells, disrupting their function. A probe was used to identify deubiquinating activity in T spir larvae, and immuno-blot and imm-precipitation identified several potential Ds. These were analyzed by LC/MS, yielding peptides with homology to 5 conserved human Ds: UCH5, U3, HAP, OT6, and Atin-3. The gene encoding putative U5 homologue, Ts37, was cloned and recombinant protein expressed and purified. Deubiquinating activity was verified by Ub-AM assay. Recombinant Ts37 co-precipitated with putative spir proteome components, including yeast homologue ADR1. Inhibitor LD-44 specifically inhibited recombin Ts37 and reduced L larvae viability. This study reports the first T spir D, a cystine protease orthologous to human U5. Results suggest interaction with proteome conserved throughout evolution.
Researchers have identified a new potential target for treating Chagas disease, a tropical illness caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. The parasite's cysteine protease enzyme, cruzain, has been considered a valid target for treatment, but its inhibition doesn't fully explain the effectiveness of certain compounds against the parasite. Two nitrile-based cystine protease inhibitors showed anti-tryosomal activity in the 0.1-1μM to 1μM range, with two compounds having EC50 values of 0.12μM and 0.25M, significantly lower than their Ki values against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzain. This suggests the compounds' anti-tryosomal activity may not be solely due to cruzain inhibition, indicating a potential polypharmacological profile towards cystine proteases. Another study evaluated cathepsin inhibitors on a cyclohexane dicbox scaffold, showing anti-tryosomal activity greater than expected from cruzain inhibition. cruz is a validated target for Chagas treatment, with oral activity of cystine inhibitor 777 in animal models providing basis for validation. Efficacy of 3 and analogs in a murine Chagas model motivated the study. Potent dipeptyl nitr inhibitors of cruz showed no anti-tryosomal activity, questioning cruz potency as predictor. Results suggest anti-tryosomal effects of potent compounds may be due to inhibition of other cystine proteases, such as cruzain-2, not yet identified as targets. Compounds 5 and 11 may have a polypharmac profile, targeting cruzain isoforms or other cystine proteases in the parasite. Cystine inhibition profile suggests a new antag target may share characteristics with cathein, and phenic screening for antag agents should include potent inhibitors of this enzyme.
Researchers have created a detailed map of the physical structure of the maize genome, which covers 93.5% of the genome and is aligned with 86.1% of the genetic map. The map contains 25,908 genetic markers that align nearly 73% of the maize genome to the rice genome. The study found that 1 kilobase in rice corresponds to 3.2 kilobase in maize, indicating a 6-fold genome expansion. This is due to maize's polyploid origin, where most regions correspond to two regions in maize. Inversions account for most chromosome variations during diploidization. The study also found evidence of ancient duplication before maize and rice divergence. Reconstructing the paleobotany of maize indicates its progenitors had 10 chromosomes.

The alignment of genomes shed light on chromosomes contributing to polloid, rearrangements and diploid, and homologous regions. RFLP mapping showed two maize chromosomes align with one rice and sorghum, a whole genome duplication event. Table 3 shows primary and secondary duplications in maize. Detection of 3 copies per over (Table 2) supports tetraploid emergence. Duplications in rice are not limited to ancestor and maize. Average size is similar to rice physical map. A genetic map was developed to anchor and orient contigs along chromosomes. Multiple events contribute to complex pattern, recent duplication easier than ancient. Synteny shows rearrangements since maize and rice divergence.
Researchers investigated the generation of infectious prions, the proteinaceous agents responsible for transmissible spong encephalopathies, in vitro. They aimed to mimic the early etiology of sporadic disease by de novo generation of infectious prions. Using protein misfolding cyclic amplification (PM) procedure, they analyzed the possibility of spontaneous generation of prions. Under standard PM conditions, de novo generation of prions was not observed, supporting its use for diagnostic applications. However, PM was modified to generate prions in the absence of pre-existing prions in different species at a low and variable rate. De novo generated prions were infectious when inoculated into wild-type hamsters, producing a new disease with unique clinical, neuropathological, and biochemical features. This study provides additional evidence for the prion hypothesis and a model to study sporadic disease mechanism. It also suggests prion diversity is not restricted to known forms, and new infectious foldings may produce novel phenotypes.
Researchers have developed a neural model, called the Angular Velocity Unit (AV), to estimate angular velocity in bees, which can reproduce experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees, including previously unaccounted behaviors. The model is based on electrophysiological data and tested with behavioral data. According to the model, the AV response can be considered an extension of the optomotor response. The model is tested behaviorally in silico with the corridor-center paradigm, where bees navigate a corridor with gratings (square or sinusoidal) on walls. When combined with an existing flight algorithm, the detector reproduces invariance of the flight path to the frequency and contrast of gratings, including deviations from centering behavior found in real bees. The detector also responds to unit movement along the corridor for a range of grating frequencies, demonstrating it can be used as a visual odometer.

The model, called the Angular Detector Unit (ADU), reproduces behavioral patterns previously unaccounted for in corridor-center response, including deviation of flight path from center due to frequency differences in sinusoidal gratings and deviations from center for square and sinusoidal gratings. The detector only responds to temporal frequencies 10-100Hz, lower than experienced in behavioral experiments on honeybees. Additional circuitry for calculating AV estimation must be present. Neural recordings from ventral nerve of honeybee found distinct responses to moving patterns in view. Odometry is unaffected by environment frequency, suggesting AV responses could estimate distance by summing output over visual field. The model tested this relationship, results in Fig 11, show for range frequencies 0.1-0.
A long-term follow-up study of 50 African trypanosomiasis (AT) patients from the Ivory Coast who refused treatment after initial diagnosis found that 10 out of 11 patients who continued to refuse treatment showed parasite clearance using microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Most of these patients (7/10) displayed decreasing serological responses, becoming negative to trypanosome antigens (Li1.3, 1.5, and 1.6). The study found two alternative progressions of AT: an asymptomatic infection with long-lasting serological responses and spontaneous resolution with negative parasitological and PCR results and dropping antibody titers. This is in contrast to the classic lethal outcome of AT. The study does not estimate the frequency of these alternative courses, but notes that field control programs encounter subjects with positive serological results but negative parasitological tests. Recognizing trypanotolerance in humans, as accepted in animals, is a step forward for future research in AT.
Researchers investigated whether ionizing radiation selects for p53-deficient hematopoietic progenitors in mice. p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, and its loss can provide resistance to genotoxic stimuli, including radiation. Given that p53 null mice develop lymphomas with high penetrance and irradiation accelerates lymphoma in p heterozygous mice, they hypothesized that selection for p-deficient cells contributes to the link between irradiation and lymphoid malignancies. They found that p53 disruption does not provide a selective advantage in unstressed hematopoietic system or previously irradiated BM allowed to recover. However, upon irradiation, p53 confers a selective advantage, leading to long-term expansion of p-def clones and increased lymphoma. Selection for p-def cells is attributed to protection from irradi-induced ablation of progenitor cells, prevention of irradi-induced loss of clonogenic capacity for stem and progenitor, improved maintenance of progenitor fitness, and elimination of competing p-type progenitors.
Researchers have identified a protein called SmKI-1 in the parasite Schistosoma mansoni, a type of flatworm that causes schistosomiasis in humans. This protein acts as a serine protease inhibitor, which means it blocks the activity of enzymes called trypsin and neutrophil elastase. Neutrophil elastase is a key component of the human immune system that helps fight off infections and inflammation. The study found that SmKI-1 binds to the active site of neutil elast, preventing it from functioning properly. This could be a mechanism used by the parasite to evade the host's immune system. The researchers also showed that Sm-1 inhibits the ability of neutil to kill schistosomes, the larval stage of the parasite. To understand the role of Sm-1 in the parasite, they knocked down its gene in the parasite and observed a significant impact on its development in vitro and in vivo. They also tested Sm-1's ability to reduce inflammation in mouse models of diseases, such as liver damage caused by acetaminophen and arthritis. Sm-1 reduced neutrophil recruitment and elast activity in these models. In another model, it reduced neutil accumulation, IL-1 secretion, and hyperiception. Sm-1 also inhibited neutil recruitment in response to carrageenan in mice. The study concludes that Sm-1 is essential for parasite survival and has potential as a therapeutic against inflammatory diseases.
Researchers have developed a new method to accurately model high-resolution structures of transmembrane helical (TM) proteins from distant homologues, which are proteins with similar but not identical structures. These proteins are crucial for various cellular functions, but their structures are largely uncharacterized and hard to predict due to lack of close homologs. The method was tested on 50 pairs of TM protein homologs with diverse topologies, sizes, and sequence identities, and achieved near-atomic accuracy in membrane-embedded regions. It outperformed starting templates and is suitable for computer-based protein engineering, redesigned and X-ray structures showed similar interactions. The method was validated in two blind predictions, including adenosine A2 and chemokine CX4 receptors, and ranked first in accuracy. It should be useful for modeling and designing large structurally uncharacterized TM proteins from various homologs.
Listeria monocytogen, the bacterium responsible for listeriosis, a foodborne disease that poses serious risks to fetuses, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals, has been found to switch from an active, motile lifestyle to a persistent state in vacuolar lifestyle in epithelial cells. During infection in human hepatocytes or trophlast cells, L monocogen ceases to produce the actin nucleating protein Act and becomes trapped in lysosome-like vacuoles termed Lister-Containing Vacoles (Lis). Subpopulations of bacteria resist degradation in Lis and enter a slow-replicative state. When Act is absent, as in ΔAct mutants, vacolar bacteria parasitize host cells in a "viable but nonculturable" (VB) state, preventing detection by conventional counting methods. Exposure to high doses of gentamicin does not trigger Lis formation but selects for vacolar and VB bacteria. These results reveal L monocogen's ability to enter a persistent state in epithelial cells, favoring asymptomatic carriage, lengthening incubation of listiosis and bacterial survival during therapy.
Researchers developed a neuromechanical model of auditory streaming to study the alternations between integrated and segregated percepts in the A-BA triplet paradigm. The model combines neurophysiological and psychoacoustic experiments to characterize the effects of manipulating stimulus parameters. Unlike previous models, it includes neuronal units with sensory-dependent inputs mimicking the pulsatilike responses to tones and a computation for competition in the primary auditory cortex. Mutual inhibition, adaptation, and noise are implemented, along with NMDA recurrent excitation for temporal memory. Percepts are identified in the firing patterns of units. The model predicts that manipulating the frequency difference between A and B tones affects the dominance of the stronger percept, a property established in visual bistable paradigms. Psychoac experiments confirmed the prediction and constrained the model, achieving quantitative agreement between results. The model provides a platform to extend to other conditions, including context and volition.

The study focuses on the dynamics after the build phase, motivated by physiological and perceptual bistability models. It incorporates sound-evoked A1 responses to a competition and identifies percepts in neuronal dynamics. NMD-like dynamics enables binding from one triplet to the next. Increasing stimulus strength favors the attended percept, but inputs should be dynamic and dependent on percept state. Future work will explore attention effects in streaming. Alternations after the build, the neuromechanical formulation distinguishes from auditory models. Parameters balance adaptation and noise were tuned to match percept durations, fitting a log distribution. A responses were interpreted using neuetric functions mimicking build.
Researchers have developed a method to assess the allergenicity of Schistosoma mansoni proteins using a humanized Ratophil Leukemia cell line (RSAT8) and a cell-free translation system. This method allows for rapid production of parasite proteins in 90 minutes, eliminating the need for purification. Antigen integrity is confirmed using Western blotting. The RSAT8 cell line is challenged with the translated proteins and luciferase activity measured, indicating cellular activation by the allergen. The method is suitable for medium to high-throughput studies using individual sera and can assess potential allergenic of anti-helminthic vaccine candidates. Characterized parasitic allergens such as Par 2, SmAL-1, and IgE factor SE/alpha-1 were expressed in wheat lysate and E.coli and activated the basophil reporter line, while SmAL2 did not. This technology enables genome-wide assessment of S mans allergenicity, the Schistos allergome, and unravelling the allergome of S mans and other parasites. This could lead to understanding of basis of allergity and relationship between parasite IgE and host mechanisms at molecular level.
Researchers studied the phenomenon of hybrid dysgenesis in Drosophila, a type of genomic incompatibility that occurs when the abundance of transposable elements (TEs) differs between two parents. They found that when TEs inherited from the father are absent in the mother's genome, they can become activated in the offspring, causing germline damage and sterility. Using D. virilis as a model, they characterized the effects of divergence in TE profile between parents on offspring. They discovered that divergence in the TE landscape is associated with persisting differences in germl TE expression between genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses, and these differences are transmitted to the next generation. Chronic and persisting TE expression coincides with increased levels of piRNAs associated with reduced gene expression. They also found that gene expression is idiosyncratically influenced by differences in piRNA profile of parents that arise from polymorphic TE insertions. These results support a model where early germl events in dysgenesis establish a stable state of TE and gene expression in germl maintained through adulthood and transmitted to next generation.
Researchers have identified a potential new target for treating Fragile X Syndrome, a neurodegenerative disorder caused by a CG repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene. They found that overexpressing three histone deacetylases (HDAC3, 6, or 11) suppresses neurodegeneration in a Drosila model of Fragile X. This suppression is due to selective transcriptional repression of the CG repeat-containing gene. The study suggests the CG repeat induces changes in histone acetylation at the F1 locus, leading to increased F1 expression and neurode. The researchers also found increased acetylation of histones at the F1 locus in patient lymphoblasts and fibroblasts with the disorder, correlating with elevated F1 expression. Histone acetylase inhibitors reduced F1 expression to control levels in patient cell lines and extended lifespan in CG repeat-expressing Dila. These findings support a model where the CG repeat promotes chromatin remodeling, increasing toxic F1 expression.
Researchers have found that genetics play a crucial role in controlling CD8 T cell function and immunopathology during chronic viral infection. CD8 T cells are vital for controlling chronic viral infections, but factors such as the host's immune response contribute to maintaining effector CD8 cell responses versus CD T cell exhaustion during chronic infection. The study examined the impact of MHC heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on the development of chronic infection by infecting mice with the clone-13 strain of lymphocytic choriomitis virus (LCMV). Results showed that mice with increased MHC diversity had better control of the virus compared to those with less MHC diversity. Notably, mice on a specific genetic background succumbed to the infection, but CD T cell depletion prevented mortality, indicating mortality was CD T-cell dependent. These mice maintained CD T effector cytokine production and reduced T exhaustion marker PD-1 expression, and induced a larger Th1 response. Mortality in these mice was also dependent on CD T-mediated IF-γ production. The study indicates that increased M heterogeneity results in a higher frequency of responding CD T cells during chronic infection, and both immune environment and M diversity contribute to T-dependent viral clearance and mortality.
A recent study analyzed the genetic characteristics of Bacillus anthracis isolated from northwestern China from 1990 to 2016. Anthrax is a re-emerging zoon disease in China, particularly in rural areas. The study described the general characteristics of human anthrax outbreaks in northwestern China over the past decade and analyzed the genetic of Bacillus anthracis using single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) and multilocus-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) with 15 markers. Five subline/subgroups, A. Br.001/002, A. Br. Voll, A. Br94, A. Br Ames, and A. Br.008/009, were detected using 13 SNP sites. All subgroups were found in Xinjiang, while one in Shaanxi, two Gans, three Qinghai, and four in Inner Mongolia. The geographical distribution of B. anthrac populations exhibited different SNP characteristics from strains before 1990 in China. A. Br Ames was observed scattered from Inner to other provinces. All 106 strains were assigned 36 MLVA genotypes, 21 of which were first observed in this study. Strains from recent outbreaks were classified subgroups A. Br.001 and A. Br and genotypes MLVA-28, ML-30, ML-31, ML-38, ML-CH3, and MLCH18. By SNP and MLVA, diversification ML genotypes and geographical B anthrac populations became balanced across northwestern China. This study provided preliminary results on B. anthrac diversity in China, promoting prevention and control of this disease.

The study used methods to track anthrax outbreaks and illustrate phylogen relationships B anthrac national international levels. China strains isolated Xinjiang 1982 genotyped these methods. Since 2005, Anthrax Surveillance covered 12 provinces mainland China. Human anth cases reported 86 total 2016. Recent human and livestock outbreaks reported provinces Liaoning, Jiang, Yunn, Xin. Four large-scale outbreaks north China 2011, 201,2016. A comprehensive retrospective epidemiological molecular study B anthrac species conducted. Br Ames found Xin. ML15 identified new genotypes MLCH3, CH7, CH18 Inner ML31 Xin. 106 B anthrac strains 13 samples provinces distributed 5 SNP subgroups described Vanrt. These subgroups Br.001 (50), Br (18), Br.008 (11), Br Voll (4), Br94 (23).
Researchers studied the role of goblet cells, a type of cell in the intestinal lining of the gut, in defending against bacterial infections. They found that goblet cells produce a molecule called REL-β, which recruits CD4 T cells, a type of immune cell, to the site of infection. This recruitment of CD4 cells leads to increased proliferation of intestinal epithelial cells, the cells that line the gut, and production of a protective cytokine called IL-22. Without RELβ, mice were more susceptible to infection and had deeper penetration of bacteria into the gut lining, leading to ulcers and increased mortality. The study suggests goblet cells play a critical role in recruiting CD4 cells to protect against enteric pathogens.
Researchers have identified a crucial interaction between the C-terminal motif of norovirus VP and the HE-1 domain of eIF4, which is essential for translation initiation. Norovirus, a major cause of gastroenteritis in humans, uses an unusual mechanism to initiate protein synthesis that relies on interactions between VP protein attached to the 5' end of the RNA and eukotic factors in the host. The study focused on murine norirus (MNV) and found that VP binds to the middle fragment of e4 (residues 652-113). Using pull-down assays, fluorescence anisotropy, and isothermal calorimetry, they demonstrated that a 20 amino acid stretch at the C-terminus of MN VP mediates direct and specific binding to HE-1 within the fragment of e4. Analysis revealed the MN C-termin binds e4 HE-1 via a conserved motif in all noriruses. Mutagenic mapping suggested the MN VP C-termin interacts e4 in a helical conformation. NMR spectroscopy defined the VP binding site on e4 HE-1, confirmed by mutagenesis and binding assays. The site is non-overlapping with binding for e4 on e HE-1, showing norirus VP can form ternary VP-e4-e4 complexes. A fusion proteins containing the C-terminal of MN VP inhibited in vitro translation of norirus but not cap or I-dependent. This defines structural and functional interaction between norirus VP and e4, revealing a binding site that might be targeted for antiviral therapy.
Researchers investigated the evolution of gene clusters in bacterial genomes, where genes encoding proteins in a common pathway are often found near each other on the chromosome. Several explanations have been proposed, including natural selection favoring clusters for efficiency, the selfish operon model, and persistence model. The selfish model suggests clusters are easily transferred to other species, improving survival, while the persistence model proposes genes in proximity are less likely to be disrupted by deletions. The study developed computational models to examine conditions for cluster evolution. The selfish model was re-implemented and run under various conditions, then a Moran process with selection and gene rearrangement by inversion was introduced, and a model with selection and inversion was developed. Surprisingly, clusters failed to evolve under many conditions. Factors promoting evolution include low gene number in pathway, high population size, and selfish model, high transfer rate. The analysis showed evolution can occur under direct and indirect selection with certain conditions, making the selfish model a viable explanation for clusters. However, the model cannot explain clusters in order of biochemical reactions, proposing multiple mechanisms, including transfer. The persistence model explains clustering of essential genes, less likely to be disrupted by deletion. The selfish model offers evolution without selection, clusters persisting due to proximity facilitating transfer between species, applying to accessory genes. A model was constructed with a Moran process and inversion, tracking a population of bacteria with a pathway of 3 or more genes. The selfish model was re-examined by varying parameters, revealing conditions for clustering.
Malaria, caused by the parasite Plasmodium falciparum, is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical regions worldwide. Pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to severe consequences of infection due to the adhesion of parasite-infected erythrocytes in the placenta. This adhesion is mediated by a variant of Pf1, a parasite-encoded, hyper-variable antigen on the surface of infected cells, called VARCSA, which binds to chondroit sulfate on syncyotrophlasts in the intervillous space of placent. VARCS is only expressed in the presence of placenta, suggesting its expression is repressed in men or non-pregnant women, but the mechanism is not understood. Researchers found that the gene encoding VARCS contains a small open reading frame that represses translation of the mRNA, a novel form of regulation in malaria parasites. This mechanism is reversible, allowing high levels of protein upon selection, enabling parasites to upregulate expression in presence of appropriate tissue.

 Studies on mechanisms of VARCS expression and protein in general will provide insights into host-parasite interactions underlying pathogenesis of disease. Analysis of 5 leader of VARCS transcripts from selected for binding and isolated from pregnant women revealed the found upstream of Pf1 region not spliced and present in mRNA, indicating VARCS encoded by bicronic transcript. This suggests additional regulation of Pf1 variant with pregnancy malaria, preventing expression when plac not available. VARCS transcripts detected in non-pregn individuals, including children and men, suggesting post-transcription mechanisms operating, lower immune exposure. Contrary evidence by proteomic study detected VARCS parasites non-plental and earlier study CSA-binding parasites nonregn hosts. The parasite genome contains 60 genes varying between isolates, VARCS conserved in most, if not all, isolates.
Researchers conducted a study on 34 children infected with deng virus (DENV) in Nicaragua to understand the differences in gene expression between severe and non-severe manifestations of the disease. They collected blood samples from patients on days 3-6 of illness and used genome-wide microarray analysis to identify genes differentially regulated between subgroups. The most striking differences were between deng patients with and without shock, particularly in mitochondrial proteins associated with protein synthesis. In deng hemorrhagic fever, a subset of genes encoded neutrophil-derived anti-microbial peptides associated with innate immunity. A meta-analysis with published datasets confirmed DENV infection is associated with changes in protein and nucleic acid metabolism. In vitro infection led to an interferon signature, not observed in patient samples by day 3-6, suggesting a transient interferon response. The study highlights differences between manifestations and commonalities of DENV infection. A large number of genes upregulated during illness were shared among all deng patients, representing a common response to infection. IRF and BL were strongly represented, supporting B cell stimulation and proliferation. A distinct profile was found between Nicaraguan deng patients with shock and DH, and between DF and DH. A meta-analysis with existing datasets identified common and differences. Comparing severe and non-severe cases, 32 genes were different, with 25 more expressed in severe and 7 in non-severe.
Researchers studied how the Herpesviruses, a type of virus that causes disease, enter the body. They focused on Murid Herpesvirus-4 (Mu-4), a virus related to the one that causes Kaposi's Sarcoma. Mu-4 targets the olfactory epithelium, a layer of cells in the nose responsible for smell. To enter, Mu-4 binds to a molecule called heparan sulfate (HS) on the cells. Without HS, the virus can't enter. The olfactory epithelium has HS on its surface, allowing Mu-4 to bind and enter. The virus goes down the cilia, tiny hair-like structures on the cells, and infects the neurons or nearby glial cells that support them. This suggests the olfactory epithelium is a key entry point for Herpesviruses.

 Mu-4 can infect neurons, even though it's not typically meant to. The olfactory epithelium may provide a way for Herpesviruses to enter the body. HS is thought to be a first step for Herpesvir to bind to cells, but it's also important for Mu-4 entry. This means targeting HS in the olfactory epithelium could be a way to stop Herpesvir infection. Other factors, besides HS, may limit Mu-4 entry to the olfactory epithelium. A study used Mu-4 to see how HS, virus binding, and infection relate in the body. They found the olfactory epithelium is targeted by Mu- due to its unique features. In lab, Mu- depends on HS to enter cells, and without HS, it can't. The study shows the olfactory epithelium is a specific entry point for Mu- and not just a result of being inhaled. The epithelium has neurons, sustacular cells, and precursor cells, each with different roles.
Researchers have identified a new regulatory mechanism by which controls the expression of genes required for Salmonella to invade epithelial cells. This mechanism involves the protein CRP, a widely known metabolic regulator, which silences the expression of SPI-1 genes under non-permissive conditions. In the absence of CRP, Salmonella expresses high levels of SPI-1 genes during mid-log growth phase. Genetic analysis revealed that CRP modulates the level of Hil, the master regulator of Salmonella invasion, at the post-transcriptional level. A newly identified motif within the 3' untranslated region of Hil is required for this regulation. Additionally, the sRNA Spot42 is under transcriptionally repressed by CRP and when repression is relieved, Spot42 positively affects Hil expression. In vivo and in vitro assays show Spot42 targets the 3'UTR of Hil transcript through its unstructured region. These findings highlight the 3'UT of Hil as a hub for postcriptional control of Salmonella invasion gene expression.
Researchers investigated the relationship between CAG repeat instability, chromatin structure, and transcription in the context of Huntington's disease (HD) using R6 and R2 transgenic mouse lines. These mice express a similar transgene, integrated at different sites, and recapitulate tissue-specific HD instability. The study found that instability rates are higher in R2 tissues compared to R1 samples. High transgene expression and chromatin accessibility correlated with increased CAG instability in R2 mice. Transgene mRNA and H3K trimylation at the HD locus were increased, while H3 dimylation reduced in R2 tissues relative R1. However, levels of transgene and histone marks were similar in striatum and cerebellum, two tissues showing different C instability. The study suggests that transcription modulates somatic CAG in vivo. Specifically, results indicate that elongation is tissue-dependent, contributing to tissue-selective C instability. The transgene is integrated in a more euchromatin and transcriptionally active region in R2 mice than R1, supporting active chrom structure in increased instability. C instability was higher in R2, irrespective of repeat size, than R1, suggesting chrom context and expression rather than initial size underlies instability. Despite similar HD expression in striatum and cerebellum, these tissues present different instability levels. Histone modifications associated with heterochrom, euchrom, and initiation were comparable in striatum and cerebell. Accessibility to DNA repair factors when chrom is open was tested, and found not to correlate with instability.
Researchers studied the genetic features of Enterovirus 71 (EV71), a highly virulent virus, to understand how it spreads in humans. They analyzed the virus in immunocompromised patients with disseminated disease at different infection sites, comparing respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and blood specimens. Three nucleotide changes occurred within five days: a non-conservative amino acid change in VP1 within the BC loop (97), a region considered immunogenic and important in poliovirus adaptation, a conservative amino substitution in protein 2 (38), and a silent mutation in protein 3 (175). Infectious clones were constructed with Br (A) and clinical (C) lineages containing one or both non-syn mutations. In vitro tropism and competition assays showed VP1 Leu to Arg substitution within BC conferred replicative advantage in SH-SY5 neuroblastoma cells. This mutation was associated with second non-cons mutation (167 or 167) in VP EF loop in neuroblast cells. Models of EV71 VP variants were built to determine substitutions' effects on structure and host interactions. No significant changes were observed, but substitutions may alter interactions with cell receptors. Results show VP1 BC loop of EV plays critical role in tropism, independent of lineage, contributing to dissemination and neurotropism in immunocompromised patients.
Researchers studied how certain bacteria called Streptoccus recognize and respond to signals that help them take in new genetic material from their environment. This process, called competence, is crucial for their evolution and allows them to gain traits like antibiotic resistance or virulence. In Streptoccus, these signals are controlled by a system called quorum sensing (QS) mediated by peptides called pherones. One such system, ComRS, involves a peptide Com that is processed, secreted, and imported into the cell where it activates a protein ComR. Com then triggers a feedback loop to express Com and an alternative factor SigX. ComRS are found in most Streptoccus species, but Com and Com diverge significantly, suggesting species-specific communication. To study cross-talk between Streptoc species and Com interaction, researchers developed a test to measure Com response to cognate and heterologous peptides in vivo, revealing strict, intermediate, and promiscuous specificity among species. They also solved the structure of Com from S suis to understand interaction and search for features that explain recognition. Using this, they probed the conformation of the binding site by mutagenesis and biochemically in vitro. Results show a model for recognition and specificity, and predict novel peptides that induce Com activity.
Researchers studied the replication of centrom DNA in the pathogenic yeast Candida albicans, a model organism with epigenetically inherited centromes. They found that each centere is associated with a replication origin that fires first on its respective chromosome, and epigen formation of new centeres (neocromes) is accompanied by shifts in replication timing, making neocere the first to replicate and associated with origin complex (ORC) components. Changing the level of centere-specific histone H isoform led to a concomitant change in OR association with centere regions, supporting the idea that centere proteins determine origin activity. Analysis of centere-associated DNA revealed a replication pattern characteristic of constitutively active origins. This pattern is conserved with centere position among strains and species, independently of DNA sequence. The study suggests that inheritance of centere position is correlated with constitutively active replication that fires at distinct time.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study to identify genetic factors contributing to chronic back pain in adults of European ancestry. They analyzed data from 158,025 individuals, including 29,531 with chronic back pain cases, from 15 cohorts in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) consortium and UK Biobank. Chronic pain was defined as back pain lasting 3-6 months or more. The study found a genome-wide significant association with a variant in the SOX5 gene, which was replicated in 283,752 UKob participants and exceeded genome-wide significance in joint analysis. Two other loci, CC26/GMC and DCC, reached genome-wide significance in joint analysis. This is the first genome-wide association study for chronic pain and identifies a genetic link to SO5.
Taenia solium cysticosis is a neglected zoonotic disease that affects humans and pigs in many developing countries, particularly in West Cameroon. The disease is underreported due to its various symptoms, with epilepsy being the most recognized, and lack of diagnostic tools in endemic areas. A study was conducted to estimate the burden of the disease in Cameroon using cost and Disability Adjusted Life (DAL) Year estimations. Parameters were collected and imported into software, with different distributions used for each type of information. Based on a prevalence of 3.6%, the number of people with neurocystercosis-associated epilepsy was estimated at 50,326 (95% CI 37,299-65,924), representing 1.0% of the population, and pigs with cysticosis at 15,961 (95% CI 12,320-20,044), 5.6% of the pig population. Total costs due to T. solium cystosis in Cameroon were estimated at €10,255,202 (95% CI 6,889-14,754), with 4.7% losses in pig husbandry and 95.3 direct and indirect due to human cystosis. The burden per case was €194 (95 CI147-253). Average DALs lost were 9.0 per thousand per year (95 CI 2.8-20.4). The study provides country-specific estimations of human and animal burden of the zoon disease. A comparison with South Africa indicates salaries play a role in monetary burden. Knowing salary and prevalence allows rapid indication of total cost.
Researchers have identified a non-coding RNA called Rsa in Staphylococcus aureus that plays a crucial role in reducing the bacteria's virulence. Rsa is present in all Staphlococcus species and its deletion increases the bacteria's invasiveness in mice and resistance to opsonic killing. However, it promotes biofilm formation and colonization in mice, leading to chronic infections. The study found that Rsa represses the translation of mgrA, a global regulator, by forming a duplex with the Shine-Dalg sequence and loop interaction within the mRNA. This repression leads to increased biofilm formation and decreased capsule synthesis, making the bacteria less susceptible to opic killing by polymonuclear leukocytes. In animal models, Rsa reduced the severity of acute infections and enhanced chronic catheter infections. Rsa is part of a regulatory network contributing to the bacteria's interactions with the host, moderating invasiveness and chronic infections. This is the first example of a conserved RNA in S aureus functioning as a virulence suppressor of acute infections. The researchers propose that R has been positively selected through evolution to support commensal and saprophytic interactions with the host.
Researchers have developed a new method to visualize the process of HIV-1 uncoating, a crucial step in establishing a long-term infection, using a fluorescently tagged version of a protein called cyclophilin A (Cyp-DRed) that binds to the HIV-1 capsid. They found that Cyp-D remains associated with the core after the viral membrane is removed and is lost concurrently with the capsid in vitro and in living cells. The rate of loss is influenced by core stability and accelerated upon initiation of reverse transcription. The majority of cores lose Cyp-D shortly after fusion, while a small fraction remains intact for several hours. Single particle tracking at late post-infection reveals gradual loss of C-D dependent on reverse transcription. Unating occurs in the cytoplasm and at the nuclear membrane. This novel assay enables time-resolved visualization of single HIV-1 unating in living cells, revealing previously unapprecited spatio-temporal features of this incompletely understood process.
Researchers investigated the use of oligonucleotides in archaeal and bacterial genomes to understand their properties, such as codon usage, DNA stacking, and structural conformation. They analyzed oligonucleotide frequencies in coding and non-coding regions and found that prokotic chromosomes can be described by hexanucle frequencies, indicating prootic DNA is short-range correlated, with information encoded in oligonotides. Oligonucle usage varied in AT-rich and host-associated genomes more than GC and free-living genomes, mainly in nonoding regions. Bias in tetranucle usage correlated with GC content, coding regions more biased than nonoding. Nonoding regions were 5.5% more AT-rich than coding, on average, in 402 examined chromosomes. Pronounced compositional differences were found within and between AT and GC genomes. GC genomes were similar in tetranucle usage nonoding than AT genomes.
