Studies not included in the analysis showed reduction in ventricular beats, tachia, and couplets. Pooled incidence of adverse effects showed amar was associated with corne microdepos 61.1 (19.0-91.5), gastrointestinal 16.1 (6.6-34.2), bradycia 12.7 (3.7-35.6), dermatological 10.6 (4-21.9), and discontinuation 7.68 (4-13.7). Quality evidence ranged from moderate to low. Amiodone is effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias but no evidence for endpoints sudden death, hospitalization.
Researchers studied the seasonal patterns of deng fever in rural Ecuador from 2009-2016 using medical records from two hospitals. They used a statistical model to determine short and long-term patterns of the disease, as well as the effect of day of the week and public holidays. The study found that deng fever cases were more likely to be diagnosed on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and less likely on Saturdays and Sundays. Public holidays did not affect deng diagnoses, except for an increase on the day after Christmas. School schedules did not impact deng diagnoses in school-aged children. The study also found that climate factors such as total precipitation, interaction between precipitation and temperature, and interaction between precipitation and days affected deng diagnoses. This is the first report of long-term deng fever seasonality in Ecuador, one of few from rural areas, and one of few using daily reports. The results can inform local disease prevention, public health planning, and global models of deng trends.
Researchers have found a way to activate the innate immune system, the body's first line of defense against infection, without triggering autoimmunity or chronic inflammation. They did this by expressing a specific part of a virus, called Rd, in the absence of other viral proteins, making it detectable to the immune system. This led to a long-lasting, dramatic increase in antiviral genes and resistance to lethal viral challenge in mice. The mechanism was found to operate through a protein called MDA and be independent of the adaptive immune system. Human cells showed similar results, with Rd inducing an antiral network and blocking HIV-1 infection. Importantly, mice remained healthy with normal longevity despite massive gene elevations. The study provides a foundation for augmenting innate immunity to achieve broad-spectrum antiral protection.
Researchers tested the independent-action hypothesis (IAH) for a plant virus, Tobacco etch virus (TEV), which states that each virion has a probability of infection and virions act independently during the infection process. They found that the number of primary infection foci increased linearly with dose and followed a Poisson distribution. At high doses, primary foci containing both genotypes were found at a low frequency (<2%). The probability of a genotype infecting the inoculated leaf systemically infecting the plant was near 1, but in rare cases, genotypes could be trapped in the inoculated leaf by other genotypes. The frequency of mixed-genotype infection was predicted by the independent model. Independent action appears to hold for TE, and Ne is dose-dependent for this RNA virus. The number of virions causing systemic infection can be small and approaches 1 at low doses. Dose dependency in TE suggests that Ne estimates for different viruses are not meaningful unless dose effects are considered.
Researchers have developed a new statistical method to study how genes are controlled by multiple genetic variants across different tissues in the body. Most previous studies looked at one tissue or cell type at a time, ignoring shared information between them. The new method, called Bayesian Sparse Regression, can analyze gene expression in multiple tissues and genetic variants simultaneously. It was tested on 2,000 genes in four tissues and showed it's more powerful than traditional methods in revealing genetic control of gene expression at the system level. It identified a genetic variant for the Hopx gene not found by other methods and showed 27% of genes have common regulation across tissues, increasing eQTL detection by 5-fold compared to single tissue analysis at 5% false discovery rate. This method can uncover complex genetic mechanisms controlling gene expression and is adaptable to other systems and humans, applicable to multiple and whole-body phenotypes.

The new method uses an efficient algorithm, Evolutionary Stochastic Search, and can identify polygenic regulation and secondary genetic effects not found by traditional methods. Global expression analysis in multiple tissues is now feasible, but few methods analyze gene expression across tissues with genetic variants. The new method can identify more cis and trans-effects than single marker methods at the same false discovery rate and finds regulation across tissue types. It also provides a list of genetic variants and assesses their contribution to gene variability.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to understand how cells decide to undergo apoptosis, or programmed cell death, in response to external signals such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF) or TRAIL. This process, called extrinsic apoptosis, is controlled by a unique "variable-delay, snap-action" switch that allows cells to choose between life and death. The model, based on mass-action representation of reaction pathways, was trained with experimental data from live-cell imaging, flow cytometry, and immunoblot of cells with protein depletion and overexpression. It accurately reproduces normal and perturbed cells exposed to TRAIL, enabling detailed study of switching mechanisms. Analysis and experiments show that the delay before effector caspase activation is determined by initiator casase-8 activity and reactions downstream of TR receptor. Sudden effector casase activation is achieved by membrane permeabilization and relocalization of proteins like Smac. Interactions among Bcl-2 family, Sm partition from XIAP, and pore assembly mechanics are critical for snap control.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Listeria monocytogen interacts with the placenta during pregnancy to cause infection. The placenta protects the fetus from the mother's immune system and other pathogens, but L monocytogen has a way to breach this barrier. A protein called Internalin P (InP) is secreted by the bacterium and helps it infect the placenta. The study found that InP binds to a protein called afadin, which is involved in cell junctions between cells. A crystal structure of InP showed a unique features, including a calcium-binding site. Cells expressing InP had less force on a substrate, similar to cells without afadin. Monocytogen mutants lacking InP couldn't form actin protrusions necessary for crossing the cell layer, and a similar effect was seen in bacteria with a deleted InP. Afadin in host cells didn't rescue the defect. The study suggests InP targets afadin to help monocogen cross the placenta, contributing to infection.
Researchers studied the proteome of Treponema pallidum s. pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis, using mass spectrometry techniques. They analyzed the DAL-1 strain of the bacteria isolated from rabbits and detected 603 peptides corresponding to 557 unique proteins, representing 54% of the predicted proteome. This is the most comprehensive description of the T. pallum proteome to date. The detected proteins were characterized by their biological function and localization, with half allocated to various categories. Proteins with unclear annotations were subjected to additional analysis. 116 potential membrane proteins were identified, 16 with evidence of outer membrane localization. 12 proteins related to the paralog tpr gene family were found. Protein abundance was semi-quantified using label-free methods. A low correlation was found between microarray data and protein abundance. The study provides insights into T. pallum protein expression, paving the way for understanding the pathogenicity of this organism.
Protein Kinase A (PKA) is a key receptor for the secondary messenger cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) in eukaryotes. AMP binds to two tandem AMP-binding domains (CBD-A and B) within the regulatory subunit of PKA (R), unleashing the activity of the catalytic subunit (C). The CBD-A in PKα is required for PK inhibition and activation, while CBD functions as a "gate" domain that modulates control exerted by CBD. Preliminary evidence suggests CBD dynamics are critical for gate function. To test this hypothesis, researchers used Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) to investigate two-domain PKα (91-379) in apo, c2, and C-bound forms. Comparative NMR analyses led to a conformation selection model where each CBD samples both active and inactive states independently of adjacent CBD within a degenerate free landscape. Degener is critical to explain sensitivity of CBD to interactions and high affinity for AMP. Binding AMP eliminates degener, stabilizing active conformation within CBD and inter-C contacts, which require AMP. The inter-C interface is dispensable for intra-C conformation selection but indispensable for PK activation as occludes subunit sites within CBD. Structurally homolog c-bound CBD exhibit differences in dynamics, supporting conservation of structure does not imply dynamics.
A study investigated the role of interferon-stimulated gene 15 (IS15) in macrophages during vaccinia virus infection. IS15 is a protein induced by interferon and associated with antiviral immunity. Researchers compared the proteomes of IS15- and IS+ bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMD) after vaccinia virus (VV) infection. The results showed that mitochondrial and oxidative phosphorylation (OXOS) pathways were altered in IS- MD treated with interferon. Mitochondrial respiration, adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and reactive species (ROS) production were higher in IS+ MD than IS- MD following interferon treatment, indicating IS-dependent mechanisms. IS depletion led to a change in macroage polarization. IS- macrophages showed a pro-inflammatory cytokine pattern typical of M1, but blocked nitric oxide (NO) production and arginase activation. Following interferon treatment, NO release was higher in IS+ macroages than IS- macroages, concomitant with a decrease in viral titer. IS- macroages were permissive for VV replication following interferon treatment. The study demonstrates that IS governs the functionality of mitochondria, specifically OXOS and mitagy, broadening its role as antiral agent.
HIV-1 protein Vpu plays a crucial role in the virus replication by degrading the cellular CD4 receptor and enhancing viral particle release. It binds to CD4 and recruits the βTr subunit of the SCβCP ubiquitin ligase complex through its phosphorylated DS52XX56 motif. However, V escapes degradation by inhibiting the degradation of βTr targets such as β-caten and Iκα. This study investigated V's inhibitory function on Em1 and Cdc25, βTr substrates involved in cell cycle progression. Phosphorylation of V at serine 61, adjacent to the βTr-binding motif, triggers V degradation by a βTr-independent process. Mutation of V61 in the HIV-1 provirus extends the protein's half-life and increases HIV-1 release from HeLa cells. The S61 determinant is conserved in HIV-1 isolates. Results show differential phosphorylation of V determines its fate as an adaptor or substrate of ubiquitin ligases. Conservation of V degradation, despite negative effect on release, suggests a role in overall HIV fitness.
Researchers investigated how the development of tissues in the body is coordinated with whole-body development to ensure robustness against environmental and physiological perturbations. They proposed two hypotheses: tissue pattering is coordinated with whole-body over time or at developmental milestones. A staging scheme was developed for the wing imaginal discs of Drosila larvae based on patterning gene expression, linked to whole-body events: moulting, larval, and pupation. The progression of pattern showed alignment at moul and pupation, indicating these events represent milestones. Between milestones, pattern showed variability in response to temperature and physiological changes. Data showed discs from wandering larvae had greater variability in patterning stage, suggesting wandering is not a milestone. Tissue patter remains robust against perturbations by aligning at milestones. This work provides insight into how individual tissue development is coordinated with the body as a whole.
In highly polarized cells, such as fungal hyphae, endosomes play a crucial role in both endocytosis and long-distance transport of various cargo, including mRNA and protein complexes. However, the relationship between these processes is not well understood. This study demonstrates that the ESCRT regulator Did coordinates endosomal transport in fungal hypha of Ustago may. Loss of Did results in defective vacuolar targeting, less processive long transport, and abnormal shuttling of early endosomes. The late endosomal protein Rab7 and vacuolar protease P1 exhibit increased shuttling on these aberrant endosomes, suggesting defects in endosomal maturation and identity. Molecular motors fail to attach, explaining disturbed processive movement. The endosomal RNP linker Up1 is absent on endosomes, resulting in defects in long-distance mRNA transport. The ESC regulator Did coordinates endosomal maturation and provides correct identity for efficient endosomal long transport. Endosomal maturation and fusion with vacuoles depend on functional ESC machinery for vacolar sorting. In the absence of Did, late endosomal Rab and cargo vacu protease shuttle intensively on early endosomes. A link between ESC complex and endosomal transport is discovered, but indirect, affecting mRNA loading on endosomes. Endosomal maturation is essential for endytic recycling and polar growth in cells. ESC components are present early during long trafficking. Did is required for endytic functions and long transport. Loss causes localization of end proteins and decreased processivity of endosomes.
Researchers studied two types of riboswitches, which are molecules that regulate gene expression by binding to adenine, in two different bacteria: Bacillus subtilis and Vibrio vulificus. They found that while both bind adenine, they control gene expression at different levels: transcription and translation. The Bacillus subtil ribwitch depends on co-transcription binding of adenine to function, whereas Vibrio vulus ribwitch can bind adenine after transcription is completed and still regulate translation. The rate of transcription is crucial for Bacillus ribwitch to perform efficiently, supporting co-transcription regulation. In contrast, Vibrio ribwitch can regulate without transcription-translation coupling. The study suggests that the nature of regulation, transcription or translation, has a significant impact on ribwitch mechanisms.
Researchers studied the process of transcription initiation in bacteria Escherichia coli and Vibrio cholera using high-throughput sequencing of RNA 5 ends (5 RNA-seq). They found that a type of transcription initiation called primer-dependent initiation (PDI) occurs in both bacteria, where a 2-4 nucleotide oligonucleotide primer is used to start transcription. PDI is prevalent in stationary phase of growth in E coli, but its role and occurrence in other bacteria was unknown. The study established P as a regulatory mechanism that modulates biofilm formation in E coli and found similar pattern in V cholera. P is detected in stationary phase, not exponential, and preferentially at promoters with T-1+1 and G-1+ sites. RNA-seq and primer analyses indicate P from T-1 and G-1 produces transcripts from position 1. In E coli, P is involved in biofilm growth. The study also found P in pathogenic Gammapobacteria Vibrio cholera, with similar pattern to E coli. coli. P produces full-length transcripts with 5' hydroxyl and sequence 5-UA and 5-GG. A growth-dependent process generates 5-UA and 5- oligonucleotides in both E and V cholera.
Researchers investigated the effect of parental genome imbalance on the expression of imprinted genes in Arabidopsis, a plant species. Imprinted genes are genes that are expressed by a single parental allele, either from the mother or father, and play a crucial role in growth and development. Previous studies in mammals and plants showed that parental genome imbalance affects embryo growth and may be involved in reproductive isolation between species. The researchers tested the effect of genome imbalance on four imprinted genes FERTIZATION INDEPENDENT SE2 (F2) and FLOWERING WEN (WA) controlled by DNA methylation and MEA (MEA) and PES (P1) by histone methylation. They found that genome imbalance deregulated expression of F2 and P1 in an antagonistic manner, meaning one increased maternal dosage repressed growth while increased paternal dosage enhanced growth. Increased maternal dosage also caused loss of imprinting in F2 and MEA. However, changes in P and ME expression could not be fully explained by fluctuations in F2 expression. The study shows that genome imbalance deregulates imprinting mechanisms independent of known regulators. The complex network of expressed and silenced imprinted genes in response to imbalance does not support simple models from the parental conflict hypothesis.
Researchers have analyzed brain activity recordings from electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG) to understand how brain rhythms, or oscillations, are organized in the brain. They found that these oscillations appear as frequency bands on a logarithmic scale, preventing mutual entrainment and cross-talk. Unlike previous studies, this research focused on what brain rhythms reveal about functional connectivity rather than how they emerge or if they are necessary for function. By reverse-engineering networks, or "virtual brains", with similar dynamics to EEG/ME recordings, researchers found that these networks share structural and topological features with real brains. They also recreated diseased brains, such as epileptic and schizophrenic, with altered oscillatory activity, and found consistent alterations in connectivity and dynamics. The complexity of the network, quantified by Tononi and Edelman, was a good indicator of brain fitness, with diseased brains displaying lower complexity. The study suggests that brain rhythms convey information about functional connectivity, not anatomy, and has implications for neurobiology and disease.
Researchers conducted a genetic analysis of 1,374 Hispanic individuals from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (ESA) to understand the population structure of Hispanics in the United States. They used 60,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) selected for linkage disequilibrium to identify genetic differences among individuals from Central America, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and South America. By analyzing principal components of ancestry, they found three main origins: Caucasian, African, and Native American, and a fourth component separating Mexican and South American samples. Clustering the first four components, they identified four subgroups: Dominican/Cuban, Mexican, Central/South American, and Puerto Rican, aligning with self-identification. To demonstrate the importance of considering population structure in genetic studies, they analyzed triglycerides in the LPL and TR1 genes, previously associated with Caucasians but not confirmed in Hispanics. They found significant association in both genes, highlighting the need to account for genetic heterogeneity in Hispanic populations.
Researchers have discovered a new role for the Elong complex, a group of proteins involved in various cellular processes, in transcriptional silencing and genome stability. They found that Elong interacts with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), a protein essential for DNA replication and repair, to regulate gene silencing and sensitivity to DNA damage. Cells lacking Elong's catalytic subunit, El3, lose silencing of certain genes and are sensitive to DNA inhibitors and damaging agents. Deletion of El or mutations in other Elong subunits also result in loss of silencing and increased sensitivity. El is required for cell progression in the presence of DNA inhibitor hydroxyurea. Analysis shows El mutant exacerbates sensitivity to damaging agent methylmethanesulfate in cells lacking histone chaperone As1 and H lysine acetylase R109. El binds PCNA in vivo and in vitro, indicating a novel role for Elong in transcription silencing and genome stability linked to replication and repair.
Researchers have developed a machine-assisted method to improve the process of manually curating biomedical knowledge from publications, known as document triage, which is crucial for building accurate and organized knowledge bases. Current query-based methods often yield unsatisfactory results and are difficult to generate optimal queries. The proposed method uses deep learning based on convolutional neural networks to classify and rank publications for curation, trained on a gold-standard dataset from UniProt/SwissProt and NHRIEB GWAS Catalog. Evaluation on real-world curation of UniProt/Siss and GW Catalog shows the machine-assisted method outperforms query-based methods, improving efficiency and enriching content. The method achieves 1.81 and 2.99 times higher precision than query-based methods for UniProt/S and GW Catalog, respectively, without compromising recall. It retrieves many relevant publications query-based UniProt could not find. This demonstrates the method can make triage more efficient, allowing human curators to focus on challenging tasks improving knowledge quality.
A study investigated the link between gain-of-function mutations in the KCNJ2-encoded Kir2.1 channels and atrial arrhythmias in short QT syndrome type 3 (SQT3), which is associated with atrial fibrillation (AF). The researchers used detailed computer models of human atrial electrophysiology to understand how these mutations lead to arrhythmias and identify potential targets for treatment. They modified a model of the human atrial action potential to mimic the effects of heterozygous and homozygous forms of the D172 and E299 Kir2.1 mutations, and incorporated wild-type and mutant channels into multi-scale and heterogeneous tissue models. The study found that both mutations shortened the action potential duration and decreased conduction velocity, refractory period, and excitation threshold, and wavelength of re-entry. Stability of reentrant excitation in 2D and 3 tissue models was mediated by changes in tissue excitability and dispersion of action potential in mutation conditions. Combined block of IK and IK was effective in terminating re-entry with heterozygous D172 conditions, whereas IK block alone may be safer for E299 mutation. Combined of IK and IK produced a synergistic antiarrhythmic effect in both forms of QT3. The study provides mechanistic insights into atrial arrhythm with QT2.1 mutations and highlights pharmacological strategies for management of QT-linked AF.
Researchers investigated whether adipose-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASC) can alter the course of Chagas disease, a parasitic infection caused by Trypanosoma cruzi (T. cruzi) that affects the heart and is endemic in Central and South America. Mice were infected with T. cruzi and injected with ASC 3 days post-infection. The cells remained in the abdominal cavity for up to 9 days and most migrated to abdominal subcutaneous fat, an early parasite reservoir. ASC injection reduced blood parasitemia, cardiac inflammation, and tissue parasitism at 30 days. Cytokine analysis showed an anti-inflammatory response in ASC-treated mice. In contrast, splenocytes from placebo-treated mice produced pro-inflammatory cytokines important for parasite control. ASC mice had higher IL-10 levels at 60 days. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed right ventricular (RV) dilation prevented in ASC-treated mice. Injection of ASC after T. cruz infection prevented RV remodeling through modulation of immune response, promoting parasite control and heart protection from damage.
Researchers have developed new analogs of a compound called Retro-2, which inhibits the growth of Leishmania parasites, a type of parasite that causes leishmaniasis. Leishmania resides in specialized compartments called parasitophorous vacuoles (LPVs) within mammalian cells. The new analogs, DHZ36 and DHZ36.1, were found to be more effective in controlling Leish infections than the parent compound Retro-2. They reduced the size of LPs and lowered parasite numbers in Leish infections. Additionally, the analogs limited Leish infection in macrophages with an EC50 of 13.63-2.58μM and 10.57-2.66M, respectively, lower than Retro-2's 40.15M. The analogs also reversed Leish suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation. Unlike Retro-2, the analogs killed Leish parasites in axenic cultures, a desirable for treating Leish infections. Studies validated and extended the structure-activity relationship of Retro-2. The analogs were non-toxic to mammalian cells, suggesting the retrograde pathway is more sensitive in Leish.
Researchers have developed a method to predict which transcription factors are sensitive to the nucleosome, a complex of DNA and proteins that helps organize and regulate gene expression. They found that the Acute Myeloid Leukemia-1 (AML-1) transcription factor, which regulates immune gene expression, is sensitive to the nucleosome within the Ly49 gene family. This was confirmed in a cell line with natural expression of Ly49, where nucleosomes were depleted at AML-1 binding sites in expressed LyA compared to silent Ly genes. The study suggests nucleosome regulation contributes to Ly gene expression and proposes a method to predict nucleosome sensitivity to aid in understanding its role in gene regulation. A whole-chromosome analysis revealed many transcription factors display nucleosome coverage and lack 10 bp periodicity, identifying AML-1 as sensitive in the Ly cluster. Predictions were confirmed in a line with expressed Ly genes showing preferential nucleosome depletion at AML-1 sites compared to inactive genes. It will be interesting to study AML-1 sensitivity at non-Ly genes to determine if it's a trait for Ly regulation only. In a line naturally expressing Ly, AML-1 sites are depleted nucleosomes in promoter/enhancer regions of expressed Ly compared to unexpressed genes, implicating nucleosome in Ly regulation in vivo.
Researchers have identified a crucial step in the regulation of cell cycle progression, specifically the phosphorylation of CDK4 at T172, which determines its activity. Unlike other CDKs, CD4 is not activated by phosphorylation of its T-loop by CDK-activating kinase (CAK), but rather by dephosphorylation of inhibitory sites by Cdc phosphatases. CD4 and CD6, bound to cyclins D, initiate mitogenic signaling cascades by inactivating the cell cycle suppressor pR at the restriction point. The study used chemical genetics to inhibit CD7, the only known CA for CD2 and CD1, and found it prevented phosphorylation of CD4, but not CD6, which was partly dependent on binding to p21. In response to CD7 inhibition, p21 bound to CD increased with disappearance of its phosphorylation at S130, catalyzed by CD4 and CD2. S130 mutation of p prevented CD4 phosphorylation and inhibited CD6 and CD2 phosphorylation of p21. CD7 inhibition revealed indirect involvement in CD4 activation, existence of other CD-activating kinases, and CD-dependent feedback by p phosphorylation of CD4 and CD2 to sustain activation and p inactivation at the restriction point. CD4 and CD6 associated with cyclin D and cyclin1 phosphorylated p in vitro. CD6 was less phosphorylated than CD and its T-phosphorylated form in cyclin D-CD6 but not cyclin3CD6. Phosphorylation cyclin D-bound CD6 was inhibited by CD7. CD7 inhibition delayed CD2 activity due to T160 phosphorylation stabilized by cyclin binding.
Researchers have identified a protein called DUET/M1 that plays a crucial role in meiosis, a process that produces haploid cells essential for sexual reproduction in plants. Meiosis is triggered by transcription factors that activate a cascade of genes, but these factors are not conserved and mechanisms ensuring proper meiotic expression in multicellular eukaryotes are poorly understood. DUET1, a PHD finger protein, is essential for Arabidopsis male meiosis and functions as a transcription regulator. It binds to H3me2 in vitro and this interaction is critical for its function during meiosis. DUET is required for microtubule organization during me II, independently of its function in I. It shows stage-specific expression, confined to diplot. Two genes, TDM1 and J, are critical for cell transitions and spindle organization in meiosis, and are targets of DU, with T1 being a direct. DU regulates microtub organization and cell transitions during me and activates meiotic gene T1. Expression shows reduced expression of 12% of known meiotic genes in du mutant. Results reveal DU as transcription regulator during me in plants and suggest meiotic under stagewise control in plants like yeast.
Fragile X-associated tremor ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by fragile X premutation CG repeats. Previous studies have shown that fragile X CG repeats can cause neurodegeneration and that CG-binding proteins α and hnRNP A/B can modulate CG-mediated neurotoxicity. Researchers investigated the role of α in CG-mediated neurode using a proteomic approach and identified over 100 proteins that interact with α. Notably, R62, the Drosophila ortholog of p RNA helicase, can modulate CG-mediated neurode. Fragile X CG repeats decreased R62 transcription, leading to nuclear accumulation of H70 transcript and other mRNAs involved in stress and immune responses. This suggests that abnormal accumulation of these mRN, likely due to impaired export, contributes to FAS pathogenesis.

Fragile X premutation CG repeats reduced viability of heterozygous R62 mutant flies, supporting a strong interaction between R62 and CG-mediated cell death. R62 is the Dophila orth of p RNA helic. Nuclear accumulation of specific mRN caused by X premutation CG repeats indicates a potential deficit in export contributing to FAS path. Earlier studies showed α and hnNP A/B are CG-binding proteins that modulate CG-toxicity.

Systematic proteomic, genetic, and microarray analyses show nuclear accumulation of m caused by X premutation CG repeats contributes to FAS, possibly via impaired export due decreased R62. Altered H70 and turnover similar to R62/p mutation. Fragile premutation CG likely produce deficits in export mediated by R62, such as H70. Nuclear accumulation interferes with neurons' ability to respond to stress.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a type of bacteria, forms complex communities called biofilms on surfaces. These biofilms are held together by an extracellular matrix, a mixture of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins. Researchers studied how this matrix forms and its components during bio development. They focused on the polyschar synthesis locus (Psl polyschar) and its role in biofilm formation. During attachment, P is anchored to the cell surface in a helical pattern, promoting cell-cell interactions and matrix assembly. This holds bacteria in the biofilm on the surface. Disrupting P from the surface disrupts the matrix and bio structure. During maturation, P accumulates on the periphery of 3D microcolonies, creating a P matrix-free cavity in the microcol center. At dispersion, cells appear in this cavity. Dead and extracellular DNA are concentrated in the P-free area. Deleting genes controlling cell death and autolysis affects matrix and microcol formation. This provides a mechanism for P aerugin to build a matrix and cavity for cell dispersal. Visualization shows P is a key matrix component, opening avenues for bio-related complications.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of pancreatic cancer tumors and two types of lab models used to study cancer: patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO). Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PD) is a type of cancer with poor prognosis, and new treatments are needed to improve outcomes. PDX and PDO are promising tools to identify potential drugs for PD. To be effective, these models should match the cancer's genetic diversity and patient-specific sensitivities. The study compared the genetic makeup of 16 pairs of tumors and PDX from PD and metastasis, including a unique set of 5 pairs of primary tumor, PDX, and PDO. A pipeline was developed to score concordance between PD models and human tumors for genetic events, mutations, variations, and copy variations. Tumor comparisons showed single-gene concord across major PD driver genes but poor agreement across mutational load. Genome and chromosome analysis of structural (SV) events highlighted unrecognized conc across chromosomes. Ploidy presented a challenge when assessing copy changes; however, ploidy-correct copy suggest agreement between donor pairs. The study found that PDX and PDO can serve as transplantable systems for probing PD molecular properties, but may be selective across genomic complexity levels.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in 19,091 breast cancer cases and 20,606 controls of East-Asian descent to identify genetic factors contributing to breast cancer risk. They analyzed 690,947 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 2,918 cases and 2,324 controls, then evaluated 5,365 SNPs in 3,972 and 3,852, and 94 in 5,203 and 5,138, and finally 22 in 17,423 subjects. The study found a significant association between SNP rs9482 near the TGF-activated kinase 2 gene on chromosome 6q25.1 and breast cancer risk, with a P-value 3.8×10-12 in combined analysis. Adjusted odds ratios were 0.89 (0.85-0.94) and 0.80 (0.75-0.86) for A/A and AA genotypes compared to GG. Two other SNPs, rs3951 in the ESR gene and rs710 at 11q24.3, showed consistent association in each stage. This study provides evidence for a novel breast susceptibility locus represented by rs9482 and two possible loci in ESR and 11q.3.
A study of 230 Cryptococcus neoformans isolates from HIV-positive patients in South Africa found high genetic diversity in the region, with 50 different sequence types identified, including 18 new ones. The isolates were grouped into three main types, VNI, VNI, and VNB, with 72% belonging to seven high-frequency types. Analysis showed no geographical clustering, suggesting reactivation of latent infection rather than recent acquisition. Comparison of genetic data with clinical parameters found a link between lineage and outcome, with VNB having worse survival (HR 3.35, CI 1.51-7.20, p=0.003) even after adjusting for known indicators and treatment. Phenotypic assays on a subset of 89 isolates showed lineage-associated virulence, with VNII increased lacc activity (p=0.001) and CSF survival (p=0.000). This indicates Cryptoccus is a phenotypically heterogeneous pathogen and lineage plays a role in virulence during human infection. Understanding diversity in Africa will help investigate how diversity is structured across environments and assess risks posed to infection.
Researchers have identified the transcription factor Tec1 as the last component of a newly evolved signaling pathway that regulates the pheromone response in the white phenotype of Candida albicans, an opportunistic human pathogen. This discovery provides a comprehensive description of the pherone response pathway in the white phenotype of C. albicans and sheds light on how signaling pathways may evolve. The pherone response pathway in C. albicans appears to have derived from three ancestral programs: the upstream portion, including receptors, trimeric protein, and MAP kinase, from the mating process; Tec, the transcription factor from filamentation; and white-specific downstream genes from biofilm. This evolution of pherone pathway offers a paradigm for how signaling pathways evolve. C. alb's white pathway is young and has not had time to duplicate or modify components in response to selective pressures, making it a unique example of a new pathway's evolution. The study suggests that Tec activates genes involved in shared pathways with opaque pher response and membrane processes, adhesion, and biofilm formation. The white and opaque pathways of C. alb differ, with the opaque sharing components with S. cerevisiae haploid pher response.
Researchers investigated the variation in genomic GC content among bacteria, which ranges from less than 20% to over 70%. They tested the hypothesis that this variation is due to differences in mutation patterns by examining synonymous polymorphism datasets from 149 species. The study found a significant excess of GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations in GC-rich bacteria across diverse species, but not in AT-rich bacteria. This excess cannot be explained by mutation bias, as it would imply GC-rich bacteria are losing GC content, which is unsustainable. Translational selection and gene conversion are also ruled out, as optimal codons are AT-rich and excess GC→SNPs occur in datasets with no recombination evidence. The study concludes there is selection for increased GC content in many species, and since GC is correlated with genomic content, there is selection on base composition in bacteria. 

The study analyzed 149 species from 8 phyla, 15 classes, and 77 genera with at least 8 sequences and 10 synonymous polymorphisms at 4-fold sites. GC→AT nucleotide diversity was less than 0.1. GC-rich bacteria have a genuine excess of GC→ mutations, while AT-rich have excess AT→ mutations, possibly due to infinite sites violation. Restricting analysis to low diversity species reduces violations: 14 of 25 with diversity 0.5.
Researchers have developed a new approach to map the prevalence of soil-transmitted helminth infections (STH) in Kenya, using data from 106,370 individuals surveyed between 1974 and 2009. They combined ecological and climatic covariates from high-resolution satellite data with survey locations to create Bayesian-time geostatistical models for each species, interpolating the probability of infection exceeding 20% across the country for 1989 and 2009. Maps for each species were integrated to estimate combined STH prevalence using the law of probability, adjusting for associations between species. Population data was combined with models to estimate the population at risk and requiring treatment in 2009. Results showed high endemicity below 20% in most areas, with areas ≥20% around Lake Victoria and coast. Comparison of 198 and 2009 distributions showed STH decreased over time. The model estimated 2.8 million school-age children live in districts warranting mass treatment. Bayesian-time geostat models can estimate combined STH prevalence, suggesting a quarter of Kenya's school children live in high-prevalence areas.
Researchers investigated the role of innate immune cells, specifically invariant NKT cells, in controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. They found that splenocytes from uninfected mice produced interferon-γ when cultured with M-infected macrophages, leading to suppressed bacterial replication. This control was dependent on CD1-restricted NKT cells, which required CD1 expression on infected macrophages and IL-12 and IL-18. Even small numbers of NKT cells were sufficient to restrict M replication. Adoptive transfer of primary NKT cells from uninf mice significantly reduced bacterial burden in lungs of mice infected with virulent M by aerosol. NKT cells had a direct bactericidal effect, independent of synthetic ligands. This is the first evidence that CD-restricted N cells mediate protection against M in vivo. 

Innate lymphocytes have roles in resistance to infections, but their contribution to Mtb immunity is controversial. NK cells are activated early and produce interferonγ, critical for macrophage activation. Blocking IL-12 or IL-18 abrogated control of replication, showing N cell activation dependent on IL-12 and IL-18. Splenocytes restricted mycobacterial growth dependent on N cells. To test CD-restricted N cells, splenocytes from mice lacking N cells were tested. CD/- mice lack both invariant and CD-restricted N cells, while J/- mice lack only invariant N cells. Absence of CD-restricted cells did not alter tuberculosis outcome in previous studies. Infected macroph produced IF- by naïve splen which correlated with reduced M. The main source of IF is NK and T cells. Splenocytes from uninf R mice, lacking B and T cells but enriched for NK, restricted growth.
Researchers studied how a protein called Bacillus subtilis spore coat transglutase (Tgl) helps form strong chemical bonds between proteins in the coat that surrounds bacterial spores. Unlike other similar enzymes, T is produced in an active form and doesn't need additional factors to work. To understand how its activity is controlled during spore assembly, they found that pre-assembled substrates (other proteins) on the spore coat guide T to its location on the surface. They identified key sites on T that interact with substrates and showed that the first step of the reaction, forming an enzyme-substrate complex, is crucial for T's localization. This suggests that T's activity is controlled by its substrates to ensure proper timing and location of cross-linking pre-assembled complexes on the spore surface. In experiments, T was shown to be part of cross-linked products, indicating it becomes part of the structure. The study suggests that T's dependency on substrates is a mechanism to control its activity and specificity during spore formation in other spore-forming bacteria.
A study was conducted to investigate the distribution and risk factors of Opisthorchis vivini infection in southern Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR). Opisthoris vivini is a foodborne trematode species that causes biliary diseases and cholangiocarcinoma. Approximately 2.5 million individuals in Lao are infected, but epidemiological studies are scarce and the spatial distribution remains unknown. A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was carried out in 51 villages in Champas province in 2007. Data on demographics, socioeconomic status, water, sanitation, and behavior were combined with remotely sensed environmental data into a geographical information system. Bayesian statistical models identified age, Lao ethnic group, educational attainment, occupation, and unsafe water source as risk factors, while history of praziquel treatment, access to sanitation, and distance to freshwater were protective. Spatial patterns were governed by environmental factors, predicting two risk profiles: low in mountains and high in the Mekong corridor. The study provides the first map of infection in Champas province, important for targeting control efforts. Infection is associated with exposure to intermediate host, human behavior, and culture, sustained by lack of sanitation.
In the city of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, the presence of Anopheles and Cule mosquito larvae is common, which can lead to the transmission of lymphatic filariasis and malaria. The study aimed to determine the importance of drains as larval habitats for these vectors. Data from the Urban Malaria Control Program (UMCP) and a special survey in 2006 were used to analyze the types of habitats, focusing on drains. Logistic regression was used to evaluate factors impacting the presence of mosquito larvae. Spatial variation in proportion of habitats with larvae was assessed through Moran's indicator of association. More than 70% of larval habitats in Dar Sala were human-made. Aquatic habitats associated with agriculture had the highest Anophe presence and second highest Cule presence. However, majority of habitats were drains (42%) and 43% (1,364/3,149) of culicine and 33% (320/976) of anopheline were drains. Compared to flowing water, odds of Anophe and Cx larvae were 8.8 and 6.3 (p<.001) times larger in stagnant drains. There was association between vegetation and mosquito presence (p<.001). Proportion of habitats with larvae was spatially correlated. Restoring and maintaining drains in Dar Sala has potential to eliminate more than 40% of larval habitats treated with laricides by UMCP. Importance of human-made habitats for both diseases underscores need for synergy between control efforts.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection leads to changes in lipid metabolism in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of infected cells, favoring viral replication. Previous research showed that DENV inhibits HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) phosphorylation, creating a cholesterol-rich environment for viral replication. This study found higher MG activity in DENV-infected cells, associated with AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) inactivation. Metformin, an AMPK activator, decreased MG activity, suggesting AMP inactivation mediates increased MG. AMPK activity was reduced in DENV-infected cells at 12 and 24 hours post-infection. MG and cholesterol co-localized with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E, indicating MG and AMP activity in replicative complex formation. Metform and lovastatin, an MG inhibitor, altered co-localization and replicative complexes, suggesting active MG required for replicative formation. Metform showed dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV-infected cells, while compound C, an AMP inhibitor, increased viral copies and infected cells. PP2, MG phosphatase, was not affected by D infection. Data show elevated MG in DENV cells through AMP inhibition, not increased PP activity. Inhibition showed antiral effect in MG-independent manner. Results suggest DENV increases MG through AMP inactivation, leading to cholesterol ER for replicative complexes.
Researchers used all-atom molecular dynamics simulations to study the process of tRNA translocation on the ribosome, a crucial for protein synthesis in cells. They found that the process can be broken down into two types of movements: slow, large-scale collective motions and fast local fluctuations. The study identified specific regions of the ribosome that undergo these movements, which resemble rigid body rotations. The ribosome is thought to function as a "thermal ratchet", where random fluctuations lead to large-scale movements. However, previous studies used discrete approximations to describe dynamics, while single-molecule methods can project energy onto specific coordinates. By analyzing the dynamics of an intact ribosome, the researchers found collective coordinates that capture 30-body rotation, 30-head swivel, and tRNA displacements, essential for translocation. These motions were used to convert between kinetic and energy measurements, providing an upper estimate of the free energy barrier for translocation. This framework can be applied to other biological processes with multiple intermediates and states.
Researchers have explored the genetic landscape of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) by analyzing 84 sporadic MTC samples and 36 normal thyroid tissues. They used the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Panel to identify 101 mutations in 18 genes, with the most common being in the RET proto-oncogene, occurring in 47 cases. Other mutations were found in genes encoding Harvey sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, serine/threon kinase 11, v-kit-Zuckerman feline sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, mut homolog 1, Kiest ratcoma viral oncogene hom, and MET-oncogene. Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangement was evaluated by immunohistochemistry and break-ap fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), with 2 of 98 cases positive for ALK. Targeted sequencing identified Glutaminefructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GF1)-ALK and echoderm microtubule-associated protein 4 (E4)-ALK fusions. PCR and Sanger sequencing confirmed the GF1-ALK fusion, indicating an intra-chromosomal translocation or deletion. A metastatic M case with E4ALK showed a response to AL inhibitor crizotin. The study found several mutations in MTC and first identified AL fusions in M, suggesting E4ALK may be a driver and target for AL inhibitors, and GFALK a candidate for molecular therapy.
A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to evaluate the role of asymptomatic Leishmanias in the transmission of visceral Leishias (VL) and post-Kala-azar Dermal Leishias (PKDL) in the region. A total of 289 individuals were screened for Leishial antibody, with 185 testing positive, of which 96 had a history of VL/PK and 89 without. 79 were classified as asymptomatic Leishias and 10 as active VL with a ratio of 7.9:1. Among asymptomatic cases, 2 were lost to follow-up as they moved to other places. Among asymptomatic infected, disease progression in 8/77 (10.39%) and seroconversion 62/77 (80.52%) were noted, with 7 (9.09%) remaining ser-positive after three years. Progression to disease among asymptomatic individuals occurred up to three years after baseline. The study found a prevalence of 3.16% asympt Leishial infection, lower than previous studies in Bihar. The ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic cases was 7.9:1. Individuals with no history of VL/PK but positive for Leish antibody were classified as asymptomatic. Those who became seronegative during follow-up were referred as seroconversion and developed symptoms of VL/PK as progression.
Researchers used a technique called Multiplex Ligation-Dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze genetic rearrangements in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae genome. These rearrangements, known as gross chromosomal rearrangements (GCR), can lead to diseases and cancer. The study found that the presence of a repetitive element called Ty on a non-essential chromosome arm of S. cerevisiae increased genome instability due to increased formation of monocentric non-recipro translocations. MLPA revealed the distribution of translocations induced by Ty in wild-type was random and majority were mediated by six targets on four different chromosomes, despite 254 potential targets in S. cerevis genome. Most Ty-mediated translocations resulted from RAD-dependent recombination, but some non-recipro trans were mediated by RAD-independent between Ty elements. RAD-independent trans did not require Rad51 or Rad59 proteins or Rad1-10 complex. Defects in ASF-RT109-dependent acetylation of histone H3 lysine 56 increased Gs and whole-chromosome duplications, and aneup occurred with Gs. MLPA is a technique for rapid analysis of Gs and facilitates genetic pathways that prevent and promote G and ane.
Researchers have developed a new method called Semi-Definite-based Underestimation (SD) to improve protein docking, which is the process of associating two proteins. Docking is driven by a "free energy funnel" determined by favorable interactions near the native state. The SD method minimizes a quadratic function to estimate local energy minima and uses this underestimator to bias sampling. However, applying SD to rotational and translational space (SE(3) is challenging due to its geometry. To address this, a strategy separates variables for side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance, and five angular descriptors of relative orientations. Removing the center-to-center distance improves efficiency, as the five-dimensional space has a well-behaved energy surface for underestimation. This method explores energy surfaces of complexes corresponding to local energy minima, similar to macromolecular association through collisions. Results show the energy landscape is a funnel in a broad neighborhood of the native state, and SD generates predictions with less than 5Å ligand interface root-mean-square deviation, achieving a 20-fold efficiency gain over Monte Carlo methods.
